title: Public Survey Highlights Britons Global Ambitions
description: LONDON  The British parliamentary elections are less than 100 days away, and they are a mess  at least five parties in a fragmented system designed for two, and absolute rule by the winner.

title: As Ebola Ebbs in Africa, Focus Turns From Death to Life
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  Life is edging back to normal after the deadliest Ebola outbreak in history.

title: Fire on Williamsburg Waterfront
description: The seven-alarm fire on North 11th Street began on Saturday morning.

title: Armenia and Azerbaijan Clash With Increasing Ferocity Over Disputed Land
description: An armed conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh has escalated with deadly consequences in recent months.

title: An Imposing Team Symbol Finds a Niche in the Hoopla
description: PHOENIX  The N.F.L. has become a $10 billion behemoth partly through innovative marketing, but also through ruthless protection of its brand. The league, after all, has cracked down on businesses that have used the words Super Bowl in their advertising, one reason some critics called the N.F.L. the No Fun League.

title: Sisi Blames Muslim Brotherhood for Bombings in Sinai
description: CAIRO  President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi on Saturday blamed the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood for bombings that killed at least 30 people in the North Sinai two days earlier, and declared that Egypt was fighting the strongest secret organization in the world.

title: Tribal Loyalties Drive Jordans Effort to Free Pilot
description: AMMAN, Jordan  It is often said that in the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan all politics is tribal.

title: $3 Tip on a $4 Cup of Coffee? Gratuities Grow, Automatically
description: The flat white coffee drink was $4. A suggested tip was $3.

title: Rose Marie McCoy, a Songwriter for Rock, Pop and Jazz Legends, Dies at 92
description: For a woman who composed or collaborated on some 850 songs over seven decades, Rose Marie McCoy, who died on Jan. 20 at 92, was largely unheralded, recognized only belatedly in a nationwide radio documentary.

title: Sip the Light Fantastic
description: Is there anything more civilized than afternoon tea? The relaxing tradition of sipping tea while nibbling on sandwiches and sweets began in Britain, but one need not fly to London to enjoy it. There is no shortage of teahouses in Connecticut offering an authentic English-style experience, but the three parlors listed here excel at serving high-grade teas in combination with traditional foods.

title: Canadian Upsets Olympic Medalist in Winning 2 Races
description: Like Samson, Cam Levins figures his hair is the source of his prowess.

title: At Polich Tallix Fine Art Foundry, Master of Metals Is Artists Ally
description: In the late 1990s, the sculptor Rona Pondick arrived at Dick Polichs foundry with some challenging goals. She was working on her now-famous animal-human hybrids and was interested in new ways of incorporating color in stainless steel. She recently recalled explaining her project to Mr. Polich: He told me, Youre trying to push the envelope, and Ill go there with you. And then he said, And while Im going there with you, can I show you a few things Im playing around with?

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 31, 2015
At This Party, Youd Better Keep It Down
description: PHOENIX  When the Super Bowl begins Sunday, 70,000 fans will ease into their seats and suites at University of Phoenix Stadium, munch on hot dogs and pizza, and wash them down with soda and beer.

title: At 32, Phoenix Open Leader Seems Ancient
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Pity the old-timers on the PGA Tour, who have seen their workplace overrun by trophy kids. The millennials, a group that includes Jordan Spieth, Daniel Berger and Justin Thomas, do not hew to the stereotype of the entitled, high-maintenance employee. They deserve the praise lavished on them, they do not have padded rsums and they are respectful, addressing anyone over the age of 25 as Mister.

title: Inspired by N.F.L., Art Imitating Sport
description: Michael Levine, a preservationist and artist based in Arizona, wanted to show the N.F.L. a new way to market its product, so he made an enormous metal cardinal as a tribute to Phoenixs hometown team.

title: Rory McIlroy Widens Lead in Dubai
description: Rory McIlroy extended his lead to four shots with a 6-under 66 on Saturday in the third round of the Dubai Desert Classic in the United Arab Emirates.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 1, 2015
description: Fundamentally, this is about the extent to which societies change their behaviors, how they change them, and the speed at which they change them.

title: To Jets Geno Smith, 2015 Isnt His Last Chance, but Its Vital
description: Geno Smith, meeting with reporters Saturday for the first time since the Jets overhauled their front office and coaching staff, sounded like someone who realizes time may be growing short for him to prove himself as a starting quarterback.

title: Hardhanded Judge Is Picked for American Reporters Trial in Iran, Rights Group Says
description: A Revolutionary Court judge in Iran with a reputation for imposing harsh sentences has been selected to preside in the trial of Jason Rezaian, The Washington Posts Tehran correspondent, who has been incarcerated for more than six months on unspecified charges, a human rights advocacy group said Saturday.

title: Alexandra Corsi and Ian Lambert
description: Alexandra Corsi and Ian Paul Lambert were married Saturday evening at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. The Rev. Bruce C. Page, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Hugh Eastwood and John Holmes III
description: Hugh Athelstan Eastwood and John Arthur Holmes III were married Friday at their home in Ladue, Mo. Jean C. Hamilton, a senior United States District judge for the Eastern District of Missouri, officiated.

title: Mimi Hoesley and Benjamin Slater IV
description: Meredith Drews Hoesley and Benjamin Richard Slater IV were married Saturday at Trinity Episcopal Church in New Orleans. The Rev. Henry L. Hudson, the rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: From the Idea of a Germ
description: Injy Artense Carpenter and Dr. Timothy Francis Nichols Sullivan were married Saturday evening at India House, a private club in Manhattan. The Rev. Lissa Gundlach, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Christopher Lesisko and Albert Pfeiffer
description: Christopher Alan Lesisko and Albert Pfeiffer were married Saturday at the First Unitarian Church of Orlando in Florida. The Rev. Marni Harmony, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Shifting Gears, Incrementally
description: Sarah Marcus and Thomas Clinton Greulich were married Saturday at the Stowe Mountain Lodge in Stowe, Vt. Annie Alexander-Kramer, a minister affiliated with Rose Ministries, led a ceremony incorporating Jewish traditions and Episcopal vows.

title: Top Sundance Prizes Go to Me and Earl and the Dying Girl
description: The whimsical Me and Earl and the Dying Girl, a film that rode a crescendo of buzz after screening in Park City last month, claimed top prizes at the 2015 Sundance Film Festival awards on Saturday night. It was named the U.S. Dramatic Grand Jury Prize winner, and also won the U.S. dramatic audience award.

title: Whats on TV Sunday
description: 6 P.M. (NBC) SUPER BOWL XLIX The New England Patriots face off against the Seattle Seahawks at the University of Phoenix Stadium in Glendale, Ariz. Al Michaels provides play-by-play commentary; Cris Collinsworth is the analyst; and Michele Tafoya reports from the sidelines. Kickoff is at 6:30. Katy Perry, above, will take the stage at halftime, with Lenny Kravitz and Missy Elliott as special guests; Idina Menzel will perform the national anthem; and John Legend will sing America the Beautiful. Bob Costas will host the pregame show, starting at noon, featuring commentary and analysis; visits to the teams hotels; an interview with Ms. Perry by Josh Elliott; celebrity reports by the figure skaters Johnny Wier and Tara Lipinski; a stop at the official tailgate party; and an interview with President Obama by Savannah Guthrie.

title: Corrections: February 1, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Amanda Mason and Richard Moseley
description: Amanda Marie Mason and Richard Duraunde Moseley were married Saturday at the Chestnut Hill Friends Meeting House in Philadelphia. The Rev. Callie Swanlund, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: A Rout, and a Resurrection
description: Nearly 25 years ago, the producer Graham Leader made a film called Shuttlecock. Alan Bates had the starring role, as a British spy during World War II whose secrets inflict psychic damage on his son. The film opened the San Sebastin Film Festival in Spain in 1991 and was broadcast once on Channel 4 in Britain and on Canal Plus in France, where it had a brief theatrical release. It never found a distributor, however, and sank without a trace.

title: Protesters Once Again Fill Streets in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  Pro-democracy protesters streamed through the heart of Hong Kong on Sunday in their first sizable show of strength since the police cleared occupations that blocked streets for 11 weeks late last year.

title: 1940: Mabel Boll, Queen of Diamonds, Weds No. 3
description: Fort Lauderdale, Fla.  Mabel Boll, one-time sales girl in a cigar store, who became known as Queen of Diamonds, has married again and husband No. 3 is Theodore Cella, thirty-nine-year-old harpist and assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra. From her humble beginning in Rochester, N.Y., as a dispenser of stogies and Colorado Claros the blue-eyed blonde Mibsey Bach, the daughter of a bartender, as she was then known, suddenly found herself in luxury as the wife of a wealthy Colombian.

title: Blues and Hip-Hop Meet at the Hands of a Power Guitarist
description: Feedback erupted time and again as Jack White headlined Madison Square Garden on Friday night. It was no accident; Mr. Whites music hangs on the edge of overload, and the feedback only proves it. The occasional electronic screeches were part of his joyful assault; so were the quivering whoop in his voice and the way his guitar solos rushed way up high and stayed there, to zoom around or wriggle and wail. And so was the flat-out bashing of the bands drummer, Daru Jones, who often stood up to provide extra wallop.

title: Learning the Language in Wales
description: Chateau Rhianfa, on the Isle of Anglesey in Wales, is offering guests the chance to test their linguistic abilities by learning how to pronounce Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch  the longest place name in Europe  among other words and phrases.

title: Novak Djokovic Leaves Andy Murray Crushed in Reprise at Australian Open
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Huffing and stretching with full-throttle effort, ripping forehands from inside the baseline, Andy Murray for quite some time seemed to be a player on a mission to impose a new ending for himself at the Australian Open.

title: Hostages Apparent Beheading by ISIS Stirs Outrage in Japan
description: TOKYO  Japan reacted with sorrow and outrage on Sunday to the posting by the Islamic State of a video purporting to show the grisly killing of the journalist Kenji Goto, bringing an end to a hostage standoff that has horrified this usually tranquil nation.

title: Home Schooling, and Teaching, a Child with Down Syndrome
description: This past September we started home schooling. Before that our son, who has Down syndrome, attended public school in a regular classroom setting  often referred to as inclusion  at our request. After two years we realized school was hindering his education.

title: An Overnight Stay at Hotel 22
description: Silicon Valley, one of the most expensive places to live in America, is also one of the toughest places for the homeless to survive. As the tech boom prompted property values to skyrocket, some of the citys poorest residents have been displaced, with limited options for affordable housing. In this Op-Doc video, Elizabeth Lo documents scenes from a bus route that has become a well-known overnight shelter for the areas homeless.

title: A Month of Puzzle Love
description: TIMES INSIDER  Even in the coldest, darkest part of winter, we have cause to celebrate. The Super Bowl, Presidents Day, Valentines Day, the Chinese New Year and many more holidays help us shake off the winter doldrums.

title: Floor Waxes, Dessert Toppings, and Blogging
description: I see from Ezra Klein that Andrew Sullivan says that hes stopping blogging; Klein and others are offering various encomiums. Youll pardon me if I dont join in. You see, I remember Sullivan declaring that the decadent left was poised to become a fifth column in the war on terror  and of course I remember the campaign of character assassination he waged against yours truly for daring to criticize his then-beloved George W. Bush and his wars. If he ever apologized for any of that, I never heard about it.

title: The Disappearance of Alan Simpson
description: Not that long ago Alan Simpson bestrode Washington like a colossus  a rambling, cranky, potty-mouthed colossus. As Ezra Klein noted, reporters didnt treat him as an ordinary public figure, but rather as the voice of obvious responsibility, on whose behalf the ordinary rules of press neutrality didnt apply. And his pronouncements  like his early 2011 declaration that we faced fiscal crisis within two years  received breathless coverage.

title: London Theater Journal: Laughing Wall to Wall
description: LONDON  Comedy comes in many shades, from jet black to shocking pink. In a rare moment of giddy confluence, the theaters here seem to have the whole rainbow on display.

title: Fire at a Brooklyn Warehouse Puts Private Lives on Display
description: No lives were lost in the huge fire that gutted a storage building on the Brooklyn waterfront over the weekend. But the flames put plenty of lives on display as the crumpling warehouse belched up its contents: decades worth of charred medical records, court transcripts, lawyers letters, sonograms, bank checks and more.

title: Egypt Deports Peter Greste, Journalist Jailed With 2 Al Jazeera Colleagues
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian authorities have deported an Australian television journalist jailed for more than a year on politicized charges about the content of his work.

title: 1965: Dr. King, 300 Negroes Arrested in Selma
description: SELMA, Ala.  Civil-rights leader the Rev. Martin Luther King jr., was arrested today [Feb. 1] while attempting to lead a mass march of 300 Negroes on the Dallas county courthouse to protest voter-registration procedures. The Negroes, who were walking en masse from a church, were taken into custody on orders from Selmas Public Safety Director Wilson Baker on charges of parading without a permit. Mr. Baker stopped the procession near the church, where the Negroes had assembled. He told them: Each and every one of you is under arrest for parading without a permit. After an hour of waiting in the jail, Dr. King was released without charges filed against him. But he was quickly rearrested when he did not obey an officers orders to leave the scene. This was the first time he has been arrested since he received the Nobel Peace prize last month.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 2, 1965

title: Obamas Plans for Deficit and Taxes Are Detailed on Eve of Budget Proposal
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will propose a 10-year budget on Monday that stabilizes the federal deficit but does not seek balance, instead focusing on policies to address income inequality as he adds nearly $6 trillion to the debt.

title: Ties Between India and the U.S. Deepen
description: Where does that leave China?

title: Do-It-Yourself Orthodonture: Dont Try This at Home
description: Jamila Garza, 24, from Everett, Wash., has made no less than nine YouTube videos enthusiastically describing how she closed a gap between front teeth with $5 elastic bands. Ms. Garza is not a dental professional. Until recently, she was a fashion design student.

title: Straighter Teeth by Mail
description: When John Hofford, a 27-year-old digital media specialist, wanted to straighten his teeth, he wanted invisible plastic aligners that would correct his crowding, instead of conspicuous metal braces. But he couldnt afford the clear aligners sold at his local orthodontist in Atlanta.

title: A Job Filled With Forecasts Thats Unpredictable by Nature
description: The meteorologist Steven DiMartino signed off Twitter at 11 p.m. last Monday, warning his followers that intense heavy snow is approaching. After 20 hours of blizzard-tracking for clients who pay him to predict how the weather will affect their travel, families and businesses, he finally took a nap in his chair.

title: Even on Super Bowl Weekend, American Sniper Wins
description: LOS ANGELES  Even the Super Bowl couldnt crowd out Clint Eastwoods American Sniper, which again topped the domestic movie box office, with an estimated $31.9 million in sales during its sixth weekend in theaters and third weekend in wide release. The strong haul  a record for any film during Super Bowl weekend, if the estimates hold  pushed total domestic sales for the reality-based Iraq war story to about $249 million.

title: The Reconstruction Wars Begin
description: On Jan. 26, 1865, the Massachusetts Anti-Slavery Society convened inside Bostons Melodeon Theater, a mainstay of the citys cultural, religious and civic life, for its annual meeting. A break from frigid temperatures and heavy snow led to high attendance. The Congregationalist minister Theodore Parker had often offered sermons at the Melodeon. In 1850, the antislavery Parker called for democracy of all the people, by all the people, and for all the people. After 30 years of labor, abolitionists now believed that they were in a position to push not only for the final destruction of slavery, but also for a new definition of who made up the people. With the bloody Civil War coming to a close, the future of the abolitionist cause, according to the Boston Brahmin Wendell Phillips, was inextricably linked to Reconstruction.

title: In Liberated Kobani, Kurds Take Pride Despite the Devastation
description: KOBANI, Syria  Lasheen Abdulla steered her white minivan through the streets of her hometown, past the charred husks of bombed cars, the shattered storefronts, the unexploded mortar shells. Across the gray of destruction were streaks of color: the purple sheets hung to hide the Kurdish snipers who, for months, defended this city from the extremists of the Islamic State.

title: Scenes of Devastation in Kobani
description: The destruction in Kobani, Syria, wrought by an Islamic State siege and the American-led air campaign, is so thorough that it manages to feel unreal.

title: Cement Makers Holcim and Lafarge to Sell Assets to CRH of Ireland for $7.3 Billion
description: The European cement makers Lafarge and Holcim agreed on Sunday to sell assets to CRH plc, an Irish manufacturer of building materials, for about $7.3 billion to help pave the way for their own merger.

title: Christie Returns to Good Old London; London Says, Who?
description: LONDON  Presidential politics can be a humbling business. Local renown is revealed, uneasily, to be just that: It translates poorly onto a bigger stage, allowing a man accustomed to instant, cellphone-picture-frenzied celebrity on the boardwalks of the New Jersey shore to stroll in awkward anonymity through a packed stadium in London.

title: Fire at Library in Moscow Destroys Millions of Volumes
description: A major fire that threatened to consume one of Russias most important libraries was finally put out late Saturday, but scholars are only beginning to assess the damage from the flames, smoke and water.

title: A Question Over the Reach of Europes Right to Be Forgotten
description: Dan Shefet doesnt want you to Google his name.

title: A Bach Interpretation Springs to Life
description: John Harbisons new work for Jennifer Koh is For Violin Alone. Its a simple title, but one that evokes the essential solitude that draws listeners and violinists to Bachs solo works for violin. Theres a unique rawness to watching the sonatas and partitas played live, more so even than the cello suites. The hush is audible, the imagery statuesque.

title: To Russia, With Capitalist Ambitions
description: In the early 1990s Bill Browder invested $2,000 in a handful of Polish companies being privatized after the collapse of Communism. Eastern Europe was dipping a toe into the cold bath of free-market capitalism, and Mr. Browder, fresh out of Stanford Universitys business school, wanted to jump in, too.

title: From Early Triumph, to Toil, to Vindication
description: BETHESDA, Md.  Katherine Heiny has led a somewhat clandestine life as a writer, which is perhaps fitting for the wife of a former spy.

title: At a Benefit Event, Pressure Takes a Seat at the Table
description: It is important to pressure your opponents, whether it is in the bidding or the play. Make them come up with the best call or card. Especially when you have a fit with your partner and know that you are outgunned in high-card points, bounce the bidding as high as you can.

title: Knicks Top Lakers in Meeting of Teams Not Fit for National TV
description: Just over a week ago, the people in charge of programming at ESPN decided that Sunday afternoons contest between the Knicks and the Los Angeles Lakers was no longer worthy of a national television audience.

title: Gray and Stormy Palettes Mirroring Reality
description: Atmospheric conditions united two Juilliard-related concerts last week. Baroque music inspired by extreme weather and natural phenomena was the focus of Saturdays concert by Juilliard 415, the Juilliard Schools period-instrument ensemble, at Alice Tully Hall. And the previous night at the conclusion of the schools Focus! festival dedicated to contemporary Japanese music and its influences, Debussys Clouds led a program by the Juilliard Orchestra at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater.

title: Dreams of Flight, National Pride and Love  la Bollywood
description: About flying and freedom (and, of course, love), the Bollywood movie Hawaizaada, directed by Vibhu Virender Puri, spins legend into more legend. The year is 1895, and the setting is Bombay. The story concerns a quest by two Indians to build an airplane and to show the British rulers of India  A monkey cant make a machine! one says  what their subjects can do.

title: Basking in Seahawks Success, Not the Spotlight
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Amid the frenzy of Super Bowl media day Tuesday, as thousands of reporters and cameras surrounded the New England Patriots coaches and players, the dapper owner of the team, Robert K. Kraft, held his own impromptu news conference.

title: With Dramatic Drops, Exploiting Gravitys Force
description: When we watch a dance performance, we rarely think about where it has been and where its going. The dancers you see in New York today could have been halfway around the world last week. With a new series at Abrons Arts Center, Travelogues, the independent producer Laurie Uprichard (formerly a curator at Danspace Project and Dublin Dance Festival) frames performance as something that exists before and after we see it. The series began over the weekend with the American premiere of Solitudes Solo by Daniel Lveill, whose company is based in Montreal. (Ms. Uprichard had seen the work in Montreal and Paris before bringing it to the Lower East Side.) This is a dance that, wherever it goes, plants itself firmly in that place  or at least it did on Friday in the intimate Experimental Theater at Abrons.

title: January Job Data, Big Earnings Reports and the Greek Bailout
description: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

title: When an Abstract Artist Falls in Love With Monet
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass.  Love can be counterintuitive. If I were asked to pair up the artist Ellsworth Kelly with a historical soul mate, Claude Monet would not readily come to mind. The American painter of abstract pictures as clean as Shaker tables and the French Impressionist who piled on pigment as thick as mulch? I dont think so. Yet here they are together in a small, crystalline show called Monet/Kelly at the Clark Art Institute, and they make an utterly logical, and mind-stretching, match.

title: Melodist and Minimalist in Harmony
description: Oscillating tones, shimmering and percussive, echoed through the Appel Room on Saturday as an array of musicians from various musical worlds performed works by Stephen Sondheim and Steve Reich. This Lincoln Center American Songbook concert was a genial two-hour-plus seminar, moderated by John Schaefer, in which the composers chatted and compared notes in a program whose selections followed a through-line, each piece roughly continuing the style of the one before. An excellent trio (Tedd Firth on piano, John Beal on bass, Paul Pizzuti on drums) anchored Mr. Sondheims songs.

title: A Meeting in the Desert
description: The weeks of preparation over, the Seattle Seahawks and the New England Patriots met in Super Bowl XLIX before avid fans in Glendale, Ariz.

title: Understated Detective Wraps It Up
description: Its been a long war for the British detective Christopher Foyle. On screen, hes served as a home-front police superintendent and MI5 operative for nearly seven years, from mid-1940 to early 1947. In the real world, its been even longer  Foyles War had its premiere in Britain 13 years ago, producing 28 feature-length episodes around long hiatuses and one premature cancellation.

title: Bach, Filtered Through Balanchine and Robbins
description: Does art get any better than this? There were many moments when it was easy to ask that question during the performance of George Balanchines Concerto Barocco (1941) on Thursday night at New York City Ballet.

title: Jazz & Colors
description: Scenes from the music series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Exalting Tunes on a Big Canvas
description: Heres an image I wont forget: the saxophonist Lakecia Benjamin and her band Soulsquad blasting out the romantic anguish of Ornette Colemans Lonely Woman in front of Emanuel Leutzes painting Washington Crossing the Delaware. You know that painting  a dozen men in a rowboat breaking through the ice floes, the general facing left in the breaking light.

title: A Politically Charged Piece Meditates on Civil Liberty
description: Though set only four years ago, Laith Naklis Shesh Yak at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater is already heartbreakingly out of date. The Syrian people will prevail, declares Haytham (Mr. Nakli), an activist in his 50s who has come to New York to lead a rally. The world will stand by us and there will be reform. I am sure of it.

title: Cleaning Up Damage From a Blaze
description: A seven-alarm fire at a warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, left documents and debris strewn along the East River shoreline.

title: Theres No Branding a Symbol of Free Speech
description: Almost immediately after jihadists killed 12 in an attack on the French satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo on Jan. 7, the image went viral: Je Suis Charlie or I Am Charlie, white and light gray letters against a black background. The words are now a shorthand for support of freedom of expression. The sign is the creation of Joachim Roncin, 39, the art director of Stylist, a free Paris weekly magazine. Now, with the aid of pro bono lawyers and the good will of Frances patent office, hes trying to prevent people from capitalizing on it. I cant trademark it. Its not something that belongs to anyone, Mr. Roncin said in a telephone interview. If its a slogan, it cannot be a brand. Mr. Roncin said that even arms manufacturers had filed requests with the French patent office, hoping to sell weapons with the phrase. He said that the patent office has said it will not trademark the slogan. Mr. Roncin has only granted Reporters Without Borders permission to use the image to help raise money for Charlie Hebdo. (In its first issue published after the attacks, the magazine ran a cartoon depicting people in Bangladesh hunched over sewing machines sewing Je Suis Charlie T-shirts.) Mr. Roncin posted his image on Twitter not long after the killings. With only around 400 Twitter followers, he expected only a few friends to share the image, but it swept across social media, and tens of thousands marched in Paris on Jan. 11 holding Je Suis Charlie signs. Its incredible, Mr. Roncin said. Now its crazy.

title: In a Rare Assignment, Fireboats Battle a Blaze in Brooklyn
description: Once a common sight at urban disaster scenes, the fireboat, with its cannons of cascading water, is rarely called upon to battle fires in a New York City of receding industrial zones and new riverfront condominiums.

title: Is it Bigger Than a Breadbox?
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Its always nice to see a puzzle that celebrates my hometown, and Jeffrey Wechsler returns to do just that.

title: Hard-Charging Uber Tries Olive Branch
description: Travis Kalanick did not build Uber into a global force by playing nice.

title: Brooklyn Woman Dies in Apartment Building Fire; Brother Is Injured
description: A 49-year-old woman died early Sunday morning and her older brother was seriously injured after a fire spread noxious smoke through the three-story apartment building where they lived together in Brooklyn, officials said.

title: Football Major, Basketball Minor?
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has long clung to the idea that college athletes are essentially engaged in extracurricular activities, but evidence to the contrary is mounting.

title: U.S. Considers Supplying Arms to Ukraine Forces, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  With Russian-backed separatists pressing their attacks in Ukraine, NATOs military commander, Gen. Philip M. Breedlove, now supports providing defensive weapons and equipment to Kievs beleaguered forces, and an array of administration and military officials appear to be edging toward that position, American officials said Sunday.

title: Disney to Crown Elena, an Animated Latina Princess
description: The realm of Disney princesses is expanding to include its first member of Latina royalty. The company announced in a blog post on Friday plans for the 2016 airing of Elena of Avalor, an animated series about a princess in a fairy-tale kingdom inspired by Latino cultures and folklore. The bold, caring, funny and clever 16-year-old Princess Elena, to be voiced by Aimee Carrero of the ABC Family series Young & Hungry, will be introduced next year in an episode of the Disney Junior series Sofia the First. The spinoff show, produced by Disney Television Animation and geared to ages 2-7, will include messages of leadership, resilience, diversity, compassion and the importance of family and family tradition, according to the announcement.

title: For Greece, Bank Trouble Looms Again as New Government Takes Shape
description: In January 2013, as Cypriot banks faced collapse, Jens Weidmann, Germanys powerful representative at the European Central Bank, made it clear how unhappy he was with the Cyprus bank bailout.

title: More Snow Is in Forecast for New York, but Dont Expect a Shutdown
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio warned New Yorkers on Sunday that more snow was expected in the city overnight, but he said officials were prepared to handle the storm and schools were expected to open on Monday morning.

title: The N.F.L. Takes On Domestic Violence. Can Hollywood?
Vaccines: An Unhealthy Skepticism
description: An outbreak of measles that started at Disneyland has turned a spotlight on those who choose not to vaccinate their children. How did we get to a point where personal beliefs can triumph over science?

title: A Discredited Vaccine Studys Continuing Impact on Public Health
description: In the churning over the refusal of some parents to immunize their children against certain diseases, a venerable Latin phrase may prove useful: Post hoc, ergo propter hoc. It means, After this, therefore because of this. In plainer language: Event B follows Event A, so B must be the direct result of A. It is a classic fallacy in logic.

title: New Magazine Teaches Children Financial Lessons
description: Jean Chatzky, the financial editor of NBCs Today show, has made a career sharing personal finance tips with adults. Now, she is trying to reach a much younger audience.

title: After Turmoil, The New Republic Re-emerges on Newsstands
description: The New Republic is a small magazine that set off a big commotion.

title: Celtic Prevails Over Weak Rangers in First Old Firm Match in Nearly 3 Years
description: GLASGOW  Sundays match between Celtic and Rangers, the Glasgow giants collectively known as the Old Firm, was their first in nearly three years, but for all the hatred and bile, it seemed the two clubs had missed each other.

title: Black Ice
description: Dear Diary:

title: At 37 and Coming Off Surgery, Bode Miller Readies for Season Debut
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  The six-time Olympic medalist Bode Miller, who has not raced this season because of a back injury, has confirmed that he will compete in the Alpine world championships, which are set to begin here Tuesday.

title: For Devils Backup Goalies, Every Start Is an Audition
description: NEWARK  Before the Devils rookie goaltender, Keith Kinkaid, made his first career start on Dec. 9, he was too excited to sleep. He had been fortunate enough to learn of his starting assignment on the morning of the game against the Chicago Blackhawks, so he was not awake all night, but he was robbed of his traditional pregame nap.

title: Sex Toy Shops Prepare for Tie-Ins to Fifty Shades of Grey
description: When toys are made for movies, they are usually intended for children.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Feb. 2

title: France Offers Support, but No Debt Relief, to Greece

description: A significant part of the fun of attending the Sundance Film Festival lies in trying to guess the dominating narratives beforehand. Will a star emerge from nowhere,  la Kevin Smith in Clerks or Quvenzhan Wallis in Beasts of the Southern Wild? Will we see anything as heartbreaking as Blue Valentine or as compelling as Hoop Dreams? What, if anything, will be this years Boyhood? Theres no real indicator for where the hits will come from at Sundance  and when they do, theres a good chance youll still miss them, thanks to the festivals breadth of programming.

But it turns out that Suzanne Pag, the foundations artistic director, was secretly working on an exhibition of modern masterpieces to open in April with loans from institutions around the world including Edvard Munchs The Scream, Matisses Dance and Lgers Three Women (Le Grand Djeuner).

A team with Marshawn Lynch, one of the best goal-line running backs in football, instead opted for a far riskier option, and Malcolm Butler made them pay, intercepting the ball at the goal line to effectively end the Seahawks hopes of winning a second consecutive Super Bowl.

title: Survival and Death in a Faraway War
description: I was going to die.  And I was thinking about God and his Prophet, Aliou Diakhate recalled in the historian Joe Lunns Memoirs of the Maelstrom: A Senegalese Oral History of the First World War. And when you wish to pray you have to stand up  to stand and bend down on your knees, and put your forehead on the ground. But I could not do that [because I was wounded so badly]. So I took some earth in my hand and I put it to my forehead. And I prayed to God [to bless me] in that way.

title: How to Measure a Medical Treatments Potential for Harm
description: As we wrote last week, many fewer people benefit from medical therapies than we tend to think. This fact is quantified in a therapys Number Needed to Treat, or N.N.T., which tells you the number of people who would need to receive a medical therapy in order for one person to benefit. N.N.T.s well above 10 or even 100 are common.  But knowing the potential for benefit is not enough. We must also consider potential harms.

title: Morning Agenda: S.&P. Walks Back Retaliation Claims
description: S.&P. WALKS BACK RETALIATION CLAIMS | The giant credit rating agency Standard & Poors, which was accused of inflating the subprime mortgage bubble, had portrayed a Justice Department lawsuit as an act of retaliation for its decision to cut the credit rating of the United States in the summer of 2011. Now, it is walking back that claim, Ben Protess writes in DealBook. As part of a $1.37 billion settlement deal expected this week, S.&P. has agreed to acknowledge that it never found evidence supporting its accusations of retaliation, people briefed on the matter said.

title: Downtowns Newest Gallerist
description: Bridget Donahue, formerly a director at Gavin Browns Enterprise, is opening a massive New York gallery with a refreshingly eclectic program. Im drawn to those who engage with the long game, says the Iowa City native, who will champion artists of all kinds  older, under-the-radar, anti-establishment  who might otherwise get sidelined in Chinatowns trend-heavy scene. Her debut exhibition will celebrate the work of Lynn Hershman Leeson, a 73-year-old artist whose prescient mixed-media creations began addressing the relationship between gender and technology as early as the 1960s. Following that, Donahue will host a show featuring the work of the artist and fashion designer Susan Cianciolo, whose homespun zines, pillows and clothing demonstrate artisanal flair and a subversive sensibility that fits the space.

title: Obamas Budget Seeks to Loosen Austerity Reins

title: Obamas Defense Budget Aims Higher, and at Overseas Conflicts

title: 1890: Blood Shed for Honor
description: The much talked-of duel between the Marquis de Mors and M. Camille Dreyfus was fought at 10.25 yesterday [Feb. 2] morning in the outskirts of the little town of Comines, which lies in Belgium, just beyond the French frontier. At the word of command, M. Dreyfus fired instantly, and missed. The Marquis de Mors aimed more deliberately, and sent his ball into the arm of his opponent just above the elbow joint. The wound is painful, but not serious. Had it not been for the fact that M. Dreyfus dropped his arm immediately on firing, it is very probable that he would have been mortally wounded.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 3, 1890

title: An Icon Goes Minimal
description: Its tough to improve on perfection, but thats precisely what Herms has done with the new hyper-pared-down Birkin Sellier 40. According to Couli Jobert, the leather artistic director at Herms, natural brown was deemed too obvious for the new Birkin, which is only available in matte black with silver palladium hardware. As the goal was to create an essential design without clutter, the structured cowhide bag is extra-wide, has no lining and the stitching is extremely subtle. Its a radically modern update of the elegant classic, which has been the subject of girl envy  and the cause of waiting lists  since it was first crafted in 1984.

title: 1965: Kozlov Ashes Put in Kremlin
description: MOSCOW Slowly, their feet moving to the measured cadences of a funeral dirge, the leaders of the Soviet Union bore the ashes of Frol Romanovich Kozlov across the cobblestones of Red Square toward their final resting place in the Kremlin wall today [Feb. 2]. Leonid I. Brezhnev, first secretary of the Communist Party, and Premier Alexei N. Kosygin led the line of pallbearers that carried the urn at shoulder height, resting on a black pillow and covered by a canopy of white flowers. The funeral contained all the pomp the Soviet Communist Party, the government and the military could muster.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 3, 1965

title: David Oyelowo Says Academy Rewards Black Actors in Subservient Roles
description: David Oyelowo of Selma made news over the weekend by reiterating the idea that Hollywood was most comfortable with black actors in subservient roles.

title: In Budget, Obamas Unfettered Case for Spreading the Wealth
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama presented a budget on Monday that is more utopian vision than pragmatic blueprint. It proposes a politically improbable reshaping of the tax code and generous new social spending initiatives that would shift resources from the wealthy to the middle class.

title: Jordan Sends Envoy Back to Israel as Tensions Ease
description: JERUSALEM  Jordan said on Monday that it was sending its ambassador back to Israel, three months after he was recalled in protest of what the Jordanians called Israeli violations at a contested holy site in East Jerusalem. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel welcomed the decision.

title: Obama Proposes Tax for Upgrade of Infrastructure
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas proposed budget envisions a nearly half-trillion-dollar transportation construction spree that would seek to upgrade the nations roads, bridges and ports by imposing new taxes on overseas earnings by American companies.

title: Verbatim: Budget Politics
description: President Obama, urging Congress not to withhold funding for the Department of Homeland Security for political reasons.

title: Scene from Ballet 422
description: Choreographer Justin Peck observes New York City Ballet dancers during a rehearsal.

title: Ukraine Rebels Upbeat After an Infusion of Aid
description: HORLIVKA, Ukraine  The rebel commander casually led the way down a muddy trench, shoulder high with shaved walls of moist earth, his boots slapping at wooden slabs sunk into the muck. Finally, he reached an earth-covered observation post.

title: Two Bronze Sculptures Are Attributed to Michelangelo
description: LONDON  A group of experts, including art historians based at the University of Cambridge, researchers at the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam and a professor of clinical anatomy from the University of Warwick, is claiming that two virile bronze figures mounted on panthers were sculpted by Michelangelo.

title: An Exclusive Clip From a New Dance Documentary by a Girls Director
description: The uninitiated might see ballet as a sort of 19th-century relic, conjured to the stage by stern dance masters and ethereal waifs too beautiful to break a sweat. Ballet 422, a new documentary by the cinematographer-cum-filmmaker Jody Lee Lipes, which premieres tomorrow night at BAM, is an antidote to such illusions. Lipes, whose varied credits include Martha Marcy May Marlene, several episodes of Girls, a Jay Z video and the dance film NY Export: Opus Jazz, follows the rising choreographer Justin Peck as he creates an original work for the New York City Ballet (the companys 422nd): Paz de La Jolla, a critically-lauded reverie set on the beaches of his native Southern California. Lipes captures the young dance-maker and his collaborators during every step of the two-month process, from the first choreographic sketches through costume and lighting design to the premiere. The result is a vivid, multifaceted depiction of the hard and necessary work of making art for the 21st century.In the exclusive clip above, Peck observes and corrects several of the companys dazzlingly fast dancers during a rehearsal.

title: Obamas Priorities, in Budget Form
description: The presidents 2016 budget represents his policy aspirations as he begins negotiations with Republicans.

title: Court Sets Up a Hurdle, Not a Barrier, for Insider Trading Cases
description: It is interesting to see how a few words in a judicial opinion can mean so much. One sentence in the recent appeals court decision in United States v. Newman that overturned the convictions of two hedge fund traders has caused the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission to cry foul and ask for its removal, contending the statement will imperil the governments efforts to crack down on insider trading.

title: U.N. Weather Agency Confirms 2014 as Hottest Year
description: The World Meteorological Organization reported on Monday that 2014 was the hottest year in a historical record of global temperature dating from 1880. That finding confirms an announcement made last month by two American scientific agencies and one in Japan.

title: Mayor Bill de Blasio Did Not Kill the Groundhog This Year
description: The good news this morning: Mayor Bill de Blasio did not kill Chuck, the groundhog at the Staten Island Zoo whose otherwise cushy life requires a once-a-year photo op with the mayor on Groundhog Day. Its an easy job but can be dangerous. Last year Mr. de Blasio, wearing bulky gloves, fumbled and dropped the groundhog; she hit the ground hard and died of internal injuries soon after. So this year the mayor kept his hands to himself.

title: An Unexpected Bingo Call: You Cant Play
description: All she wanted to do was play bingo.

title: The Most Successful N.F.L. Team of the Last Half-Century
description: The Patriots of Bill Belichick and Tom Brady can now claim to be the most successful team of the Super Bowl era.

title: In Boston, Snow and Icy Winds Postpone Patriots Parade
description: BOSTON  Steve McCaul, a maintenance manager for a building on Boylston Street, was outside with a shovel on Monday, trying to clear the sidewalks as the second major storm in a week dumped more snow on the city.

title: A Procrastinators Guide to Valentines Day
description: Valentines Day has a way of sneaking up on you.

title: Out of a Marriage and Out of Africa
description: Alexandra Fuller writes about Africa with a fierce, uncompromising passion  like Isak Dinesens love for that same continent, like Joan Didions for California, like Faulkners for Mississippi.

title: Etan Patzs Mother Speaks in Court of the Day He Disappeared
description: She walked steadily through the courtroom, a lifetime of accomplishments and lasting tragedy behind her, a witness stand before her.

title: Kwame Alexander and Dan Santat Win Childrens Book Prizes
description: Memoirs, graphic novels and stories in verse were the big winners of this years American Library Associations awards for young adult and childrens literature. The awards, which are among the most prestigious literary prizes for childrens book authors, were announced Monday at the associations midwinter conference in Chicago.

title: A High-End Hotel Stay, With a Touch of Risk
description: To usher in 2015, Tim Ratliff booked a four-star hotel in Boston for half its typical price. He did not, however, know which one it was.

title: Cheering. Cringing. Loving It. Hating It. But Watching.
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The cheers did not echo through the desert here when the New England Patriots beat the Seattle Seahawks on Sunday in one of the most exciting Super Bowls ever. Far from it.

title: Just Kids
description: Virginal white lace paired with leather and suede evokes the sexy decadence of Patti Smiths punk-rock days.

title: Spreading Along With Measles: Polarization on a Hot-Button Issue
description: Will a measles outbreak persuade more parents to vaccinate their children?

title: Tracking the Weapons Used to Fight Ukraines War
description: It is the central question of the continuing civil war in Ukraine: to what degree is Russia supplying the weapons that are helping antigovernment forces sustain their secessionist movement? That question became even more relevant this week with the news that NATOs military commander now supports providing defensive weapons to the Ukraine government.

title: OSHA Cites Ashley Furniture Over Dozens of Safety Violations
description: Ashley Furniture, one of the worlds largest furniture manufacturers, faces $1.7 million in penalties to settle charges that unsafe conditions at its manufacturing plant in Arcadia, Wis., led to more than 1,000 injuries.

title: In This Song, a Bleep Fills In for Bombay
description: NEW DELHI  When he released his first music video, the Mumbai-based musician Mihir Joshi understood that it would be reviewed by Indias Central Board of Film Certification for obscene or offensive lyrics. When the board objected to a single word, he quickly agreed to part with it.

title: In Super Bowl Commercials, Puppy Is a Winner
description: The advertising lesson from Super Bowl XLIX: Ads with puppies continue to score with viewers while spots featuring a dead child are seen as a major fumble.

title: Four Surviving Copies of Magna Carta Reunited in London
description: LONDON  The four known extant copies of the original Magna Carta  often cited as Englands first cautious step toward individual rights  will unite at the British Library in London this week for the first time in their 800-year history.

title: Game Theory Says Pete Carrolls Call at Goal Line Is Defensible
description: Its the biggest moment in your N.F.L. coaching career: 26 seconds remain in the Super Bowl, your team is 4 points behind, you have the ball just one yard short of the end zone, its second down, and your team has arguably the N.F.L.s best running back. Whats your call? Run or pass?

title: Climate Record Keeping
description: Q. What is the evidence for periods of global warming in the past?

title: Lower Oil Prices Strike at Heart of Canadas Oil Sands Production
description: OTTAWA  For as long as 400-ton dump trucks have been rumbling around the open pit mines of Canadas oil sands, crews from Kal Tire have been on hand to replace and repair their $70,000, 13-foot diameter tires.

title: Leading a Mouse to Drink, or Not
description: Researchers have discovered a circuit in the brains of mice that controls thirst. Turn it on, and the mouse will drink regardless of how much water it has had. Turn it off, and the mouse avoids water.

title: Snake Ancestors Probably Had Legs
description: What makes a snake a snake? The oldest snake fossils on record are forcing researchers to reconsider the question.

title: Robin Williamss Widow and Children Tangle Over Estate
description: Nearly six months after the death of Robin Williams, the Academy Award-winning actor and comedian, his widow and his children have become engaged in a contentious legal dispute over his estate.

title: Slump in Oil Prices Brings Pressure, and Investment Opportunity
description: American history is littered with oil busts that created big winners and losers.

title: P.C. and the Political Left
description: Not content with one long post on the argument over political correctness kicked off by Jonathan Chait, I wrote my Sunday column on some deeper impulses at work in the late-Obama left that I think are connected to the new P.C.  in particular, a sense of futility around economic policy, a renewed post-post-racial scrutiny of racial injustice, and a greater confidence, in the wake of the same-sex marriage debate, that a vanguard moral minority can become an ascendant majority in a swift cultural march.

title: A Grunge Aesthetic at the L.A. Art Book Fair
description: A diverse mix of Angelenos browsed 40,000 square feet of affordable zines, prints and editions over the weekend.

title: Brady and Belichick on Super Bowl Win
description: The New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady and Coach Bill Belichick spoke on Monday after their team defeated the Seattle Seahawks to win the Super Bowl.

title: A Day Later, Tom Brady Praises the Patriots 60-Minute Effort
description: PHOENIX  Just past 8:30 a.m. Monday, a visibly exhausted Tom Brady strode to the podium to accept his Most Valuable Player Award and answer just a few more questions about what exactly happened the night before in the desert.

title: In Performance | Everybody Gets Cake!
description: Ryan Kasprzak, left, and Joel Jeske of the comedy troupe Parallel Exit in a skit about a Novocain abuse hotline, from the show Everybody Gets Cake!, at 59E59 Theaters through Feb. 8.

title: Dont Be Afraid to Stand Apart From the Herd
description: What feels safe is often risky, and what feels risky is often safe. This statement contradicts just about every evolutionary instinct we possess. We tend to seek out safety and avoid risk whenever possible. A classic example has to be the instinct that (still) tells us we are safer staying with the group.

title: Death by Black Hole
description: Neil deGrasse Tyson recites his rhyme.

title: A New Portal to Scientific Discourse
description: Thick cables snaked across the floor of the Hall of the Universe one recent evening. Not far from a 10-foot-tall pitted tooth of iron known as the Willamette Meteorite, a semicircle of cafe tables was set up.

title: Bradley Cooper Says American Sniper Debate Ignores Plight of Veterans
description: In a lengthy interview with the Fresh Air host Terry Gross that was broadcast Monday on National Public Radio, Bradley Cooper, the Oscar-nominated star of American Sniper, said that much of the controversy surrounding the movie was largely missing the point.

title: Channel in Bahrain Goes Silent After Giving Opposition Airtime
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  The television network Al Arab appeared well equipped to muscle its way into the Middle Easts crowded market of satellite news channels: top talent, backing from a fabulously rich Saudi prince and permission to broadcast from the island kingdom of Bahrain.

title: Silicon Valley Boom Unnerves Some Venture Capitalists
description: BOSTON  These are heady times to be working in venture capital, a fact that is making some venture capitalists nervous.

title: Meet Carl Heastie, the Flawed Politician Who Might Lead the N.Y. Assembly
description: As the New York legislature waited for the resignation of Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver at11:59 p.m. on Monday, Democratic lawmakers appeared all too ready to choose Assemblyman Carl Heastie of the Bronx as his replacement.

title: An Illustrated Super Bowl XLIX
description: The illustrator Bob Eckstein gave his take on Super Bowl XLIX during The Timess live blog on Sunday. Heres a collection of his work from before, during and after the Patriots victory.

title: Floridians Lukewarm on Bush for President, and Cold on Rubio, Poll Finds
description: A new poll has provided some insight into how Floridians view the political future of two favorite Republican sons in 2016.

title: Raspberry Pi Computer Gains More Horsepower
description: LONDON  How much computer can you buy for just $35?

title: A Comics Scholar Draws a New One of His Own
description: The cartoonist Scott McCloud has spent the last two decades examining, in a scholarly way, the medium of comic books. It began with Understanding Comics (1993), a primer, appreciation and history of the form, and stretched to Making Comics (2006), about technique, characters and creative choices.

title: A Fresh Look at the Watery Side of Earths Climate Shows Unabated Planetary Warming
description: A fresh analysis of thousands of temperature measurements from deep-diving Argo ocean probes shows (yet again) that Earth is experiencing unabated planetary warming when you factor in the vast amount of greenhouse-trapped heat that ends up in the sea. This is not even close to a new finding, but the new study shows more precisely where most of the heat has been going since 2006 (in the Southern Ocean outside the tropics; see the red splotches in the map below).

title: A Day in the Life of Eddie Huang
description: Performer and chef, writer and provocateur, Eddie Huang tries to take his brand of Asian-American anarchism to the mainstream.

title: Businesswomen Navigate Traditions in Saudi Arabia
description: WOMEN traveling to Saudi Arabia often raise eyebrows there, and Michelle Obama was no exception.

title: In the Face of the Extreme, Finding Balance (and Mashed Potatoes)
description: AFTER college, I joined the Peace Corps and eventually started working with refugee charitable organizations. When I started working with Catholic Relief Services, I had some travel under my belt, and now almost all of my work is focused on going to countries where people are in crisis, whether because of a natural disaster or war.

title: Wrangling Deer From the Sky
description: To protect migration routes, wildlife biologists at the University of Wyoming are capturing mule deer by helicopter to learn exactly where they go, what they eat and how healthy they are.

title: For Mule Deer, an Incredible 150-Mile Migration
description: THE RED DESERT, WYO.  As a small group of scientists and volunteers waits by the side of a gravel road here, a helicopter swoops down, carrying two blindfolded mule deer in slings. It hovers for a moment in a furious swirl of rotor-blown snow, detaching the deer slings. As it lifts and turns, the team runs into the stinging cloud.

title: More Snow Pummels Massachusetts
description: Scenes from around Massachusetts as more snow bore down on Monday, creating near-blizzard conditions in some parts of the state.

title: Pictures of the Day  Syria and Elsewhere
description: Syria and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Pushing Ethics Reforms, Cuomo Wants Lawmakers to Reveal Income or Lose It
description: Declaring that New Yorks government faces a crisis of public trust, Gov. Andrew Cuomo challenged the Legislature on Monday to pass a thorough clean-government program in the aftermath of Speaker Sheldon Silvers arrest and vowed not to sign a budget this year that lacks a full slate of ethics reforms.

title: Feb. 2, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Syria, Ukraine, Bangladesh and Pakistan.

title: Can Attention Deficit Drugs Normalize a Childs Brain?
description: Dr. Mark Bertin is no A.D.H.D. pill-pusher.

title: Tales of Dating, Whose Audience Is Also the Cast
description: You dont have to participate in The Human Symphony, a playful, patchy and compassionate show conceived by Dylan Marron, a member of the New York Neo-Futurists. When you check in, you can pretend to be under 18, or you can invent a medical condition (I will break out in hives, I heard one woman threaten), or you can simply decline. But six willing spectators will be plucked from the audience and invited to the stage. There, Mr. Marron will hand each of them an MP3 player with a specialized track dictating a particular set of instructions.

title: How Broadway Weathered Last Weeks Storm
description: Last weeks winter storm in the Northeast did only minimal damage to ticket sales for Broadway shows, according to box-office data released on Monday. Broadway musicals and plays grossed $17.5 million for a total of 25 productions, compared to $16.7 million for 26 productions for the same week in January 2014. Attendance was 177,158 last week, compared to 183,092 a year ago. Shows benefited from the snow coming during a traditionally slow-selling week and on a night  Monday  when few performances are held anyway; and snowfall was below projections in New York City, leading most shows to resume performances on Tuesday.

title: S.T.D. Care for Two
description: Recently, while William, 21, was manning the chicken-wing fryer at a fast-food restaurant in suburban Seattle, he pulled aside his sort-of girlfriend, 18, a pizza deliverer there. He had bad news.

title: Mayor Faces Groundhog in New Ceremony
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio took part in a new Groundhog Day ceremony meant to avoid a repeat of a falling rodent last year, with Staten Island Chuck emerging via elevator from his underground home.

title: Oil and Gas Prices Steady Despite a Refinery Strike
description: HOUSTON  Oil prices rose and gasoline prices remained low and stable on Monday, the opposite of what usually happens when labor strife threatens the operations of refineries.

title: A Spirited Journey Backward, From Modernism to Classical
description: WASHINGTON  The Mariinsky Ballet demonstrated on Saturday and Sunday that it is still one of the worlds supreme ballet companies. In the final week of its three-week visit to the United States, it produced its best dancing in the tours oldest ballet, the Grand Pas from Paquita (1881). In New York, the companys way with classical style had seemed straitjacketed in its tempos and phrasing by its musical director, Valery Gergiev. He, however, stayed in New York to conduct the Metropolitan Opera and, at Carnegie Hall, the Mariinskys orchestra.

title: Whos Unreasonable Now?
description: OK, so as I understand the latest from the new Greek government, Yanis Varoufakis is saying that he and his colleagues dont care what happens to the headline value of the debt  if you want to claim that there has been no write-off, OK. What they want instead is substantive but not outrageous relief from the burden of running primary surpluses (surpluses ex interest payments), reducing the amount of resources transferred to creditors from 4.5 to 1-1.5 percent of GDP; they also want flexibility to achieve these surpluses with a mix that includes more revenue and less spending austerity.

title: Walkabout: Kayak Adds Cuba to Its Search Database
description: New Destinations Kayak, the travel search engine, will now include Cuba hotel and flight information in its search function. Information will now be listed for flights to Havana, Santiago de Cuba and other cities. (Newsweek)

title: Apple to Open Giant Data Center in Arizona
description: When youre as rich as Apple and life gives you lemons, you make data centers.

title: Michelin Announces 2015 Rankings for France
description: On Monday morning, Michelin announced the star rankings for the 2015 red guide to France, which goes on sale Friday.

title: Hillary Clinton to Be Inducted Into Irish America Hall of Fame
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will be inducted into Irish America magazines hall of fame next month, giving her an early opportunity to try to charm a critical voting bloc.

title: Head of McKinsey Is Elected to a Third Term
description: Dominic Barton, the soft-spoken Canadian who helped McKinsey & Company weather the worst crisis in its 88-year history, has been elected by the firms partners to a third term as managing director.

title: The Young Lion Aesthetics Updated, but With an Earthy Intensity
description: For much of the last decade, Marquis Hill fit the description of a prized local phenomenon. A dauntingly skilled trumpeter from the South Side of Chicago, he came up through that citys jazz infrastructure, which extends to the classroom as well as the bandstand. He worked with a smart range of collaborators and made several albums, but the glowing reputation hed earned was concentrated within a single metropolitan area.

title: Dont Ask the Royal Cook for Any Pie Recipes
description: How many times can the poor red-nosed Clown be killed?

title: U.S. Declassifies Some Information on Afghan Forces
description: WASHINGTON  The American military command in Afghanistan on Monday abruptly reversed its decision to classify details about the Afghan Army and police, information that it had said could pose a grave security risk if disclosed.

title: Back in Command
description: TORONTO  Its always news in the opera world when an important singer takes on a touchstone role of the repertory for the first time. Preferably, an artist stepping up to such a challenge wants attention, but not too much.

title: For Williams, Triumph and Pain Come at One Speed
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Serena Williams is now prepared to confess what led to her stumbling about the grass in a bizarre and brief doubles match at Wimbledon last year.

title: Journal Eyes Corruption in Indias Medical Schools
description: A leading British medical journal has harshly attacked corruption in Indias medical schools.

title: A Different Kind of Opening
description: BEIJING  Outside China, he is best known as the man behind Mr. Chow  the high-end Chinese restaurants and longtime watering holes for artists and celebrities in London, New York, Beverly Hills, Miami Beach and Malibu.

title: British Pottery, Illustrated
description: A series of paintings by Leanne Shapton based on the book Lucie Rie: a Survey of Her Life and Work.

title: A Planet With Rings That Dwarf Saturns
description: Astronomers have discovered a planet with a ring system that is 200 times larger than Saturns. The planet, the first of its kind to be found outside our solar system, is surrounded by 30 rings, each tens of millions of kilometers in diameter with large gaps that indicate the presence of small moons. The discovery, described in Astrophysical Journal, was made by scientists at the University of Rochester and Leiden Observatory in the Netherlands. They were investigating mysterious eclipses of the planets star, which turned out to be caused by the rings.

title: A Path for Precision Medicine
description: For three years, Dr. Robert Green, a researcher at Brigham and Womens Hospital and Harvard Medical School, has been painstakingly gathering genetic data on thousands of Alzheimers patients, trying to figure out whether genetic differences explain why the disease progresses over a quarter century in some people and kills others within five years. He has called in favors from colleagues and filled out the reams of paperwork required to share data across institutions, but still has only half of what he needs to do the analysis.

title: A Struggle to Survive in Each Soulful Lyric
description: I walked through a wall of fire

title: A Grunge Aesthetic at the L.A. Art Book Fair
description: This past weekend, Los Angeles hosted three very different art fairs in three very different locales: Art Los Angeles Contemporary in Santa Monica, Paramount Ranch in Agoura Hills and Printed Matters L.A. Art Book Fair downtown. With 40,000 square feet worth of affordable zines, prints and editions on offer, the latter event was the most populist, and populous. For three days, the normally quiet streets of Little Tokyo teemed with pedestrians as art lovers, thrill-seeking teenagers and curious onlookers migrating from the Hello Kitty exhibition next door crowded the Geffen Contemporary at MOCA. Live bands and food trucks lent a music-festival feel; fittingly, the fashion on view tended toward the grungy, with black-on-black layers and mom jeans (on both men and women) among the more visible trends. The style outliers, many of whom were exhibitors, took things a step further. Highlights included statement shoes, sparkling face paint and multiples of symbolic jewelry from the artist Tauba Auerbach, whose Diagonal Press hosted a booth at the fair. The photographer Laure Joliet was on hand to capture the action for T.

title: Releases From Bob Dylan and Diana Krall
description: Its not a put-on. Bob Dylans Shadows in the Night, an album of 10 songs that were all recorded by Frank Sinatra, is a tribute from one venerated American musician to another, a reconsideration of a school of songwriting, a feat of technical nostalgia and a reckoning with love and death.

title: F.C.C. Chief Wants to Override State Laws Curbing Community Net Services
description: Tom Wheeler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, will propose an order to pre-empt state laws that limit the build-out of municipal broadband Internet services, senior F.C.C. officials said on Monday.

title: Your Letters: Stardust and Animal Friendships
description: Cosmology

title: At Oscar Nominees Luncheon, a Regal Eastwood and a Savvy Arquette
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  If the point of ritual is reassurance, few pop cultural rituals are as pointed as the annual Oscar nominees luncheon. It arrives without fail in early February, as nearly changeless as a yearly ceremony can be.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Measles: Perilous but Preventable
description: Measles has been spreading in the United States at a rate that worries health officials, with 102 cases so far this year in at least 14 states.

title: Closing Education Gap Will Lift Economy, a Study Finds
description: Study after study has shown a yawning educational achievement gap between the poorest and wealthiest children in America. But what does this gap costs in terms of lost economic growth and tax revenue?

title: Viewing a Composer in a New Light
description: It may be true that the Russian composer is too far advanced for the present generation and that his doctrine and music will be accepted in years to come, the Musical Courier wrote of Alexander Scriabin in March 1915, a month before that composers early death. But as the writer is not a reader of the future, the work is condemned for the present.

title: Maternal Depression Often Starts Before Giving Birth, Study Says
description: A large new study has documented unexpected links in the timing and severity of symptoms of maternal depression, which could help mothers and doctors better anticipate and treat the condition.

title: Johnny Manziel Enters Treatment Program
description: PHOENIX  Cleveland Browns quarterback Johnny Manziel, who has earned a reputation as a hard-partying celebrity, has entered a treatment program, said the teams general manager, Ray Farmer, and Manziels advisor Brad Beckworth.

title: SS&C to Buy Advent Software for $2.3 Billion
description: SS&C Technologies agreed on Monday to buy Advent Software for about $2.3 billion in cash, uniting two big providers of software for the financial services industry.

title: Paul Calls Vaccination a Matter of Freedom
description: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky took a firm position Monday on the side of people who say vaccination is a personal choice, overshadowing similar comments made earlier in the day by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, a fellow Republican, and inserting himself into a hot debate that will likely resurface if the senator runs for president.

title: Broadway Debut of a Country Star
description: Jennifer Nettles, a country music singer-songwriter with a limited dance background, is learning Bob Fosses choreography to star as Roxie Hart in the musical Chicago on Broadway.

title: All That Fosse, With a Twang
description: The country music singer-songwriter Jennifer Nettles probably knows a promenade from a two-step. But can she do the mess-around?

title: Video Analysis Suggests Egyptian Officer Shot Protester, Rights Group Says
description: A detailed forensic analysis of video recorded in Cairo on Jan. 24 strongly suggests that an Egyptian police officer fired the shotgun pellets that killed her, Human Rights Watch said in a report released on Sunday.

title: Shooting the Moon
description: A loose-knit group of photographers in Los Angeles meets monthly with a very specific purpose: to make the perfect photograph of planes set against the moon.

title: Jeep Cherokees to Be Recalled to Upgrade Airbag Software
description: Chrysler will recall more than 228,000 vehicles because their airbags could unexpectedly inflate without a crash. The company will upgrade software governing side-curtain and seat-mounted side airbags in Jeep Cherokees from the 2014-15 model years, including more than 168,000 vehicles in the United States. Chrysler engineers initiated an investigation after getting reports of a small number of inadvertent deployments involving drivers who executed extreme maneuvers. In these cases, the airbag systems, sensing potential rollovers, automatically activated. The action follows a much larger recall for inadvertent airbag deployments announced on Saturday by regulators at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. That recall covers about 2.1 million vehicles made by Chrysler, Toyota and Honda with airbags that might suddenly deploy.

title: Catholics Fear Campaign of Church Attacks in India
description: NEW DELHI  A series of episodes at churches over the last two months has prompted Roman Catholics here to worry about a deliberate campaign of violence, and to call on Prime Minister Narendra Modi to speak out against religious intimidation.

title: Trial Begins in Hit and Run That Killed Expectant Brooklyn Couple
description: It was Saturday night in Orthodox Williamsburg, and Shabbos had ended not long before. Raizy Glauber, who was almost seven months pregnant, was leaving her parents house with her husband, Nathan. She affectionately tapped her older brother, Joseph Silberstein, on the shoulder as he entered the house and they left.

title: Frances Ideals, Forged in Revolution, Face a Modern Test
description: CLICHY-SOUS-BOIS, France  In the aftermath of the Charlie Hebdo attacks, France has begun a defensive but potentially decisive debate over what it means to be French  and whether that definition can make room for its vibrant, growing Muslim population.

title: Want More Vaccinated Kids? End Religious and Personal Exemptions.
description: There is a simple and effective way to decrease the number of parents who choose not to vaccinate their children against preventable diseases, and it doesnt require suing those parents or criminally charging them. Instead, state legislatures need to end both religious and personal exemptions to the requirement that children be vaccinated in order to attend public schools. A strict vaccine requirement  without loopholes  is all it would take to reduce the numbers of unvaccinated children to levels that would allow us to maximize protection for everyone.

title: U.S. Declines to Prosecute News Corporation Phone Hacking
description: The Justice Department will not prosecute Rupert Murdochs News Corporation or 21st Century Fox over voice mail interceptions and payments to public officials, actions done by their journalists in London, the companies said on Monday.

title: A New Sandals in Barbados
description: The new couples-only Sandals Barbados, which opened late last month, is poised to be one of the most upscale in the group of 15 all-inclusive resorts.

title: Belgium: Man Accused of Threat Close to Parliament
description: A man with a gun and a chain saw in his car was detained Monday by the police near the European Parliament, prompting the temporary evacuation of several buildings. The man, a Slovakian citizen born in 1982 and identified only as W.R., was dressed in camouflage and sought a meeting with the Parliaments president, according to a statement by the Brussels prosecutors office. He was arrested, accused of threatening an attack and possessing unauthorized weapons. Belgium has been on alert since recent raids in which the authorities killed two men suspected of planning a terrorist attack.

title: North Korea: Investigator Rules Out Reforms by Kim
description: The special United Nations investigator of human rights abuses in North Korea suggested in an interview published Monday that the ruling Kim family must be replaced before the countrys extensive network of prison camps can be broken up. The investigator, Marzuki Darusman, emphasized in the interview with The Associated Press that he was not advocating force to oust North Koreas government. But in discussing how to end abuses, most notably in the Norths penal system, he was quoted as saying: That can only happen if this cult leadership system is completely dismantled. And the only way to do that is if the Kim family is effectively displaced, is effectively removed from the scene, and a new leadership comes into place. North Koreas rights abuses were documented in a United Nations report published last year, which the government of Kim Jong-un has denounced as propaganda orchestrated by the United States.

title: San Francisco Symphony Ratifies Musicians Contract
description: In a reminder that labor negotiations in the world of classical music are not always marked by disharmony, the San Francisco Symphony announced Monday that it had ratified a new contract that would keep its players among the best-paid in the world.

title: Chief Who Guided Ally Financial After Crisis Steps Down
description: The chief executive of Ally Financial, the former lending arm of General Motors, has stepped down from his post.

title: What to Watch Out For at the Alpine Championships
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  The Alpine World Ski Championships come to the United States for the first time since 1999, with the first races of the two-week competition set for Tuesday. Here are five races to watch:

title: Judge Asks for Revisions to Concussion Settlement
description: PHOENIX  The federal judge overseeing the settlement between the N.F.L. and the 5,000 former players who accused the league of hiding the dangers of concussions from them has asked both sides to revise parts of their deal before she would give her final approval.

title: Tax Reform Is the Cry, Until Details Are Offered
description: It has been a regular refrain from corporate Americas chief executives, Corporate tax in this country needs to be reformed, Jeffrey R. Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, has said repeatedly. Timothy D. Cook, Apples chief executive, told lawmakers, Apple has recommended to the Obama administration and several members of Congress  and suggests to the subcommittee today  to pass legislation that dramatically simplifies the U.S. corporate tax system.

title: German Chancellor Rules Out Weapons Aid to Ukraine
description: BUDAPEST  Chancellor Angela Merkel on Monday ruled out any German supply of weapons to Ukraine, but emphasized that Europe must stay united against Russian aggression.

title: Sony Sells Online Game Business
description: Sony said on Monday that it has sold Sony Online Entertainment, a business that has developed Internet games since the late 1990s, to Columbus Nova, an investment firm.

title: Leader of War Crimes Inquiry Into 2014 Gaza Conflict Resigns
description: UNITED NATIONS  The chairman of a United Nations panel investigating possible war crimes in the 50-day Gaza conflict last summer resigned Monday, attributing the decision to Israeli accusations of personal bias that led to a formal inquiry over whether he should be removed.

title: Gotham Recap: Hallelujah! The Penguin Escapes Again
description: Season 1, Episode 14, The Fearsome Dr. Crane

title: Carl Heastie, Legislator From Bronx, Is Poised to Become New York Assembly Speaker
description: ALBANY  History within reach, Assemblyman Carl E. Heastie of the Bronx had seemingly secured the speakership of the New York State Assembly on Monday, as a final challenger bowed out and reports that his campaign spending was once under scrutiny did little to buffet his ascent.

title: A Long Path to Survival
description: The 150-mile Red Desert-to-Hoback migration path allows a swath of Wyoming to support a mule deer population. Scientists now use it to study the deer.

title: How One Bad Giants Call Ended an N.F.L. Career
description: PHOENIX  In Florida, there is an old coach, now in his late 80s, who still watches football. He occasionally draws up plays and names them for his grandchildren.

title: Measles Outbreak Proves Delicate Issue to G.O.P. Field
description: WASHINGTON  The politics of medicine, morality and free will have collided in an emotional debate over vaccines and the governments place in requiring them, posing a challenge for Republicans who find themselves in the familiar but uncomfortable position of reconciling modern science with the skepticism of their core conservative voters.

title: President Obamas New Budget
