description: President Obamas fiscal 2016 budget, released on Monday, pulls together the themes and policies set forth in his State of the Union address and other recent speeches and gives them a force and coherence  an ambitiousness  that a more piecemeal delivery does not convey.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 2, 2015
Pharmacies in Venezuela Are Accused of Sabotage
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The authorities detained several executives of the countrys top pharmacy chain over the weekend amid accusations that retailers were seeking to maintain long lines outside stores as part of what President Nicols Maduro called a guerrilla tactic to sow discontent in the economically beleaguered nation.

title: Bratton Says Terrorism and Protests Will Be Handled by Separate Police Units
description: The New York Police Department will soon have two new groupings of officers: a heavily armed unit given the task of combating terrorism, and a mobile unit trained to handle more common events, like protests and neighborhood crime spikes.

title: A Heated Path Toward S.&P.s Legal Settlement With Prosecutors
description: When lawyers for Standard & Poors traveled to the Justice Department in Washington last month, they hoped to settle an array of government lawsuits and extinguish two years of bad blood. But within minutes of arriving, their plan collided with the demands of government negotiators  all 25 who attended.

title: True Hero for Patriots Put Rookie Butler in Spotlight
description: With less than a minute remaining in the Super Bowl on Sunday, the Seattle Seahawks lined up in a three-wide-receiver set at the 1-yard line. To the right of quarterback Russell Wilson, Ricardo Lockette stood nearly directly behind another wide receiver, Jermaine Kearse, a yard back and on Kearses outside shoulder  an alignment commonly used on pick plays.

title: Lands End, Post Sears, Replaces Its Chief
description: Lands End announced on Monday that it would replace its chief executive with the president of the high-end Italian fashion label Dolce & Gabbana, offering clues about the classic American brands new direction months after it separated from the Sears Holding Corporation.

title: Uber to Open Center for Research on Self-Driving Cars
description: Uber, the ride-hailing start-up, prides itself on the tens of thousands of jobs it says it has created for people across the world.

title: Nailed the Test
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Now heres a Tuesday puzzle I can get behind. When youve been solving for a while and love the late-week challenges, you might start to feel like you are still doing the early-week puzzles out of a sort of loyalty. In my case, its to feel smart. Once in a while, however, you have to shake things up. Joe Krozel is back and, as usual, hes stirring the pot.

title: Sleepy Hollow Recap: White Eyeballs and a Book of Spells
description: Season 2, Episode 15: Spellcaster

title: Chris Christie Shows Fondness for Luxury Benefits When Others Pay the Bill
description: As Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey waited to depart on a trade mission to Israel in 2012, his entourage was delayed by a late arrival: Mr. Christies father, who had accidentally headed to the wrong airport.

title: In 2nd Year, Mayor de Blasio Will Focus on Making Housing Denser and More Affordable
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday is set to declare housing as the focal point of his second year in office, unveiling a vision for an even denser yet more affordable New York City that will transform neighborhoods from East Harlem in Manhattan to Staten Islands North Shore.

title: Rangers Put a Damper on the Panthers Postseason Hopes
description: Flush with young talent, and with a smattering of accomplished veterans, the Florida Panthers are the leading team among the Eastern Conferences also-rans, perhaps the only squad outside the top eight that still has a chance at a playoff spot.

title: Lindsey Vonn, Healthy, Will Have Momentum on Her Hometown Slopes
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  Nearly two years after injuring her right knee in a horrific crash, Lindsey Vonn was primed to compete in Tuesdays super-G, the opening race of the 2015 Alpine World Championships here.

title: In Williamsburg Warehouse Fire, Lingering Risks of New Yorks Analog Age
description: The fire that engulfed a Brooklyn warehouse over the weekend revealed how dependent government agencies and hospitals are on paper records, even in the age of digital media.

title: Facts About the Measles Outbreak
description: A map of counties where cases have been reported so far this year, and a chart showing how the number of cases compares to previous years.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 3, 2015
description: I watched him walk one block away. I turned around to go back upstairs, and that was the last time I saw him.

title: Drug Makers Data on Side Effects Is Called Lacking in a Report
description: The main system for keeping track of the dangerous side effects of prescription drugs is deeply flawed, primarily because drug makers are submitting incomplete information about the problems to the Food and Drug Administration, according to a new study by a nonprofit group that tracks drug safety issues.

title: Super Bowl Was a Stunner, and Thats Just the Size of the TV Audience
description: The other day I suggested that even a lousy game can yield sensational Super Bowl viewership, which happened last year. But a game that is incredible, surprising, tightly played and has everything but an elf on the sideline deflating balls?

title: Inside Mercado Roma, Mexico Citys Newest Foodie Destination
description: Tomorrow, more than 120 galleries from 22 countries will descend upon Mexico City for the 12th edition of the Zona Maco International Contemporary Art Fair. And this year, the art set has a new culinary destination to hit up between booth visits: Mercado Roma. Situated in the hipster neighborhood of La Roma, the bustling food market, which opened last summer, takes its cues from sleek stateside food halls like Manhattans Chelsea Market. There are communal tables set against a vertical garden out back, where guests can enjoy prepared foods and artisanal treats from approximately 60 vendors, most of whom produce local, farm-to-table dishes and desserts.

title: New York Attorney General Targets Supplements at Major Retailers
description: The New York State attorney generals office accused four major retailers on Monday of selling fraudulent and potentially dangerous herbal supplements and demanded that they remove the products from their shelves.

title: Whats in Those Supplements?
description: The New York State attorney generals office accusedfour national retailers on Monday of sellingdietarysupplements that were fraudulent and in many cases contaminated with unlisted ingredients.

title: President Tweaks the Rules on Data Collection
description: WASHINGTON  A year after President Obama ordered modest changes in how the nations intelligence agencies collect and hold data on Americans and foreigners, the administration will announce new rules requiring intelligence analysts to delete private information they may incidentally collect about Americans that has no intelligence purpose, and to delete similar information about foreigners within five years.

title: Retailers Are Warned Over Herbal Supplements
description: These cease-and-desist letters were sent to GNC, Target, Walgreens and Walmart by the New York State attorney general, who demanded that the retailers explain how they verify the ingredients in their herbal supplements.

title: Word of the Day | viscous
description: viscous \vis-ks\ adjective

title: Obamacare, Back at the Supreme Court: Frequently Asked Questions
description: A list of frequently asked questions about the King v. Burwell Supreme Court case and its implications for Obamacare.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 2:30 P.M. (Sundance) THE KINGS SPEECH (2010) Colin Firth, in the role that won him an Oscar for best actor, portrays Albert Frederick Arthur George, or Bertie, as his family called him, the shy second son of George V of Britain (Michael Gambon) in this film from Tom Hooper. Geoffrey Rush is Lionel Logue, the speech therapist who helps Bertie conquer a debilitating stutter. And Helena Bonham Carter is Elizabeth, Alberts wife and staunch support system, who cant quite stomach Wallis Simpson (Eve Best), the American divorce who leads Berties older brother, David (Guy Pearce), to abdicate as Edward VIII. It isnt exactly Pygmalion, not least because Mr. Hooper has no intention of satirizing the caste system that is one of this movies biggest draws, Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, said of the film, which received 12 Oscar nominations and also won for best director, best picture and original screenplay. Like many entertainments of this pop-historical type, she added, The Kings Speech wears history lightly no matter how heavy the crown.

title: Corrections: February 3, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Alibaba and Lending Club to Form Financing Partnership
description: The companies behind two of the hottest stock market debuts of 2014, Lending Club and the Alibaba Group, are teaming up  to help American companies buy parts from Chinese manufacturers.

title: China Considers Whether to Allow Baijiu With Bling
description: Among the casualties in Chinas continuing crackdown on corruption have been the spirits makers who sell to the countrys monied elite. With ostentatious imbibing now highly frowned upon, the makers of liquor like baijiu have seen serious hits to sales growth over the past two years.

title: Central Banks in India and Australia Take Steps to Lift Growth
description: HONG KONG  Two more central banks have joined the growing international trend toward monetary stimulus as an antidote for weak global demand, as India on Tuesday reduced the reserves that commercial banks must hold while Australia cut its benchmark interest rate to a low.

title: Coming Out as Anxious
description: When I was 10, I was diagnosed with a collection of anxiety disorders. For the next three and a half decades, I hid my condition from those around me. I concocted elaborate explanations for the absences caused by my therapy appointments. I kept my medications out of sight. I generally did everything I could to project an aura of competence and confidence that was often at odds with the vulnerability, and sometimes the terror, that I felt.

title: In New York State, a Chance for Major Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: The Supreme Courts Secret Decisions
description: CHICAGO  A CONVICTED murderer, Charles F. Warner, was executed in Oklahoma last month after the United States Supreme Court denied his request for a last-minute stay. Mr. Warner and other death-row inmates had challenged the states lethal injection procedures as unconstitutional. In a strange twist, the court agreed to hear his claims  a week after Mr. Warner had been executed.

title: Support for Gay Marriage: What Our History Shows
description: To the Editor:

title: Obamas Drilling Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Government Handouts at Wireless Auctions
description: Large telecommunications companies have repeatedly taken advantage of rules meant to help small, rural, female- and minority-owned businesses buy licenses for airwaves for wireless phone and data transmission, including in a recent auction that raised nearly $45 billion for the government. Congress and the Federal Communications Commission should crack down on such abuse.

title: To Stop Violence, Start at Home
description: THE pattern is striking. Men who are eventually arrested for violent acts often began with attacks against their girlfriends and wives. In many cases, the charges of domestic violence were not taken seriously or were dismissed.

title: Building Better Secularists
description: Over the past few years, there has been a sharp rise in the number of people who are atheist, agnostic or without religious affiliation. A fifth of all adults and a third of the youngest adults fit into this category.

title: Arcapita Gets More Than $1 Billion in Sale of Pods
description: LONDON  The Bahrain private-equity firm Arcapita said on Tuesday that it had sold Pods, a moving and storage container company, to the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan in a deal worth more than $1 billion.

title: Measles and the Vaccine Opponents
Reckless Rejection of the Measles Vaccine
description: It is bad enough that many misguided parents are endangering their own children by refusing to let them be vaccinated against measles and other contagious diseases. But it is shockingly irresponsible of them to put other children and adults at risk of catching measles from their unvaccinated children.

title: Inside Syrias Jails
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In the spring of 2011, hundreds of thousands of Syrians rose up in protest to demand democracy and freedom and an end to the dictatorship of President Bashar al-Assad. The response of the regime was to escalate the methods of repression that had been tried and tested against political opponents since the 1970s: arbitrary detention, disappearance and torture.

title: Melody
description: In this short documentary, students in a youth orchestra program in Chile pursue their love of music to escape poverty.

title: Melody
description: For more than two decades, my home country of Chile has had a stable democracy, as well as a thriving economy. At the same time, Chile has one of the largest wealth disparities in the world, reinforced by high tuition rates for secondary and college education.

title: Banco Santander Profit Rises 69 Percent as Loan Provisions Decline
description: LONDON  Banco Santander of Spain reported on Tuesday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 69 percent as it continued to benefit from a decline in provisions for bad loans.

title: South Korean Who Killed 5 Fellow Soldiers Is Sentenced to Die
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A South Korean Army sergeant was sentenced to death on Tuesday for killing five of his fellow conscripts and wounding seven others in a shooting rampage in June.

title: BP Posts Net Loss of $4.4 Billion in Fourth Quarter
description: LONDON  BP on Tuesday reported a net loss of $4.4 billion in the fourth quarter of 2014, attributed mainly to write-offs of about $5.5 billion on the value of assets in the North Sea and Angola because of lower estimates of reserves and falling oil prices.

title: What Would It Mean to 'Fix' No Child Left Behind?
Test Yourself | Super Bowl Ads
description: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 1 review, Super Bowl Commercials Go for Heart, Not Just Funny Bone and Jugular.

title: 6 Qs About the News | A Boy Praises the Principal of His Brooklyn School, and a Fund-Raising Campaign Takes Off
description: In A Boy Praises the Principal of His Brooklyn School, and a Fund-Raising Campaign Takes Off, Winnie Hu and Jonah Bromwich write about a remarkable social media campaign that has raised money for a New York City public middle school.

title: Shooting the Moon
description: Raul Roa has been a general-assignment photographer in Los Angeles for 20 years. He covers everything. The overturned tractor-trailer on I-5. The water polo meet at Glendale High. The protests in downtown Los Angeles after Ferguson. He does it all.

title: How Do You Think Dinosaurs Went Extinct?
description: Update | Feb. 5, 2015

title: On Obamas Budget
description: President Obamas new budget relies on large tax increases, on corporations and the wealthy, to fund infrastructure and education projects.

title: Fiji Will Drop Union Jack From Its Flag, Premier Says
description: HONG KONG  Fiji will replace its national flag this year to remove symbols of British colonialism, Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama announced Tuesday.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: The Tough Path Facing Chris Christie and Marco Rubio
description: The end of Mitt Romneys candidacy has brought the so-called invisible primary  the behind-the-scenes competition for the resources and credibility needed to win the nomination  into a new phase, with new players. Marco Rubio and Chris Christie, in particular, seem as if they might benefit. The two are racing against Jeb Bush to earn the support of Mr. Romneys former supporters, according to my colleague Nicholas Confessore.

title: China Proposal on NGOs Raises Transparency Concerns at U.N.
description: A proposal by China that would have withheld the names of countries that criticize nongovernmental organizations at the United Nations has drawn condemnation from diplomats and rights groups, citing concerns about transparency.

title: New York Today: Whats the State of Your Block?
description: Good morning on this fiercely cold Tuesday.

title: Daily Report: In Net Neutrality Plan, F.C.C. Chief Aims to Govern Web Like a Utility
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission this week is widely expected to propose regulating Internet service like a public utility, a move certain to unleash another round of intense debate and lobbying about how to ensure so-called net neutrality, or an open Internet, Steve Lohr reports.

title: E.U. Focuses on Belgium in Tax Avoidance Inquiry
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union authorities on Tuesday broadened their drive against tax avoidance by multinational companies, opening an investigation into the way Belgium appeared to grant unfair state aid.

title: Exclusive Preview: Fresh Off the Boat
description: Constance Wu, Hudson Yang and Randall Park in a scene from the new show inspired by Eddie Huang.

title: Eddie Huang Against the World
description: On a cold, dark street in Tijuana, Mexico, I asked Eddie Huang a question that many people were sure to ask him in the months to come. What did you expect?

title: Art for Moneys Sake
description: You could be forgiven for thinking the boxy structure that opened last November in Long Island City, Queens, with gray-and-white stripes flanking a blue frontispiece, was a bold new art museum. The modern-looking facility, built from the ground up at a cost of $70 million, is set to span 280,000 square feet when an adjacent building opens this spring. The complex will be packed with thousands of works of art, from old masters to contemporary rising stars. But unlike at a museum, few will ever see the works that live inside it.

title: A Republican Joins Obama in Seeking Ties to Cuba
description: WASHINGTON  Two days before President Obama  ended a half-century of diplomatic estrangement with Cuba, his national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, asked Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona to be the only Republican on a secret flight to Havana to bring home a jailed American, Alan P. Gross  and to tell no one.

title: Today in Politics
description: Democrats Look to Protect Obamas Immigration Directives

title: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 27-Feb. 2, 2015
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Morning Agenda: The Road to S.&P.s Settlement
description: THE ROAD TO S.&P.S SETTLEMENT | An overflow crowd of government regulators, including attorneys general from states across the country, spent a day in January ticking off their demands before eventually negotiating a $1.37 billion settlement with the giant ratings agency Standard & Poors, Ben Protess reports in DealBook. The settlement, expected to be announced on Tuesday, was the culmination of a heated, two-year fight between S.&P. and the Justice Department, according to an account assembled through interviews.

title: A Plan Is Slow to Take Shape
description: There were 60 million good reasons for Phil Jackson to accept the formidable challenge of rebuilding the Knicks along with one intangible benefit that could not be banked. Some might think the one he chose, however, borders on obsession: to resurrect his beloved triangle and prove to the world that it is an offense for the ages.

title: London Theater Journal: A Harrowing Descent Into War
description: LONDON  The boys with the rifles separated us according to sex, the men forced into one group and the women into the other. Most of us complied, a startled and sheeplike herd.

title: Tough Fedding
description: The monetary-policy gap between insiders and outsiders  between economists at the Fed and other policy institutions, who still seem eager to raise rates, and those of us on the outside, who think this is a really, really bad idea  continues to widen. This morning Tim Duy  one of the outsiders who, commenting from his perch at Mark Thomas invaluable blog, has seemed most sympathetic to the urge to hike rates  joins the what-are-they-thinking chorus. Core inflation is drifting downward, not upward, and is now well below the Feds target. So why hike?

title: Comedy Material Woven From Real Life
description: Having worked together on and off for more than 40 years, Catherine OHara and Eugene Levy can withstand almost anything one says about the other, unless it is complimentary.

title: Cisco Makes Its Annual Predictions on Mobile Data Traffic
description: If everybody has a smartphone, maybe well soon just start calling them phones.

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Last week, we looked at near-miss word choices. This week, a roundup of homophone problems, many of them familiar by now. Put them on your list  and look them up every time if you need to.

title: For Transgender Students, Business Schools Are a Transition
description: It was 2 a.m. when Danielle Piergallini composed an email to classmates at Vanderbilt Universitys Owen Graduate School of Management announcing she was transgender. She had spent her first semester in the M.B.A. program presenting as male and worried what kind of response she would get after she clicked send.

title: A University Recognizes a Third Gender: Neutral
description: Rocko Gieselman looked like any other undergraduate at the University of Vermont but perhaps a little prettier, with pale freckles dancing across porcelain skin and bright blue eyes amplifying a broad smile. Black bra straps poked out from a faded black tank top emblazoned with the logo of the indie band Rubblebucket; a silver necklace with an anchor dangled over ample dcolletage.

title: In Performance: Ryan Kasprzak and Joel Jeske of Everybody Gets Cake!
description: This weeks video features the performers Ryan Kasprzak and Joel Jeske in an excerpt from Everybody Gets Cake!, a new show from the comedy troupe Parallel Exit. The scene takes place at an unusually taxing taping of a public service announcement about Novocain abuse. In his review, Neil Genzlinger called the skit pretty hilarious. The show, directed by Mark Lonergan, continues through Feb. 8 at 59E59 Theaters.

title: ECO 348, The Great Recession, 2-2-15
description: Notes here (pdf)

title: Viktor & Rolf Hop Off the Ready-to-Wear Treadmill
description: Well, this is a turn of the fashion wheel I did not see coming: A season after Jean Paul Gaultier announced he was closing his ready-to-wear line to concentrate on couture, the Dutch designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren, otherwise known as Viktor & Rolf, have followed suit.

title: Grid Sensors Could Ease Disruptions of Power
description: For decades, utility companies have relied on customers telling them when their lights have gone off as a sign that there may be a broader power disruption. The utilities then send workers to drive along mile after mile of power lines, looking for tiny devices  little red circular tabs  that have popped up, signaling the source of the problem in the network.

title: A Solo Travelers Guide to Meeting People
description: When you are traveling solo, its not always a breeze to strike up a conversation with a stranger.

title: In London, an Olympic Park Anchors a Resurgence
description: Before London snagged the 2012 Olympic Games, Stratford  due east of Hackney, on the banks of the Lea River  was among the poorest areas of the capital, renowned mostly for its industrial pylons and its fridge mountain, an imposing fortress of discarded appliances, along its waterfront. More than nine years and 9 billion (about $13 billion) later, the industrial wetlands have been transformed into a gleaming sports and shopping hub.

title: New York Times Co. Profit Falls Despite Strides in Digital Ads
description: The New York Times Company said on Tuesday that its annual operating profit declined in 2014 because of investments in digital journalism and severance costs from a round of job reductions. Revenue was flat as growth in digital advertising and circulation offset declines in its print business.

title: CCTV Appoints Hosts for Lunar New Year Gala, With Some Surprises
description: Lunar New Year celebrations in China are typically marked by travel back home, dumplings with family members and, on New Years Eve, the Spring Festival Gala on China Central Television.

title: S.&P.s $1.37 Billion Reckoning Over Crisis-Era Misdeeds
description: Nearly a decade after credit ratings agencies became a symbol of a financial crisis they helped create, one of the industrys biggest players faces a costly reckoning.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Strange Interlude in the Subway
description: Dear Diary:

title: Baccarats Crystal Palace
description: Not surprisingly, the new Baccarat Hotel, a grand mansion opening next month in midtown Manhattan, is a shiny affair. The French designers Patrick Gilles and Dorothe Boissier have adorned lamps, walls, arches and even armchairs with the companys gleaming crystal. Thousands of backlit Harcourt tumblers  Baccarats most iconic design  flank the entrance, and tiered chandeliers hung from slack hemp-covered chains intensify deep red walls in the bar. The sumptuous guest rooms, bathed in crisp whites and grays, mix elegance with informality  which, says Boissier, is so not French.

title: Saudi Oil Is Seen as Lever to Pry Russian Support From Syrias Assad
description: WASHINGTON  Saudi Arabia has been trying to pressure President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to abandon his support for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, using its dominance of the global oil markets at a time when the Russian government is reeling from the effects of plummeting oil prices.

title: Obama Unveils 2016 FIscal Year Budget
description: The president discussed his budget for the next fiscal year at the Department of Homeland Security headquarters.

title: A Gender-Neutral Glossary
description: SEX Classification as male or female or, rarely, intersex (not exclusively male or female). Sex is usually assigned based on external anatomy but is determined by characteristics like chromosomes, hormones and reproductive organs.

title: Is Book Reviewing a Public Service or an Art?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Anna Holmes debate whether book reviewing should be considered a public service or an art.

title: Richard Linklater and Ellar Coltrane on Nerding Up
description: Richard Linklaters crowning cinematic achievement, Boyhood, seems locked neck-and-neck with Alejandro G. Irritus Birdman in the race for best picture. Yet way back in the early aughts, when Mr. Linklater decided to move ahead with his idea of filming a fictional family over a dozen years, he wasnt sure if such a movie could even work. The idea hinged on finding the right boy, which Mr. Linklater did in Ellar Coltrane, who was cast when he was 6.

title: Verbatim: Boehner on Vaccinations
description: Speaker John A. Boehner, adding his opinion to the vaccination debate.

title: Staples Said to Be in Talks to Buy Office Depot
description: Eighteen years after regulators shot down a merger between Staples and Office Depot, the two big office supply retailers may try to join forces once again.

title: Fidel Castro Appears Animated and Alert in New Photos
description: MEXICO CITY  Photographs of Fidel Castro taken 10 days ago appeared on an official website late Monday, the first to be published since rumors about Mr. Castros death swirled through Havana and Miami in December.

title: Should Slut Be Retired?
description: The word slut, says Leora Tanenbaum, has changed.

title: French Soldiers Guarding Jewish Site Are Attacked
description: PARIS  The French police on Tuesday arrested a man believed to have attacked and wounded three soldiers who were guarding a Jewish community center in the southern city of Nice, prosecutors said, heightening anxieties just weeks after terrorist attacks in Paris shook the country.

title: Healing Touch
description: Arizonas cactus doctor, Rile Leblanc, tends to the regions ailing desert plants.

title: For the Prickliest Patients, a Desert Doctor Makes House Calls
description: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz.  The aging patient, prickly and stiff, loomed over the doctor, showing a number of troubling signs. The doctor noted poor posture, callused skin, limbs pocked with deep scars. He feared survival would hinge on drastic action, maybe even an amputation.

title: 1940: Rationing May Be Started
description: Paris newspapers yesterday [Feb. 3] published articles intimating that ration cards for at least a few food products may be introduced in the capital, if not in all of France. Thus far in the war, France alone of the belligerents has not introduced the ration system. Several newspapers also announced the fact that the Seine Department General Council on December 30 passed a resolution asking that ration cards for sugar, coffee, oil, macaroni and spaghetti be issued within the department. At the same time, it was revealed that ration cards were printed by the government in 1937 and distributed to town halls throughout the nation. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 4, 1940

title: Marriage Equality in Alabama
description: A television ad now airing across Alabama delivers a well-timed message about the human costs of denying gay couples the right to marry.

title: Harper Lee, Author of To Kill a Mockingbird, Is to Publish a Second Novel
description: For more than half a century, To Kill a Mockingbird has stood apart as a singular American literary masterpiece, a perennial best seller that has provoked countless classroom discussions about racial and social injustice. It brought instant and overwhelming fame to its enigmatic author, Harper Lee, who soon retreated from the spotlight to her native Monroeville, Ala. She never published another book, leaving her millions of fans yearning for more.

title: Ron Lieber: By the Book
description: The Book Review editor, Pamela Paul, talks books with Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist.

title: Springs Points of Interest
description: Reflective metal hardware turns otherwise architecturally simple shoes and bags into modern art.

title: State of City Address: Full of Ambition, but Light on Details
description: Express ferries gliding along the waterways. A dusty railyard transformed into a diverse and thriving new neighborhood. Thickets of tall buildings and construction cranes sprouting on waterfronts all over New York City.

title: Time to Leave the N.I.C.U. Behind
description: Come on, Joel. If we dont leave now, Im going to want to go to sleep rather than have dinner.

title: Apparent Discount Mars $41 Billion Spectrum Sale
description: The United States government has made a windfall. Some $41 billion of bids in its latest radio spectrum sale added up to about twice as much as expected. But the small print is making the auction look flawed. By bidding through entities it doesnt fully control, the $33 billion Dish Network seems to have secured a 25 percent price discount aimed at small businesses.

title: Cosme
description: Mexican cuisine from the chef Enrique Olvera

title: Cosme in the Flatiron District
description: A woman I once worked with had a facility for languages that was matched by her self-assurance. The rest of us had a hard time keeping track of her various proficiencies, and one time we asked her to remind us whether she knew Chinese.

title: Track Fire Disrupts Subway Service on N, Q and R Lines
description: A small track fire in a subway tunnel on Tuesday morning disrupted service on three lines, the N, Q and R, a spokesman for the Fire Department said.

title: Brokerage Firms Worry About Breaches by Hackers, Not Terrorists
description: The online attack on Sony Pictures Entertainment in the fall that federal authorities linked to the North Korean government raised alarm bells about the hacking threat posed by foreign governments. But brokerage firms based in the United States remain most concerned about an attack carried out by a loose band of hackers or employees with a grudge.

title: Croatia and Serbia Cleared of Genocide by Hague Court
description: PARIS  The highest court of the United Nations ruled on Tuesday that neither Croatia nor Serbia committed genocide against each others peoples when they waged war during the breakup of Yugoslavia in the early 1990s.

title: Heastie Elected Speaker of New York Assembly
description: ALBANY  Carl E. Heastie was elected speaker of the New York Assembly on Tuesday, culminating a rapid rise from a Bronx backbencher to holder of one of the most powerful offices in state politics.

title: A Local International Art Scene
description: It might not be as flashy as Dubai or Qatar  but Sharjah has a sheikh with a penchant for botany and his daughter, Hoor Al Qasimi, whose talent lies in gentle transgression.

title: Jordanian Pilots Death, Shown in ISIS Video, Spurs Jordan to Execute Prisoners
description: AMMAN, Jordan  When relatives learned Tuesday night that the Islamic State had released a video showing the death of a Jordanian fighter pilot, First Lt. Moaz al-Kasasbeh, they tried to keep it from his mother, Issaf, and his wife, Anwar. They switched off the television and tried to wrest a smartphone out of his wifes hand, but she had already seen a mobile news bulletin.

title: Prep Hits the Playground Set
description: Showing 6-year-olds and middle schoolers the way to campus.

title: Croatia and Serbia Absolved of Genocide
description: The president of the International Court of Justice ruled on Tuesday that Serbia and Croatia did not commit genocide against each other during the breakup of Yugoslavia.

title: Denied Prime Targets, Rubio Still Unloads at Cuba Hearing
description: Washington was waiting for fireworks on Tuesday morning when Senator Marco Rubio, a Florida Republican who is an outspoken critic of President Obamas Cuba policy, convened a hearing on United States-Cuba relations, and he did not disappoint.

title: Proposal for a Theme Park Draws From Crimeas Distant Past
description: LES EPESSES, France  Philippe and Nicolas de Villiers, father and son, run one of Frances most popular theme parks, a grand and gaudy take on the countrys past. So naturally, they are planning to expand. To Crimea.

title: A Stroll Through French History
description: Puy du Fou, a historical theme park in Les Epesses, France, may become a model for a park planned for Crimea.

title: Text of Mayor de Blasios State of the City Address
description: Following is the text of Mayor Bill de Blasios State of the City address, as prepared for delivery:

title: Raising Fitness Levels and Eyebrows
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Not far from the right-field line of Tradition Field, the Mets spring training home, a private fitness center has opened for business.

title: Auto Sales Stayed Strong in January, Bucking Trend for Month
description: Coming off the best sales year in nearly a decade, the auto industry showed little sign of slowing down in January.

title: Christie Goes Silent as He Wraps Up His Trip to Britain
description: LONDON  On the final day of his trade mission to Britain, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey met with titans of London finance, visited a drug rehabilitation center, dined with the chancellor of the Exchequer and took in a rehearsal of Henry V at Shakespeares Globe.

title: The Right Way to Pay Ransoms to Terrorists
description: DURHAM, N.C.  IT all began in 2003, when a German official flew into the wilds of northern Mali with three suitcases full of cash to secure the release of 14 European hostages. That first big ransom breathed life into the militant group known as Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, and laid the groundwork for a kidnap economy that now finances Islamist extremist groups around the globe.

title: Fall in Fortunes for Pennsylvania Attorney General
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  The question before Pennsylvanians is this: Is Kathleen G. Kane, the first woman to be elected as the states attorney general, the victim of angry men who targeted her after she exposed their pornography habits?

title: Rand Paul Shushes Interviewer, and Some Women See Sexism
description: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky appeared to stumble on Monday night when he stepped into a controversy over vaccine mandates, but his bigger problem may be a backlash from women.

title: Pope Francis Honors scar Romero, Salvadoran Archbishop, as Martyr
description: ROME  Pope Francis has formally ratified the martyrdom of the Salvadoran archbishop scar Romero, who was shot to death at the altar as he was saying Mass in 1980 in an act of hatred for the faith, the Vatican said on Tuesday.

title: Secondhand Smoke Exposure Drops, C.D.C. Reports
description: Americans exposure to secondhand smoke has declined by half since 2000, federal health authorities reported Tuesday, as states and municipalities banned smoking in bars, restaurants and offices, and fewer Americans smoked inside their homes.

title: Danny Meyers Porchlight Bar to Open
description: Danny Meyer has opened many restaurants over the years that offer sophisticated cocktails. But he never felt tempted to open a stand-alone bar.

title: Suge Knight Pleads Not Guilty to Murder Charge in Hit-and-Run Case
description: Marion Knight, the former Death Row Records chief executive known as Suge, was rushed directly from a Los Angeles courtroom to the hospital on Tuesday morning after pleading not guilty to murder charges stemming from a hit-and-run last week, the Los Angeles County Sheriffs Department said.

title: LVMH, theLuxury Goods Giant, Posts a 64% Gain in Annual Profit
description: Paris  LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the worlds largest luxury goods group, said on Tuesday that its profit jumped by 64 percent last year, bolstered by stronger demand in the United States and Europe, despite an overall softening of global demand for high-end goods.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Attitudes About Aging
Obamas Budget Seeks International Minimum Tax for Corporations
description: Sometimes, a tax increase saves jobs.

title: Macroeconomic Cronyism
description: My old teacher Rudi Dornbusch  whose presence is sorely missed in this world gone mad  once wrote an influential analysis, with Sebastian Edwards, of what they called macroeconomic populism. This is the historical tendency of some (not all) populist governments to engage in wishful thinking, to believe that they can repeal the usual rules  that they can indefinitely contain inflation in an overheated economy with price controls, that they can ignore limits on capacity, etc..

title: Fiat Chrysler Profit in U.S. Declined 56% in 2014 on Charges From Merger
description: DETROIT  Fiat Chrysler reported that profit for its American division fell 56 percent in 2014, mostly because of charges related to the merger of the Italian automaker Fiat and the former Chrysler.

title: Permanent Midnight
description: What is a true self? For an author whose rare illness forces her to live in literal darkness, the issue is far from metaphorical.

title: Man Jailed in 92 Killings and Later Cleared Sues New York City
description: A man whose conviction for the murder of his mother, sister and a friend in 1992 was vacated last year is suing New York City.

title: Colin Quinns Streaming Cop Show to Satirize Police Dramas
description: Colin Quinn will join the list of mainstream comedians to star in their own web series with Cop Show, a satirical take on the making of a crime drama in New York City.

title: Dreams Deferred and Lived
description: The poet Langston Hughes was a courtly man with a slow fuse. Violent anger, he wrote in his memoir The Big Sea (1940), makes me physically ill.

title: Fame & Fortune? How About a Free Portfolio Review
description: If youre a young photographer looking for a way to start your career, a midcareer photographer looking for more assignments, or even an established artist looking for gallery representation, we have a question for you.

title: Local Politics Are Fracturing European Unity
description: The euro had been enshrined in a treaty but not yet come to life in the autumn of 1997, when Martin Feldstein, the influential president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, published an essay arguing that European leaders hopes that a monetary union would foster greater harmony and peace in a Continent repeatedly ravaged by wars were misplaced.

title: Rosa Parks Papers to Be Opened to Researchers
description: The Rosa Parks Collection at the Library of Congress is set to open to researchers on Wednesday, coinciding with what would have been Ms. Parkss 102nd birthday.

title: Dirt Candy Finds More Room
description: Headliner

title: Thom Tillis on Burdensome Regulations, Like Hand-Washing at Restaurants
description: It is often hard to tell whether Republican legislators are joking, because so many of the things they say are unintentionally funny. So I dont know whether Senator Thom Tillis, Republican of North Carolina, was trying to be a latter day Jonathan Swift or was perfectly serious when he said restaurants are over-regulated and should not be required to tell employees to wash their hands after using the toilet.

title: Draft of Arrest Request for Argentine President Found at Dead Prosecutors Home
description: BUENOS AIRES  Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor whose mysterious death has gripped Argentina, had drafted a request for the arrest of President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, accusing her of trying to shield Iranian officials from responsibility in the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center here, the lead investigator into his death said Tuesday.

title: Coming to Mourn Tahrir Squares Dead, and Joining Them Instead
description: CAIRO  Her friends wanted to lay a wreath in Tahrir Square as a memorial, but Shaimaa el-Sabbagh urged them to reconsider. She feared that the police might attack, mistaking them for supporters of the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood, said a cousin, Sami Mohamed Ibrahim.

title: Fifty Shades of a Stay
description: Raunchy isnt usually the best way to describe most Valentines Day packages, but two Kimpton hotels in New York City are going a little racy this year with a Fifty Shades of Grey promotion.

title: American Sniper Pulled From Iraq Theater
description: One group that seemed destined to take offense at American Sniper is Iraqis, and, according to The Washington Post and a GlobalPost article that ran in USA Today, the film was yanked from a cinema in Baghdad days after opening there.

title: Wilmington Seeks a Youthful Energy Downtown
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  In a downtown district previously characterized by pawnshops and check-cashing stores, hundreds of apartments are being built here for a new generation of young professionals who want to live and play in the communities where they work.

title: Final Moments of Activist Shot in Cairo
description: Videos captured the final moments of the Egyptian activist Shaimaa al-Sabbaghs life before and after she was shot by the police during a peaceful protest in Cairo on Jan. 24.

title: Saddle Bronc Part 1 Intro
description: Intro sequence for part 1.

title: Museum of Biblical Art to Seek a New Home in New York
description: After almost 200 years in New York City, American Bible Society is moving its national headquarters to Philadelphia.

title: Intrigue Deepens at Republican Committee in Virgin Islands
description: The strange case of the Virgin Islands political action committee took another strange twist.

title: Columbia HiresPeter Pilling as Athletic Director
description: Columbia has hired Peter Pilling, a vice president at IMG College, the sports marketing firm, to be its next athletic director, the university said Tuesday.

title: A Cultish French Shoe Brand From an Alumna of Louboutin and Pierre Hardy
description: The ideal mens footwear symbolizes power, taste and singularity, the French shoe designer Alexia Aubert says. Those are the qualities Im attuned to in a man. Aubert, who started her career assisting Christian Louboutin, went on to run the studio at Pierre Hardy and to transform the footwear division at Oscar de la Renta from a collection of licensing agreements into a proper design collection. Since then, shes been consulting for various brands (including Mulberry and Balmain) and, last year, launched her own line of footwear, initially intended for men. She deems Solovire  named after her maternal grandfather  a laboratory for new classics. And her latest experiment came at the request of the Parisian boutique Colette: to offer additional sizes, effectively making some of her designs unisex.

title: New York Philharmonic to Celebrate 50 Years of Concerts in the Parks
description: The New York Philharmonic will mark the 50th anniversary of its free parks concerts this June with Alan Gilbert leading the orchestra in a program of American music on Central Parks Great Lawn featuring the violinist Joshua Bell performing a suite from West Side Story.

title: Senate Democrats Block Republicans Homeland Security Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats on Tuesday blocked a Republican bill that would finance the Department of Homeland Security, objecting to a measure that would have gutted President Obamas recent executive actions on immigration. The vote set up an urgent confrontation over the department, which will see its funding run out at the end of the month.

title: 1965: Connoisseurs Steal Paintings
description: PARIS  A sophisticated gang of thieves carted off four paintings and silverware worth $400,000 from a chteau east of Paris, it was learned today [Feb. 3]. The theft was the latest in a series of about 60 committed in chteaus, mainly in the Paris region in recent years. In most of the cases, the gang des chteaux carefully selected only a few of many valuable items readily available for the taking. The style of the operation has been so consistent that police investigating the latest theft reportedly are working on the theory that the burglars are replying to the orders of a private collector.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 4, 1965

title: Leon Silverman, 93, Dies; Lawyer Led Inquiry of Labor Secretary
description: Leon Silverman, a tenacious litigator best known outside the legal profession as the federal investigator who found insufficient evidence to prosecute Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan in 1982 on charges that he had ties to organized crime, died on Thursday at his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 93.

title: Some See Risk in de Blasios Bid to Add Housing
description: Every month, city planners come to East New York to explain how the city wants to help this corner of Brooklyn, scarred by decades of poverty and violent crime, grow. They will invite developers to build up local streets in exchange for more units of affordable housing. They will invest in new trees and sidewalks. Better services and shops will follow, they say.

title: Lindsey Vonn Slips to Third but Sees a Silver Lining
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  As Lindsey Vonn crossed the finish line and took the lead in the super-G at the Alpine World Ski Championships here on Tuesday, her boyfriend, Tiger Woods, shouted and pumped his right fist repeatedly as he watched nearby.

title: Saddle Bronc Part 2 Intro
description: Intro sequence for part 2.

title: SXSW Film Festival Announces Lineup
description: From lovers of sneakers to lovers of spies, this years South by Southwest film festival seems to have a little something for everyone. Organizers on Tuesday announced the bulk of their features lineup, which includes 100 world premieres.

title: Palestinian Newspaper Accused of Running Muhammad Cartoon
description: JERUSALEM  Saying it was a grave mistake for an official Palestinian newspaper to publish a cartoon that some readers thought depicted the Prophet Muhammad, the president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, has ordered an investigation, according to Wafa, the official Palestinian news agency.

title: U.N. Concerned About Reports That Food Aid to Syria Is in ISIS Hands
description: GENEVA  The United Nations food relief agency said it was extremely concerned about the possible manipulation of its aid to Syria after images posted on jihadist websites and social media appeared to show Islamic State supporters distributing the agencys relief supplies rebranded with the militant groups logo.

title: Preventing Suicides Among Veterans Is at Center of Bill Passed by Senate
description: As a Marine serving in Iraq, Clay Hunt barely missed being killed by a sniper, yet he faced what proved to be more powerful foes after leaving the corps: depression and post-traumatic stress disorder. Mr. Hunt killed himself four years ago, even as he worked to help other struggling veterans.

title: Holder on S.&P.s Settlement
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced that the agency will pay $1.37 billion to settle an array of government lawsuits that accused S.&P. of inflating subprime mortgage investment ratings.

title: Gender Bias Case Against Sterling Jewelers Can Proceed
description: An arbitrator overseeing a gender discrimination case against Sterling Jewelers, parent of 12 chains in the United States including Kay Jewelers, has certified a class of thousands of women to proceed to trial.

title: What Travelers Need to Know About Measles
In Black and White, Illustration Sparks Reader Concerns
description: Liz Ananat was one of many readers who wrote to me about an illustration accompanying an Op-Ed essay published Tuesday on domestic violence. The piece was powerful, making the point that men who are eventually arrested for violent acts often began with attacks against their girlfriends and wives. But for some readers, dismay at the illustration overwhelmed their reaction to the article itself.

title: Photographing a Filipino View of the Streets
description: An exhibit opening this week in the Philippines showcases the work of street photographers, many of whom live among that countrys far-flung diaspora.

title: E.P.A. Says Pipeline Could Spur Emissions
description: WASHINGTON  An Environmental Protection Agency review of the Keystone XL pipeline emphasized that the recent drop in global oil prices might mean that construction of the pipeline could spur increased development of the Canadian oil sands  and thus increase planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions.

title: De Blasios State of the City Address
description: The complete State of the City address of Bill de Blasio, the New York mayor.

title: Smucker to Buy Big Heart Pet Brands for $5.8 Billion
description: Ever since Jerome Monroe Smucker first started selling apple butter in 1897, the company that bears his name has been best known for jams, peanut butter and other treats.

title: Shares Fall at Chipotle Although Sales Rise
description: Chipotle Mexican Grill, the made-to-order burrito chain that is the darling of the millennial generation, continues its sizzling financial performance.

title: Macys to Buy Bluemercury Spa and Beauty Chain
description: Macys is planning a bit of a makeover, announcing on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy the beauty and spa chain Bluemercury for $210 million, a move that could help broaden the department stores customer base.

title: SAP Aggressively Moves Customers to Its Database
description: Youve got to hand it to SAP for competitive vision. Then take some back for how its explaining itself.

title: Beheadings Frame a New Debate About Restraints on Japans Military
description: TOKYO  As the shock from the beheadings of two Japanese hostages by the Islamic State faded Tuesday, a battle to gain political advantage from their deaths began.

title: Green Dots Decision to Stop Selling MoneyPak Cards Will Take a Toll
description: The decision by Green Dot to stop selling MoneyPak, its popular prepaid card, will take a bite out of the companys projected revenue and bottom line this year, and that has taken a toll on the companys share price over the last several days.

title: Cracking Codes Through the Centuries
description: WASHINGTON  The Sigaba encryption machine squats in the Folger Shakespeare Library here like a thuggish interloper. Used by the American military in the 1940s and 1950s to send coded messages, it looks like an oversize, boxy typewriter with rotors rising above the lid like a mechanical brain. No object could seem less Elizabethan, yet appearances deceive.

title: A Two-Bedroom House on a Hillside in St. Barts
description: The house, designed to maximize views, is on the market for $3.9 million.

title: Donating Embryos, Not Giving Up Babies
description: This past November, we ran an essay by Maya Grobel Moskin, When All Else Fails, Embryo Adoption Offers Hope. Katherine, a mother who thought her family was complete after a successful IVF procedure and the birth of her twins, described her and her husbands decision to donate their three remaining frozen embryos in the comments. I wanted to know more. I wrote her, asking if she would be willing to share her story.

title: An Orchestral Group Effort, With a Star Turn for Banjo
description: Conventional wisdom holds that a surplus of cooks spoils the broth. And surely the same is true for composition: Can you name a masterwork of classical music composed by committee?

title: Elgar and Haydn, Found Warming in a Hidden Space
description: Two dozen hardy souls made it through snow and ice to the Kosciuszko Foundation on Monday night. Small numbers make for acute listening, though, and often for rewarding experiences in chamber music. That was true of this brief, absorbing concert from the Manhattan String Quartet, presented by a venerable club for musicians and the musically inclined, the Bohemians.

title: A Day in the Life of Eddie Huang
description: Performer and chef, writer and provocateur, Eddie Huang tries to take his brand of Asian-American anarchism to the mainstream.

title: An Immigrants Tale, With All-American Tropes
description: In the buildup to Wednesdays premiere of Fresh Off the Boat, weve been hearing repeatedly that this ABC series will be different: a comedy centered on an Asian-American family, something network prime time hasnt seen in years.

title: Rand Paul Gets a Booster Vaccination
description: Senator Rand Paul, facing a backlash over his comments that cast doubt on whether he believes vaccines can pose a health risk to children, asserted on Tuesday that he believes vaccinations are indeed safe and that all parents should have their children inoculated.

title: Britain Set to Approve Technique to Create Babies From 3 People
description: LONDON  Despite warnings that a new ethical threshold was being crossed, British lawmakers on Tuesday voted to allow the in vitro creation of babies using the DNA of three people, a procedure that could prevent the inheritance of genetic diseases.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Where Do Potential 2016 Presidential Candidates Stand on Vaccines?
description: A measles outbreak has spurred a political debate over vaccine mandates, turning a public health question into one of personal liberty and becoming a wedge issue for potential candidates for the White House in 2016.

title: When Company Is Fined, Taxpayers Often Share Bill
description: When a Montana judge ordered Hyundai to pay $73 million in punitive damages last year to the families of two teenagers killed in a car crash, she found that the South Korean automaker had recklessly ignored scores of warnings over more than a decade about the steering defect blamed for the accident.

title: Symphonies and Solace in an Orchestras Three-Night Stand
description: It was almost a toss-off, but telling.

title: Dispatch From Debaltseve: Reporters Notebook
description: On Sunday, Andrew Kramer wrote about a small city in eastern Ukraine that has been nearly surrounded by attacking rebels. Here, Mr. Kramer provides an up-close look at his reporting.

title: Reporter Fights to Air Diary of James Browns Wife
description: NEWBERRY, S.C.  Sue Summer may seem at first glance an unlikely candidate to be involved in one of South Carolinas most contentious press freedom cases in recent years.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Get caught up on the days top stories.

title: Disney Profit Jumps 19%, Even as ESPN Falters
description: LOS ANGELES  Disney reported a 19 percent increase in quarterly profit on Tuesday, with growth from its consumer products, theme parks and movie businesses offsetting another period of modest decline at ESPN.

title: Louboutin Nails It
description: The maestro of the stiletto opens the chicest polish boutique in all of Paris.

title: Photos of the Day  Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Ukraine and More: Pictures of the Day

title: Bill de Blasios Big Plans for New York
description: Give Mayor Bill de Blasio time and he can toss out a lot of numbers. Its what he did in his State of the City Address on Tuesday: nearly half-a-million potholes filled in 2014, a plan to cut greenhouse gases by 80 percent by 2050, a 65 percent drop in marijuana arrests, 1.6 million calls answered by the New York Fire Department.

title: Feb. 3, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Ukraine, France, Spain and China.

title: Living in Yorkville
description: The Upper East Side neighborhood is drawing young families as well as retirees seeking more value for their money.

title: Sales of Sovaldi, New Gilead Hepatitis C Drug, Soar to $10.3 Billion
description: Gilead Sciences sold $10.3 billion of its new hepatitis C drug Sovaldi in 2014, a figure that brought it close to being the best-selling drug in the world in only its first year on the market.

title: A Conversation With Joshua McClure
description: Mr. McClure, 41, is a founder and the chief executive of RealMassive, a start-up open marketing anddataplatform specifically for commercial real estate. The company, which is based in Austin, Tex., serves 21 markets, including Austin, Dallas,San Francisco, Boston and Los Angeles, and plans to expand into New York.

title: Turkey Revokes Passport of Cleric in Exile in Pennsylvania
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish government informed the United States that it had revoked the passport of an influential cleric based in Pennsylvania on Tuesday in a push for his deportation, Turkish media reported.

title: Lively Morgue Tumblr 470  472
description: Lively Morgue Tumblr 470  472

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: U.N. Names U.S. Judge to Lead War Crimes Inquiry Into 2014 Gaza Conflict
description: GENEVA  The United Nations Human Rights Council on Tuesday picked an American judge serving on an inquiry into possible war crimes in Gaza to lead its work to completion a day after the inquirys chairman resigned after Israel accused him of a blatant conflict of interest.

title: ISIS Video Presents Grim Choice for News Media
description: The images spread rapidly online Tuesday, some more graphic than others: A caged Jordanian pilot, captured by the militants of the Islamic State late last year, was shown apparently being burned alive.

title: Video Shows Obamas 2008 Comments on Vaccines Were Misreported
description: As reporters press potential 2016 presidential candidates on the question of whether parents should be compelled to vaccinate their children, new attention has been focused on how the issue was handled in the 2008 campaign, particularly by President Obama.

title: Alternate-Side Parking Suspended Through Saturday
description: Because of snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City through Saturday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Metro-North Train Hits S.U.V. in Railroads Deadliest Accident
description: A crowded Metro-North Railroad train passing through Westchester County at the height of the evening rush on Tuesday slammed into a sport-utility vehicle on the tracks at a crossing, creating a fiery crash and explosion that killed seven people, injured a dozen and forced the evacuation of hundreds. It was the deadliest crash in the railroads history.

title: Ex-Contractor Charged in Navy Bribery Case
description: Paul Simpkins, a former senior contracting officer for the Navy, was arrested Tuesday and charged with conspiracy to commit bribery in a scandal involving ship-supply contracts in the Pacific. Federal prosecutors said Mr. Simpkins, 60, accepted several hundred thousand dollars in cash, trips and the services of prostitutes from Leonard Francis, a Malaysian businessman who recently pleaded guilty to bribing Navy officials for help in overbilling the services by at least $35 million. Prosecutors said Mr. Simpkins, who pleaded not guilty, overruled a subordinate who wanted to drop a contract with Mr. Leonard in Thailand that included many exceedingly high cost items.

title: Mayor de Blasio Moves to Expand Ferry Service in New York City
description: It has become a modern political axiom in New York, as bipartisan as it is expensive, according to transportation advocates: Elected officials love ferries.

title: A City and Sea Hotel Pairing in Thailand
description: Travelers to Thailand who want to experience bustling Bangkok as well as pristine beaches can get a dose of both with the new customizable Island and City Break offer from the Point Yamu by Como hotel in Phuket.

title: Our Curse
description: In this Oscar-nominated documentary, a young couple struggles to overcome every new parents worst nightmare: a child born with a life-threatening illness.

title: Nasza kltwa
description: Cztery lata temu, u mojego nowonarodzonego syna Leo zdiagnozowano bardzo rzadk i nieuleczaln chorob, tak zwan Kltw Ondyny. Znana jest rwnie jako zesp wrodzonej orodkowej hipowentylacji.

title: Our Curse
description: Four years ago, my newborn son, Leo, was given a diagnosis of a very rare and incurable disorder known as Ondines Curse. Also called  Congenital Central Hypoventilation Syndrome (C.C.H.S.), the disorder prevents the thousand or so people known to have been born with it from breathing while asleep, and sometimes also while awake. Though the disorder is manageable when treated, our son is likely to need a ventilator for the rest of his life.

title: Low Energy Prices Offer Opening for Subsidy Cuts
description: In Saudi Arabia, drivers pay roughly 45 cents a gallon to fill up their cars, and in Venezuela even less. Energy is so inexpensive in Kuwait and Qatar that residents chill their enormous swimming pools in the summer and typically leave their air-conditioners on at full blast while they are away on vacation.

title: U.S. Official Says Cubas Political Detentions Declined
description: WASHINGTON  Cuba temporarily detained 178 political prisoners in January, Tom Malinowski, the State Departments senior human rights official, said Tuesday.

title: On Tour, Greek Leaders Wear No Ties and Aim for Looser Belts
description: ROME  Less than two weeks after taking power in national elections, Greeces leftist-led government is now taking Europe. Fashion critics in London are debating whether the Greek finance minister is an arbiter of cool chic or looks like a nightclub bouncer. Politicians in Brussels and Berlin are mulling whether the new Greek prime minister is a radical looking to bring down the eurozone or a canny operator looking for a deal.

title: In a Sale Gone Awry, a Lesson for Other Deal Makers
description: The prolonged takeover battle for the GFI Group, a New York brokerage firm and clearinghouse, has been littered with missteps by Michael Gooch, its founder and executive chairman, raising the question of why supposedly intelligent leaders time and again do dumb things when they sell their companies.

title: House G.O.P. Again Votes to Repeal Health Care Law
description: WASHINGTON  The House passed a bill on Tuesday to repeal the Affordable Care Act for the first time in the new Congress, but Democrats appeared to show more zeal in defending the law than Republicans did in trying to get rid of it.

title: N.H.L. Trailblazer Finds Forgiveness in the Tip of a Pen
description: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario  A little more than a year ago, the former N.H.L. player Val James handed his wife, Ina, the first draft of his autobiography and asked her to read it.

title: S.&P. Settlement Leaves Future Unclear for Ratings
description: It cost $1.37 billion, but Standard & Poors has finally appeared to close the darkest chapter in its 150-year history as a rating agency.

title: MoussaouiCalls Saudi Princes Patrons of Al Qaeda
description: WASHINGTON  In highly unusual testimony inside the federal supermax prison, a former operative for Al Qaeda has described prominent members of Saudi Arabias royal family as major donors to the terrorist network in the late 1990s and claimed that he discussed a plan to shoot down Air Force One with a Stinger missile with a staff member at the Saudi Embassy in Washington.

title: New Speaker in Albany: A Skilled Operator, Embracing Change
description: ALBANY  After his election on Tuesday as speaker of the New York State Assembly, Carl E. Heastie echoed calls to reform the opaque and almost czarlike system in which the legislative chamber is ruled by its speaker, one of the three men in a room who dominate state government.

title: Lincolns Failed Peace Process
description: On Feb. 3, 1865, a lovely false spring day, the president of the United States traveled south by train and steamboat to a spot near the front lines of the Civil War for a peaceful talk with the enemy. Such high-level negotiations in the middle of a shooting war had never happened before, and have never happened since. After nearly four years of battering, the Confederacy was all but broken  and Lincoln was eager to stop the killing and begin to heal the country with a peaceful reconciliation instead of a military conquest. Thats why, that afternoon, Abraham Lincoln welcomed three Confederate leaders to the presidential steamboat River Queen, the Air Force One of her day, and exposed himself to political attack for the mortal sin of compromise.

title: Lawsuit Seeks to Legalize Doctor-Assisted Suicide for Terminally Ill Patients in New York
description: A group of doctors and terminally ill patients are asking New York courts to declare that doctor-assisted suicide is legal and not covered by the states prohibition on helping people take their own lives.

title: A Crashing End to a Work of Ice a City Had Warmed Up To
description: SUPERIOR, Wis.  The ingredients needed to build the worlds tallest ice sculpture  bountiful water and extremely cold weather  exist in abundance in this small city hard on the states northwesternmost tip. A perfect place, in other words, for a self-taught engineer named Roger Hanson to surpass that record.

title: Regulators Cite a New Danger in the Skies: Selfies
description: WATKINS, Colo.  In an age of digital distractions, the lethal risks of driving  or just crossing the street  while looking at a cellphone have been well-documented.

title: With Ones Head in the Clouds
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE The idiom Your mileage may vary comes up a lot on this blog, particularly when it comes to how a puzzle might make you feel. Thats an unusual stance to begin with, because many people believe that a puzzle cant really affect your feelings one way or another. I understand that, and I respectfully disagree. We can agree to disagree, right?

title: A Crumbling Tower of Ice
description: Roger Hanson calls himself the iceman. The 66 foot-high ice sculpture hes been working on in Superior, Wis., since November came tumbling down Tuesday morning.

title: What You Get for ... $750,000
description: This weeks properties include a log house in Kentucky, a contemporary in Arkansas and a houseboat in Seattle.

title: High-Tech Fashion Redefines Meaning of Revealing Clothing
description: New to the city last year, Billie Whitehouse was struck by the inevitability of small-scale disaster on the streets of New York. Everywhere, it seemed, people walked with noses pointed into their smartphones. Like herself, these pilgrims were seeking directions. But they were liable to step blindly off sidewalks, to walk up the backs of people ahead of them, or to not notice that shop doors swing open.

title: Evasive on Stand, Prosecution Witness Is Declared Hostile at Patz Trial
description: The trial of a man accused of killing 6-year-old Etan Patz in 1979 took an unexpected twist on Tuesday, after a prosecution witness  an employee at the bodega where prosecutors say the boy was murdered  was declared a hostile witness because he became evasive on the stand.

title: The 10 Most Painful Losses in Super Bowl History
description: The Seattle Seahawks were a yard from history. Trailing by 4 points in the final minute of Sundays Super Bowl, Seattle had the ball, on second down, at the Patriots 1-yard line. According to the website Advanced Football Analytics, that gave the Seahawks an 88 percent chance of winning the Super Bowl.

title: A Matchmaker and a Festival Keep an Irish Tradition Alive
description: LISDOONVARNA, Ireland  After 50-odd years in the business of romance, Willie Daly has a lot of stories to tell.

title: United Arab Emirates, Key U.S. Ally in ISIS Effort, Disengaged in December
description: WASHINGTON  The United Arab Emirates, a crucial Arab ally in the American-led coalition against the Islamic State, suspended airstrikes against the Sunni extremist group in December, citing fears for its pilots safety after a Jordanian pilot was captured and who the extremists said had been burned to death, United States officials said Tuesday.

title: Purchase by Mexican President Is Under Scrutiny
description: MEXICO CITY  President Enrique Pea Nieto announced Tuesday that a new federal comptroller would lead an investigation into the purchase by the president and his wife of two houses from government contractors.

title: In Closing Arguments, Conflicting Accounts of Mans Role in Silk Road
description: A prosecutor asked a Manhattan jury on Tuesday to convict a California man, Ross W. Ulbricht, of narcotics trafficking conspiracy and other charges in a trial involving Silk Road, the black-market website for drugs and other illicit goods.

title: Knicks Fall to Celtics in a Matchup of Duds
description: The sad drumbeat continued on Tuesday for the Knicks, who lost to the Boston Celtics, 108-97, in a mostly listless affair at Madison Square Garden between two rebuilding franchises.

title: Syria: Chemical Weapons Plant Razed
description: Seven months after Syria exported the last of its known stockpile of chemical weapons ingredients, the first of its 12 production facilities has been destroyed, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons reported Tuesday. Ahmet Uzumcu, director general of the organization, which polices the chemical weapons treaty that Syria signed in late 2013, said the destruction of the first facility had been completed Jan. 31 after a delay he attributed to technical reasons. He gave no timetable for the rest. Western countries have accused President Bashar al-Assad of Syria of procrastination in complying with the terms of the treaty, which he agreed to sign after a chemical weapons attack in a Damascus suburb for which government forces and insurgents blamed each other.

title: Accuser in Strauss-Kahn Case Builds Restaurant and a Refuge
description: As the news media again turns its attention to Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former leader of the International Monetary Fund who is on  trial in France on accusations that he participated in a prostitution ring, the woman who accused him of sexual assault in New York City in 2011 has quietly resumed her life, this time behind the counter of a West African restaurant in the Bronx.

title: Islanders Struggling to Adjust Without Injured Kyle Okposo
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Life without Kyle Okposo presents many challenges for the Islanders, who are clinging to first place in the Metropolitan Division with a sputtering offense.

title: Justified Recap: Ava Sticks to Boyd, and Her Own Dark Side
description: Season 6, Episode 3, Noblesse Oblige

title: Walkers Wisconsin Budget Has a National Message
description: Gov. Scott Walker, a possible contender for the Republican presidential nomination, on Tuesday proposed a new spending plan for Wisconsin that relies on borrowing and spending cuts, including deep reductions to state universities, and steers clear of tax increases.

title: New York City Schools Chancellor Objects to Cuomos Plan for Grading Teachers
description: The New York City schools chancellor, Carmen Faria, spoke out forcefully against some of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos  education proposals on Tuesday, making clear the de Blasio administrations opposition to a core part of the governors 2015 agenda.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I was a first-time writer, so I did as I was told.

title: Excerpts From Carl Heasties Speech
description: In a speech lasting almost eight minutes, the new Assembly speaker, Carl E. Heastie, spoke of restoring integrity to the Legislature through fiscal transparency and other measures.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 3, 2015
New York City Councilman Arrested on Corruption Charges
description: A New York City councilman was arrested on corruption charges on Tuesday for the second time in less than nine months.

title: Aksel Lund Svindal Set to Compete at Alpine Championships
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  After three months away from the slopes because of injury, Aksel Lund Svindal of Norway, the three-time Olympic medalist and defending downhill world champion, confirmed that he would race in Wednesdays super-G and Saturdays downhill at the Alpine World Ski Championships here.

title: Sherry Arden, Publisher With a Passion for Best Sellers, Dies at 91
description: Sherry Arden, whose exuberance as a promoter and perspicacity as a publisher helped invigorate the book industry with a raft of celebrity tell-all memoirs like Christina Crawfords Mommie Dearest and pop psychology primers like Gail Sheehys Pathfinders, died on Jan. 27 at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 91.

title: Sandy Socolow, CBS Newsman During Heady Days, Dies at 86
description: Sandy Socolow, a longtime executive at CBS News who worked closely with Walter Cronkite and helped shape television coverage of the Vietnam War and the Watergate scandal, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Monty Oum, Web-Series Animator, Dies at 33
description: Monty Oum, the creator of the animated web series RWBY and director of animation for Rooster Teeth Productions, a company best known for repurposing the bloodthirsty avatars in the Halo video games into angst-ridden slackers in the popular web series Red vs. Blue, died on Sunday near his home in Austin, Tex. He was 33.

title: Aldo Ciccolini Dies at 89; Pianist Interpreted Satie
description: Aldo Ciccolini, an Italian-born pianist who specialized in the music of French composers and was known in particular as a champion of Erik Satie, has died at his home outside Paris. He was 89.

title: Meh Head
description: The hairstyle of choice this season seems like no hairstyle at all. Unremarkable in color and length, and replete with flyaway bits, the look is effortless, but of course, it isnt.

title: The Softer Side of Spring Manicures
description: Last fall, at shows from Thakoon to DKNY, light and neutral nails marked the departure of dark manicures for spring 2015. And the seasons crop of nail polish offerings, an array of delicate colors that just hit the market this month, pair as seamlessly with snow gear now as they will with ready-to-wear when the weather warms up. Consider some of Dolce & Gabbanas romantic new hues (aptly named Innocence, Bella and Rosebud) and Nails Inc.s garden party varieties (soft shades and confetti-like top coats that mimic May flowers).

title: The Rise of Japanese Chefs in Paris
description: For years, aspiring culinary stars from Japan have been decamping to Paris to learn new techniques, but recently theyve been leaving behind the Michelin-starred dining temples that trained them  from Astrance to Taillevent  to headline their own spots. At Restaurant ES in the Seventh Arrondissement, the chef Takayuki Honjo improvises with simple, market-driven dishes, such as roast pigeon in cocoa sauce, which are as delicate in flavor as they are graphic in presentation. At Neige dt in the 15th, Hideki Nishi dabbles in modern French cuisine including salmon with a Gorgonzola millefeuille. Over in the 11th, at 6036  a 14-seat izakaya named for the distance, in miles, between Paris and Tokyo  the chef Haruka Casters plays up seasonal small plates (sake-steamed clams with cabbage, teriyaki burgers). Paris is a cosmopolitan city with many opportunities to improve ones cooking, says Casters. But its also much easier to be seen here than in a megalopolis like Tokyo.

title: Anywhere, U.S.A.
description: Athletic sportswear has come a long way from the track and the field. High fashion sounds a call to action with all-American lettered jerseys, motocross stripes and high-tech mesh.

title: Word of the Day | thermal
description: thermal  \thr-ml\ adjective and noun

title: Ford Raises Pay for 500 Workers as Demand Grows for F-150 Pickup
description: DETROIT  Growing demand for Ford Motors new pickup truck will prompt a transition to higher wages for up to 500 of the companys entry-level union workers.

title: Corporate Tax Reform: Focusing on Where the Money Is, Not Where the Jobs Are
description: Discussions of corporate tax policy involve a lot of rhetoric about whether it encourages companies to move overseas.

title: Taiwan: Plane Crashes in Taipei
description: A small passenger airplane crashed into a river in Taipei after clipping a bridge on Wednesday morning, Taiwans Central News Agency reported, citing a local government official. The TransAsia Airways twin turboprop crashed shortly after takeoff from Taipei Songshan Airport on a flight bound for the Kinmen islands, near the Chinese province of Fujian. About a dozen people were rescued from the plane, an ATR-72, while 10 were still trapped, the news agency reported, citing local television reports. Local television showed the planes fuselage resting in the Keelung River near the southeast side of Taipei, the Taiwanese capital.
