The crash is the second for the airline in just over six months, following an ATR-72 crash on July 23 that killed 48 people. The cause of that crash is still under investigation.

title: Plane Clips Road and Crashes in Taiwan, Killing at Least 31
description: HONG KONG  A passenger plane crashed into a river in Taiwans capital, Taipei, shortly after takeoff on Wednesday morning, killing at least 31 people, officials said. Rescue operations were underway to pull survivors from the water.

title: After the Metro-North Crash
description: A train accident in Valhalla, N.Y., in Westchester County, was deadliest in the railroads history.

title: Area of the Crash
description: The commuter train struck a vehicle on the tracks in Valhalla, N.Y.

title: Whats On TV Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (WE) MATCH MADE IN HEAVEN Shawn Bullard, a real estate developer and former college football player, receives guidance from Ken Johnson, chaplain and spiritual adviser to the Indianapolis Colts, who is charged with discerning the authenticity and godliness of 24 women hoping to make a love connection with Mr. Bullard. But it may be Mr. Bullards opinionated mother, who, after moving into the house with the contestants, has the final say on her prospective daughter-in-law. And forget about roses: The women will each be given a white cellphone at the start of the show to which Mr. Bullard will text messages as to the outcome of their romantic encounters.

title: Metro-North Crash Brings New Trouble Amid String of Setbacks for Railroad
description: For Metro-North Railroad, the once-unthinkable has happened twice in 14 months.

title: Editors Note: February 4, 2015
description: OPINION

title: Qualifying for Obamacare
Anti-Police Video
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax on Medical Devices
description: To the Editor:

title: When Sports and Academics Compete
Europes Expanding Right to Be Forgotten
description: European officials are pushing an idea that will encourage autocrats everywhere to demand greater censorship on the Internet. They want companies like Google and Microsoft to abide by the European Unions recently recognized legal principle of a right to be forgotten not just in the 28 countries of the union but everywhere.

title: A Bad Mistake
description: The decision by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and House Speaker John Boehner to cook up an address to Congress by Netanyahu on why the U.S. should get tougher on Iran is churlish, reckless and, for the future of Israeli-American relations, quite dangerous.

title: It Is Time to End Subminimum Wages
description: In New York, restaurants are allowed to pay servers a minimum wage of $5 an hour, as long as that hourly wage plus tips equals at least $8.75, the state minimum for nontipped workers (rising to $9 by 2016). That subminimum tipped wage is a vestige of the early days of modern labor law, when minimum-wage mandates were riddled with industry-specific exemptions, long since ended. It survives for tipped workers because of the strength of the restaurant lobby.

title: ISIS Is Losing in Iraq. But What Happens Next?
description: WASHINGTON  IN Iraq, the good news always seems to come mixed with bad.

title: The Problem With Middle-Class Populism
description: In his State of the Union address last month, and in four subsequent addresses to the public, President Obama used the phrase middle class (approvingly) a total of 49 times, and the term superrich (in an accusatory sense) eight times. It sounded like this:

title: 150 Years of Working on the Railroad
description: SAN FRANCISCO  IN 1864, my great-grandfather arrived here, a teenager from Ireland with few prospects. Hed left County Galway with a coat and shoes and crossed the Atlantic, caught a steamer to Panama, then another one to San Francisco. The journey took three months, an eternity for a young man hungry to work.

title: Philosophys Lost Body and Soul
description: This is the sixth in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This weeks conversation is with Linda Martn Alcoff, a professor of philosophy at Hunter College and the CUNY Graduate Center. She was the president of the American Philosophical Association, Eastern Division, for 2012-13. She is the author of Visible Identities: Race, Gender, and the Self.  George Yancy

title: Sony Earnings Bolster Full-Year Forecast, Despite Costs From Hacking
description: HONG KONG  After a rough few months, Sony got some relief on Wednesday as net profit almost doubled analysts expectations and the company reduced its loss projections for the year.

title: Hong Kong Newspaper Staff Protests Editors Shifting of Tiananmen Article
description: At every newspaper, journalists enthusiastically kvetch about editors bumping their articles from prominent spots in print, depriving them of glory, if not readers.

title: Test Yourself | Vitamin Drinks
description: Here are several paragraphs from a Jan. 30 Well blog article, Are Vitamin Drinks a Bad Idea?

title: 6 Qs About the News | Harper Lee, Author of To Kill a Mockingbird, Is to Publish a Second Novel
description: In Harper Lee, Author of To Kill a Mockingbird, Is to Publish a Second Novel, Alexandra Alter reports on the discovery of a long-lost manuscript.

title: New Leaders at Paris Opera Unveil an Ambitious Future
description: PARIS  In a major coup, the Paris Opera Ballet has secured one of the dance worlds biggest names, William Forsythe, as the companys associate choreographer.

title: Uber Tries to Ease Concerns in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The ride-hailing service Uber said on Wednesday that it was asking the South Korean government to register its drivers so that it could overcome legal challenges and continue to operate here.

title: Photographing a Filipino View of the Streets
description: When Rick Rocamora left his career selling pharmaceuticals to become a photographer in 1990, he was guided by the advice and encouragement of everyone from Eli Reed and Ed Kashi to Gordon Parks. He has been paying it forward ever since, serving as a mentor to a new generation of Filipino photographers, both in Manila and among his native countrys far-flung diaspora.

title: Do You Have an Idea for a Business or App?
description: Have you ever had an idea for a business that would make life easier, better or more fun? Have you ever considered inventing a game or another kind of app?

title: New York Today: Train Crash Snarls Commute
description: Good Wednesday morning to you.

title: When to Take the SAT
description: During morning announcements, loudspeakers blare out SAT words and definitions at all elementary and middle schools in the Malverne, N.Y., school district. Kindergartners keep a word of the week journal  recently, incentive and consequence  in which they draw the words meaning or, if able, write a sentence using it. Students and teachers at all grade levels weave the new words into conversation; the district sends home definitions for parents.

title: The Wardrobe Politics of Greeces New Prime Minister
description: Last week, as the Twitterati and the talking heads tied themselves in knots over the nonstory of Michelle Obama doing like her peers Hillary Rodham Clinton and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and eschewing a head scarf on a visit to Saudi Arabia, an actual political sartorial revolution was, in fact, taking place elsewhere.

title: Slow Runners Come Out Ahead
description: The ideal amount of running for someone who wants to live a long and healthy life is less than most of us might expect, according to a new study, which also suggests that people can overdo strenuous exercise and potentially shorten their lives.

title: Age 6 and Applying to College
description: College awareness starts early for the first graders at Johnsonville Elementary School in Harnett County, N.C.

title: Is Your First Grader College Ready?
description: What is college? To Madison Comer, a confident 6-year-old, it is a very big place. Its tall, she explained, outlining the head of Tuffy, the North Carolina State mascot, with a gray crayon. Its like high school but its higher.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Defense Nominee Says He Would Consider More U.S. Military Aid to Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  Ashton B. Carter, President Obamas nominee for secretary of defense, told senators on Wednesday that he would consider increased American military assistance to Ukraine, including the sale of lethal arms, as part of the countrys effort to fight Russian-backed separatists in the east.

title: Toyota Profit Gets Lift From U.S. Market and Favorable Exchange Rates
description: TOKYO  Buoyed by a growing American car market and the most favorable exchange rates in decades, Toyota Motor is closing in on its most profitable year ever, the automakers latest earnings report suggested on Wednesday.

title: China Moves to Free Up Money in Its Economy
description: HONG KONG  China signaled fresh concerns about its slowing economy as the countrys central bank moved on Wednesday to stimulate growth by freeing up more money for banks to lend.

title: 1915: Novelist Dies at Richmond
description: LONDON Miss Braddon, the novelist, whose real name was Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Maxwell, died at her home, Lichfield House, Richmond-on-Thames, Surrey, this morning at the age of seventy-eight. Miss Braddons health only began to fail about a fortnight ago, just after she had completed her last novel. Miss Braddon was devoted to literary workfrom the age of twenty and publishedher first novel, The Trail of the Serpent, in serial form so long ago as 1860. She secured her first big success withLady Audleys Secret, a sensationalnovel which enjoyed a great vogue. From that time onward Miss Braddonwas an indefatigable producer of novels.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 5, 1915

title: The Shame of Americas Family Detention Camps
description: Christina Brown pulled into the refugee camp after an eight-hour drive across the desert. It was late July of last year, and Brown was a 30-year-old immigration lawyer. She had spent a few years after college working on political campaigns, but her law degree was barely a year old, and she had only two clients in her private practice in Denver. When other lawyers told her that the federal government was opening a massive detention center for immigrants in southeastern New Mexico, where hundreds of women and children would be housed in metal trailers surrounded by barbed wire, Brown decided to volunteer legal services to the detainees. She wasnt sure exactly what rights they might have, but she wanted to make sure they got them. She packed enough clothes to last a week, stopped by Target to pick up coloring books and toys and started driving south.

title: Tim OReilly Explains the Internet of Things
description: Tim OReilly has been at the cutting edge of the Internet since it went commercial. In fact, he helped take it there: In August 1993 he released the Global Network Navigator, a web page containing information, catalogs and a marketplace, which may have been the first site with advertising.

title: Today in Politics
description: Bush Takes Not-Yet-Campaign to Detroit, Symbol of a Bygone Era

title: Morning Agenda: What S.&P.s Settlement Means
description: WHAT S.&P.S SETTLEMENT MEANS | Standard & Poors $1.37 billion settlement with prosecutors, announced on Tuesday, will settle an array of government lawsuits against the giant rating agency. But it does not represent closure for the broader ratings business, DealBooks Ben Protess and Nathaniel Popper report. An uncertain future still lies ahead for S.&P., as well as its main rivals, Moodys and Fitch.

title: Staples and Office Depot Say a Merger Will Keep Them Competitive
description: Updated, 6:48 p.m. | In planning a $6.3 billion merger, Staples and Office Depot are betting that 18 years was long enough for government regulators to change their minds about how consumers buy office supplies.

title: Investigation Underway in Metro-North Train Crash
description: When a crowded commuter train slammed into a car on the tracks on Tuesday night, it dislodged the electrified third rail, which, combined with gasoline from the vehicle, created a deadly inferno, federal investigators said at a news conference Wednesday evening.

title: A Boost From the State Capitol Helped Penn State Escape N.C.A.A. Penalties
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  Like his father before him, State Senator Jake Corman represents the district that includes Penn State, his alma mater, in the Pennsylvania General Assembly. In his office as Senate majority leader, he keeps a box of Wheaties autographed by Joe Paterno, a model of Beaver Stadium and a small statue of the universitys Nittany Lions mascot.

title: Without a Message, Christie Is Blown Off Course in Britain
description: LONDON  Candidates for the American presidency have been lifted and diminished here in Europe.

title: Sam Smith, Up for Six Grammys, Is Getting Used to Arenas
description: All through his most recent American tour, the British singer Sam Smith has been stunned by the size of his crowds.

title: Despite Recalls, G.M. Pays Workers a Big Bonus
description: DETROIT  To cope with the gravest safety crisis in its history, General Motors has spent freely  almost $3 billion  to compensate accident victims and recall nearly 30 million vehicles.

title: Craft Beer Is Booming, but Brewers See Crossroads
description: When the term microbrewery had scarcely entered the vocabulary, Rich Doyle saw possibilities. Almost three decades ago, he became a co-founder of the Boston-based Harpoon Brewery, which has grown into the 12th-largest craft beer maker in the country.

title: Greek Guerrilla Group Claims Responsibility for Attack on Israeli Embassy
description: ATHENS  A guerrilla organization known for targeting political and foreign diplomatic sites in Greece has claimed responsibility for a gun attack on the Israeli Embassy in December, a Greek police official said on Wednesday.

title: Kindness From Con Ed
description: Dear Diary:

title: Jordans King Abdullah II Returns Home to Cheers After Swift Executions
description: AMMAN, Jordan  King Abdullah II returned here to an unexpectedly warm welcome on Wednesday, as cheering crowds expressed support for the countrys swift executions of two terrorist prisoners in retaliation for the Islamic States grisly killing of a Jordanian pilot.

title: A Mans Death Strikes a Nerve in China
description: Once again, video footage of a citizen, lying helpless in the road as passers-by ignore him and a car runs over his body, has set off outcries online about apathy in Chinese society.

title: River Views, and Soon a Subway
description: The Yorkville neighborhood on Manhattans Upper East Side, snarled until recently by Second Avenue subway construction, is on the rebound.

title: Gravity Dispute
description: Even as the 2015 Oscar race heads into its final weeks, theres still old business to settle from the 2014 race. Tess Gerritsen, the author of the 1999 novel Gravity, claimed that Warner Bros. owed her credit or 2.5 percent of the net profit for the film of the same title, which wound up winning seven Academy Awards. Last week a judge ruled that Ms. Gerritsen had not provided enough support for her claim, reports the Baggers colleague Michael Cieply, who adds that the writers lawyer has said that he would file an amended complaint.

title: London Theater Journal: In the Shadow of the Nazis
description: LONDON  Nazis have crept into this citys theaters during the past month, glowering with murderous hatred and occasionally singing a song or two. Their arrival was perhaps inevitable in a town where life on the stage tends to echo the word on the street.

title: Morning After Fatal Crash, Metro-North Riders Adjust to a New Commute
description: NORTH WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.  The morning after a horrific Metro-North train accident, commuters in Westchester filed in and out of the North White Plains train station while Metro-North workers directed traffic and called out directions.

title: European Authorities Fine ICAP $17 Million in Libor Investigation
description: LONDON  European competition authorities fined the British financial firm ICAP about 14.9 million euros, or $17 million, on Wednesday, saying the firm had breached antitrust laws by facilitating attempts by several banks to rig a benchmark interest rate.

title: Wells Fargo Customers Can Cash Out Rewards at A.T.M.s
description: With mobile payment options increasingly available to consumers, the automated teller machine might seem like an anachronism. Who needs cash when you can buy stuff with your phone?

title: Two Versions of Twelfth Night Coming From Bedlam Theater Troupe
description: Twelfth Night, Or what you will is the full name of the dark comedy by Shakespeare that is simply called Twelfth Night in most productions, like the hit revival on Broadway last season. And that four-word subtitle will be put to inventive use this spring by Bedlam, the critically acclaimed Off Broadway troupe that recently mounted innovative stagings of Sense & Sensibility and The Seagull.

title: Rand Paul Is Linked to Doctors Group That Supports Vaccination Challenges
description: WASHINGTON  Back in 2009, when Rand Paul was pursuing his long-shot bid to win Kentuckys Republican Senate primary, he spoke to a small physicians association that has publicized discredited medical theories, including possible links between vaccines and autism and between abortion and an increased risk of breast cancer.

title: $750,000 Homes in Seattle, Arkansas and Kentucky
description: BEREA, KY.

title: Graceland Is Taking Its Show on the Road to Las Vegas
description: Graceland has left the building.

title: E.C.B. Move Is Setback to Greece on Debt Relief
description: FRANKFURT  Greeces efforts to renegotiate its bailout suffered a serious setback on Wednesday when the European Central Bank shut off a major source of lending for the countrys troubled financial institutions.

title: 1965: Pompidou Off to Pakistan
description: A French television report on President Georges Pompidous official visit to Pakistan in 1965. (ina.fr)

title: House Hunting in ... St. Barts
description: A TWO-BEDROOM VILLA ON POINTE MILOU

title: Frenchman Was Detained Before Attack at Jewish Site
description: PARIS  The man accused of stabbing  three soldiers guarding a Jewish community center in southern France this week had been questioned by counterterrorism officers and released in the days before the attack, a senior police official said on Wednesday.

title: Tax Breaks for the 'Merely Affluent'
Dashboard Camera Records TransAsia Crash
description: Video from a drivers dashboard camera captured the moment a Taiwanese TransAsia Airways plane with 58 people on board crashed into a Taipei river.

title: Mourning Lincoln and Lincolns Body
description: Abraham Lincoln died on April 15, 1865, of a gunshot wound to the head. He was 56 years old and 6 feet 4 inches tall: a giant, felled. He was the 16th president of the United States and the first one killed in office. (A madman once tried to shoot Andrew Jackson, but both of his pistols misfired.) An assassination is treason by way of murder. Lincolns assassination was more  an act of war. Lee surrendered to Grant on April 9. Lincoln was the last of the Union dead. His death had another meaning, too. It founded a civic religion, dedicated to the memory of Lincolns sacrifice and to the proposition that emancipation is redemption.

title: A Laugh for Every Season
description: Theres a very particular allure to a picture book that teeters on the verge of becoming a chapter book  that divides into three or more micro-stories featuring the same characters, with a title page for each vignette. James Marshalls classic George and Martha books from the 1970s, with their hilariously bickering pair of hippos, are probably the gold standard, but there are many good examples from recent years, like Laura Vaccaro Seegers Dog and Bear books and Grace Lins Ling and Ting series.

title: A Documentary Collaboration That Didnt Start Out Promisingly
description: The German film director Wim Wenders is also a photographer with numerous exhibitions and books to his credit, and has collected the work of the Brazilian photographer Sebastio Salgado since the 1980s. But the two men met for the first time only about six years ago, and initially there was no talk of the collaboration that led to the making of The Salt of the Earth, one of five nominees for the Oscar for best feature documentary.

title: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center to Spotlight String Quartet Works
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center announced Wednesday that it would present six complete string quartet cycles next season  including Beethovens 16 quartets, along with cycles of quartets by Bartok, Zemlinsky, Carl Nielsen, Alberto Ginastera and Leon Kirchner.

title: The Test, by Anya Kamenetz
description: Teachers and their unions have resisted standardized testing since the early 20th century. Their critics have claimed they do so because they fear being held accountable for how much children learn. But over the past few years, on both the right and the left, in scattered suburbs and in urban neighborhoods, a small yet growing group of parents have begun to join teachers in denouncing standardized testing. They complain about the narrowing of the school curriculum to the questions asked on high-stakes exams, the many hours and days  sometimes up to a quarter of the school year  spent testing and prepping for tests, and the stress that testing imposes on children. Some parents even have their children opt out of standardized testing altogether.

title: Its What I Do, by Lynsey Addario
description: The modern battlefield can induce a peculiar strain of skewed logic among those sent to chronicle it. Upon a landscape where it is often mortally dangerous simply to stand in one place, how much worse can it be to venture a little farther, to get a bit closer? And having assumed the added risk of getting closer, how then to leave before youve taken the perfect image, conducted one last interview? What makes such calculations especially tricky is that most modern battlefields have no recognizable boundaries or rules of conduct; they bear less resemblance to any traditional war movie than, say, to Mad Max.

title: Picassos Granddaughter Plans to Sell Art, Worrying the Market

title: The Corn Cakes of Red Hook

What grew up around them was a propane-fueled paradise: tacos, huaraches and elotes, tamales tonged out of pots wheeled around in shopping carts. People and flavors from Mexico, Guatemala, Ecuador, Honduras, Colombia, all just blocks away from where Americans fired cannonballs at a British frigate during the Revolutionary War, desperately trying to keep intruders out.

title: 36 Hours in Anguilla

title: 36 Hours in Anguilla
description: Anguilla has no right to be fabulous. The Caribbean island, a British overseas territory about seven miles north of St. Maarten/St. Martin, is a blip on the radar  a mere 35 square miles with just six traffic lights. Its dry and flat, and its tourism scene took off only some 20 years ago; until the 1960s, after all, much of the island lacked electricity and telephone service. Yet fabulous Anguilla is home to some of the regions toniest resorts, epicurean eateries and breathtaking beaches. It has architecturally striking villas like those at Altamer, named for exotic gemstones. And it is a magnet for celebrities like Kevin Bacon and Jimmy Buffett, a kind of British St. Barts. Without the pretension, though  Anguillan style is a perfect paradox: unfussy chic, barefoot elegance. There are no cruise ships, casinos or high-rise hotels, but there is a thriving local music scene, headed by notable up-and-coming singer-songwriters like Omari Banks and Ruel Richardson, and showcased at Moonsplash, the islands annual reggae festival. And the fabulous factor grows with every season: luxe hotel unveilings include Malliouhana, reopened late last year after a three-year overhaul, along with coming debuts of Zemi Beach Resort and Spa, an opulent 115-room resort, and the Reef by CuisinArt, a boutique hotel powered by a four-acre solar field.

title: Classical Playlist: Chopin, Mendelssohn, Gilbert Kalish and More
description: CHOPIN: 24 Preludes (Op. 28); Selected Impromptus, Mazurkas and Other PreludesAndrew Tyson, pianist(Outhere Music, Zig-Zag Territories ZZT347)The young American pianist Andrew Tyson, who has been picking up competition prizes and winning many admirers, proves a poetic, elegant and aptly impetuous performer of Chopin on this splendid recording, issued by one of the many new smaller labels. Mr. Tysons feeling for rubato and over-expressive freedom is balanced by his attentiveness to structure, clarity and inner details. In the 24 Preludes (Op. 28), he brings individual character to each one. Yet Chopins collection of preludes in all the major and minor keys emerges in this reading as a compositional entity. A beautiful recording. (Anthony Tommasini)

title: Among the Anti-Vaxxers

But the related and largely nonpartisan debate over how best to argue with/persuade/shame the kind of parents who decide not to vaccinate their kids (see this piece from Conor Friedersdorf, and this one from Slates Phil Plait, for interesting discussions) islikely to remain relevant for quite a while  at least as long as we keep having diseaseoutbreaksthat seem to cluster in areas with clear pockets of strong anti-vaccine sentiment.

title: Pops Isnt Budging. Hear Me, People?
description: A highly desirable piece of Manhattan real estate is once again on the market. Its location  to use the name of the Stephen Adly Guirgis play opening at Second Stage on Feb. 11  is Between Riverside and Crazy, and it is a place where distinctions of mental health and morality blur vividly. First seen in an Atlantic Theater Company production last summer, this constantly surprising work from Mr. Guirgis (author of the unprintably titled The ______ With the Hat) tells the story of a retired police officer (the wonderful Stephen McKinley Henderson) doing his best to hold onto to his dignity, his family and, most crucially, a rent-controlled apartment on the Upper West Side. Mr. Hendersons character is called Pops, but this angry old man is far less cozy and more complicated than his folksy nickname suggests. The same is true of this play, directed by Austin Pendleton with a sharp ear for everyday urban ambivalence. (Through March 22, 305 West 43rd Street, Clinton, 2st.com.)

It had no effect in patients with more virus in their blood, who are more likely to die.

title: Do We Really Want to Regulate Internet Providers?
An Animators Death Releases a Flood of Sadness
description: For fans of a certain kind of animation, Monty Oum was the Wizard  and the King, the Knight and the Pawn, all rolled into one. Millions of people watched his web series Red vs. Blue and RWBY. At conventions, thousands of fans, sometimes dolled up in the outfits of fantasy characters he created, waited for hours just to meet him.

title: Bobby Shmurda Will Stay in Jail After $2 Million Bail Package Is Withdrawn
description: Bobby Shmurda will remain in jail for the time being.

title: Joy in Boston, and a Parade of Questions in Seattle
description: Thousands of fans ignored freezing temperatures Wednesday in Boston and turned out to honor their beloved New England Patriots with a championship parade. Despite two recent storms, which have buried the city under three feet of snow, the Patriots faithful lined a route from the Prudential Center to City Hall Plaza and cheered as amphibious trucks carrying players and coaches passed by.

title: At Championships in China, Deft Defense but a Lost Match
description: I won the battle but lost the war. That might have been the comment by Bill Pollack of New York City after the diagramed deal.

title: Led by Tinder, a Surge in Mobile Dating Apps
description: BLESS or curse the smartphone, but you cant doubt its impact. Even digital dating has become a hand-held activity.

title: Androgynous Eccentrics, All Moving on Their Own
description: The dancers of Nederlands Dans Theater  or rather its junior company, NDT2  look individual, frank, unorthodox. As the companys quadruple bill at the Joyce Theater proceeds, everything looks increasingly offbeat.

title: Making Overtures Across the Plaza
description: It was a day of rehearsals all around Lincoln Center, and plenty of well-known artists were hard at work  but not in their usual places.

title: Galleries Records Are Subpoenaed
description: Several art galleries and dealers have received subpoenas from the Manhattan district attorneys office requesting sales and shipping records, according to lawyers for the businesses, suggesting that investigators may be revisiting the issue of whether galleries and collectors are properly paying sales tax for art sold in New York, the lawyers said.

title: Grain by Wood Grain, a Movable Feast
description: SAN MARCOS, TEX.  On the day before New Years Eve, after making the 19-hour drive to Texas from Wisconsin, the writer and artisan Gaylord Schanilec began checking the status of the precious cargo that had been sitting, uninsured, in the bed of his Chevy Silverado. In the home studio of Craig Jensen, a bookbinder here, Mr. Schanilec plucked more than half a million dollars out of Rubbermaid storage bins. The money was in the form of 100 bubble-wrapped copies of Lac Des Pleurs, Mr. Schanilecs ode to Lake Pepin, near his home in Stockholm, Wis., population 69. The going rate for each copy is $5,000.

title: Homeland Insecurities
description: The heroine of Allegiance has a brilliant son who works at the C.I.A. and has no idea that his mother is a Russian spy.

title: Men Is Cheap
description: In February 1865, The New York Times announced sensational news: 27 recruitment and bounty brokers had been arrested after a federal government investigation into allegations of huge military recruitment fraud. Spearheaded by Lafayette C. Baker, the governments detective in chief, the investigation laid bare a nationwide network of malfeasance, implicating businessmen, local government officials, military officers and soldiers engaged in a concerted effort to fraudulently help communities achieve their draft quotas by forging enlistment documents, and then surreptitiously pocketing the commissions paid for reaching those numbers.

title: On the Red Carpet, a Revolt Builds Over the Pageantry
description: At this years Screen Actors Guild Awards, Julianne Moore, Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston made headlines, of a sort, by taking the revolutionary step of refusing to stick their paws in E!s Mani Cam.

title: Photographing a Filipino View of the Streets
description: An exhibit opening this week in the Philippines showcases the work of street photographers, many of whom live among that countrys far-flung diaspora.

title: Why Google Glass Broke
description: This is a story that involves lots of public intrigue, a futuristic wearable technology, a secret laboratory, fashion models, sky divers and an interoffice love triangle that ended a billionaires marriage. This is the story of Google Glass.

title: Under Armour Buys 2 Fitness Apps, Including MyFitnessPal
description: To expand its fitness empire, Under Armour has again looked online for growth opportunities.

title: Attuned in Rhythm, Whether Together or Apart
description: The split bill can feel like a tired format: One person shows work, then another does, and then we go home. But with Super We, the dancers Raja Feather Kelly and Tzveta Kassabova really made something of it. In this collaborative evening at St. Marks Church, part of Danspace Projects Dance: Access series, Mr. Kelly and Ms. Kassabova presented four pieces they created on their own, together and with the more seasoned choreographer Sara Pearson. And they put refreshing thought into how the night would unfurl, from simple flourishes, like programs folded into paper airplanes, to hypnotic musical interludes by the composer Aleksei Stevens.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Schock Says Haters Gonna Hate on Office Decor
description: The fallout from Representative Aaron Schocks Downton Abbey- inspired office continues.

title: Wait, What, Im a Millennial?
description: The news that millennials will soon overtake baby boomers as the United States largest living generation disturbed me. Not the prediction itself, but the realization that, according to the standard definition, I am a millennial. Anyone born between 1981 and 1997 has been thrust into that category, and I was born in 1983. The label doesnt feel right. I dont identify with the kids that Time magazine described as technology-addled narcissists, the Justin Bieber fans who boomerang back home instead of growing up.

title: Diana Ross in Brooklyn
description: Diana Ross performed at the reopening of the renovated Kings Theater in Brooklyn on Tuesday night.

title: At Madewell, Mickey Drexlers Third Act
description: Millard Drexler took three steps into the Madewell store on the corner of 19th Street and Fifth Avenue and already he was annoyed. Eight soggy umbrellas were scattered on the hardwood floor, rain collecting in puddles.

title: Pop Royalty, Rechristening a Regal Stage
description: Early on Tuesday, Mayor Bill de Blasio delivered his State of the City address, staking out his vision of a more unified New York, promising to invest in neighborhoods that had been long overlooked in hopes of curbing economic inequality.

title: A House in the Woods
description: The farmhouse in Columbia County was a new kind of habitat for a pair that had spent a quarter-century at the beach.

title: The Bruce Jenner Story Goes From Gossip to News
description: For the last few years, there have been rumors and anonymously sourced tabloid items suggesting that Bruce Jenner, the former Olympic champion and somewhat comically befuddled patriarchal figure on Keeping Up With the Kardashians, was transitioning from male to female.

title: Syracuse Bars Its Mens Basketball Team From Postseason
description: Syracuse announced a self-imposed one-year postseason ban for its mens basketball team Wednesday because of a continuing N.C.A.A. investigation.

title: Patricia Arquette
description: The middle child of five in a performing family of several generations and varying levels of goofiness, Patricia Arquette, 46, has received a cavalcade of accolades for Boyhood.

title: Pictures of the Day: Taiwan and Elsewhere
description: Taiwan and More: Pictures of the Day

title: Beauty Is Not Enough
description: Gardens that support native species were the focus of Plant-O-Rama, at the Brooklyn Botanical Garden.

title: Taking Video Games to the Next Level
description: The video game industry is rapidly evolving with the rise of e-sports. But not everyone has the skills to play at the professional level.

title: Shopping With Etienne Coffinier and Ed Ku
description: As the designers of many bars for restaurants and private homes, the pair has spent ample time studying cocktail shakers.

title: Feb. 4, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Taiwan, Jordan, South Korea and the United States.

title: The Fine-Wine Theory of Fashion Advertising
description: What becomes a legend most? Boy toys.

title: A Sweet Blur Hides All
description: BEE SHAPIRO  Somewhere amid attending law school, pulling corporate lawyer hours, switching careers and having a baby, I gave up on under-eye concealer. I had all the typical complaints  puffiness, dark circles and even the beginnings of something crepe-y  but concealer didnt do much more than my foundation did. Besides, many under-eye concealers rely on radiance (a.k.a., shimmery stuff) to distract from imperfections. Instead I would pat-pat some liquid or powder base below my bloodshot peepers and call it a day. So you could say I was skeptical about the Giorgio Armani Maestro Eraser Dark Circle Concealer ($42).

title: Infections Tied to Lower Rheumatoid Arthritis Risk
description: Stomach and urinary tract infections may have a bright side: A new study reports that they are associated with a reduced risk for rheumatoid arthritis.

title: Meet Olivier Polge, Chanels New Fragrance Creator
description: The world of fragrance can be Old World and clubby, so it didnt appear much of a stretch when Chanel appointed Olivier Polge, right, to succeed his father, Jacques Polge, the houses fragrance creator since 1978 and the man behind hits like Coco Mademoiselle, Chance and Allure. The younger Mr. Polge, 40, brings his own bragging rights to the plum spot: He created best sellers like Viktor & Rolfs Flowerbomb and Balenciagas Florabotanica. But will he fare as well in todays changing landscape? Beauty counters are littered with niche brands, and according to the research firm Canadean, the fragrance market in the United States is projected to grow far slower (4.8 percent from 2013 to 2018) than in, say, India (23.4 percent) or Russia (8.9 percent).

title: Desktop Diversions
description: In an era of digital devices, why are simple desktop toys still so appealing?

title: A Walk-In Bar for Hair Extensions
description: Blow-dry bars have made no-appointment blowouts as easy as popping in off the street, but for more-complex hair care, planning is still required. But those days may be numbered. When RPZL opens Thursday in the Flatiron district, hair extensions will get the same kind of treatment. Women will be able to walk in and get extensions on the spot.

title: Lasting Love, by the Letters
description: When Lauren Fleishman discovered her grandparents love letters, she decided to find couples who have stayed married for a half-century or more.

title: Lisa Perry Evening Wear, Valentines Day Clutches and More Shopping News
description: Last fall, after reading an article on Dara Caponigro, the creative director of the 125-year-old fabric company Schumacher, Lisa Perry, known for her 60s-style shifts and Pop Art collaborations, knew immediately that she wanted to collaborate with the company on an evening-wear collection. Ms. Perrys family owned a home-textile business, and she had long been aware of Schumachers celebrated prints. The 13-piece capsule collection combines Schumacher patterns with Ms. Perrys favorite shapes. The silk gown shown here uses the Art Deco Les Gazelles au Bois print released in 1927 ($1,995). The chenille minidress is Serengeti in Tigre Blanc ($1,495). The collection will be at Lisa Perry, 988 Madison Avenue, and lisaperrystyle.com on Feb. 23.

title: A Selfie With Lady Gaga at MoMA PS1
description: Where does the globe-trotting art world go in the winter lull between Art Basel Miami Beach and the spring art fairs and biennales?

title: Greta Lee Has the Devil-May-Care Character Down Pat
description: AGE 31

title: Friends and Colleagues Remember Lives Lost in the Metro-North Crash
description: The five men rode up front, whether out of preference or habit or for no good reason. They were going home from a days work. Finance work. Art work. Things like that.

title: Palmieri, White House Communications Director, to Join Clinton Team
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has added Jennifer Palmieri, the White Houses communications director, to her fledgling 2016 presidential campaign staff.

title: In Hudson, N.Y., Painting by Numbers
description: Hudson, N.Y.  Last month, Isidro Blasco and Sarah Jay invited a few friends over to help renovate the 164-year-old, brick two-family house they bought in November. But if youre imagining an episode of This Old House, think again.

title: Asking More of the Landscape
description: I cant believe Ive been running this event for 19 years, but you seem to keep coming back, Bob Hyland told the cheering crowd at the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens auditorium last week. A few growers from the North Fork are still digging out of 30 inches of snow. But theyre with us in spirit.

title: Designing Distraction: Executive Toys
description: The Museum of Modern Art is a temple of useful design. It has sponsored chair-making competitions, turned a vacant lot into a showcase of prefabricated housing and exhibited paper clips as if they were Rothkos. Its retail arm, the MoMA Store, is filled with beautiful but sensible objects.

title: Shopping Sales and Events in New York City
description: Love  or is it lust?  is definitely in the air. On Friday, from 6:30 to 9:30 p.m., the emerging designer showroom the Shiny Squirrel will host a lovecentric event with 25 percent off jewelry, like ridge brass cuffs by Laurel Hill Jewelry ($96, originally $128), and tarot card readings ($10). At Species by the Thousands, 171 South Fourth Street, Brooklyn.

title: The Art of Renovation
description: Fourteen artists were invited to burrow, excavate and embellish a couples home in Hudson, N.Y.

title: Charmed, Even by the Snakes
description: After 25 years of owning a beach house, Dr. Sam Grubman and Paul Morris decided to trade it in for a house in the woods. And not for the happiest of reasons, initially at least: Dr. Grubman, an allergist who is now 55, had developed melanoma.

title: Mix Masters: Cocktail Shakers
description: As the owners of Coffinier Ku Design in Manhattan, Etienne Coffinier and Ed Ku have designed plenty of bars, for both restaurants and private homes. So theyve spent a certain amount of time studying the intricacies of cocktail preparation.

title: The Eggs Are Happy, Too
description: While working on the design of a synagogue for a nonprofit organization, Stephen Cassell, a partner in Architecture Research Office, the New York firm, was approached by a board member.

title: Discounts from Jonathan Adler, Victoria & Son, T. Anthony Ltd. and Thomas Paul
description: Some items are up to 40 percent off at Jonathan Adler (the Pierre side table, originally $1,650, is about $1,000); 53 Greene Street (Broome Street), 212-941-8950, jonathanadler.com.

title: Antiques at Your Fingertips
description: Conventional wisdom suggests that shoppers would be reluctant to buy something as pricey as, say, a $22,000 Sergio Rodrigues bench in grained jacaranda wood on their smartphones. But 1stdibs, the online antiques marketplace where the bench was sold, isnt a place for typical consumers, or spendthrifts. And so, after several years with only a website, the company is introducing its first mobile app.

title: Metal and Concrete Show Their Delicate Sides
description: It isnt easy to make a piece of furniture look lightweight enough to float when youre using materials like steel and concrete. Yet that is exactly what Joshua Howe has done with his Y-series coffee table.

title: Like a Kindle, Just Spread Out
description: Ekaterina Panikanova is a book lover, but not in the traditional sense. A Russian-born artist, she uses the pages of old French and Italian books that she finds at flea markets as her canvases.

title: Even Your Dreams May Be About Nature
description: It sounds so easy, but its not, Eileen Mockus said. Ms. Mockus, the chief executive of the textiles company Coyuchi, was referring to the rigors of adhering to international standards for manufacturing organic household goods.

title: Overseer of Fannie and Freddie Takes Cautious Steps to Strengthen Housing Market
description: WASHINGTON  The housing market is finally on the mend, but any major transformation in the governments role in the housing economy does not appear to be on the agenda of a top federal housing regulator.

title: Chief of Troubled Casino Operator Caesars to Step Down
description: Gary Loveman, the longtime chief executive of Caesars Entertainment, the troubled casino operator whose largest unit recently filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, plans to step down from that role, the company said on Wednesday.

title: Passenger Describes Metro-North Crash
description: Steven Lichtenthal, of Bedford Hills, N.Y., rode in the back of a middle car involved in the fatal Metro-North crash on Tuesday. He described how the accident unfolded.

title: Fox Reduces Its Forecast for Growth
description: Twenty-First Century Fox slashed its guidance for long-term growth on Wednesday because of struggles in its broadcast group, unfavorable foreign currency exchange and shifts in its film group, sending shares in Rupert Murdochs media empire tumbling more than 5 percent in after-hours trading.

title: Mary Healy, Actress and Singer, Dies at 96
description: Mary Healy, an actress and singer who was part of a husband-and-wife comedy team with Peter Lind Hayes in the 1950s and 60s, appearing on television and in a life in suburbia radio broadcast from their home in Westchester County, N.Y., died on Tuesday in Calabasas, Calif. She was 96.

title: Crash on the Tracks
description: The morning after a deadly Metro-North accident, riders adjusted their commutes as investigators worked to understand how a sport-utility vehicle became stranded on the tracks in Valhalla, N.Y.

title: North Korea Says It Sees No Reason to Hold Talks With U.S.
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Wednesday that it saw no reason to negotiate with the gangster-like United States any more, warning that it was ready to fight any type of war with Americans, including ones involving cyberattacks and nuclear weapons.

title: Senate Democrats Again Block Homeland Security Funding Tied to Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  For the second consecutive day, Senate Democrats blocked their Republican colleagues from bringing a bill to the floor to fund the Department of Homeland Security, which has become a proxy for a broader policy disagreement over President Obamas executive actions on immigration.

title: Amid Economic Woes and Public Discontent, Putin Critic Sees Opening
description: MOSCOW  Glancing out the window at the swirling snow, Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition activist, mused aloud about how mounting economic problems, along with some public antagonism toward the Kremlins role in the war in Ukraine, may have damaged President Vladimir V. Putins administration enough to make it vulnerable.

title: Operator of Drone That Crashed Outside White House May Be Charged
description: WASHINGTON  Secret Service agents investigating the man who operated the drone that crashed on the White House lawn last week believed there was enough evidence to charge him with a crime, and they have presented the case to federal prosecutors, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Governor of Illinois Takes Aim at Labor
description: Joining the ranks of Republican governors taking aim at the power of labor unions, the new chief executive of Illinois, Gov. Bruce Rauner, said on Wednesday that the state should ban some political contributions by public employee unions and allow local right to work laws.

title: New Challenges to Secrecy That Protects Police Files
description: A case headed for a Staten Island courtroom on Thursday that seeks to unlock grand jury evidence in the police killing of Eric Garner is part of a national push to pry from law enforcement information long kept secret.

title: Tiger Woods Is Lost, on Course and in Thought
description: LA JOLLA, Calif.  Using his wedge, Tiger Woods hit two dozen balls from just off the second green of Torrey Pines North Course. His compulsive chipping called to mind someone hoping that with enough swings of a fly swatter he could silence the buzzing around his head.

title: Brian Williams Admits He Wasnt on Copter Shot Down in Iraq
description: The NBC News anchor Brian Williams apologizedWednesdayfor mistakenly claiming he had been on a helicopter that was shot down by ground fire in Iraq in 2003.

title: Walter Liedtke, Curator at Metropolitan Museum of Art, Dies at 69
description: Walter Liedtke, who served for 35 years as a curator of European paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and was a renowned scholar on Vermeer and the Delft School, died on Tuesday, one of six victims of the crash of a Metro-North commuter train in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 69.

title: Irans President Accuses West of Distorting Atomic Plans
description: Portraying himself to be as tough as his domestic critics, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran criticized nuclear-armed powers on Wednesday, singling out the United States and Israel for what he described as false and hypocritical warnings about Iranian atomic ambitions.

title: Man Accused of Killing His Girlfriend in 2013 Goes on Trial
description: They met online, like so many young couples these days, and found they had a lot in common: They were both deaf, young and from the Dominican Republic. She attended a school for the deaf in Rhode Island; he lived with his grandmother in Upper Manhattan, and worked at a sports club.

title: As Greece Rebels, the Notion of Debt Forgiveness Returns
description: Europes most powerful policy makers dismiss the idea, investors fear it, and it would almost certainly face fierce resistance from within the Continents richer countries.

title: Patriots Parade Through Boston, as Fans Brave Snowstorms Aftermath
description: BOSTON  Rob Gronkowski slurped beer and gyrated. Malcolm Butler, until recently his fairly little-known teammate, grinned at his newly adoring public. Even Bill Belichick, the stoic coach, cracked a smile.

title: A Day of Grand Displays, but the Pen Is Mightiest
description: On the fourth Thursday of November, Americans gather with their families to give thanks. On the last Monday of May, they remember those who gave their lives for their country. And on the first Wednesday of February, they scan Twitter to find out where several dozen talented 18-year-olds have decided to go play college football.

title: S.E.C. Commissioners Split on Waiving Financial Industry Punishment
description: Oppenheimer & Company has looked the part of a financial industry recidivist, its rap sheet replete with at least 30 regulatory actions over the last decade.

title: Lawyers Who Appeared in Anti-Police Video Are Forced to Resign
description: Two lawyers from a city-funded nonprofit group have been forced to resign over their appearance in a rap video that endorsed murderous retribution for the death of Eric Garner, the mayors office said on Wednesday.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 4, 2015
Barges Sit for Hours Behind Locks That May Take Decades to Replace
description: PADUCAH, Ky.  On a recent winter morning, Randy Holt piloted the boat Bill Berry as it pushed a group of barges nearly as long as two football fields steadily down the Tennessee River to the Kentucky Lock and Dam here. But then Mr. Holt had to wait several hours at what has become a major choke point as boats moved one at a time through the narrow, cracked, 70-year-old lock.

title: Jim Harbaugh, Playing Catch-Up, Snares Recruits for Michigan
description: Soon after Jim Harbaugh returned to the college ranks to coach at his alma mater, Michigan, he started a new Twitter account. He sent out motivational messages, occasionally retweeted the pope and offered a glimpse into his intense psyche.

title: Rail Crossing Accidents Decline Nationwide, but Less So in New York Region
description: Railroad crossings, with their flashing lights and descending gates, are a fixture of suburban living. The hundreds of crossings along commuter rail lines in New York and New Jersey can be a nuisance for drivers whose journeys are being interrupted, but they are also something to be feared, crossroads that can easily turn dangerous.

title: G.O.P. Lawmakers Propose Alternative to Obamacare
description: WASHINGTON  Three influential Republican members of Congress unveiled a comprehensive proposal on Wednesday to replace President Obamas health care overhaul with an alternative that would halt the expansion of Medicaid and scale back subsidies for middle-income people to buy private insurance.

title: Guiding Lights
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Its always impressive when a constructor can intersect 15-letter entries in a puzzle, but when the entire theme is made up of interlocked 15s and theyre all song titles, I think thats really elegant.

title: The Americans Recap: Elizabeth, Prepared to Carry On
description: Season 3, Episode 2: Baggage

title: In Surprise, Lindsey Vonn Will Race in Super Combined and Giant Slalom
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  Fresh off her third-place finish in Tuesdays super-G and gearing up for Fridays downhill, Lindsey Vonn announced that she would also compete in the super combined and the giant slalom next week here at the Alpine world ski championships.

title: On a Metro-North Train, Passengers Pause Before Picking a Seat
description: John Rose has been taking Metro-North trains home to White Plains for 30 years, and he sits in the second row of the first car whenever he can. He paused on Wednesday night at Grand Central Terminal as he boarded the 5:49 train on the Harlem line, but habit won again. The car was nearly empty, he said, and he was not afraid.

title: Sri Lankas New Government Hopes to Revisit Past on Its Own Terms
description: UNITED NATIONS  Sri Lankas new government, which swept into power in January on a platform of national reconciliation, is lobbying to quash  or at least defer for a few months  a landmark United Nations inquiry into war crimes set to be released in March.

title: Two Million New Yorkers Have Signed Up for Insurance on Health Exchange
description: About two million New Yorkers have signed up for insurance under the Affordable Care Act, with three out of every four of them poor enough to qualify for Medicaid, according to figures released Wednesday by the Cuomo administration.

title: New York State Attorney General Reaches Deal to Reduce Price of Heroin Antidote
description: Two months after sharply criticizing a drug manufacturer for raising the price of its heroin antidote medication, Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York State attorney general, is expected to announce on Thursday an agreement with the company to offset those rates, as well as any new increases, for one year.

title: Pre-9/11 Ties Haunt Saudis as New Accusations Surface
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  During the 1980s and 90s, the historic alliance between the wealthy monarchy of Saudi Arabia and the countrys powerful clerics emerged as the major financier of international jihad, channeling tens of millions of dollars to Muslim fighters in Afghanistan, Bosnia and elsewhere. Among the projects major patrons was Prince Salman Bin Abdulaziz al-Saud, who last month became Saudi Arabias king.

title: Law Professor Opposes Grand Central Tower Plan
description: In the long-running battle over a proposed 65-story office tower next to Grand Central Terminal, a little-known real estate investor has lobbied New York City officials, supported community opposition and offered to buy the project site from the developer.

title: South Korea Vows Strong Crackdown on Uber
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The South Korean government on Thursday rejected a regulatory compromise suggested by Uber and vowed a strong crackdown on its ride-hailing services.

title: The Sounds of the Downhill
description: Some of the top ski racers in the world describe the sounds of a World Cup downhill.

title: Cuba: Artist Awaits Decision on Charges
description: Tania Bruguera, a Cuban artist based in New York who was arrested in December in Havana, where she planned to stage an open-mike performance to ask citizens to speak about their visions for Cuba, said Wednesday that she had not been able to find a lawyer willing to defend her and that prosecutors had been given 60 more days to decide whether to charge her. The charges being considered include inciting public disorder. She has been released, but her passport has been confiscated. She said six lawyers had refused to represent her because they believed that her case was a lost cause or feared that defending her might hurt their careers.

title: Greece: Rightists Ordered to Stand Trial
description: A panel of judges ruled Wednesday that the leader of the neo-fascist party Golden Dawn and more than a dozen party lawmakers are among 72 people who would stand trial on charges that include participation in a criminal organization, murder and assault. The ruling followed a 15-month investigation into the party, which is widely regarded as one of Europes most violent far-right groups. The defendants include 18 Golden Dawn lawmakers who were elected to Greeces Parliament in the 2012 general elections, including two who have since left the party, as well as 54 members or supporters of Golden Dawn. Golden Dawn dismissed the charges, saying the party and its supporters are victims of persecution and a political frame-up.

title: Claims Against Saudis Cast New Light on Secret Pages of 9/11 Report
description: WASHINGTON  A still-classified section of the investigation by congressional intelligence committees into the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks has taken on an almost mythic quality over the past 13 years  28 pages that examine crucial support given the hijackers and that by all accounts implicate prominent Saudis in financing terrorism.

title: Q. and A.: Matt Ferchen on China and the Price of Oil
description: The recent global drop in oil prices has made winners of consumers in places like the United States and Japan, and losers of countries that depend heavily on oil exports such as Russia, Iran and Venezuela. China, a leading crude oil importer and the worlds largest energy consumer, has responded to the fall in oil prices  the steepest since 2009  by going on a buying spree to ensure that its strategic oil reserves at the end of 2014 were twice what they were the year before. Last month, in another move to bolster the countrys supplies, Chinas top economic planning agency, the National Development and Reform Commission, directed domestic oil refiners to stock up on crude oil and to provide the government with monthly updates on their inventories.

title: Justin Peck  Finds a Sub for Injured Dancer: Himself
description: Justin Peck does not lack for causes of anxiety. As the resident choreographer for New York City Ballet, the 27-year-old is perpetually auditioning for the role of rightful heir to George Balanchine. So imagine what Mr. Peck must have felt when he learned that Andrew Veyette, one of the lead dancers in his Rodeo: Four Dance Episodes was injured and could not perform on Wednesday evening at its premiere at the David H. Koch Theater.

title: Kiko Lopezs Gift for Glass
description: Kiko Lopez makes mirrors that combine an 18th-century technique with a renegade spirit. Using the painstaking process of verre glomis, he covers engraved glass with gold and silver leaf, a skill he mastered in the South of France while apprenticing for several retired artisans after, he says, they realized I was serious and wasnt just going to make reproductions. Although hes committed to respecting tradition, the Puerto Rican-born artist makes pieces that feel completely modern, sometimes tweaking the patina with an accidental coffee spill or cigarette ash. Decorators such as Alberto Pinto, Chahan Minassian and Caroline Sarkozy have commissioned his work, which includes lustrous large-scale mirrors and Jean-Michel Frank-inspired glass fireplaces, and which is now available in America through the New York design shop Maison Gerard.

title: Haunting Portraits of Abandoned Places
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: More College Freshmen Report Having Felt Depressed
description: High numbers of students are beginning college having felt depressed and overwhelmed during the previous year, according to an annual survey released on Thursday, reinforcing some experts concern about the emotional health of college freshmen.

title: The Broad Museum in Los Angeles to Open in September
description: LOS ANGELES  After a series of construction setbacks, the billionaire art collectors Eli and Edythe Broad have announced that their new art museum downtown will open this year on Sept. 20. The Broads originally expected the building, designed by Diller Scofidio & Renfro, to be completed about two years ago, but they never issued a specific date. (A $19.8 million lawsuit by the museum against the German manufacturer Seele, which fabricated the buildings intricate honeycomb-like facade, is pending.)

title: The Broad Museum in Los Angeles to Open in September
description: LOS ANGELES  After a series of construction setbacks, the billionaire art collectors Eli and Edythe Broad have announced that their new art museum downtown will open this year on Sept. 20. The Broads originally expected the building, designed by Diller Scofidio & Renfro, to be completed about two years ago, but they never issued a specific date. (A $19.8 million lawsuit by the museum against the German manufacturer Seele, which fabricated the buildings intricate honeycomb-like facade, is pending.)

title: Word of the Day | acidulous
description: acidulous \-si-j-ls\ adjective

title: Millions of Anthem Customers Targeted in Cyberattack
description: Anthem, one of the nations largest health insurers, said late Wednesday that the personal information of tens of millions of its customers and employees, including its chief executive, was the subject of a very sophisticated external cyberattack.

title: Twitter and Google Said to Reach Deal on Search
description: Twitter is expected on Thursday to announce a new partnership with Google, clearing the way for tweets on the microblogging service to be easier to find on the worlds most popular search engine.

title: Mystery Science Theater 3000 Among Offerings From Shout! Factory Streaming Service

title: Whats on TV Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (E!) LANCE LOVES MICHAEL: THE LANCE BASS WEDDING In what is being billed as the first gay celebrity marriage to be televised, Mr. Bass of N Sync fame and his fianc, Michael Turchin, look back on their relationship and their Dec. 20 ceremony, where they exchanged vows before 300 guests at the Park Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles. The actresses Jamie-Lynn Sigler and JoAnna Garcia officiated. Mr. Bass involved his former bandmates as well: J. C. Chasez performed Cant Help Falling in Love, and Joey Fatone was the ring bearer.

title: Jeb Bush, Evangelicals and the Pandering Question
description: Jeb Bush, the early establishment favorite for the Republican nomination, has suggested that he doesnt want to have to pander to the partys base to win the nomination.

title: British Telecom Giant BT to Buy EE for $19 Billion

Money for Womens Groups

title: What Causes Girls to Enter Puberty Early?
description: RECORD numbers of girls not yet old enough for middle school are starting puberty. Almost by definition, puberty arrives at an awkward age, but these are grade-school girls, thrown into a developmental gantlet before they are ready for the change.

title: Bruce Jenners Courage
description: When I was a growing up, yearning with my pals to be a track star, one of our heroes was Bruce Jenner. He won a gold medal at the 1976 Olympics in the decathlon, and he adorned our Wheaties boxes. We all wanted to be Bruce Jenner.

title: The Supreme Court at Stake
description: In the first Affordable Care Act case three years ago, the Supreme Court had to decide whether Congress had the power, under the Commerce Clause or some other source of authority, to require individuals to buy health insurance. It was a question that went directly to the structure of American government and the allocation of power within the federal system.

title: Lessons From a Deadly Train Crash
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Do It, Harper Lee
description: THE news was greeted online with tweets and tumbles of enthusiasm and joy: Harper Lee, the writer who swore she would never publish another book after the instant classic To Kill a Mockingbird, had changed her mind. Her new book will be released in July.

title: Gov. Cuomo Talks Reform
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo sounded this week a lot like the candidate he was in 2010, when he promised that his first job as governor would be restoring public trust and accountability in state government. He has done little to fulfill that pledge, and worse, he canceled the Moreland Commission midway through its investigation of ethical lapses by lawmakers last year. With the arrest of the former Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, on corruption charges, Governor Cuomo, the reformer, has reappeared on the scene.

title: Will Anyone Pay for Abu Ghraib?
description: What happened at the Abu Ghraib prison during the early days of the Iraq war is no secret: The whole world has seen the appalling photos.

title: Abe Is Said to Have Plans to Revise Pacifist Charter
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has said that he wants to start the process of revising Japans Constitution as early as next year, a senior lawmaker in his party said Thursday, giving the clearest indication yet that the Japanese leader will seek to change a document that has undergirded the countrys postwar pacifism.

title: BNP Paribas Finishes Dismal Year on an Up Note
description: PARIS  BNP Paribas, the largest French bank, on Thursday reported strong fourth-quarter profit, putting a positive finish on a year in which it paid a record fine in the United States and pleaded guilty to having traded illegally with blacklisted countries.

title: Trade Groups Urge U.S. to Push Against Chinese Regulations
description: HONG KONG  United States trade groups gave the Chinese government an earful last week about new policies that could hamper the ability of major technology multinationals to do business in China.

title: TransAsia Airways Faces Scrutiny After 2nd Fatal Crash
description: HONG KONG  The crash of a passenger plane into a river in Taiwan on Wednesday, which killed at least 31 people, has renewed questions about the safety of the airline, TransAsia Airways. It was the carriers second deadly accident in less than seven months.

title: After Argentine Leaders Comments, a Challenge to Try Speaking Chinese
description: A day after President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner of Argentina, on a state visit to China, raised eyebrows with a post on Twitter making fun of Chinese pronunciation, the Chinese state media continued to ignore the episode, focusing instead on her meeting with President Xi Jinping, and on their talks about cooperation in areas including telecommunications, mining and energy.

description: Can we trust our own memories?

title: Test Yourself | Choosing the Ivy League
description: Here are several paragraphs from a Jan. 30 article, Harvard-Bound Player Has 2 Careers on His Mind.

title: 6 Qs About the News | A University Recognizes a Third Gender: Neutral
description: In A University Recognizes a Third Gender: Neutral, Julie Scelfo writes about a growing movement of students who identify as transgender.

title: Lasting Love, by the Letters
description: Like many love stories, it started with a letter.

title: Whats the Best Way to Get Over a Breakup?
description: Have you or anyone youre close to suffered a romantic breakup? How did you, or they, handle it? What worked to ease the pain? What made it worse?

title: E.U. Raises Its Forecast for Growth
description: BRUSSELS  European Union officials on Thursday nudged up growth forecasts across the 28-nation bloc amid optimism that falling oil prices, a weaker euro and intervention by the European Central Bank were brightening the outlook for a region wrestling with economic stagnation.

title: Offer for Canary Wharf Owner Has Enough Support to Proceed
description: LONDON  Qatars sovereign wealth fund and Brookfield Property Partners said on Thursday that they had received enough support from investors to move ahead with their $3.9 billion offer for the owner of the Canary Wharf office and retail development.

title: Takata, Maker of Faulty Airbags, Expects Wider Loss
description: TOKYO  Takata, the Japanese car parts supplier embroiled in a crisis over dangerously defective airbags, added $50 million on Thursday to its loss forecast for its fiscal year, saying that it was facing growing costs to replace faulty components in millions of affected vehicles.

title: U.S. and Europe Working to End Ukraine Fighting
description: KIEV, Ukraine  With fighting intensifying in eastern Ukraine and the White House weighing whether to send arms to bolster the governments forces, Western leaders embarked on a concerted diplomatic effort on Thursday aimed at ending a conflict that has strained relations with Russia.

title: For A.L.S. Patients, a Hopeful Drug That Is Out of Reach
description: After the height of the Ice Bucket Challenge last fall, I found myself at a dinner party where the conversation turned to A.L.S.  amyotrophic lateral sclerosis  the disease for which millions were dousing themselves to raise awareness and money.

title: Stranger in a Strange Land: An Internship Gone Bad
description: On my first night in La Paz, Bolivia, I was indoctrinated into the intern culture. Five fellow interns and an 18-year-old staff assistant smoked a blunt until two of them threw up. Over the following weeks, whether it was imbibing San Pedro mescaline around the Tiwanaku ruins or snorting at the underground cocaine bar, Route 36, our social agenda almost always involved substances.

title: Internships Abroad: Unpaid, With a $10,000 Price Tag
description: Picture this: A summer behind the scenes at the Edinburgh Art Festival, helping set up a show and banquet, managing a guest list and communicating with artists and agents, plus an excursion to London and a tour of a Scotch distillery and 12th-century castle.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Greek Markets Stumble After Face-Off With Bailout Lenders
description: PARIS  Stocks and bonds fell sharply in Athens on Thursday as the new Greek governments showdown with its European partners appeared to be nearing a decisive stage.

title: New York Today: Scene of the Crash
description: Good morning on this quickly cooling Thursday.

title: Franois Hollande Vows to Defend Frances Republican Ideals
description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande of France on Thursday sought to reassure a nation still shaken by the recent terrorist attacks in and around Paris, saying that the country would not be cowed by terrorists and would defend its republican ideals of liberty and free expression against those who sought to undermine them.

title: Daily Report: F.C.C. Proposes Strong Rules to Regulate the Web
description: For the last year, Tom Wheeler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has been working on new rules to ensure so-called net neutrality, or an open Internet. Over that time, his hints and comments have shown a steady shift toward stronger regulation  and a more direct confrontation with the cable television and telecommunications companies that provide high-speed Internet service to most American homes, Steve Lohr reports.

title: My Dad, the Pornographer
description: My father, Andrew Jefferson Offutt V, grew up in a log cabin in Taylorsville, Ky. The house had 12-inch-thick walls with gun ports to defend against attackers: first Indians, then soldiers during the Civil War. At 12, Dad wrote a novel of the Old West. He taught himself to type with the Columbus method  find it and land on it  using one finger on his left hand and two fingers on his right. Dad typed swiftly and with great passion. In this fashion, he eventually wrote and published more than 400 books. Two were science fiction and 24 were fantasy, written under his own name; the rest were pornography, using 17 pseudonyms.

title: A Dance With Draghi
description: Update: Frances Coppola has the same take, with much more detail.

title: Today in Politics
description: Obama Loses Two Guardians of the White House Message Machine

title: Morning Agenda: Idea of Forgiving Greek Debt Returns
description: IDEA OF FORGIVING GREEK DEBT RETURNS | Talk of slashing the government debt loads of European countries, beginning with Greece, is back, DealBooks Peter Eavis writes. For all the opposition, the idea has resurfaced with a vengeance in recent days as the new government in Athens, facing a cash squeeze and aiming to make life easier for its citizens, looks for immediate ways to reduce what it owes, he adds.

title: Pfizer Bets $15 Billion on New Class of Generic Drugs
description: Pfizer is making a $15.2 billion bet on the drug industrys new, more elite class of generics: costly, complex copies of already expensive biotech drugs.

title: Where Camaraderie Never Gets Old
description: Ernie Herman was pursuing an angle against a familiar defender when he raised for a hook shot. Harry Bogdos, a 5-foot-8-inch guard who, by his own admission, has shrunk a bit in recent years, did what he could to force Herman into a difficult attempt by extending his arms.

title: Ordinary People, Wayward Son
description: Anne Tylers novels tend to walk a narrow line between the moving and the sentimental, the sympathetic and the maudlin, the evocative and the banal. Her best work  like The Accidental Tourist, Breathing Lessons and the ambitious Digging to America  gives us intimate portraits of middle-class life, tracing the centrifugal and centripetal forces of family that can propel individuals outward into the world at large or hold them close at home. Her lesser books, like A Patchwork Planet and Noahs Compass, stumble into predictability and clich. Ms. Tylers latest novel, A Spool of Blue Thread, unfortunately falls into that category. It recycles virtually every theme and major plot point she has used in the past and does so in the most perfunctory manner imaginable.

title: Anne Tyler: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of A Spool of Blue Thread says reading her own books always feels like lying awake in a bedroom Ive painted myself; the mistakes are so noticeable and so upsetting.

title: Italy, Beyond the Tourist Traps
description: John Hooper says he is often a little puzzled by Italy.

title: Petit St. Vincent, a Dot of Green in the Ocean Blue
description: When our dive boat captain cut the engine, just east of the island of Mayreau, we lurched for a few minutes in the cyan waters as we prepared to jump overboard. Beneath our hull, our small group had been told, were Mayreau Gardens, a sweep of coral reef massed with gorgeously colored sponges and vibrant sea life, and one of the most beautiful dive sites in St. Vincent and the Grenadines.

title: Throwback Thursday | Harper Lee and To Kill a Mockingbird
description: If you heard the jaw-dropping news this week that Harper Lee, the 88-year-old author of To Kill a Mockingbird, is publishing a second novel, then youll understand why the tweet above received so many retweets.

title: Coming Home to Damaging Stereotypes
description: WASHINGTON  Chris Marvin began to believe veterans might have an image problem when he went out to his mailbox one morning and found a check from a wounded veterans charity for $500.

title: Veterans Pan, and Cheer, Their Counterparts on the Screen
description: Chris Marvin, 35, a retired Army helicopter pilot who broke his legs, an arm and bones in his face in a crash in Afghanistan in 2004, says he often does not recognize the veterans he sees portrayed in movies and television shows. He has had enough of the broken hero story lines about the grunt who did incredible things but is now forever damaged.

title: Profit at Private Equity Firm Apollo Falls Sharply on Energy Industry Turmoil
description: The turmoil in the energy sector weighed on Apollo Global Management in the last three months of 2014, as the private equity giant reported sharply lower profit.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: In Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Room for a Baby
description: Three years ago, Elise Porter and Jose Moran Moya decided to move from a noisy, cramped studio near Union Square in Manhattan.

title: Long and Loose Pendant Necklaces
description: These modern talismans give a hint of hippie magic.

title: Ball Corporation in Merger Talks With British Aluminum Can Maker Rexam
description: LONDON  Rexam, the British aluminum can maker, said on Thursday that it was in talks to potentially be acquired by Ball Corporation in a deal that would value it at 4.29 billion pounds, or about $6.5 billion.

title: Poetry Pairing | Love (III)
description: This Poetry Pairing features George Herberts poem Love (III) and the Vows column Their Chart-Toppers Are Each Other by Lois Smith Brady.

title: China Holds a Canadian It Says Stole State Secrets
description: BEIJING  A Canadian man with ties to a Christian group that provides humanitarian aid to North Koreans has been formally detained by China on suspicion of stealing state secrets, while his wife, also Canadian, was released on bail after they were held for six months without charge, Chinas Foreign Ministry said Thursday.

title: New York Finally Gets Its Own Mens Wear Week  But Will Anybody Come?
description: A week before the autumn-winter 2015 womens wear collections are due to kick off in New York, the Council of Fashion Designers of America finally confirmed the rumors that have been floating aroundand announced that it is creating a standalone mens wear week, to take place fromJuly 13 to 16.

title: The Secret World of a Well-Paid Donor Adviser in Politics
description: A constellation of left-leaning nonprofits and super PACs are raising tens of millions of dollars to pave the way for Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign  and nearly all of them have paid Mary Pat Bonner a cut.

title: Decade-Long Night Curfew to Be Lifted in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  Seeking to normalize life in the embattled capital, Iraqs prime minister said on Thursday that the authorities would lift a nighttime curfew in Baghdad that has been in force, with some interruptions, for over a decade.

title: Greek Debt Diplomacy Doesnt Sell Well in Germany
description: BERLIN  An attempt by Greece to shift the countrys debt narrative away from austerity ran into a wall of inflexibility during a two-day trip to Germany.

title: Rapping a Revolution
description: If Hamilton were on Twitter, he would have been a worse oversharer than me, said the composer-performer Lin-Manuel Miranda recently over lunch at Fraunces Tavern in Lower Manhattan. Mr. Miranda, who won a Tony for the score of In the Heights, was holding forth on Alexander Hamilton, the nations first treasury secretary, who is the unlikely subject of his new musical, Hamilton, now in previews at the Public Theater. In contrast to such relatively taciturn rivals as Thomas Jefferson and Aaron Burr, Mr. Miranda said, Everything we know about Hamilton, we knew when he was alive, because he told us.

title: In Delicate Dance With Gravity, Downhill Racers Are Soothed by Cacophony
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  In an Alpine downhill race, there is no more lonely and solitary position than standing over a pair of skis hurtling down the mountain at 80 miles an hour.

title: Menendezs Views on Cuba and Iran Show Rifts With Obama
