description: Can you project your voice? Memorize dates? Respond to questions while walking backward? If yes, you might just have a chance of becoming a college tour guide.

title: Film Studies: The Academia Awards
Skipping Class at Harvard
description: Secret cameras trained on Harvard lecture halls to study attendance raised quite a stir last fall. To some professors, the research methodology used by the Harvard Initiative for Learning and Teaching clearly invaded the sanctity of the classroom, despite a noble goal: to find out how often students skip lectures. So how hot, or cold, were the seats? Results are out.

title: Cauliflower: Marinated, Mashed and Smashed
description: Cauliflower is a vegetable that I have no qualms about buying on impulse. It keeps very well in the refrigerator  I have made perfectly good meals using florets I found lingering in my produce drawer that had been there for more than a week. Not that I recommend this approach, but it is good to know that you need not use it up right away, especially when you find large heads weighing anywhere from 1 1/2 to 2 pounds.

title: Lani Guinier Redefines Diversity, Re-evaluates Merit
description: Lani Guinier, the first tenured woman of color at Harvard Law School, went through a trial by fire in 1993, when President Bill Clinton withdrew her nomination for assistant attorney general for civil rights.

title: Pop Quiz Answers
description: Blackboard Jumble

title: How to Raise a Universitys Profile: Pricing and Packaging
description: One day in 2013, I sat down in a Starbucks in the Foggy Bottom neighborhood of Washington with Hugh Moren, then a junior at the nearby George Washington University. I asked him how much money he was borrowing to go to college.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Feb. 6
description: Photographs from the past week from New York City and the region include images from a fire in Williamsburg and a deadly train crash on a Metro-North Railroad line.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Whats On This Week Around the World
description: London

title: New Yorkers Clamor for IDs, Swamping Mayors Key Project
description: First there were long lines and waits that lasted hours, followed by website errors, protracted hold times on telephone information lines and extreme difficulty in arranging appointments.

title: Obamas Prayer Breakfast Words to Dalai Lama Ruffle China and India
description: BEIJING  Prayer breakfast speeches in Washington are rarely, if ever, the source of bruised feelings overseas. Not so this year.

title: When Hospitals Buy Doctors Offices, and Patient Fees Soar
description: Imagine youre a Medicare patient, and you go to your doctor for an ultrasound of your heart one month. Medicare pays your doctors office $189, and you pay about 20 percent of that bill as a co-payment.

title: New York Today: Pictures on the Shore
description: Good morning on this frozen Friday.

title: Enthusiasm for I.P.O.s Returns in Europe as 4 Companies Debut
description: LONDON  Enthusiasm for initial public offerings returned with strength in Europe on Friday after having dimmed somewhat in the fourth quarter of last year.

title: Daily Report: Revenue at Twitter Rises, but User Growth Slows
description: Twitter just cant seem to catch a break, Mike Isaac reports.

title: A Herder Strikes Gold, in the Shape of China
description: The mountains of the remote Altay area of northwestern China have a storied history of gold mining. People in the region talk about mines that Russians helped build and operate in the first half of the 20th century. The Russians left the area after the Peoples Liberation Army took over the vast Xinjiang region. Altay sits near the borders with Russia, Mongolia and Kazakhstan, and it is a place from which legends travel far.

title: British Court Says Spying on Data Was Illegal
description: LONDON  The court that oversees intelligence agencies in Britain ruled on Friday that the electronic mass surveillance of cellphone and other online communications data had been conducted unlawfully.

title: Chinese Student to Contest Expulsion From Norway, Lawyer Says
description: A lawyer for a Chinese doctoral student who was expelled from Norway last month on the grounds that his research could be used for military purposes said that the student would contest the Norwegian governments decision and that the case will be sent to the court on Monday.

title: The Saudi Game
description: Washingtons ties with Saudi Arabia are being further strained by assertions that people in the Royal family have close ties to Al Qaeda.

title: Reply All: The 1.25.15 Issue
description: THE MEGYN KELLY MOMENT

title: Can We Reverse-Engineer the Environment?
description: Across the top of the map, above the Arctics Mer Glaciale, there floats a banner inscribed with a legend that in translation reads New Discovery of Many Nations in New France in the years 1673 and 1674. This legend is a bit misleading. Although the terrestrial features seem to have been distorted by a fun-house mirror, the aquatic features are strikingly recognizable and strikingly out of scale, as if we were peering down through a magnifying glass poised over the Great Lakes. Read the semi-legible calligraphic names along the coasts and riverbanks, and you begin to perceive that this isnt really a map of North America nor of New France. Its a navigation chart and a relic of a time when waterways assumed out-of-scale proportions in our geographies.

title: The Hazards of Other Planets
description: The company Mars One is trying to establish colonies on Mars by offering one-way trips there within the next 10 years. Ive gotten into heated debates about the ethical implications of sending people on these trips. Even though the people selected signed up knowing they would never return to Earth, I believe the entire endeavor is unethical because they will not really have a full grasp of what theyve signed up for until they get to Mars, at which point, return to Earth is impossible. Do you agree? ANNIE LUBIN, BROOKLYN, N.Y.

title: Blow Up
description: One October afternoon in 1996, when I was 10, my mom sat me down at the kitchen counter and told me that Uncle Wolfgang had died. He fell asleep while smoking in bed, and his Upper East Side apartment caught fire. It was the smoke inhalation that killed him, not the flames. No one else was injured. He was 45.

title: Kid Rock: Theres No Winning That Battle
description: The musician talks with Jeff Himmelman about how his music, lifestyle and political mindset have changed.

title: Today in Politics
description: Obama Homes In on a New Secret Service Director

title: Gun Debate Reignites in Colorado, 2 Years After Aurora Theater Shooting
description: DENVER  Two years after Colorado tightened its gun laws in response to mass shootings at a Connecticut elementary school and a suburban Denver movie theater, newly empowered Republicans here at the State Capitol are trying to repeal those measures, reviving an emotional debate over gun violence.

title: Teenagers in The Times | January 2015
description: We present the January edition of Teenagers in The Times, a feature that presents almost everything published in The Times about young people during that month.

title: Morning Agenda: RadioShacks Bankruptcy Filing
description: RADIOSHACK FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY | RadioShack has filed for bankruptcy, but is poised to live on in a diminished form, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. The Chapter 11 filing, in federal bankruptcy court in Delaware on Thursday, had long been expected for the 94-year-old electronics retailer, which has not been profitable since 2011.

title: Rates and Ratings
description: The big story in the bond markets these days is the emergence of negative interest rates for a number of sovereigns, which is pretty amazing. But theres another story that shouldnt be overlooked: borrowing costs for supposedly risky debtors not named Greece have plunged below those of supposedly safe borrowers. Heres the view this morning:

title: Ukraine Insists Any Pact With Russia Must Adhere to Terms of September Accord
description: KIEV, Ukraine  As the leaders of Germany and France met with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow on Friday to discuss a deal to end the war in eastern Ukraine, officials in Kiev insisted that any agreement must hold to the cease-fire lines and to other terms of a truce negotiated in September but that never took hold.

title: As Jindals G.O.P. Profile Grows, So Do Louisianas Budget Woes
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  In recent weeks, the office of Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana has issued news releases about the mindless navet of Hillary Rodham Clinton, the folly of opening diplomatic relations with Cuba and the threat of radical Islam in Europe, prompting a flurry of commentary about what it all might mean to Republican voters in Iowa and South Carolina should Mr. Jindal decide, as has long been expected, to run for president.

title: In Pond Hockey, No Reason to Have One Big Fish
description: MINNEAPOLIS  For one long weekend every January, nearly 1,500 men and women in skates converge on frozen Lake Nokomis to revisit their childhoods.

title: Debt Is Money We Owe To Ourselves
description: Antonio Fatas, commenting on recent work on deleveraging or the lack thereof, emphasizes one of my favorite points: no, debt does not mean that were stealing from future generations. Globally, and for the most part even within countries, a rise in debt isnt an indication that were living beyond our means, because as Fatas puts it, one persons debt is another persons asset; or as I equivalently put it, debt is money we owe to ourselves  an obviously true statement that, I have discovered, has the power to induce blinding rage in many people.

title: Q. and A.: Andrew Small on the China-Pakistan Relationship
description: Andrew Small, a policy researcher at the German Marshall Fund of the United States in Washington, explores Chinas ties with Pakistan in a new book that delves into the relationships history, the Chinese origins of Pakistans nuclear weapons, extremism in the two countries and how the future might develop as the United States recedes from Pakistan and Afghanistan.

title: Harris Corporation to Buy Defense Contractor Exelis for $4.7 Billion
description: The Harris Corporation, which makes satellite and other communications equipment for businesses and governments, said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire Exelis for $4.7 billion in cash and stock.

title: In Key West, a Taste of Cuban Coffee Culture
description: We were sitting on benches, my new coffee mate, Anthony, and I. Side by side, half-listening to the baritone rumble of washers and dryers in the laundromat behind us, we watched the cars on Key Wests busy White Street glide by as the island slowly woke up on a Saturday morning.

title: A Road Hog Advertises
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Lure of the Gold Coast
description: For the past several years, wealthy buyers from China have been purchasing investment properties and pieds--terre in luxurious Manhattan high-rises. Lately, though, some have moved their portfolios east to the exclusive enclaves of Long Island, springing for the pricey houses of the North Shores Gold Coast.

title: Revenge Tales Drawn from Everyday Indignities
description: Emerging from a bakery where he has just bought a birthday cake for his daughter, a man discovers his car has been towed. At her wedding reception, a bride realizes her new husband has been cheating on her. On an empty highway, the drivers of an Audi and a jalopy jockey for position and insult each other. Each of the six episodes in Wild Tales, an Argentine movie nominated for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, begins with a disagreeable incident drawn from daily life  but escalates from there into an almost baroque tale of revenge.

title: Cynthia Nixon on Her Directorial Debut, De Blasio and How Mirandas Doing These Days
description: This Wednesday, Feb. 11, the New Group theater company will open Rasheeda Speaking, an exquisitely tense (and often cringingly funny) portrait of racial paranoia in a small doctors office, starring the incomparable Tonya Pinkins and Dianne Wiest. The play also marks the directorial debut of the Sex and the City veteran Cynthia Nixon, who since the release of the franchises second film in 2010 has appeared on Broadway in Wit and on TV in The Big C, and has crusaded hard for marriage equality and for the election, in 2014, of New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio. Nixon chatted with T about launching her career as a director, the other projects that will keep her busy this year  and, of course, the latest news about Miranda.

title: Perversity in Wartime and After
description: Liliana Cavani is a filmmaker of ideas, but at least one of her images has proved indelible: a topless Charlotte Rampling wearing an SS officers cap and suspendered trousers, shielding her breasts with long leather evening gloves. The poster for The Night Porter made this Italian writer-directors work synonymous with what some called Nazi chic.

title: Four Stops Across Morocco
description: Planning a seven-day journey across Morocco, from Atlantic shores to Saharan dunes, can be an odyssey. Heres how to do it.

title: Enrolled at Her Majestys Spy School
description: LONDON  The British director and producer Matthew Vaughn and the screenwriter Jane Goldman have worked together on several film projects, beginning with Stardust in 2007 and including their newest, Kingsman: The Secret Service, which opens in the United States on Feb. 13. Weve written five and a half things, and they have all actually been made into films, Mr. Vaughn said proudly. (The half refers to X-Men: Days of Future Past, which Mr. Vaughn was hired to direct but ultimately didnt; the two received story credit.)

title: Judge Hears Case Over Release of Garner Grand Jury Materials
description: A judge on Staten Island on Thursday weighed arguments for the release of evidence, testimony and instructions presented to the grand jury whose decision in December not to charge a police officer in the chokehold death of Eric Garner touched off weeks of protests.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Philippine President Accepts Police Chiefs Resignation After Deadly Raid
description: MANILA  President Benigno S. Aquino III accepted the resignation of the Philippines national police chief on Friday, two weeks after a disastrous raid left 44 police commandos dead and put the countrys peace agreement with rebels in jeopardy.

title: From Agadir to Merzouga
description: Scenes from across Morocco.

title: Morocco, From Coast to Desert
description: The temperature was easily 90 degrees as Mohamed wrapped my head with a long blue chech, the sun protection worn by Moroccan desert nomads. Nearby, camels snorted and moaned while handlers outfitted them with saddles for the imminent journey. Behind us loomed a long two-story dune and an ocean of sand, undulating toward the vanishing point. After a weeklong voyage across southern Morocco, I was about to venture at last into the Sahara, the culmination of a personal two-decade dream.

title: Watching Youth Fly By, in Fiction and Fact
description: The slacker mirror sees what it wants to see.

title: Chanel Raises the Stakes in the Young Designers Game
description: In the wake of the LVMH Young Fashion Designer Prize  and what is increasingly looking like a horse race to make nice with the next generation of maybe-possible fashion stars (and win their loyalty and affection for a maybe-possible future)  Chanel is putting ever-more assets into the game. Its latest vehicle: the Andam award, the second-largest grant to a young designer, albeit one willing to be based and working in France.

title: Connections Become Clear, Given Time
description: Stanley Nelson has to admit that his timing was good. His new documentary, The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution, is starting to play at festivals  it had its premiere at Sundance last month  in the wake of the nationwide protests over police killings of African-American men in Ferguson, Mo., and Staten Island. The moment is right for a documentary history of the Panthers, with its images of armed black men patrolling the streets and walking onto the floor of the California Legislature.

title: This Is a Great Jobs Report Across the Board
description: Now thats more like it.

title: Open-Skies Agreements Challenged
description: For more than two decades, domestic airlines and successive administrations have pushed for, and achieved, broad international agreements that have fostered greater competition, lower airfares and more flights to hundreds of destinations like Tokyo, Beijing and Rio de Janeiro.

title: Madam C.E.O., Get Me a Coffee
description: LATE one Friday afternoon at a leading consulting firm, a last-minute request came in from a client. A female manager was the first to volunteer her time. She had already spent the entire day meeting with junior colleagues who were seeking career advice, even though they werent on her team. Earlier in the week, she had trained several new hires, helped a colleague improve a presentation and agreed to plan the office holiday party. When it came time for her review for partner, her clear track record as a team player combined with her excellent performance should have made her a shoo-in. Instead, her promotion was delayed for six months, and then a year.

title: Power Lifting of a Residential Kind
description: Izak Senbahar, the president of the Alexico Group and co-developer of 56 Leonard, the undulating tower that redefined TriBeCas skyline, didnt hesitate when it came time to select a fitness guru to assemble what, in his opinion, is the most pivotal amenity component of a luxury residential project: its fitness center.

title: Video Reviews of Jupiter Ascending, The Voices and Ballet 422
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Jupiter Ascending, The Voices and Ballet 422. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Bearing Witness to Sorrow in Jordan
description: This week, the Islamic State released a video showing the execution of First Lt. Moaz al-Kasasbeh, a Jordanian pilot the group had been holding hostage. Rod Nordland, a foreign correspondent, and Ranya Kadri, a Times contributor, were working on a profile of the pilot and were with Lieutenant Kasasbehs family members when they learned of his death.

title: How Obamas Tax Plan May Not Work as Intended
description: Companies offshore cash holdings are a tempting target for American tax writers, as President Obamas proposal this week to tax deferred offshore earnings proves. Those same offshore earnings may attract foreign buyers as well.

title: The Scott Walker Boomlet
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Pond Hockey: Theyre Naturals
description: Images from the United States Pond Hockey Championships in Minneapolis. The sport has grown from a curiosity into one of hockeys most popular genres.

title: Stuff We Liked: From Health to Hues
description: Our staff found loads of stuff elsewhere on the web that we wanted to share. Let's start with disease and move on to happier fare from there.

title: Chinas Fog Weighs Heavily on Shoulders of Its Premier Architect
description: BEIJING  IT is a winter day in Chinas smoggy capital, and Wu Liangyong is wondering what went wrong.

title: 1890: A Catastrophe in the Pits
description: NEWPORT  A colliery explosion of the most appalling character in South Wales within living memory occurred early this morning [Feb. 6] at the Llanerch pits at Abersychan. Three hundred men went down at seven oclock, and the last man had scarcely settled to work when a terrific explosion took place. The work of rescue continued all day, body after body being sent up to the surface. From the less injured men the explorers ascertained that the seat of the explosion was in a remote patt [sic] of the workings, known as Cooks slope. The efforts of the explorers were now directed to this point.On their way they came upon mutilated bodies and wreckage. Some of the corpses were legless, from others arms had been torn violently, and all were hideously burned or otherwise injured about the face, rendering identification difficult or impossible.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 7, 1890

title: Dark Chocolate Pudding
description: Melissa Clark makes this rich dessert with bittersweet chocolate, heavy cream and brown sugar.

title: Rebels in Yemen Say They Intend to Form a New Government
description: SANA, Yemen  The Houthi rebels in Yemen, who effectively forced the countrys president and cabinet to resign last month, announced on Friday that they intended to dissolve Parliament and take control of the country, which does not now have a functioning government.

title: The Dollar and the Recovery (Wonkish)
description: Good news in todays jobs report, and the dollar shot higher. But a stronger dollar will make US goods less competitive, and act as a brake on further recovery. So how do we think about this? How much of the US recovery will be diffused to other countries via dollar strength and a bigger trade deficit?

title: The Bittersweet Kiss of Chocolate
description: I once baked heart-shaped chocolate shortbreads for my sweetie at the time. The cookies were a recipe of my own invention  crisp, crumbly, seasoned with sea salt and near-black cocoa powder, and utterly delicious.

title: Translating in Tongues
description: The Hungarian language, or Magyar, is notoriously difficult to learn for nonnative speakers: Meanings are tucked away in multiple suffixes; word order often has more to do with context than predictable rules of syntax; and as part of the Finno-Ugric language group, Hungarian has few linguistic relatives.

title: Debut Novels
description: ETTA AND OTTO AND RUSSELL AND JAMES  By Emma Hooper  Simon & Schuster, $26.

title: Right of Boom, by Benjamin E. Schwartz
description: Nuclear terrorism has long been a staple of movies and television shows. But typically, Hollywood productions end with the bomb being defused. What would happen if heroes didnt save the day and the United States experienced the worst 24 hours in its history?

title: Love and Lies, by Clancy Martin
description: When it comes to personal life, even the smartest people, those most capable of irony, humor and subtlety, may well show a weakness for the kind of thinking that precludes all three. This is one explanation for Love and Lies: An Essay on Truthfulness, Deceit, and the Growth and Care of Erotic Love, a new and remarkably insight-free book of self-reflection by the novelist and philosophy professor Clancy Martin.

title: Stella by Starlight and Moonpenny Island
description: Childhood may be the easiest time to go to bed as one person and wake up feeling like someone else. In two new middle-grade novels, young heroines discover that adults are not always truthful, and that the world is more dangerous than anyone has been letting on. Theyre life-changing realizations, for sure, and in both books they present an opportunity to find a moral compass.

title: Paperback Row
description: KINDER THAN SOLITUDE,  by Yiyun Li. (Random House, $16.) Lis intricate mystery spans the two decades after the Tiananmen crackdown of 1989. Shaoai, a brash student protester in Beijing, is poisoned, and three members of her circle are implicated: Ruyu, her orphaned teenage cousin, and their friends Moran and Boyang. As Shaoai lingers for years, brain-damaged and uncommunicative, the three become separated by distance and estrangement, haunted by what happened in their youth.

title: Editors Choice
description: GUANTNAMO DIARY,  by Mohamedou Ould Slahi. Edited by Larry Siems. (Little, Brown, $29.) A longtime captive has written the most profound and disturbing account yet of what its like to be collateral damage in the war against terror.

title: The Door, by Magda Szabo
description: Magda Szabo, who died in 2007, was one of Hungarys most important 20th-century writers. Not that most of us Anglophones would know it, as very little of her work has been translated into English. The Door, her best-known novel, which appeared in Hungary in 1987, was initially translated by Stefan Draughon and brought out here by an academic publisher in 1995. Subsequently translated into French, the book won the Prix Femina tranger in 2003 and was beautifully retranslated by Len Rix for British publication in 2005. A decade later, New York Review Books Classics  acting, yet again, in its capacity as the Savior of Lost Greats  has now delivered this version to an American audience.

title: Mo Yans Frog
description: In October 2012, Mo Yan became the first citizen of mainland China to be awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature. Since then, he has been attacked both inside and outside China for his collaboration with the Communist literary establishment: for his vice chairmanship of the state writers association, for remarking that censorship falls in the same category as airport security. In the summer of 2012, he controversially hand-copied, for a special commemorative edition, part of the 1942 Talks at the Yanan Forum on Literature and Art, Mao Zedongs statement of orthodoxy on the arts that became the theoretical ur-text of Chinese socialist realism and literary censorship. Yet readers will find little in Frog, Howard Goldblatts fluent translation of Mo Yans 2009 novel about his countrys one-child policy, that validates the society created by the Chinese Communist Party. It is an anarchic, brutal book about the inhumanity of servants of the Communist state, the inadequacy of Chinese men and the moral vacuum at the heart of post-Mao China.

title: My Name Is Truth, Chasing Freedom and The Case for Loving
description: At home in the world. The first time I heard this expression, I reveled in the very idea of it. It felt like the perfect life goal for all humankind: a feeling of complete belongingness and freedom, unconstrained by societys perceptions of your capabilities, wherever you happen to be  at home or in public. The phrase resonates in three new picture books that highlight issues of race, gender and justice. These stories  about Sojourner Truth, Harriet Tubman and Susan B. Anthony, and the Loving v. Virginia case that struck down laws prohibiting interracial marriage  all have main characters with a steadfast determination to change their lives. They are willing to fight their known hell for an unknown, possibly harsher fate. In each book, the law looms as a character, too, a force that can save lives or kill spirits. And all three books are, in different ways, interracial tales, reminding us that diverse coalitions have always worked together to achieve racial progress.

title: Letters: Books at War
description: Books at War

title: Inside the List
description: Equal Weight: Jill Leovys Ghettoside, a true-crime narrative about a murder case in South Los Angeles that opens into a larger exploration of black-on-black violence, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 8. Leovy is a longtime reporter for The Los Angeles Times, where for years she maintained the Homicide Report blog to track every murder in the county, in an effort to communicate the horror of it, as she said on NPRs Fresh Air recently. I dont like blogs very much, she told the host Dave Davies. You can scan a newspaper front page and get an idea of what you need to be thinking about very quickly. A blog is just a stack, an undifferentiated stack of news. You cant tell the trivial from the weighty. And so it doesnt work for a lot of things  but it occurred to me that it would work for this, that the form would suit what I was trying to say exactly, which is to give everything equal weight. . . . This is not a new story about the sensational case, about the case getting attention. This is just all of them stacked up in a row so that the reader can peruse them and get an idea of whos dying.

title: The Last Time We Say Goodbye and I Was Here
description: This review comes with a disclaimer: The subject is radioactively sad. There are no silver linings or surprise resurrections in either of these devastating novels in which teenagers take their own lives. Even if you think you have a high tolerance for gut-wrenching fiction, the tragedy may knock you flat.

title: Founders Son: A Life of Abraham Lincoln, by Richard Brookhiser
description: In 2012, Fords Theater, the site of Lincolns assassination, erected an unusual tribute to the 16th president: a 34-foot tower, eight feet around, created from some 7,000 of the more than 15,000 books about Lincoln that have been published since his death. Richard Brookhiser, the award-winning author of biographies of the founding fathers, now adds to that list, venturing past the Revolution into a new era to explore the life of this most written-about American. In many ways, however, this is less a book in which Brookhiser moves forward in time than one that endeavors to pull Lincoln back into the 18th century, claiming him, in the titles words, as fundamentally the founders son. Brookhiser casts Lincoln as what might today be called an originalist, a leader who applied the doctrines of both the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution in accordance with the founders intentions in order to chart his way through a new national crisis.

title: The Poets Keeper
description: W. H. Auden said that a great book reads you. Eileen Simpsons beautiful, recently reissued memoir of her doomed marriage to the poet John Berryman, Poets in Their Youth (1982), read me twice, just a few weeks ago and about 30 or so years before that, when I was in my early 20s. I might well have been two different people.

title: X, a Novel About Malcolm X
description: It would be fascinating to get Malcolm Xs take on the current surge of racial tension in America. At first glance, we seem to have made great strides toward equality since the civil rights movement. We elected Barack Obama, a black man, president. Twice. We almost universally condemn outright racism. But is it possible that racism (most notably against African-Americans) hasnt receded so much as it has evolved and become more refined? The elegant racist, Ta-Nehisi Coates has written, knows how to injure nonwhite people while never summoning the specter of white guilt. Housing segregation, for instance, is both devastating and hard to detect. And according to the Sentencing Project, a group that advocates for prison reform, racial minorities are more likely than whites to be arrested, to be convicted and to face stiff sentences. With recent racially charged events like the deaths of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., and Eric Garner in New York City  as well as the rising plea for more representation of minorities in childrens literature from the We Need Diverse Books movement  I cant think of a more appropriate time for a book about the early years of Malcolm X.

title: Bookshelf: Love
description: New books include Love Always Everywhere and Theres This Thing.

title: Republicans Look for the Dark Side on the Jobs Report
description: Economists called it one of the best monthly jobs reports since the recession, with hiring and wages on the rise, but for Republicans on Friday the challenge was how to tamp down the cheers.

title: Lawmakers Call for Investigation Into Verizons Use of Mobile Supercookies
description: Three Democratic lawmakers on the influential Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation are calling on federal regulators to investigate Verizon for its practice of using unique customer codes to track the online activities of its wireless subscribers.

title: Can Narendra Modi Keep Winning?
description: NEW DELHI  Narendra Modi became Indias prime minister after his Bharatiya Janata Party won a parliamentary election in May, crushing the Indian National Congress that had controlled Indian politics for most of the past 60 years. Propelled by his popularity, the BJP then extended its mandate by sweeping a succession of state elections.

title: A Fashion Designer Stages an Erotic Exhibition in Lieu of a Runway
description: The German designer Bernhard Willhelm may have grown up near the Bauhaus stronghold Ulm School of Design, where lecturers included Mies van der Rohe and Buckminster Fuller, but hes since become the fashion worlds champion of form following a different sort of function. In Willhelms hands, geometric cuts and experimental textiles explore not utility, but the sometimes messy rules of attraction and hes quick to cite the adage that we put on clothes hoping someone else will take them off later. I think if you have sex with somebody its very, very important that you have a little laugh together, says Willhelm, noting that he was the first cover boy for the magazine Butt. When sex gets too serious its unbearable, and thats the same with sexy fashion. This good-humored dedication to liberation is on full display in Willhelms exhibition When Fashion Shows the Danger Then Fashion Is the Danger, co-conceived with his longtime collaborator Jutta Kraus, and opening this weekend at theMuseum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles.

title: 1940: Canadian Ship Torpedoed
description: LONDON  The first Canadian ship of the war to be lost, the 9,874-ton Beaverburn, of the Canadian Pacific Steamship Company, was torpedoed by a German submarine off the southern coast of Ireland today [Feb. 6]. Other ships in the vicinity hurried to the scene and rescued all but one of the seventy-seven members of the crew. Constructed in 1928, the Beaverburn was one of the fastest Canadian freighters and carried the most modern equipement for fruit refrigeration. Its attacker was believed to be the same submarine unofficially reported in the trans-Atlantic shipping lane off Cornwall peninsula. Fifty-four members of the 100-man crew of the 875-ton British minesweeper Sphinx were lost when it foundered yesterday as it was being towed to port, after having been attacked by German planes. The captain and four seamen were killed during the attack and the other forty-nine were drowned. During the week ending February 5, eight British merchant-ships, totaling 25,069 tons, and six neutral ships totaling 17,546 tons, were lost by enemy action.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 7, 1940

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Love and Lies
description: This week, Adelle Waldman discusses Clancy Martins Love and Lies; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Dana Goldstein talks about Anya Kamenetzs The Test; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: ISIS Declares Airstrike Killed a U.S. Hostage
description: She had always been the unidentified, lone female American hostage of the Islamic State. For nearly 17 months, while her fellow American captives were beheaded one after another in serial executions posted on YouTube, Kayla Muellers name remained a closely guarded secret, whispered among reporters, government officials and hostage negotiators  all fearing that any public mention might imperil her life.

title: Finding the Right Way to Dispose of Ill-Gotten Gains
description: SEVERAL years ago, a large European company asked Thomas M. DiBiagio to run an internal audit on its South African operations. The company suspected that something might be amiss. And it was right. In the course of the audit, he discovered about $12 million that might best be described as ill-gotten gains.

title: Should Children Be Forced to Perform?
description: Cai came to the front of the stage, his skin pale, his eyes void of their usual joy. He looked up and blinked excessively. The blinking became more rapid and his eyes stayed shut for longer periods and suddenly it looked as if his eyes were rolled back. For a few horrible moments, my husband, Matt, and I believed our son was having a seizure. Then the song ended and a new group of first graders came to the front. Cai receded to the back row, disappearing from view.

title: Ask Well: Measles and Day Care
description: Question:

title: Care Is the X Factor at Work
description: Earlier this week, a midlevel employee at a company I work with got on a plane at his own expense, prompted by a decision that he felt had not been fair to one of his colleagues, and flew several thousand miles across the ocean to discuss the situation directly with his supervisor.

title: Alan Gilbert to Leave New York Philharmonic in 2017
description: Alan Gilbert will step down as music director of the New York Philharmonic in 2017, after eight seasons, the orchestra said on Friday, setting off what promises to be an intense search for a successor to lead the ensemble through the planned renovation of Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Carpetbagger Video: Patricia Arquette on Leaving the Ingenue Behind
description: Patricia Arquette has been among the consistent front-runners this awards season for her performance as the mother in Boyhood, the coming-of-age tale filmed over 12 years. In part, she has been celebrated for agreeing to age on camera. But as the Oscar-nominated Ms. Arquette tells the Bagger, she has long been leery of following the rules Hollywood dictates for actresses careers.

title: Premature Babies With Asthma Outgrow It
description: Parents of premature babies worry about many things, including an increased risk of asthma. But a large Danish study has found that asthma, common in premature babies, disappears as the children grow older. By the time they are adults, their risk of asthma is no greater than that of babies born full term.

title: Bufflehead Ducks Bob Along the Atlantic Shoreline
description: The cure for winter blues is often trudging right in, so with only the slightest north wind and the light babble and hiss of clear green wavelets for company, I started a short walk along the Rockaway Inlet on a recent break in the snow. A cool fog, which sometimes follows a warm winter day, reduced anything beyond my immediate surroundings to haze. I had to stop at one point to admire this trick of the Atlantic  making a thousand-mile horizon vanish  and as I did, five buffleheads appeared as if fashioned just that moment on the limpid seawater. They bobbed like corks, sharply defined in black and white, and I resisted the urge to make them agents with greater intentions. Finally, unable to resolve their vague message, I spent my time figuring out the birds instead.

title: A Reading of Almost Your Life by Fady Joudah
description: The Palestinian-American poet reads his meditation on love and longing.

title: Gap Persists in Homeownership
description: The rising tide of economic recovery is not lifting those most in need, according to an annual scorecard of financial security and opportunity put out by the nonprofit Corporation for Enterprise Development. Low- to moderate-income households and households of color remain far behind on a number of measures of financial well-being, especially when it comes to homeownership.

title: In Upper Manhattan, Restoring the Golden Halo of Mother Cabrini
description: In the apse of a midcentury chapel in Upper Manhattan, there is a sparkling mosaic mural that depicts the life of Americas first saint, Frances Xavier Cabrini. The mural was recently restored to its original luster using period tiles, or tesserae, made of various types of marble (Carrara, Botticino) as well as gilded Venetian glass tiles, made by fusing 22-karat gold leaf between layers of glass and crystal.

title: What I Love | David and Cherilyn Frei
description: After a false start, David and Cherilyn Frei find a home their dogs can live with. For starters, its near a park.

title: Home Loan Programs Let Buyers Put Less Down
description: One of the biggest hurdles to buying a home is accumulating the pile of cash for a down payment. By some estimates, it could take two decades to come up with a respectable 10 percent.

title: Never-Before-Seen Photos of John & Yoko
description: Kishin Shinoyama took the snapshots, one of which became the cover of their album Double Fantasy, just months before Lennons death in 1980.

title: Debate on Arming Ukraine Fractures Washington Think Tank
description: Ukraine isnt the only place consumed by civil war thanks to Russia. The venerable Brookings Institution, long one of Washingtons most prestigious research centers, has fractured very publicly this week over Russia as well.

title: Ex-Federal Prosecutor in New York Joins Ackmans Hedge Fund
description: Until a few weeks ago, Jenna Dabbs was a federal prosecutor in Manhattan, leading the charge in prosecuting some of the biggest and toughest drug kingpins in the world.

title: The Masthead of The New York Times.
description: The Masthead of The New York Times.

title: From the Magazine: Kid Rock on Republicans and More
description: Kid Rock: Theres No Winning That Battle

title: Pandora Readies for Another Royalties Battle, This Time With BMI
description: LOS ANGELES  On Sunday, the eyes of the music world will be on the Grammy Awards in the Staples Center. But shortly afterward, the industrys attention will shift to a much less glamorous location: a federal courtroom in Manhattan, where Pandora will square off against the giant licensing agency BMI in the latest fight over music royalties in the digital age.

title: The Well-Housebroken Seal of Approval
description: Angel and Grace Frei live in a one-bedroom condominium near the river on East 72nd Street. The setup is beyond perfection, what with a sectional that fairly begs to be flopped on, and a flat-screen television thats always set to their favorite channel, NY1. Even better, theyre on the fourth floor, which means its a quick elevator ride to the great outdoors, and a very short walk to the park where all their friends hang out.

title: How Elementary School Teachers Biases Can Discourage Girls From Math and Science
description: We know that women are underrepresented in math and science jobs. What we dont know is why it happens.

title: Sochi, Russia, a Year After the Games
description: Common to the postscript of every Olympics, and especially the very expensive Games in Sochi, Russia, is the difficult task of moving beyond past glories and recouping the investment.

title: No Need to Be Afraid. Its Only a Performance Review.
description: NANCY MORRIS has been on the giving and receiving end of bad feedback.

title: Photos: Hardly a City Frozen in Time
description: A year after the Sochi Olympics, the flags of the competing nations continue to flutter in the breeze rolling in from the Black Sea, and oversize cuddly mascots still roam the vast expanse of the Olympic Parks central plaza, the heart of Russias monumental Olympic effort.

title: Chocolate Gifts for Valentines Day
description: Sweet confectionery gifts in every shape and size in time for Feb. 14.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Love and Lies
description: This week, Adelle Waldman and Dana Goldstein.

title: College Kids Are Getting More Depressed
description: An annual survey of college freshmen released on Thursday shows that a worrisome proportion of them had felt depressed and overwhelmed during the previous year. An intensifying pressure to succeed is taking a toll on college-bound high school seniors. The pressure is worsened by the fact that they have lost the ability to kick back and relax among friends.

title: $25,925,000 for a Perch Above Central Park
description: A spacious three-bedroom apartment with stunning park, city and river vistas at 15 Central Park West, the exclusive twin-towered limestone condominium designed by Robert A. M. Stern Architects, sold for $25,925,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Larry Kramer to Be Honored by Gay Mens Health Crisis
description: Larry Kramer and Gay Mens Health Crisis are coming full circle. The volunteer AIDS organization, which grew out of a gathering in Mr. Kramers living room in 1982, but whose leaders ousted him the next year due to his confrontational tactics for drawing attention to the epidemic, will honor him at its annual spring gala on March 23 by creating a lifetime achievement award bearing his name, the group announced on Friday.

title: 4 Accounting Firms China Affiliates Agree to S.E.C. Settlement
description: The Chinese affiliates of the Big Four accounting firms have agreed to pay a combined $2 million as part of a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over their failure to produce documents from their audits of Chinese companies under investigation by the agency.

title: Brooklyn Trust Company Building Condos
description: The building, at 177 Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights, is undergoing conversion to condos on its upper floors.

title: Books on a Ramone, the Algonquin Set and Weegees New York
description: Marc Bell grew up in Crown Heights, the grandson of the head chef at 21 and son of a longshoreman. He and his twin brother shuttled to nursery school in a converted Cadillac hearse. In 1961, when he was 9, he got a transistor radio (AM only) as a Christmas gift, and by the time he was 13, as a self-taught drummer, he started a band that began playing gigs at Ditmas Junior High and eventually worked its way out of the neighborhood.

title: Concerns Over Safety of Air Travel in Asia
description: Fatal crashes of Malaysia Airlines, AirAsia and TransAsia Airways planes in the past year have prompted travelers to raise questions about the safety of Asian carriers and whether steps are being taken to ensure their security.

title: Palazzo Living in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Trust Company Building, an imposing structure on the edge of Brooklyn Heights and Downtown Brooklyn, was built to resemble an Italian palazzo, with a grand banking hall meant to impress patrons. Soon, it will also be a place to live, as work is underway to transform the upper floors into a boutique condominium.

title: Republicans, Feeling Shut Out, Question Obamas Legislative Intentions
description: WASHINGTON  Four days before President Obama unveiled a sweeping $60 billion vision of free community college for millions of Americans, his staff reached out to Senator Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, a former education secretary and a Republican authority on the issue.

title: MacArthur Award Recognizes Documentary Film Company
description: Firelight Media, a New York City documentary film company, was among nine organizations named as recipients of the MacArthur Award for Creative and Effective Institutions on Friday by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation.

title: Elite Horses Keep Going, and Fans Are Set to Follow
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  At 77, Art Sherman is old enough to recall horse racings heyday. A half-century ago, he was an exercise rider for Swaps, nicknamed the California Comet, and marveled at the supercharged throngs lured to the track by the thoroughbred.

title: Even Young Werther Would Be Happy: Goethe-Institut New York to Return to Renovated Home
description: The Goethe-Institut New York  will reopen in renovated headquarters on Irving Place on March 28, after spending the last five years in a temporary residence on Spring Street. The institute, part of an international network of similar institutions sponsored by the German government to promote German language and culture abroad, plans to expand its programs and to offer its own language courses for the first time. In the past language students attended courses at Deutsches Haus at New York University.

title: Landscapes, After Katrinas Storm
description: Colleen Mullinss photos of post-Katrina New Orleans chronicle a changing landscape, focusing on how people are working to undo damage to the ecosystem.

title: Ellen Brody, S.U.V. Driver in Metro-North Crash, Is Mourned
description: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y.  The woman whose sport utility vehicle was at the center of the train crash that claimed six lives, including her own, was remembered on Friday morning in a packed funeral service here for what was described as a larger-than-life personality and her devotion to family and friends.

title: Still Giving the Joint Class
description: Its called chutzpah, said Charlotte White, describing how she, at age 100, could be bustling  with a walker, no less  around the elegant Hungarian Consulate on East 52nd Street one recent weeknight making final preparations for an evening billed as Charlotte Whites Salon de Virtuosi.

title: The New School Divests Fossil Fuel Stock and Refocuses on Climate Change
description: Many universities have decided to drop fossil fuel stocks from their investment portfolios, but the New School in New York City has decided to go a step further.

title: Child, Bride, Mother: Guatemala
description: In Guatemala, many young girls marry far older men and become mothers long before they are physically and emotionally ready.

title: Profiteroles With a Prize Inside
description: I am neither a chocophile nor a chocophobe, but Im definitely not a chocoholic. You wont tempt me with a slice of chocolate layer cake or a molten chocolate souffl, you wont win my heart with a ribbon-wrapped box of bonbons and you certainly wont find me participating in a communal chocolate fondue.

title: Rushing to Cater to Americas Rich
description: In Houston, Chanels new 5,000 square-foot galleria is styled after Coco Chanels Baroque-inspired apartment, with bronze screens, an antique fireplace and a chandeliered shoe salon.

title: An Upbeat Jobs Report Narrows a Political Debate
description: WASHINGTON  Ever since the midterm elections in early November, in the face of reports on the economy and jobs, politicians from both parties have been struggling to figure out the best way to exploit what is going on.

title: Alan Nunnelee, Republican Congressman, Dies at 56
description: Representative Alan Nunnelee, Republican of Mississippi, died on Friday, months after undergoing brain surgery. He was 56.

title: Resting Place for the High and the Low
description: The remains of an unlikely confederation of aristocrats and scalawags are condensed in a Washington Heights graveyard in the shadow of THE CHURCH OF THE INTERCESSION. The imposing Gothic Revival chapel, at West 155th Street and Broadway, was consecrated in 1915 and designed by a self-taught architect named Bertram Grosvenor Goodhue. His body is entombed in the transept of the soaring sanctuary. Patchworks of stained glass diffuse sunlight, and the altar is inlaid with more than 1,500 stones collected from pilgrimage locations around the world. A cloistered walkway encloses an English-style garden, and a vaulted crypt resembles the Grand Central Oyster Bar without the tables.

title: John Harwood Talks to Michael B. Froman
description: Highlights from a conversation with Mr. Froman, who is negotiating the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade pact that is considered one of the few points on which Democrats and Republicans can agree.

title: Who Might Replace Gilbert at the Philharmonic
description: What kind of conductor the New York Philharmonic chooses to succeed Alan Gilbert, who announced Friday that he would step down as music director in 2017, will say a lot about how the orchestra sees its mission in the 21st century. Here are some types of conductors officials may consider, though many of the maestros named are under contract elsewhere.

title: In Los Angeles, Vintage Houses Are Giving Way to Bulldozers
description: LOS ANGELES  For 50 years, the science fiction writer Ray Bradbury lived and wrote at 10265 Cheviot Drive, a bright yellow stucco home built in 1937 that is tucked away on a winding street in an eclectic and charming, affluent neighborhood on the West Side of Los Angeles.

title: Theyre Always Borrowing His Stuff
description: Thomas Ads almost broke up the Punch Brothers. I wanted to be him, Chris Thile, the frontman of that progressive bluegrass band, recently recalled of his first encounter with the surreal music Mr. Ads composed. I was wondering if I should go back to the drawing board: put everything on hold for five years and figure out a way to do something more like that.

title: Biden Expected to Miss Netanyahu Speech to Congress
description: Sorry, Mr. Prime Minister, but Im busy that day.

title: Striving for Steps That Look Effortless
description: PHOENIX  If you love the warmth of the sun ... go. These words, which you might find in a tourist brochure about this desert city, actually come from the 19th-century Danish ballet choreographer August Bournonville, recounting in his memoirs a trip to southern Italy, not the American Southwest. Yet there is a connection between those sentiments and him and Phoenix, or there will be on Thursday, when Ballet Arizona becomes the first American company to mount a complete production of the 1842 ballet inspired by that Italian journey, Bournonvilles Napoli.

title: NYFW: Mens, Sports Illustrateds Swimsuit Issues and Channing Tatum Waxes Off
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: A Robust Reception After a Rocky Start
description: Sky View Parc, a mixed-use project in Flushing, Queens, that stumbled during the recession, only to right itself quickly in subsequent years, is barreling ahead with its next phase to a very strong reception.

title: A Pop Sampler, a Rap-Rock Hybrid and Daytime Funk
description: Fifth Harmony

title: Check, if Not Checkmate, in DuPont vs. Peltz
description: DuPont has driven a wedge between shareholders and the billionaire activist Nelson Peltz.

title: Finding a Balance Between Two Worlds
description: PARIS  The 20-year-old Daz twins, who make up the Franco-Cuban duo Ibeyi, are almost comically different. Lisa-Kaind, far right, with her dramatic halo of hair, is chatty and easygoing; Naomi is almond-eyed and enigmatic. They live with their mother, who is also their manager, but have never attended the same school and have different social circles. People never called us the twins, Lisa-Kaind said. We arent detached, but ...

title: The Politics of Trade: The Top U.S. Negotiator Answers 10 Questions
description: WASHINGTON  The United States trade representative, Michael B. Froman, a Harvard Law School classmate of President Obamas, is scrambling to complete the one big deal that appears ripe for compromise between Republicans and Democrats  the Trans-Pacific Partnership with a dozen countries from Canada to New Zealand. The deal, being negotiated, forms the core of Mr. Obamas much-promoted pivot toward Asia.

title: 2 Down, 3 to Go as Skier Pursues a Singular Feat
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  After Tina Maze of Slovenia won the silver medal in Tuesdays womens super-G at the Alpine world ski championships, she insisted she could win a medal in each of the five womens races during the 13-day competition.

title: English Premier League Rights Could Cost U.K. Broadcasters Billions
description: LONDON  For many, soccer remains the beautiful game. But for others, it has become more like moneyball.

title: In Yemen, Hard Times Remain a Constant as Rebels Take Charge
description: SANA, Yemen  Twelve-year-old Nefisa Nasser lined up four jerrycans by a faucet on the side of a busy street, patiently waiting her turn to fill them with water. She completed the daily routine, capping each container and sliding it into a wheelbarrow that she pushed back home through the clamor of morning traffic.

title: A Graceful New Video That Doubles as Performance Art, From the Woods Alum Kevin Morby
description: [Watch the video on YouTube.]

title: Giving Something Back to the Kids
description: Felipe Lopez, a basketball prodigy in high school and at St. Johns who later played professionally, now works with teenagers in the Bronx.

title: For Felipe Lopez, a Basketball Ambassador, a Day to Pray
description: Felipe Lopez has a special place in New Yorks basketball pantheon: a gravity-defying phenom at Rice High School in Manhattan in the early 90s, a star at St. Johns University in Queens. His National Basketball Association career, less prolific, lasted five journeyman seasons before an injury cut it short. Now, as the N.B.A. All-Star festivities return to New York Feb. 13 to 15, Mr. Lopez will be making a different kind of star turn, working with city teenagers as an ambassador for the leagues N.B.A. Cares program. The goal is to reach over a million kids in the five boroughs, Mr. Lopez, 40, said. He also runs a free Saturday basketball clinic at the Evangelical Spanish Church, near his childhood home in the Bronx. He moved to Astoria, Queens, last year with his girlfriend, Marija Kero, 30, a math teacher at Mott Hall Charter School in the Bronx.

title: Chef Jamie Oliver Said to Hire Bankers to Find New Investors
description: For years, diners have flocked to Jamie Olivers restaurants and made his recipes. Now Mr. Oliver, the British celebrity chef, is hoping to draw in new investors.

title: New Yorks New Speaker Is One of the Nations Most Liberal State Lawmakers
description: Carl Heastie, the new speaker of the New York State Assembly, isnt just the first African-American in the states history to hold that leadership post. Hes also one of the most liberal state lawmakers in the nation, according to an analysis by two political scientists.

title: Seizing the Day With Others
Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Merger of CIT and OneWest Faces Additional Scrutiny
description: The proposed merger of OneWest Bank and the CIT Group faces a new and somewhat rare regulatory hurdle.

title: Canada Court Strikes Down Ban on Aiding Patient Suicide
description: OTTAWA  The Supreme Court of Canada on Friday struck down laws banning physician-assisted suicide for patients with grievous and irremediable medical conditions.

title: How Brian Williamss Iraq Story Changed
description: A compilation of Brian Williamss television appearances shows how his accounts of a 2003 episode on military helicopters in Iraq gradually became more perilous.

title: Obama on Christianitys History of Abuse
description: The president reminded attendees at the National Prayer Breakfast on Thursday of Christianitys own history of religious persecution, saying people committed terrible deeds in the name of Christ.

title: At Diplomatic Conference, Turkey-Israel Rift Worsens
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish foreign minister withdrew at the last minute from a high-profile international security conference in Munich on Friday, after learning that Israeli diplomats might take part. The abrupt move was the latest twist in a bilateral relationship between Israel and Turkey that was once friendly but has become strained and bitter.

title: Writing Around Gender
description: This week, Julie Scelfos article on how the University of Vermont has recognized students outside the traditional male/female norm presented special concerns. The story had to be written without using the pronouns she or he to identify Rocko Gieselman, its main character.

title: Outside Ellen Brodys Funeral
description: A friend of the woman who was killed when she drove her sport utility vehicle over a rail crossing and was hit by a Metro-North train said that if this happened to her, it could happen to anybody.

title: Dress Blues
description: From double-breasted jean jackets to starched culottes, tailored denim is the next big thing.

title: Brian Williams Faces Fact-Checking Inquiry at NBC
description: Scrambling to contain a crisis engulfing one of its most prominent on-air personalities, NBC will begin an internal investigation into Brian Williams, the embattled evening news anchor who has admitted he misled the public with a harrowing tale of a forced helicopter landing in Iraq.

title: Lundqvist, Hit in Throat, Will Miss at Least 3 Weeks
description: Rangers goaltender Henrik Lundqvist will be sidelined at least three weeks after sustaining a vascular injury when he was hit in the throat in a game last Saturday.

title: Consulting as a Bridge Between Full-Time Work and Retirement
description: CAROL BERNINGS career as a consumer psychologist was ahead of the curve for her generation. She received a doctorate 40 years ago when few women were in graduate school. Her sole employer for 34 years was Procter & Gamble, where she focused on consumer research.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: A four-bedroom 2003 house with a pool in Dix Hills, N.Y, and a five-bedroom renovated 1954 house in Darien, Conn.

title: Roots Cafe in the South Slope
description: Roots Cafe, which occupies a sliver of a storefront on Fifth Avenue and 18th Street in the South Slope in Brooklyn, is the kind of place where customers linger.

title: A Cozy Living Room With a Barista: Roots Cafe in the South Slope
description: On a slushy Saturday morning, Ashley Brazenor, 30, was babysitting for 2-year-old Beckett Abbott at Roots Cafe. She ordered a cold-brew iced coffee and a tofu scramble with vegan cheese  no toast, extra Sriracha  while Beckett nibbled on a berry muffin. Bluegrass riffs bounced off walls lined with washboards, acoustic guitars and mounted driftwood. A line snaked almost to the door, as patrons waited to order ginger apple cider or egg-and-cheese burritos slathered with mashed avocados and black beans.

title: In Defense of Tinder
description: IS the smartphone revolution sullying the online dating world?

description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York City region:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties include co-ops in Lenox Hill, Turtle Bay and Cobble Hill.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
description: A look back at the week in politics.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York York City:

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
The Pitfalls in the Greek Debt Proposal
description: Greece and Germany are heading at each other at high speed, fundamentally disagreeing about Greeces need to stick to the austerity provisions in its loan agreements. The question is whether either will turn off at the last second. Domestic political concerns in both countries argue against it.

title: New Data Shows Apples Explosive Growth in China
description: When Apple reported a record-shattering profit of $18 billion last month, the company said its growth came largely from sales in greater China. This week, some research firms gave a clearer picture of just how big Apple has become in China.

title: Observing a Matterhorn Milestone
description: The Swiss town of Zermatt will celebrate the 150th anniversary of the first ascent of the Matterhorn with a show.

title: Book Review Podcast: Love and Lies
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Adelle Waldman reviews Clancy Martins Love and Lies: An Essay on Truthfulness, Deceit, and the Growth and Care of Erotic Love. Ms. Waldman writes:

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Ukraine and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Feb. 6, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Ukraine, Mexico, Jordan and Taiwan.

title: In a New Book, Never-Before-Seen Photos of John Lennon and Yoko Ono
description: A little over 30 years ago, the Japanese photographer Kishin Shinoyama walked through Central Park with one of the most famous couples in the world. It was sunset, autumn; they sat on a bench just in front of the pond, bordered by trees, a sliver of New York skyline visible in the distance, including the building where they lived. He asked them to kiss, and he clicked the shutter. Three months later, on Dec. 8, 1980, John Lennon was fatally shot at the entrance to the Dakota, home to him and his wife, Yoko Ono. Just three weeks prior to Lennons death, Shinoyamas photograph of John and Yokos kiss at Central Park Pond had appeared on the cover of what would be their final studio album, Double Fantasy. Shinoyama made other photographs that day, of course  800 in all, in fact  but many of them have never been shown until now, on the occasion of Taschens forthcoming publication of Kishin Shinoyama. John Lennon & Yoko Ono. Double Fantasy ($700), out this month. A video trailer for the book premieres here.

title: Saluting the Rodgers Songwriting Dynasty
description: From father to daughter to grandson: The Lincoln Center American Songbook program Judy Kuhn Sings Richard Rodgers, Mary Rodgers and Adam Guettel on Wednesday evening convincingly portrayed the lineage of the composer Richard Rodgers as more than bloodline; it is a proudly romantic musical tradition. The performer making the connections was that top-of-the-line singer Judy Kuhn, whose approach to theater music might be described as one of passionate restraint.

title: Chastised at Home, Iranian Diplomat Refrains From Intimacy With U.S. Counterpart
description: MUNICH  Irans foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, was assailed by hard-liners in Tehran last month for talking a widely photographed walk in Geneva with Secretary of State John Kerry during a break in their talks on Irans nuclear program.

title: Netanyahus Bibi-Sitter Ad Draws Praise From U.S. Conservatives
description: As campaigning intensifies ahead of elections next month in Israel, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is making his case to stay in office by playing the role of the nations babysitter in chief in an online comedy sketch posted on Facebook and YouTube.

title: Persevering in Love
description: Saira Hussain and Assad Akhter were married on Jan. 3, at the Hilton Garden Inn New York in Graniteville, Staten Island. The bride had initially rebuffed the grooms advances, but he never stopped pursuing her.

title: Rachmaninoffs Comeback Work, Sprawling Onstage
description: Beauty of tone proved one of many impressive elements that distinguished Lisa Batiashvilis performance of the Barber Violin Concerto on Thursday evening with the New York Philharmonic, conducted by David Zinman at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Gov. Walkers Drafting Error
description: It was not enough for Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin suddenly to propose a destructive 13 percent cut in state support for the University of Wisconsins widely respected system. His biennial budget plan, released Tuesday, reached gratuitously into the universitys hallowed 111-year-old mission statement to delete a bedrock principle: Basic to every purpose of the system is the search for truth.

title: Wanted: Better Jobs, Higher Pay
description: Job growth got off to a good start in 2015. The economy added 257,000 jobs in January and tallies for November and December were revised upward, for an average monthly gain of 336,000 jobs over the past three months  a clear acceleration in the growth trend, at long last.

title: Diana Taurasi Can Rest Easy, but W.N.B.A. Cant
description: When Diana Taurasi announced recently that she would not play in the W.N.B.A. in 2015, she did not have to explain herself to Sue Bird. After all these years, rest for rubles, Bird knew what Taurasi had earned.

title: Letting Go With Spins and Swirls
description: In yoga, the act of letting go is just as important as perfecting a downward dog. Its a slippery sensation, but you know it when you feel it. A similar quality is found in Rise, a new dance by the choreographer Suzanne Beahrs that explores the idea of surrendering to ones true nature  how, when you strip away the layers, you just might uncover your essence.

title: A Little Star Wars and Pop Energy
description: Ben Munisteri, an accomplished choreographer with a reputation for formal invention, has been lying low for the past couple of years. On Thursday, he re-emerged with a short, self-produced program at the Actors Fund Arts Center in Downtown Brooklyn. It was a modest showing, less like a butterfly emerging from a chrysalis than like a groundhog peeking out from its burrow.

title: Beyond a Rink, a World
description: Of Miracles and Men, Sundays installment of ESPNs 30 for 30 documentary series, is a much deeper, more thoughtful film than a pocket description might lead you to believe.

title: Finding Balance in Braying, Shattering, Crackling Electronics
description: Tinnitus, a new concert series organized by the editor and writer Brandon Stosuy and the producer Adam Shore, focuses on what it has called composers of extreme sound. Whats that mean?

title: Knee Replacement Device Unapproved, but Used in Surgery
description: Carla Muss-Jacobs didnt give much thought to the tools her surgeon would use to replace her knee. Like most patients, she just wanted to feel better and trusted that any devices in the operating room would be safe.

title: Soldiers in Brian Williamss Group Give Account of 2003 Helicopter Attack
description: In the earliest days of the Iraq war, in March 2003, two convoys of helicopters left a base in Kuwait, flying toward Najaf and the front line. One convoy was hit by enemy fire, and the other was not, according to four people present that day.

title: Boko Haram Widens Fight, Striking Niger
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The Islamist terrorist group Boko Haram on Friday morning struck across Nigerias border into Niger for the first time, broadening the regional conflict to a fourth country in West Africa.

title: Chopping Up the Body, Then Walking
description: The title of The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst appears to come from a short exchange in this six-part HBO documentarys second segment. Mr. Durst, the very rich New York real estate heir with the very strange and violent history, is discussing children  or his lack thereof. I didnt want to raise children, he says. I  somehow I thought it would be a jinx.

title: Change in Management at Petrobras Does Little to Appease Its Investors
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Brazils scandal-ridden petroleum giant, Petrobras, has new management and the markets are not pleased.

title: Debt: A Thought Experiment
description: Im getting some outraged/confused responses to my post on debt as money that we owe to ourselves. Many people seem to find it hard to step outside the misleading analogy between an individual and the economy as a whole. If I owe money, thats a claim on my future. But debt levels in the economy as a whole are not a claim by some outside party on the economy as a whole.

title: Insider Tips: Best TV Right Now
description: Best new network drama: The Slap, a mini-series on NBC. A little like The Affair, on Showtime only its a cultural collision, not an extramarital clinch.

title: Friday Night Music: Rhiannon Giddens
description: No words necessary:

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Spank Mixes Artsy Gay Party With Zine
description: Around 2 a.m. last Sunday at the Bell House in Gowanus, Brooklyn, the barnlike backroom was packed with well-toned gay men dancing to house music when something mildly shocking happened: A seven-foot-long Italian sub was carried in by two bespangled go-go boys and devoured by the crowd in 10 minutes, carbs be damned.

title: Iowa Gets a Vice Presidential Visit Next Week
description: Iowa has been crawling with potential Republican presidential candidates in recent months, but a big name Democrat is heading there next week.

title: Falling Marriage Rates Reveal Economic Fault Lines
description: Will Valentines Day, always a popular moment for popping the question, see fewer marriage proposals this year than in generations past?

title: Unsure You Need a Measles Shot? Get Vaccinated
description: Question:

title: Bill Cunningham | Winter Wear
description: The way men handled the snow and slush on Wednesday spoke volumes about their sartorial habits.

title: In the End, No Matchmaker Need Apply
description: At times it seemed as if everyone in Assad Akhters universe had but one goal in mind: to find him a suitable wife.

title: The Best Decade Ever? The 1990s, Obviously
description: BACK in the late 1980s, when I was a co-editor of Spy magazine, we published a cover story about the 1970s. Spy being Spy, it was a grand feast of love-hate celebration: A Return to the Decade of Mood Rings, Ultrasuede, Sideburns and Disco Sex-Machine Tony Orlando. One of its implicit premises was the silliness of the pandemic of American nostalgia, especially for a culturally dubious decade that had ended less than a decade earlier. Over the last half century, we Americans have come to create and consume automatically and continuously a kind of recent-past wistfulness.

title: A Famed Restaurateurs Grand Return
description: A successful comeback makes for an inspiring, feel-good story. This isnt a television show or movie were talking about  its the real-life tale of Chris Cannon and his four month-old contemporary American dining venture in Morristown, Jockey Hollow Bar & Kitchen.

title: A Raunchy Comedy Club Crawl With Whitney Cummings
description: The comedian Whitney Cummings visited New York recently, where she appeared on the Late Show With David Letterman and was the guest host for The Late Late Show.

title: Art and the African-American Experience
description: Those planning to attend the Feb. 8 concert at Hofstra University commemorating Black History Month, be prepared: There will be a vocal call and response moment during the otherwise instrumental performance of Imani Winds.

title: How to Be a Friend in Deed
description: A single mother of two teenage boys loses her job. Then she loses her car. Then her house. Then she cant pay her bills. When this happened to Michelle Bergeron a few years ago, it was a slow-motion spiral out of control.

title: Engineer Helped Passengers Escape Burning Train, Federal Investigator Says
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.  He saw the car pull onto the track. He hit the emergency brake. He saw that a woman was at the wheel, felt the impact as the train he was driving hit the vehicle. As fire tore toward the front of the first car of a crowded commuter trainon Tuesday evening, the engineer set to evacuating passengers. He had helped five or six people clamber out the side doors, he told federal investigators, before the smoke overwhelmed him.

title: Extracting Data from a Dead Tablet
description: Q. My tablet just died and nothing Ive tried can revive it. When asked, the I.T. staff at my place noted there may be a risk that if I recycle the device, someone else might be able to either revive it or get personal information off it. Their advice was to work it over with a hammer. While that sounds like fun, are there better and greener alternatives?

title: Judith Regan Is Back. Watch Out.
description: In Judith Regans corner office on the eighth floor of an office building on Bleecker Street is a picture frame with a quote inside it that reads, Against the ruin of the world, there is only one defense: The creative act.

title: Her Art, Her Passion, Her Torment
description: The life of the French sculptor Camille Claudel is a tangle of art, passion, madness and betrayal. A student and lover of Rodins, Claudel was a critically acclaimed artist when she began to show signs of mental distress, which led her family to commit her to an institution, where she spent the remaining 30 years of her life.

title: Geir Helgemo Plays at the Rosenblum Open Teams
description: There are some bridge players who can, to use a hackneyed term, think outside the box. Geir Helgemo, a Norwegian by birth who plays for Team Monaco, is one of the few  as exhibited by his decision in the diagramed deal.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Evening Hours | Global Celebrations
description: Enchanting music, international pride and deserving honorees.

title: A Rogue by Any Other Name
description: Lately, the news has been filled with reports of privileged men, from star athletes to venerated comedians, using their power, in some cases their physical power, to seduce and control women. So, by comparison, the sex-fiend side of the charming Don Giovanni, the title character of Mozarts most complex opera, can seem not so threatening.

title: Herzogs New World: A Womans Story
description: BERLIN  Werner Herzog has made films about swashbuckling men contending with some of the most extreme environments on earth, from the Amazon to Antarctica. But with Queen of the Desert, which made its debut here on Friday at the 65th annual Berlin International Film Festival, the director has ventured into previously uncharted territory for him: a love story starring a woman.

title: For Two Aloof Neighbors, All the Wrong Moves
description: There are New York minutes and New York strip steaks, but the man and woman in Dancing Lessons are New York neighbors  that is, they live in the same building two floors apart and have never exchanged a word or a nod.

title: Bill Cunningham | MensWinter Wear
description: The way men handled the snow and slush on Wednesday spoke volumes about their sartorial habits. Men who were otherwise conservatively clothed refused to change their dress shoes to storm-appropriate footwear. Meanwhile, men exploring fashion frontiers had a new dare: loafers without socks. For the first time, the Bryant Park fountains base froze with mini-icebergs forming in the corners.

title: 15 Minutes of Fame? More Like 15 Seconds of Nanofame
description: Perhaps you remember Jeremy Meeks, the handsome felon turned Internet sensation.

title: Fondly Squabbling Harmony. Enter a Movie Star.
description: It is not essential to know the Russian plays of Anton Chekhov to like the all-American charms of Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike, Christopher Durangs amiable comedy about a wacky weekend spent in Bucks County with three middle-aged siblings and a boy toy.

title: For New York Fire Departments 150th Anniversary, a Special Insignia
description: The occasion is a celebration of the New York Fire Departments past, all 150 years of it. But a commemorative patch designed by a veteran firefighter speaks more to the present and the future.

title: Crossing an Ocean in Attitudes
description: It always seems slightly superhuman, that luminosity some actors possess. Lillias White had it back in 1997, when she won a Tony Award for playing a middle-aged prostitute in The Life, and she is incandescent still as an elderly poet-songstress in Alan Govenars Texas in Paris, at the York Theater Company.

title: An Oboist Who Sees Beyond His Own Reeds
description: For an oboist, James Austin Smith can deliver a punch line.
