That much became clear last month when Mr. Smith, a slim, smiling figure, found himself onstage at the Tenri Cultural Institute in Greenwich Village during a party for the release of his latest CD, Distance, where he recalled with feigned horror the conservative teachers who had been mortified at his youthful predilection for modern music.

title: Highlights of the Sharjah Biennial
description: A look at some of the artists and exhibits featured.

title: Using Genetics to Improve Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: Rep. Nadler to Music Industry: Get It Together on Copyright Issues
description: LOS ANGELES  The events leading up to the Grammy Awards have plenty of glamour and glitz. But there are also industry gatherings over important but decidedly unglamorous topics like online royalty rates and legislation.

title: Iraq After ISIS: Is a Civil War on the Horizon?
description: To the Editor:

title: What Anthem Customers Should Do Next After Data Breach
description: Consumers first worry in a major security breach is usually about their financial and credit accounts. But cyberthieves can do some serious damage with medical information as well.

title: Nursing Home Payments
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stylish Setting for Thai Classics
description: Describing a restaurant as a storefront can sometimes be misleading; it can suggest anything from an order-at-the-counter spot to an elegant, white tablecloth affair. Krung Tep Thai Bistro, a typical-looking storefront that opened near the train station in Great Neck in November, falls somewhere in the middle.

title: Tips That Are Over the Top
description: To the Editor:

title: Guardrail System Passes First Tests, U.S. Agency Says
description: Federal officials said on Friday that the first tests of a guardrail system, banned by more than 30 states after safety concerns were raised, had met the tests criteria.

title: Asbestos Lawsuits
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Siemens Executive Dies; Cause Appears to Be Suicide
description: FRANKFURT  A former chief financial officer of Siemens died this week, apparently by suicide, only days after settling a long-running legal dispute stemming from a bribery scandal in 2006.

title: Space Age Relic Enters Astronomical Real Estate Market
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  When President John F. Kennedy wanted his home state to benefit from the emerging space program in the early 1960s, it was simple enough: He put an item in the federal budget, and in short order, NASA built an Electronics Research Center near M.I.T. in Cambridges Kendall Square.

title: Report Finds No Evidence of Abuse at Immigration Center in Texas
description: After investigating complaints of widespread sexual misconduct by guards in an immigration detention center in Texas for women and children, the inspector general of the Department of Homeland Security found no evidence of abuse, according to a report published Friday.

title: A Greek Spot Where Salads Reign
description: On a Scarsdale street packed with Asian restaurants, Petra fills a need for an informal spot that offers both small and large plates and good strong coffee at modest prices. At the moment, however, the place has a few problems.

title: Egyptian Gets 25-Year Term in 1998 Embassy Bombings; Judge Calls Plea Deal Generous
description: An Egyptian man who admitted to helping Osama bin Laden issue threats and make claims of responsibility for terrorist bombings was sentenced to 25 years in prison on Friday, a result of a deal that the judge said was generous.

title: On Campus, Obama Makes Case for Plans Including Free Community College
description: INDIANAPOLIS  President Obama on Friday pressed voters to demand that their representatives reach across the political aisle to pass initiatives in his budget including free community college, more generous child care subsidies and new roads and bridges, making the case for his agenda in a heavily Republican state.

title: Strains Grow Between Israel and Many Jews in the U.S.
description: In the last few weeks, an uncharacteristic rift has opened between the United States and Israel, provoked by the announcement that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will address Congress in March at the invitation of House Republicans. His speech, contrary to diplomatic custom, was planned without notifying the White House and the president, who happens to be a Democrat.

title: In Defense of Annual School Testing
description: WASHINGTON  DURING a recent hearing by the Senate Education Committee, its Republican chair, Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, questioned whether the federal governments annual standardized testing requirement, embodied in the No Child Left Behind law of 2001, may be too much. He pointed out that students now spend 1 to 3 percent of their school year taking federal, state and local tests in reading and math.

title: Sochi, Russia, a Year After the Games
description: Common to the postscript of every Olympics, and especially the very expensive Games in Sochi, Russia, is the difficult task of moving beyond past glories and recouping the investment.

title: Houthis Dissolve Parliament in Yemen
description: A member of the Houthi group that recently took power in Yemen announced on Yemeni television the dissolution of Parliament and the creation of an interim assembly.

title: Beyond the Burrito
description: When Valencia Luncheria moved from its modest storefront location on Main Street in Norwalk to a stand-alone building a block away, out went the paper plates and plastic cutlery and in came the conventional dishes and silverware.

title: China Opposes Dalai Lamas Foreign Visit
description: A spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, Hong Lei, condemned any country that allowed the Dalai Lama to visit or that used the Tibet issue to interfere in Chinas domestic affairs.

title: Is the Professor Bossy or Brilliant? Much Depends on Gender
description: Male professors are brilliant, awesome and knowledgeable. Women are bossy and annoying, and beautiful or ugly.

title: The Labor Picture in January
description: The unemployment rate edged higher to 5.7% from 5.6%, but the U.S. economy added a better-than-expected 257,000 jobs in January, according to the latest data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Thriving After a Ban, Notre Dames Jerian Grant Impresses a Hall of Famer
description: At his home in Maryland, Adrian Dantley was a proud alumnus as he watched the Notre Dame mens basketball team overcome a 10-point second-half deficit to defeat Duke last week. The victory continued the Fighting Irishs improbable success this season, made the senior guard Jerian Grant a national player of the year candidate and brought back memories of when Dantley starred for Notre Dame four decades ago.

title: Obama, Trying to Add Context to Speech, Faces Backlash Over Crusades
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama personally added a reference to the Crusades in his speech this week at the National Prayer Breakfast, aides said, hoping to add context and nuance to his condemnation of Islamic terrorists by noting that people also committed terrible deeds in the name of Christ.

title: U.N. Prepares Resolution to Confront Islamic State on Oil and Antiquities
description: UNITED NATIONS  In a show of unity by the world powers against the Islamic State, the United Nations Security Council is preparing to adopt a legally binding resolution intended to choke the terrorist groups ability to trade in oil, antiquities and hostages.

title: Can the Church Return to the Faithful?
description: I ONCE had a friend with a boomerang. One day we took it to the Jersey Shore and I watched as he whupped it around. It was beautiful: the young man and the boomerang, the bright sun and the water. Then, late in the day, he tossed it out over the ocean, and the boomerang didnt come back. For a while we stood together, looking out, wondering whether we might just have lost sight of it. We glanced around nervously, on the off chance that it might yet clock us on the head, returning from a direction we had not anticipated.

title: A Walk Through the Gallery
description: This is the last weekend of an exhibition of Henri Matisses painted-paper works in New York. Cant make it? Explore the art in this wall-to-wall experience.

title: Data Breach at Anthem May Forecast a Trend
description: After an online attack on Anthem, by far the largest breach in the industry, security experts warned on Friday that more attacks on health care organizations were likely because of the high value of the data on the black market.

title: Will a Passion for Royalty Ruin a Prime Ministers Career?
description: It has been a long time since a prince toppled a prime minister.

title: Revenue Rises, but Postal Service Posts Loss
description: WASHINGTON  A record number of packages that were delivered over the Christmas holidays and an increase in prices for other products helped the Postal Services operating revenues rise by 4.3 percent for the first quarter, which ended Dec. 31, the agency reported on Friday.

title: Purple Heart to Be Awarded to Victims at Fort Hood
description: The Army will award the Purple Heart to victims of the deadly 2009 shooting at Fort Hood in Texas, after Congress approved a measure expanding eligibility for the award.

title: Shivering, Hungry and Tearful in Rebel-Held Eastern Ukraine
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Nikita, who has been living for several months with his mother and 1-year-old sister in a basement labyrinth of makeshift tents and rubber-bucket lavatories, explained why he cannot return to his toy-filled apartment.

title: Don Covay, Performer and Writer of R&B Hits, Dies at 78
description: Don Covay, a singer and songwriter whose rhythm-and-blues compositions  among them Pony Time, Chain of Fools and Mercy, Mercy  became hits for a variety of performers and standards of rock n roll and soul music, died on Jan. 31 in a hospital in Valley Stream, N.Y., not far from his home in Queens. He was 78.

title: Politics by Restaurant Review
description: Today, were going to talk about God, Guns, Grits and Gravy, Mike Huckabees entry into the presidential book-writing sweepstakes. These tomes are going to be piling up soon, and remember: We read them so you dont have to.

title: Lizabeth Scott, Film Noir Siren, Dies at 92
description: Lizabeth Scott, a sultry blonde with a come-hither voice cut out for the seething romantic and homicidal passions of her Hollywood film noir roles in the late 1940s and early 50s, died on Jan. 31 in Los Angeles. She was 92.

title: The Transition of Bruce Jenner: A Shock to Some, Visible to All
description: Bruce Jenner has been an Olympic superstar, the hunk on the Wheaties box, a Playgirl cover boy, the author of inspirational sports books and a sometime actor and celebrity game-show contestant. In recent years, he has also been an ancillary but vivid participant in the bizarre public spectacle that is the Kardashian family.

title: Can New York Be Affordable Again?
description: The New York of the 1950s and early 60s, for all its grime and problems, was far more hospitable than todays city to working-class and middle-class families, full of stable and affordable neighborhoods where they could live and strive.

title: 2 Troubled Brothers Are Reunited, Then Torn Apart by an Errant Bullet
description: Shane Van Williams was born in 1991; his brother Sean followed three years later, with a second brother born in between. They were the sons of a no-nonsense correction officer named Roger Van Williams, who worked in state prisons.

title: Citing Overseas Travel Plans, Biden Wont Attend Netanyahus Speech to Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. announced on Friday that he would not attend the speech to Congress by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel next month, further escalating a diplomatic flap that has already soured relations between the Obama administration and one of Americas closest allies.

title: Herbal Supplements Without Herbs
description: An investigation of herbal supplements by the New York State attorney generals office carries a sobering message for the rest of the nation as well.

title: Rice Updates National Security Strategy
description: Susan E. Rice, the national security adviser, talked about the fight against the Islamic State and the pressure being put on Russia over Ukraine.

title: Top Aide Leaps to Defense of Obama Security Stance
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama officially rolled out a new national security strategy for his final two years in office, his top foreign policy aide on Friday denounced alarmism over various international crises, saying the challenges now facing the United States are nothing like those presented in the past by Nazi Germany or the Soviet Union.

title: Dustin Johnson Falls Short in a Return After a Mysterious Hiatus
description: SAN DIEGO  If the six-month gap in Dustin Johnsons golf career were any more mysterious, Rose Mary Woods would be summoned from the afterlife to explain it. In his first competitive start in six months, Johnson missed a birdie putt on his last hole Friday that would have put him above the cut line at the Farmers Insurance Open.

title: Bubonic Plague in the Subway System? Dont Worry About It
description: No human being has caught it in New York City for at least a century, but still, there it was, researchers said, in places touched by hundreds, maybe thousands, of people every day.

title: Mexico: State Officials Find 60 Bodies Inside an Abandoned Crematorium
description: The bodies of 60 men, women and children have been found piled in an abandoned crematorium in Acapulco, the authorities in Guerrero State said Friday, but they appeared to have been prepared for cremation and then left behind rather than dumped there by drug gangs. It is another kind of crime, said Osbaldo Berber, an adviser to the state prosecutor. The crematorium, Cremaciones Pacfico, above, had been closed for a year, and the bodies, which were found Thursday night, had been embalmed and doused with quicklime to cover the scent of decomposition, officials said. Investigators are gathering local funeral home records to determine the identities of the bodies, the prosecutors office said, and are considering charges of improper burial and abuse of a corpse. The owner of the crematorium, Guillermo Estua Zerdain, is missing, officials said. With no sign of organized crime, the discovery of the corpses appears to be unconnected to the case of 43 missing college students believed to have been rounded up by corrupt police officers and turned over to a drug gang in Guerrero in September.

title: Net Neutrality Rules
description: In 2009, President Obama nominated Julius Genachowski, a trusted friend who had acted as candidate Obamas technology adviser, to be the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. They both firmly believed in the importance of net neutrality, in which Internet service providers, or I.S.P.s, would not be able to give one website an advantage over another, or allow companies to pay to get into a fast lane ahead of competitors. That was the surest way to allow innovation to flourish, they believed.

title: United Arab Emirates, Key Ally in U.S. Fight Against ISIS, to Rejoin Air Campaign
description: MUNICH  The United Arab Emirates has informed the United States that it plans to resume its participation in the American-led airstrikes against the Islamic State group, a senior State Department official said Friday.

title: Venezuela: Grocery Chain to Be Seized
description: Ratcheting up a conflict with retailers of basic goods, President Nicols Maduro on Friday ordered the government takeover of a supermarket chain that officials have accused of hoarding products as part of an economic war against his government. Mr. Maduro did not name the company, which he said had 35 medium-size stores in seven states, but it was clear that he was referring to the Da a Da chain. The stores are generally located in lower-middle-class or poor neighborhoods. Promising to use an iron fist in tackling economic problems, Mr. Maduro said the chain, which had a warehouse full of cooking oil and other items, was making war on the people and would be taken over by a government supermarket network known as Pdval. Venezuela has been hit hard by the drop in the price of oil, its only major export, and shortages and long lines at stores are common. Also on Friday, the government filed criminal charges against a manager of the supermarket chain, accusing him of destabilizing the economy. It filed similar charges this week against two executives of the countrys largest pharmacy chain, Farmatodo.

title: Providers of Housewarmings
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  It seems kind of weird to be grateful for cheesy Madonna movies, but today thats what got me my toehold in Byron Waldens twisty Saturday puzzle. So, just for today, I am grateful for cheesy Madonna movies.

title: Anita Darian, a Singer With an Eclectic Range, Dies at 87
description: For the singer Anita Darian, getting to Carnegie Hall not only took practice; it also took a kazoo.

title: Before Rivalry Yields to Cooperation, Nets Hold Off Knicks
description: While Barclays Center was fizzing with applause late Friday night, Jarrett Jack and Alan Anderson of the Nets came together to perform an elaborate celebratory handshake near midcourt.

title: An Uninvited Guest, Treated Like a Monarch, Makes Itself at Home
description: When Skye Rothstein gazes out her window, she is reminded of winters chill and the long, dark nights.

title: Aaron Schock, a Lawmaker Used to Attention, Draws a Little More Than He Wanted
description: WASHINGTON  Aaron Schock was 27 years old, a fresh-faced and ambitious Republican from Peoria, Ill., when he joined Congress in January 2009. Today, Representative Schock has earned a reputation  not for legislating, but for his ripped ab muscles, shirtless poses, racy Instagram account and, now, a Capitol Hill office decorated like a drawing room from Downton Abbey.

title: U.S. Subpoenas Travel Records of Ex-Port Authority Chief
description: Federal prosecutors investigating the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge have issued subpoenas that appear to focus on allegations that the former chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey pushed an airline to reinstate the flights he used to travel to and from his weekend home.

title: In Patz Case, 2 More Testify to Defendants Confession in 1979
description: It was the last thing any of the men in the prayer circle were expecting to hear. They had gathered on a New Jersey farm for a religious retreat in the summer of 1979, all working-class Puerto Ricans from Camden, all seeking spiritual solace.

title: Vaccination Rates for Every Kindergarten in California
description: More than a quarter of schools in California have measles-immunization rates for kindergarteners that are below the standard the C.D.C. says is needed to maintain so-called herd immunity.

title: Fire Tears Through Building in Ocean Grove, N.J.
description: A fire on Friday afternoon tore through a three-story building in Ocean Grove, N.J., destroying several ground-level stores and about 10 apartments in the heart of the small, historic shore community, officials said.

title: In an Ocean of Cynicism, Sturdy Faith
description: The three dominant characters in this political memoir by David Axelrod, one of the Democratic Partys best-known strategists, are Mr. Axelrod, his once-in-a-lifetime client Barack Obama and belief. Mr. Axelrod believes in politics as a calling; in campaigns as an opportunity to forge the future we imagine; in government as an instrument for that progress. Though he does not expound on this theology, it is manifest in his unswerving fidelity to the president.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 6, 2015
Yankees to Meet With Alex Rodriguez
description: Alex Rodriguez is scheduled to meet with Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman and perhaps other front office officials before spring training.

title: From Agadir to Merzouga
description: Scenes from across Morocco.

title: Corrections: February 7, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 1:15 P.M. (Starz Cinema) BEFORE MIDNIGHT (2013) Nine years after rekindling a romance in Paris (Before Sunset) that began nine years before that in Vienna (Before Sunrise), Celine (Julie Delpy) and Jesse (Ethan Hawke) are in Greece, at the end of a vacation with their twin daughters (Jennifer and Charlotte Prior) and Hank (Seamus Davey-Fitzpatrick), the son Jesse left behind in Chicago. Jesse wonders if they could move from Paris to the United States to spend more time with Hank. Celine sees his question as a demand. And so they will fight about this  and the meaning of love, the nature of time and the difference between men and women  throughout the course of a day. Before Sunrise, Before Sunset and Before Midnight are modest, charming movies that together add up to the great romantic epic of a generation defined, in the popular mind and our therapists offices, by hedged bets, easy ironies and perpetual confusion, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this trilogy from the director Richard Linklater. This final installment, he added, is a wonderful paradox: a movie passionately committed to the ideal of imperfection that is itself very close to perfect. Before Sunset will be shown at 8:40 a.m. on HBO2.

title: North Korea Says It Tested New Missile With Success
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Saturday that its leader, Kim Jong-un, had overseen the test-firing of a new antiship missile, weeks before planned joint military exercises by South Korea and the United States that the North has protested.

title: Western Nations Split on Arming Kiev Forces
description: MUNICH  Differences within the Western alliance over whether to send defensive arms to Ukraine were thrust into the open on Saturday when Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, bluntly opposed providing lethal military support to Kiev and called instead for continued efforts to persuade Russia and separatist forces to cease fire.

title: A Site and an App With Appetites in Mind
description: Two new digital platforms are helping travelers get closer to cuisine and the people who make it.

title: Curfews End Brings Hope and Fear to Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  As the curfew expired on Sunday, one famed Iraqi musician celebrated by playing his cello for bystanders in the street. Elsewhere, dozens of men, too young to remember life before the nighttime restrictions, jumped into their cars and toured the city in a roaring convoy, suddenly freed.

title: Are C.E.O.s That Talented, or Just Lucky?
description: The divorce of the oil billionaire Harold G. Hamm from Sue Ann Arnall has gained attention largely for its outsize dollar amounts. Mr. Hamm, the chief executive and founder of Continental Resources, who was worth more than $18 billion at one point, wrote his ex-wife a check last month for $974,790,317.77 to settle their split. Shes appealing to get more; hes appealing to pay less.

title: The Near Death, and Revival, of Monticello
description: Thomas Jefferson designed his beloved Monticello (little mountain in Italian) as an expression of his political and aesthetic values. And yet, 50 years after Jefferson died in 1826, his shrine to American democracy in Charlottesville, Va., was enmeshed in weeds, with the main house in danger of collapse.

title: The Shrinking American Labor Union
description: 24.2%: private sector union membership rate, 1973

title: Wheels for the Short Haul
Lois Braverman of the Ackerman Institute: Making Room for Differences
description: This interview with Lois Braverman, chief executive of the Ackerman Institute for the Family, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: The Great American Dream, Still Deferred
description: The housing market has shown signs of life recently. Prices have risen, mortgage rates are very attractive and construction is reviving.

title: When Apartment Listings Are Misleading
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Anxiety and Interest Rates: How Uncertainty Is Weighing on Us
description: Anxiety and uncertainty are weighing on individuals even where the overall economy is growing.

title: London Theater Journal: Crawling Inside a Family Saga and a Jacobean Noir
description: LONDON  Certain plays allow you to crawl inside them in the way that good books do. You come to inhabit such productions so completely that when they end you experience that glazed resentment that arrives when you have to put down a novel thats consumed you for the length of a plane or train ride.

title: Andr Brink, South African Literary Lion, Dies at 79
description: Andr Brink, a towering South African literary presence for decades whose work in English and Afrikaans fell afoul of apartheid-era censors, died Friday, South African news reports said, citing his publisher, N.B. Publishers. He was 79.

title: Variety: A Decisive Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  We have a challenge thats been thrown down by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon in the notes below, but first, lets see if we can conquer this acrostic.

title: Share Your Thoughts
description: Share your views and submit questions for the reporters.

title: Contact the Reporters
description: Contact the reporters on this story.

title: A Summary: The Hidden Money Buying Condos at the Time Warner Center
description: For more than a year, The New York Times examined the influx of global cash fueling the citys high-end real estate boom. The investigation pierced the secrecy of more than 200 shell companies that have owned condominiums at one complex, the Time Warner Center. Spurred in part by a series of stories by The Times, the de Blasio administration imposed new disclosure requirements on shell companies buying or selling property in New York City.

title: Stream of Foreign Wealth Flows to Elite New York Real Estate
description: On the 74th floor of the Time Warner Center, Condominium 74B was purchased in 2010 for $15.65 million by a secretive entity called 25CC ST74B L.L.C. It traces to the family of Vitaly Malkin, a former Russian senator and banker who was barred from entering Canada because of suspected connections to organized crime.

title: Luxury Condos Unlocked
description: The New York Times investigates the millionaire and billionaire luxury condominium buyers who use real estate as a safe deposit box for their money.

title: Trouble, on Field and Off, for Mighty U.S. Before Womens World Cup
description: QUIBERON, France  The slow buildup to this summers Womens World Cup has not featured the same level of competitive worry for the United States national team as it did for the mens team in 2014. The womens team qualified easily for its tournament, which begins in Canada in June, and will enter the field as one of the clear favorites to win the trophy.

title: Paul Ryan Finds New, Unlikely Role as Gatekeeper of Obamas Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin has been many things in his political career: Republican vice-presidential candidate, uncompromising budget hawk, conservative policy maven and, for Democrats, the breathing symbol of draconian fiscal policies.

title: Saudis Unswayed by Houthi Rebels Overture in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  Leaders of the Houthi rebels announced on Saturday that they had appointed four key ministers from the recently ousted government to a national security committee, part of their efforts to begin building institutions to replace those disbanded by their effective coup.

title: After Geno Auriemmas Reign, UConn Could Lose Clout
description: South Carolina travels to Connecticut on Monday night for a meeting of the top two N.C.A.A. womens basketball teams. The matchup will tell us something about the present and raise a thorny question about the future.

title: Ohio State Freshman Has Fun, and Seizes the National Stage
description: Antonio Russell said he lost track of time Friday sitting at a computer in his Louisville home, captivated by a YouTube highlight reel of his son.

title: 1896: A Call for Reader Submissions
description: Long before social media called 0ut for contributions, The New York Herald ran a contest in 1896 asking its readers to report on their holidays in famous watering places in Europe. The letters should be full of news and gossip of interest to the HERALD readers the paper wrote, a requirement that a reader with the pen name Causeur took very seriously. He won 1,000 francs for the following account of life in Ostende, Belgium.

title: In a Game of Honor, a Cry for a Fair Share
description: SAN DIEGO  In the 1969 Ryder Cup, Jack Nicklaus took a strong hand and, through the alchemy of grace, turned it into golfs trump card. On the 18th hole, Nicklaus conceded Tony Jacklins 2-foot par putt to halve the final match and create the first tie in the events history.

title: Differential Recovery and the Dollar (Wonking Continues)
description: Rereading my post on the dollar and the recovery, I realize that its probably a very difficult read even for professionals; a bit too much writing down my own thought processes. So can I make my basic point using an off-the-shelf standard model, with only minor tweaking?

title: What Were Watching: Sunday Shows
description: The Jordanian military bombed Islamic State targets this week after the terrorist group released a video showing a captured Jordanian pilot being burned to death. On Friday, the Islamic State said the Jordanian attacks had killed an American hostage, the aid worker Kayla Mueller.

title: Anchors Aweigh
description: WASHINGTON  THIS was a bomb that had been ticking for a while.

title: Sandy McGill
description: Sandy McGill is the lead designer in the color and materials area of the BMW Groups DesignWorksUSA studio, which determines not only how the companys cars look but also the appearance and feel of products in a range of other industries, including aviation, marine and telecommunications.

title: The Futility of Vengeance
description: LAST month an Australian entrepreneur created a service that allows you to send your enemies an envelope full of glitter. When opened, bits of sparkly spite will fall out and stick  as glitter and grudges do. A rush of customers crashed the companys website within 24 hours. The owner then made a tidy profit, selling the days-old business for $85,000.

title: Ageism in Our Society
description: Readers respond to a letter decrying the ageism and stereotyping that affect how older people are perceived and treated.

title: Confusion About College Sexual Assault
description: The exact size of the campus sexual assault problem remains unclear. The commonly cited statistic that one in five women who attend college is assaulted before she graduates  repeated by the White House  comes from a flawed 2007 study based on undergraduates at just two unnamed public universities. That figure often shocks, yet there is no reliable alternative estimate. Under the federal Clery Act universities are required to publish data on campus crime, but activists have long suspected that administrators underreport sex crimes.

title: Medicine Just for You
description: President Obamas new budget contains a farsighted proposal that could ultimately transform the practice of American medicine. The proposal seeks to design treatments for the individual, which are sometimes called personalized medicine or precision medicine to distinguish them from the one-size-tries-to-fit-all approach.

title: Do Gays Unsettle You?
description: WHAT an altered world we live in. What an advanced one. The man I love and I can be married in New York or 35 other states if we ever get organized enough, if we decide that we want public vows and a gaudy cake  Im thinking devils food, for a host of reasons  to seal our commitment.

title: Good Lovers Lie
description: VALENTINES DAY is not a celebration of truth telling. God forbid! Relationships last only if we dont always say exactly what were thinking. We have to disguise our feelings, to feint, to smile sometimes when we want to shout. In short, we have to lie.

title: Another Outbreak of False Balance?
description: ON the list of journalistic subjects that New York Times readers care about most, false balance is surely in the top 10. It may even be in the top three, right after fairness and accuracy.

title: The Pentagons Excess Space
description: For the past three years, officials at the Pentagon have asked Congress for permission to take stock of how many of the militarys vast network of installations across the country have become obsolete and ought to be shrunk or shuttered. The Defense Department, by far the nations largest and costliest bureaucracy, estimates that it could operate far more efficiently and save billions of dollars each year by shedding at least 20 percent of its real estate.

title: The Best Way to Address Campus Rape
description: THE campus rape debate took another hairpin turn last week when The Daily Beast published an interview with Paul Nungesser, the Columbia student accused of raping a fellow student, Emma Sulkowicz. She has been carrying a mattress around the campus to raise awareness about sexual assault and to protest the schools failure to expel Mr. Nungesser, who was cleared by a campus tribunal.

title: Obama the Theologian
description: PRESIDENT OBAMA, like many well-read inhabitants of public life, is a professed admirer of Reinhold Niebuhr, the famous mid-20th-century Protestant theologian. And more than most presidents, he has tried to incorporate one of Niebuhrs insights into his public rhetoric: the idea that no society is innocent, and that Americans in particular need to put aside illusions about our own alleged perfection.

title: The Dangers of Vaccine Denial
description: IN a few backward parts of the world, extremists resist universal childhood vaccinations. The Taliban in tribal areas of Pakistan. Boko Haram militants in Northern Nigeria.

title: When Doing Everything Is Way Too Much
description: In trying to honor Vincents autonomy, we abandoned him in hell. A decade ago, as a doctor in the intensive care unit at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark, I met Vincent  Im using this name to protect his privacy  on his ninth stay of the year. He was a frequent flier, back and forth between the I.C.U. and his nursing home down the street. He would come in dying, wed plug him into life support, treat his infection, pump up his blood pressure and send him back to the nursing home. But then hed deflate like an old tire and be rolled back in by paramedics within anywhere from three days to three weeks.

title: The Fraud Years
description: As the Bush II administration fades in the rear view mirror, theres a tendency  indeed, an avid desire on the part of many people in the media  to blur the reality of what happened, to make it seem as if were just an ordinary time when a Republican happened to be president.

title: Surviving the Nazis, Only to Be Jailed by America
description: WORLD leaders gathered at Auschwitz last month to mark the liberation 70 years earlier of the Nazis most infamous concentration camp. More ceremonies will follow in coming months to remember the Allied forces discovery, in rapid succession, of other Nazi concentration camps at places like Bergen-Belsen that winter and spring of 1945.

title: How to Be Invisible
description: IN one of the most popular ads shown during the Super Bowl last weekend, the Indian-American actress Mindy Kaling thinks shes become invisible. Cabs pass her by, and men barely look up on the sidewalk. And yet she embraces her invisibility as a kind of liberation. More of us should do the same.

title: Ancient Savagery, and How It Worked
description: As blood sports go, the Super Bowl has nothing on the Colosseum and its events. Built near Neros onetime pleasure palace by the emperor Vespasian as a symbol of Roman military might, the amphitheater (capacity: 50,000 or so) boasted gladiators, wild beasts, crucifixions and elaborately staged Greek myths that often didnt end well for the performers, as when criminals were catapulted above the arena to recreate Icaruss flight toward the sun. The pice de rsistance might be a mock sea battle, the better for mass drownings, in which the amphitheater would be flooded in the morning and drained in time for the afternoon mayhem. But how, exactly, was all this achieved? With a labyrinthine system of underground pulleys, lifts and trap doors to rival the most elaborate Broadway show, says Heinz-Jrgen Beste of the German Archaeological Institute in Rome. In Colosseum: Roman Death Trap, the first installment of Building Wonders on Nova, Wednesdays on PBS, Mr. Beste proves his point, recreating an ancient lifting machine to release a wolf into the arena. (Check local listings.)

title: From Iphignie To Modern Morsels
description: Glucks operas dont get enough hearings, but the Juilliard School has done well by him in its collaborations with the Metropolitan Opera. The early-music specialist Jane Glover conducted a Met-Juilliard Armide in 2012, and she returns with semi-staged performances of Iphignie en Aulide on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday. The cast includes Yunpeng Wang, Liv Redpath, Ying Fang, Andrew Stenson, Takaoki Onishi and Brandon Cedel. (8 p.m., Tuesday and Thursday, and 2 p.m. Saturday, Peter Jay Sharp Theater, Lincoln Center, 212-769-7406, juilliard.edu.) On Monday, the brilliant keyboard performer Richard Egarr plays Bach and Handel at Carnegie Hall. (7:30 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, carnegiehall.org.) The same night, the New York Philharmonics Contact! series offers new music from Israel jointly presented by the 92nd Street Y, including chamber pieces by Josef Bardanashvili, Avner Dorman, Yotam Haber and Shulamit Ran. (7:30 p.m., SubCulture, 45 Bleecker Street, near Lafayette Street, East Village; 212-875-5656, nyphil.org.)

title: Weeklong Tribute to a Genre Juggler
description: John Boorman, now in his 80s, may not be the most prolific director in movie history, but he has certainly shown versatility, with a rsum that includes the crime drama Point Blank, the fantasy Excalibur and the lighthearted Hope and Glory. Film Forum begins a weeklong tribute to him on Wednesday that includes screenings of those three films and several others, including the movie that provided perhaps the biggest jolt of all, Deliverance, the 1972 survival adventure based on James Dickeys novel.

title: Outliers Defying Easy Definition
description: Masculinity and tradition can seem like stable formulas in modern country, but there will always be those who complicate the math. Sam Hunt is a former football star whose debut album, Montevallo (MCA Nashville), is chock-full of aw-shucks entreaties  including some, like Take Your Time, that sound about as indebted to R&B as to any country norm. On Wednesday, he performs at Irving Plaza. (7 p.m., irvingplaza.com.)

title: Glories of Japan, Aglow at the Met
description: In 1881, a year after opening its building on Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, the Metropolitan Museum of Art received its first official bequest of Japanese art: a collection formed by Stephen Whitney Phoenix, scion of a New York merchant and political family. The Met has since amassed a world-class Japanese collection. That story will be told in Discovering Japanese Art: American Collectors and the Met, opening at the museum on Saturday.

title: The Only Partner He Really Trusts
description: As a child growing up in Taiwan, Huang Yi both longed for and identified with robots. To meet his parents high expectations, he says, he found himself adopting the obedient, emotionless characteristics of a machine. He was also lonely and sought the companionship of something selfless and reliable. These strong emotional currents flow through Huang Yi & KUKA, presented by 3-Legged Dog, making it more than just an amusing exercise in blending dance and technology.

title: The Unreal America
description: Oh, my. Gail Collins tells us  my words, not hers  that Mike Huckabee is running for president as, basically, a Sarah Palin wannabe. Hes the candidate of real Americans, who shoot guns, cook with propane, and would never think of ordering a latte or eating sushi.

title: A Startling Announcement in Yemen
description: Leaders of the Houthi rebels in Yemen announced on Saturday that a national security committee would include four key ministers from the government they ousted last month.

title: At Grammys Event, Bob Dylan Speech Steals the Show
description: LOS ANGELES  At the Grammys annual charity gala on Friday, Bob Dylan stole the show without singing a single note.

title: Appeal to Be Heard in Serial Murder Case
description: A Maryland court has agreed to hear an appeal by Adnan Syed, the man whose murder conviction was investigated in the popular Serial podcast.

title: District of Columbia Sees Loophole in Congresss Move to Halt Marijuana Law
description: WASHINGTON  Last fall, voters in the District of Columbia chose to join a handful of states in legalizing the growth and possession of small amounts of marijuana. But unlike in the states, the free will of district voters  no matter how overwhelmingly expressed  is never the end of the story.

title: An Elaborate Tale of Broken Rims and Moxie
description: With the N.B.A. All-Star Game returning to Madison Square Garden next Sunday, there is sure to be a good deal of talk about New York, and the way the city and its famous arena have long been viewed as basketball meccas, even if many of the best players now come from elsewhere. Mention will surely be made of the citys playgrounds and the formidable players who graced them.

title: Insured, but Not Covered
description: WHEN Karen Pineman of Manhattan received notice that her longtime health insurance policy didnt comply with the Affordable Care Acts requirements, she gamely set about shopping for a new policy through the public marketplace. After all, shed supported President Obama and the act as a matter of principle.

title: A Year Later, Stumbling Creighton Grasps at Hope
description: It has been a long season for Creighton Coach Greg McDermott, one filled with disappointing days and disappointing performances and disappointing results. Saturday was no exception. As he leaned against the wall outside his teams locker room after an 84-66 loss to St. Johns at Madison Square Garden, McDermott wiped his face and exhaled.

title: U.S. Men Make Stunning Leap in the Downhill in the Alpine Championships
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  When the Alpine world ski championships were last on American soil, in 1999, no member of the United States team won a medal. With the championships back in Colorado this month, the event was expected to be a chance for the American racers to show how far they had come as an international power.

title: New Generation of N.B.A. All-Stars Will Add to Legacy at Madison Square Garden
description: The 1968 N.B.A. All-Star Game, at Madison Square Garden, was a special one for Lenny Wilkens, whose deep respect for the arena started when he was growing up in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

title: Brian Williams, Under Scrutiny, Will Take Leave From NBC Nightly News
description: Brian Williams, acknowledging that the scrutiny and criticism he was attracting was becoming a distraction for his network, said on Saturday that he was stepping aside as anchor of NBCs Nightly News for the next several days.

title: In N.H.L. Terms, Snipers Skate Alongside Danglers
description: Washington Capitals Coach Barry Trotz knows an honest game when he sees one  and it has nothing to do with officiating.

title: ESPN Anchors Tenacity Permeates Unexpected Memoir
description: When the longtime ESPN anchor Stuart Scott quietly agreed to write a memoir last year, appendiceal cancer and chemotherapy were weakening him. His appearances on the network were dwindling. His life was slipping away.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: No More, From N.F.L., Only Begs For Action

title: Norm Drucker, Referee Who Felled N.B.A. Giants, Dies at 94
description: Norm Drucker, one of pro basketballs most prominent referees, who notoriously ejected Wilt Chamberlain from a game  the only minutes Chamberlain missed in his epic 1961-62 season  died on Friday. He was 94.

title: New Yorks New Assembly Leader Vows to Aid Blacks
description: Carl E. Heastie, the first African-American to serve as speaker of the New York Assembly, vowed on Saturday to use his powerful new position to call attention to the needs of black New Yorkers.

title: Bruce Jenner Involved in Deadly Car Crash in Malibu
description: LOS ANGELES  Bruce Jenner, the former Olympic champion and reality television star, was involved in a multicar collision in Malibu, Calif., on Saturday that left one person dead and five people injured, the Los Angeles County Sheriffs Department reported.

title: Shiite Militia Drives Back Islamic State, but Divides Much of Iraq
description: CAMP ASHRAF, Iraq  At their victory rally, the Shiite militiamen used poetry, song and swagger to sweeten their celebration of an ugly battle.

title: The Mysterious Death of Alberto Nisman
description: A prosecutor in Argentina accuses the president of attempting to cover up a secret deal to shield terrorists. Days later, the prosecutor is found dead and the president alleges a conspiracy. An overview of key developments in the case.

title: Whodunit? In Obsessed Nation, Question Becomes Who Didnt
description: BUENOS AIRES  The president did it. No, it was the Argentine spymaster plotting against her. Maybe it really was a suicide, the tragic fall of a man whose case was coming undone. Or was it Iran, the Israeli Mossad, the C.I.A.? And what about the lingering influence of the Nazis who fled here after World War II?

title: Multifaceted
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  If you have a fondness for sparkly jewels, this is the Sunday puzzle for you.

title: Health Law Case Poses Conundrum for Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  On the one hand, Republicans in Congress are urging the Supreme Court to strike down subsidies for health insurance provided to millions of people in more than 30 states. On the other, they are chiding the Obama administration because it has no plan to avert the hardship that could occur if they win in court.

title: In Gaza and the West Bank, Love Struggles to Bridge the Separation
description: KHAN YOUNIS, Gaza Strip  He said he fell for her ideas, her thoughts. She said he made her forget she was overweight, and feel beautiful.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: A Sleepless Nights Fancy Nears Space After 17 Years
description: GoreSat is going to space at last.

title: A Startling Announcement in Yemen
description: Leaders of the Houthi rebels in Yemen announced on Saturday that a national security committee would include four key ministers from the government they ousted last month.

title: Mayor of Paris Grows Into Her New Role as Comforter in Chief
description: PARIS  Even after Fox News apologized for broadcasting false claims that Paris was blighted by dangerous Muslim-ruled no-go zones, the mayor of Paris could barely conceal her indignation.

title: Economic Plan Is a Quandary for Hillary Clintons Campaign
description: With advice from more than 200 policy experts, Hillary Rodham Clinton is trying to answer what has emerged as a central question of her early presidential campaign strategy: how to address the anger about income inequality without overly vilifying the wealthy.

title: Alex Vraciu, Indestructible Ace of World War II, Dies at 96
description: Alex Vraciu, who was just 25 when he reigned as the Navys top World War II fighter ace after downing 19 Japanese aircraft and destroying 21 more on the ground in only eight months in 1944, died on Jan. 29 in West Sacramento, Calif. He was 96.

title: Stewart Stern, 92, Screenwriter of Rebel Without a Cause, Dies
description: Stewart Stern, an Academy Award-nominated screenwriter who wrote Rebel Without a Cause, Rachel, Rachel and other acclaimed films before forsaking Hollywood three decades ago, died on Monday in Seattle. He was 92.

title: For Saudis and Pakistan, a Bird of Contention
description: For decades, royal Arab hunting expeditions have traveled to the far reaches of Pakistan in pursuit of the houbara bustard  a waddling, migratory bird whose meat, they believe, contains aphrodisiac powers.

title: The Real America, Continued
description: Not the most reliable numbers, but still: 13.7 million hunters, 20.4 million yoga practitioners.

title: Nigeria Postpones Elections, Saying Security Is a Concern
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Nigerias election agency on Saturday night put off a closely contested presidential election after weeks of pressure to postpone it from the ruling party, which analysts say was facing potential defeat for the first time in more than 15 years.

title: Christine Valmy, Builder of U.S. Skin-Care Business, Dies at 88
description: Christine Valmy, an immigrant from Communist Romania who helped build the professional skin-care industry in the United States from the ground up in the 1960s, founding the countrys first licensed skin-care school and becoming a sought-after authority in the field, died on Jan. 18 in Bucharest. She was 88.

title: Australias Leader Expedites Vote Threatening His Job
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Prime Minister Tony Abbott on Sunday moved forward by a day a vote challenging his leadership, calling for an end to uncertainty before Parliament goes back into session after the summer recess.

title: Jimmy Walker Chases Victory at Event That Has Mowed Down Top Talent
description: SAN DIEGO  Jimmy Walker interrupted golfs youth migration Saturday with this news flash: He did not take his first formal lesson until his junior year in college.

title: Shared Belief Edges California Chrome in Showdown at Santa Anita Park
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  As California Chrome surged in front on the backstretch, the persistent buzz from the crowd at Santa Anita Park escalated to a small roar.

title: Greek Austerity Spawns Fakery: Playing Nurse
description: ATHENS  Fotini Katsigianni wears a white nurses hat that protrudes prominently from the top of her head. She is head nurse at Evangelismos Hospital, one of the citys most prominent.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 7, 2015
John C. Whitehead, Who Led Effort to Rebuild After 9/11, Dies at 92
description: John C. Whitehead, for decades one of New Yorks most prominent citizens, a veteran of D-Day who capped a lauded career on Wall Street and in the State Department by shepherding the first years of the citys fractious effort to rebuild after the 2001 terrorist attacks, died on Saturday at his home in New York. He was 92.

title: Against Knicks, Steve Kerr Sees What Might Have Been. It Isnt Pretty.
description: Steve Kerr hesitated for a split-second and smiled as he walked out of the visitors locker room at Madison Square Garden late Saturdayafternoon and noticed a pack of reporters, several rows deep, waiting to speak to him before his Golden State Warriors played the Knicks.

title: New York City Teaching Assistant Charged With Rape of Mentally Ill Student
description: A New York City substitute teaching assistant was fired on Saturday night hours after she was accused of having sex with a mentally ill 14-year-old student inside her apartment in the Bronx.

title: Billy Casper, Overlooked Titan of Golf, Dies at 83
description: Billy Casper, a two-time United States Open victor, a Masters champion and the player with the seventh most wins in PGA Tour history, died on Saturday at his home in Springville, Utah. He was 83.

title: Devon Bundy and Clovis Maalouf
description: Devon Anais Bundy and Clovis Christopher Maalouf were married Thursday at the summer home of the brides parents in Liberia, Costa Rica. Priscilla Solano Castillo, a Costa Rican lawyer and notary, officiated. On Saturday, Mark Maalouf, the grooms brother, who is a minister of the American Marriage Ministries, led a ceremony that included Arabic wedding traditions.

title: Tulika Mehrotra and Mohit Chopra
description: Tulika Mehrotra and Mohit Chopra were married Wednesday by Carla F. Ward, a magistrate, at the Arlington County Courthouse in Virginia. The couple had a Hindu ceremony Jan. 25 at the Leela Palace hotel and resort in New Delhi, where Pandit Rajendra Shastri officiated.

title: Allegra Ouroussoff and Morgan Eifler
description: Allegra Cecilia Ouroussoff, the daughter of Cecilia Cobb Clarke of Brooklyn and Nicolai Ouroussoff of Manhattan, was married Saturday to Carl Morgan Eifler, a son of Elizabeth Reese Eifler of New Canaan, Conn., and Carl Morgan Eifler of Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Victor L. Austin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

title: James Brodsky and Philip McCarthy II
description: James Sharp Brodsky and Philip Edward McCarthy II were married Saturday at St. James Church in New York. The Rev. Adrian Dannhauser, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Katherine Tyler, Joshua Monroe
description: Katherine Davis Tyler and Joshua James Monroe were married Saturday at St. Anthonys Chapel in Tampa, Fla. The Rev. Timothy H. Sherwood, a cousin of the groom and a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Allison Bailey and Alexander Tanton
description: Allison Kay Bailey and Alexander Herrick Tanton were married on Saturday at the Barr Mansion, an events space in Austin, Tex. The Rev. Christina Branum-Martin, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Their Breakups Wouldnt Take
description: Lindsay Ross Anmuth and Demetrios Peter Yatrakis were married Saturday evening at Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. The Rev. Katherine Jeddah Vailakis, an interfaith minister ordained by the New Seminary, officiated.

title: Jodie Mendelson and Gregory Kay
description: Jodie Anne Mendelson and Gregory Steven Kay are to be married Sunday at the Los Angeles River Center and Gardens, an event space in Los Angeles. Rabbi Shimon Paskow is to officiate.

title: Finally, a Keeper
description: Marcia Marie Larson and Eric Nathan Peiffer were married Saturday at Camelback Bible Church in Paradise Valley, Ariz., where Pastor Tim Savage, a minister ordained by Emmanuel Faith Community Church in Escondido, Calif., officiated.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 57TH ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS L L Cool J (above) returns as host of this ceremony honoring artists in country, hip-hop, jazz, pop and rock and broadcast live from the Staples Center in Los Angeles. Leading the pack with six nominations each are Sam Smith, Pharrell Williams and Beyonc, who, with 53 nominations now has more than any other female performer in the awards history. Iggy Azalea, Jay Z, Sia, Usher, Jack White, Miranda Lambert, Beck, Drake, Eric Church, Gordon Goodwin and the engineer Tom Coyne follow with four. George Harrison, Buddy Guy and the Bee Gees will be honored as this years lifetime achievement recipients. After six years, Kanye West will return to the Grammy stage in a solo performance as well as in a collaboration with Paul McCartney and Rihanna on her new single, FourFiveSeconds. Paired performers include Tony Bennett and Lady Gaga; Hozier and Annie Lennox; Jessie J and Tom Jones; and Adam Levine and Gwen Stefani. Katy Perry, AC/DC, Common, John Legend, Mary J. Blige, Juanes, Ariana Grande, Madonna and Ed Sheeran are also scheduled to take the stage. Pre-event coverage begins at 4 on E!; Pop joins the red carpet at 5; and E! moves to the after-party at 11:30.

title: Corrections: February 8, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Two Lives, in Harmony
description: Under skies as cloudy as her future, Melody Jerez, a young Chilean girl, discovered music, and with it a world of possibility. Years later, she took over a youth orchestra in an even smaller town, where another child, Georgina vila, was similarly entranced.

title: VPNs Dissolve National Boundaries Online, for Work and Movie-Watching
description: Rod Drury, an entrepreneur in Auckland, New Zealand, regularly visits the United States. Sometimes there are multiple visits a day.

title: North Korea Tests Five Missiles
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea fired five short-range missiles off its eastern coast on Sunday in a demonstration of its improving missile technology, the South Korean Defense Ministry said.

title: Childhood Heroes: Once Self-Made, Now to the Manner Born
description: How, I wonder, did I ever miss the difference between yesterdays popular childrens heroes and todays?

title: Deadline Nearing, Iran Presses for Progress in Nuclear Talks
description: MUNICH  Irans foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, said Sunday that Tehran did not favor another extension of the talks on limiting its nuclear program and expected economic sanctions to be quickly lifted if an accord was reached.

title: Irritu Takes Directors Guild Prize
description: The Directors Guild of America on Saturday gave its top prize to Alejandro G. Irritu for Birdman, his backstage tale of a washed-up movie star seeking a comeback on Broadway. He beat out a field that included Richard Linklater (Boyhood) and Clint Eastwood (American Sniper). In the documentary category, Laura Poitras took the honors for Citizenfour, her film about Edward J. Snowden and his revelations about snooping by the National Security Agency.

title: Dean Smith, Champion of College Basketball and of Racial Equality, Dies at 83
description: Dean Smith, who built the University of North Carolina mens basketball team into a perennial national power in his 36 years at Chapel Hill and became one of the games most respected figures for qualities that transcended the court, died on Saturday in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 83.

title: 1915: Lusitania Flew Stars and Stripes to Protect U.S. Lives
description: LONDON  It is now known that the great Cunard liner Lusitania, carrying 700 passengers, including very many prominent Americans, steamed up the Irish Sea under the protection of the American flag, which was only hauled down just before she reached her home port of Liverpool early on Saturday [Feb. 6] morning. Captain David Dows actions in substituting Stars and Stripes for the Red Ensign was obviously intended as a precaution taken as a result of a wireless warning from England. The incident has been widely commented on on both sides of Atlantic.

title: At 50, a Hip-Hop Pioneer Still Has Stories to Tell
description: When Mandy Aragones watches a movie or television show with her husband, Ricky Walters, she is ready for a running commentary.

title: Monroeville, Ala., Home of Harper Lee
description: In Monroeville, the town square has murals depicting scenes from To Kill a Mockingbird, and for several weeks each year, residents perform a play based on the book, acting out some scenes in a former courthouse.

title: After Harper Lee Novel Surfaces, Plots Arise
description: MONROEVILLE, Ala.  One morning late last summer, Tonja B. Carter was doing some legal work for her prized client, Harper Lee, when she found herself thumbing through an old manuscript of what she assumed was To Kill a Mockingbird. The characters were familiar, as they would be to millions of readers  the crusading lawyer, Atticus Finch, and his feisty daughter, Scout. But the passages were different. Atticus was much older. Scout was grown up. The story unfolded in Alabama during the racial turmoil of the 1950s, not the Depression of the 1930s.

title: Basking in Past and Present, in Whimsical and Raw
description: At the end of the night on Saturday, one by one, DAngelos band members took leave of the Apollo Theater stage. Theyd been playing Untitled (How Does It Feel), the solemn declaration of lust that had, thanks to its erotic video 15 years ago, transformed DAngelo from soul music savior to something far trickier, and sweatier. It has become the song that, for many, defines this singer. And it has at times been the song that DAngelo runs away from.

title: You Cant Win Them All? The Globetrotters Beg to Differ
description: Despite an almost certain outcome, the famous exhibition team has kept its routine fresh for nearly 90 years.

title: Cant Win Em All? Globetrotters Come Close
description: ROCHESTER  Lou Dunbar seems happy. He smiles a lot. He laughs constantly. He claims that his job has never felt like a job because he enjoys it too much. And it all begins to make sense once you consider that Dunbar, who goes by Sweet Lou, is the winningest basketball coach in the world.

title: In Treating Ebola, Even Using a Stethoscope Becomes a Challenge
description: Doctors treating Ebola patients while wearing the full spacesuit  protective gear, including waterproof hoods  are struggling with a clinicians dilemma: what to do if they cant use one of the oldest, most basic tools in medicine  a stethoscope.

title: Some Sharp Notes Amid the Performances at Hottest Pre-Grammy Party
description: LOS ANGELES  Clive Daviss annual pre-Grammy party here is always the most star-chocked event connected to the awards, and this years gathering on Saturday night was no exception.

title: Judge Strikes Down Puerto Ricos Debt Restructuring Law
description: Investors in billions of dollars of Puerto Rico bonds secured a major legal victory when a federal judge ruled that the commonwealths recently enacted debt-restructuring law was unconstitutional.

title: 1940: French Raid Soviet Paris Trade Office
description: News that the Soviet trade offices in Paris, as well as the Intourist Bureau and the former Soviet School, were raided by the French police Monday was revealed yesterday [Feb. 8] when the press reproduced a German D.N.B. dispatch from Moscow quoting a Tass Agency announcement of the raids. At the same time, it was disclosed that the French authorities rejected the protest of Jacob Souritz, Soviet Ambassador to France, against the raids. The French government took the stand that the three Russian organizations did not enjoy the privilege of extra-territoriality. The raids were justified on the ground that it was necessary to suppress the Soviet propaganda emanating from these premises, which it was stated, was assuming the dimensions of a veritable fifth column. It was denied officially that the police action had the character of hostility toward a country with which France maintains normal diplomatic relations.

title: As Debaltseve Residents Try to Flee, the Window Closes
description: For seven months, the Ukrainian town of Debaltseve, northeast of the rebel stronghold of Donetsk, has been battered by shelling from rebel forces on all sides.

title: Desperation and Destruction in Contested Ukraine City
description: DEBALTSEVE, Ukraine  A line of furious, bedraggled women, holding tight to their wind-whipped clothes, waited for a chance to fill their plastic jugs from a water truck. Outside city hall, old men and women grabbed desperately at loaves of bread dropped off by Ukrainian troops. A few more gathered inside to recharge their radios and other electronic gear at the community generator.

title: Legislative Lessons
description: A look inside the new Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston.

title: Tycoon and Mubarak Ally Seeks Return to Parliament
description: CAIRO  The steel tycoon who once steered the ruling party for President Hosni Mubarak has filed papers to run again for Parliament in the latest unwinding of the Arab Spring revolt.

title: At Box Office, SpongeBob Outguns Sniper
description: After successfully returning the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles to the multiplex, Paramount has pulled off the same trick with another aging cartoon crew. The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water soaked up a stellar $56 million at North American theaters over the weekend, demonstrating the power of nostalgia and the promotional strength of Nickelodeon, Paramounts corporate sibling.

title: Diverging Fates of Two Veterans Encapsulate the Knicks Misfortune
description: It was a night of imagery, not intrigue, at Madison Square Garden, beginning with Carmelo Anthony being ceremonially handed his All-Star jersey by those distinguished Knicks alumni, Walt Frazier, Allan Houston and John Starks. Then Anthony, in a handsome tapered suit, took a seat on the bench, where he should surely remain with his sore knee for the Knicks final 15 home games after he exhausts his right shoulder shooting jump shots in Sundays dunk-and-pony show at the self-proclaimed Worlds Most Famous Arena.

title: Prime Minister of Greece Will Not Prolong Bailout
description: ATHENS  As pressure grows on Greece to reach a deal with its international creditors and avert fears that it will default on its huge debt, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said Sunday that his government would not seek an extension of a stringent bailout program and would carry out its campaign pledges to roll back austerity, but gradually.

title: Packing Up the Coolers
description: With the Islanders set to move from Nassau Coliseum to Barclays Center in Brooklyn, a tailgating culture supported by die-hard fans is nearing an end.

title: Bidding Farewell to Their Cold Patches of Pavement
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Alex Kleins minibus is painted the green and white of the Jets, but it is also festooned with orange and blue flags, towels and other accouterments.

title: As Debaltseve Residents Try to Flee, The Window Closes
description: For seven months, the Ukrainian town of Debaltseve, northeast of the rebel stronghold of Donetsk, has been battered by shelling from rebel forces on all sides.

title: Looking Back, a Horn Player Dips Into Every Mood
description: Past the midpoint of his second set at Smoke on Friday night, the trumpeter Eddie Henderson announced the first composition he ever wrote, a dose of drifting intrigue titled Dreams. His preamble almost could have seemed sheepish, coming from someone else: Im not really a composer, he said. I just write sketches, and let the band fill them in.

title: Seeing Art in the Diagramed Deal
description: Bridge is primarily a science, but it can also be artistic. In the diagramed deal, for example, how did South play in five clubs doubled after West led his spade ace and continued with a second spade?

title: In the Mold of a Senator Who Bartered
description: When it opens next month in Boston, the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate will be aiming to restore respect for Congress at a time when rancor and partisanship have seriously damaged its reputation.

title: ODonnell Saying Goodbye to The View
description: Rosie ODonnell is leaving ABCs The View at the end of the week to focus on her health and family. Cindi Berger, Ms. ODonnells publicist, told the The New York Posts Page Six that the 52-year-old comedian and actress wanted to spend more time with her five children after separating from her second wife, Michelle Rounds, in November. Rosie has teens and an infant at home that need her attention, Ms. Berger said. This has been a very stressful situation. She is putting her personal health and family first. Ms. ODonnell wont be walking out of the spotlight completely. Rosie ODonnell: A Heartfelt Stand Up, her HBO Documentary special about cardiac health (she suffered a heart attack in 2012), premieres Feb. 14. And a Tweet posted on The View Twitter account said Ms. ODonnell would be back often with her unique point of view and updates on her work and family.

title: With Dream-Girl Stand-Ins, a Riotous Heyday Recalled
description: In the giddy, goofy history of the movie musical as traced in Heres to the Girls!: Hollywoods Leading Ladies, the 92nd Street Ys Lyrics and Lyricists program on Saturday, each major studio had its own pantheon and signature style. One of the most clearly defined, identified as the Warner Bros. Dames, were brassy streetwise characters played by the likes of Ruby Keeler and Joan Blondell.

title: Saucy Temptress Keeps the Temperature Cool
description: As she has risen to stardom over the past decade the Latvian mezzo-soprano Elina Garanca has been one of the most frustrating singers in opera. There are few voices as sheerly lovely as hers: a smooth, evenly produced instrument, rich but not heavy, with high notes that penetrate without blaring.

title: Portrait of the Nation as a Panoply of Hope and Clashing Egos
description: In 1842 Charles Dickens published American Notes, a travelogue detailing impressions formed during a six-month journey up and down the Eastern Seaboard. American Notes is also the title of this seasons commissioning program by the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which invites composers to write works that take the temperature of the country today  not quite a State of the Union, perhaps, so much as a national selfie.

title: In Vietnam, a Tightening Grip on a Flourishing Sector
description: As the government overhauls its information technology policies, running a tech business in Vietnam is getting riskier.

title: Drifters Drop In and Stay for a While
description: To break the fourth wall at The Listeners, Matthew Freemans new play at the Brick, youll need a battering ram. The set is an enclosed, roofless room in the middle of the Bricks black-box space. Audience members can peer at the play through letterbox slits sliced into the walls. If you come early enough to grab a chair in front of one of the two panels of one-way glass, youll enjoy the rare luxury of seeing two or even three characters at once.

title: Prime Minister Tony AbbottKeeps Hold of Job in Party Vote in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Tony Abbott will remain Australias prime minister, fighting off a challenge to his position on Monday by lawmakers from his conservative Liberal Party.

title: Time for All Kinds of Fancy Before the Clock Strikes 12
description: Cinderella, everyone knows, has to squeeze in as much fun as she can before midnight. But a ballet production of Cinderella intended for young children has to abide by an even more inexorable time constraint: the attention span of its audience. New York Theater Ballets  Cinderella, which returned to Florence Gould Hall over the weekend, succeeds in condensing the fairy tale and Prokofievs three-act score down to just over an hour without sacrificing all the fantasy.

title: A Play Space for Rhythm Set on the High Seas
description: In Cambuyn, a percussive dance and music show that opened at the New Victory Theater on Friday, rhythm comes from many sources: wooden crates, metal buckets, matchsticks, glass bottles, kitchen utensils, feet slapping the floor and hands slapping the body. The concept bears more than a little resemblance to Stomp, but in this production by Enlace Servicios Culturales, a company based in the Canary Islands and in Barcelona, all of the tapping and clanging happens aboard a ship whose location in time and space remains open to interpretation.

title: Brooklynite Wins Choreography Award
description: The choreographer, performer and musician Steven Reker of Brooklyn is the winner of the American Dance Institutes second annual Solange MacArthur Award for New Choreography, organizers of that Maryland-based nonprofit announced Sunday. The award recognizes a rising American choreographer with financial and administrative support for presenting a commissioned work. Mr. Reker said in a statement that the award, which includes a $10,000 commission, would allow him to create a piece I have wanted to make for years but could only imagine making since my resources are somewhat limited in NYC. Mr. Reker was selected by the institutes artistic advisory board  which includes the choreographers Brian Brooks, David Dorfman and Doug Elkins  after a closed nomination process. The award is named for Solange MacArthur, a former member of American Ballet Theater and supporter of the institute, who died in 2012. The first recipient was Chris Schlichting of Minnesota.

title: Wolsey Angels to Go to the V&A Museum
description: The Victoria and Albert Museum surpassed its goal on Sunday of raising 2.5 million pounds ($3.8 million) to purchase four statues created by the Italian sculptor Benedetto da Rovezzano for the tomb of Cardinal Thomas Wolsey, an adviser to Henry VIII and once one of Englands most powerful men. The statues, known as the Wolsey Angels, were commissioned in 1524, just before the cardinal lost his power after failing to convince the pope to annul the kings marriage. The cardinal appeared in Hilary Mantels novel Wolf Hall. Ms. Mantel said in a statement that the recovery of the angels is one of those miracles that historians pray for; something that seems irrevocably lost has been there all the time. After Wolseys death in 1530, Henry VIII acquired the statues for his own tomb, which was never completed. They were eventually sold during the 1640s to raise money during Englands Civil War and were unheard of again until two surfaced at an auction in 1994. The other pair was discovered in 2008 at a country house in Northamptonshire in central England. The majority of the funds for the purchase came from a two-million pound grant from the National Heritage Memorial Fund, while another 500,000 pounds came from the Art Fund, a charity that helps British museums purchase art. Additional funds came from donations and museum supporters  including 33,000 pounds from on-site donations and one-pound Save the Wolsey Angels badges. The statutes are on display at the museum but will be temporarily removed to undergo conservation treatment.

description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Were looking deeply into our Monday grid today. Lynn Lempel is back, and shes hidden a famous childrens book character in our puzzle.

description: CAIRO  Egypt began moving on Sunday toward a retrial of two journalists whose yearlong incarceration has drawn widespread condemnation from Western governments and human rights groups. Defense lawyers raised alarms that the government was failing to fulfill a deal for the imminent release of one of them.

title: A Black Correspondent at the Front

He was also, toward the end of the Civil War, the only black war correspondent for a major daily newspaper.

title: Uncovering Security Flaws in Digital Education Products for Schoolchildren
description: When Tony Porterfields two sons came home from elementary school with an assignment to use a reading assessment site called Raz-Kids.com, he was curious, as a parent, to see how it worked. As a software engineer, he was also curious about the sites data security practices.

title: Soccer Stadium Stampede Kills at Least 25 in Egypt
description: CAIRO  At least 25 soccer fans died on Sunday in a confrontation with the police at the gates of a stadium, morgue officials said, in the latest flash of violence to confront the military-backed government as it struggles to restore security 18 months after coming to power.

title: Police Force in Afghanistan Is Studied for Ties to Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  When Mullah Mujahid, a Taliban commander in Kunduz Province, was arrested last month, there was little reason to think it would have much consequence, either for him or for the government of Afghanistan.

One is an Emmy-winning, sober, talented anchor on the NBC Nightly News and the other is a funny, urbane celebrity who hosts Saturday Night Live, slow-jams the news with Jimmy Fallon and crushes it in every speech and public appearance he makes.

title: Ferguson One of 2 Missouri Suburbs Sued Over Gantlet of Traffic Fines and Jail
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Herbert Nelson Jr. says he was 18 the first time the police pulled him over. The ticket, for speeding, felt small in the moment. But more traffic tickets piled up, as did warrants for failing to appear in court or pay his fines. So Mr. Nelson, now 26, has found himself repeatedly jailed in this St. Louis suburb and in the maze of municipalities nearby  part of a pattern that black residents here complain has grown all too common.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 7:15 P.M. (HBO Signature) BELLE (2014) The biracial daughter (Gugu Mbatha-Raw) of a British Navy captain (Matthew Goode) struggles to transcend life as a black woman in slave-trading England after being raised in privilege by her aristocratic uncle and aunt (Tom Wilkinson and Emily Watson), and alongside her white cousin (Sarah Gadon, above right, with Ms. Mbatha-Raw), in this biopic about the historical figure Dido Elizabeth Belle (1761-1804). Directed by Amma Asante and written by Misan Sagay, the film chronicles the challenging love life of Belle, an educated beauty  including a dashing suitor, John Davinier (Sam Reid), as well as several not-so-charming ones. The movie also covers Belles uncle, the lord chief justice who must decide on a case involving a Zong slave ship on which more than 130 Africans were massacred for an insurance payment. The movie plays with the historical record for dramatic effect, as is often the case when the past is disinterred for entertainment, and its realism at times groans under the weight of too many passionate speeches, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Yet the weave of the personal and the political finally proves as irresistible as it is moving, partly because it has been drawn from extraordinary life.

description: Many economists, including Janet Yellen, view global economic troubles since 2008 largely as a story about deleveraging  a simultaneous attempt by debtors almost everywhere to reduce their liabilities. Why is deleveraging a problem? Because my spending is your income, and your spending is my income, so if everyone slashes spending at the same time, incomes go down around the world.
