description: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 5 article, Among New York Subways Millions of Riders, a Study Finds Many Mystery Microbes.

title: Should Brian Williamss Misleading Personal Account of a 2003 Event Cast Doubt on His Journalistic Integrity?
description: NBC Nightly News anchor and managing editor Brian Williams is facing criticism for embellishing an account of an incident that occurred when he was working as a reporter in Iraq in 2003. Over the years he came to say that he was in a helicopter that was hit by enemy fire, an assertion he now says is not true. He now says he was in a trailing helicopter, and that he conflated the two aircraft.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: Whats the Local Version of a Wintry Mix?
description: Good morning on this unpleasant Monday.

title: New Claims That HSBC Aided Tax Evaders
description: HSBC found itself under fire again on Monday after news reports over the weekend provided more details about long-running accusations that its Swiss private banking arm helped clients hide billions of dollars in assets from international tax authorities before 2007.

title: Daily Report: Rivalry Brewing Between Uber and Google
description: When Googles venture capital arm poured more than $250 million into Uber in 2013, it looked like a match made in tech heaven, Mike Isaac reports.

title: How to Prioritize and Save Young Lives
description: In an ad during the Super Bowl last week, Nationwide Insurance chillingly reminded us that accidents are the No. 1 killer of children. Aside from the odd setting for the commercial, one of the reasons that it shocked so many people in the United States is that we have a disconnect between what we think kills children and what really does.

title: Greece: The Tie That Doesnt Bind
description: Relations between Greece and its creditors are not improving. Was this bad diplomacy on the part of Tsipras/Varoufakis? Maybe, but my guess is that there was nothing they could do to avoid a bitter confrontation short of immediate betrayal of the voters who put them in office. And creditor-country officials are acting as if they still expect that to happen, just as it has repeatedly over the past five years.

title: Seeking a Beautiful Death
description: Virgie Divinigracia had the kind of death last month that most Americans say they want: at home, relieved of physical and mental pain, surrounded by those she loved, a beautiful death as those present described it. Alas, this is true for too few Americans. Most still die in costly medical facilities tethered to machines, often unable to communicate, in a futile attempt to prolong their lives.

title: David Axelrods Believer
description: Would Barack Obama have been elected president without David Axelrod?

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 9, 2015
description: Updated: Feb. 10, 2015

title: Today in Politics
description: House Vote to Put G.O.P. and Obama Closer to Keystone Showdown

title: Morning Agenda: U.S. Takes On Payday Lenders
description: U.S. TAKES ON PAYDAY LENDERS | The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will soon release the first draft of federal regulations to govern a wide range of short-term loans made by the $46 billion payday loan industry, Jessica Silver-Greenberg reports in DealBook. The rules are expected to address expensive credit backed by car titles and some installment loans that stretch longer than the traditional two-week payday loan, according to industry lawyers, consumer groups and government authorities briefed on the discussions.

title: From Beyonc to Sam Smith: The Worst Trend of the Grammys (and Every Other Award Ceremony)
description: There were many folks who looked surprisingly good at the Grammy Awards on Sunday, managing to combine rock n roll edge with actual elegance (chief among them in my book: Nicki Minaj in Tom Ford, Iggy Azalea in Armani Priv, and Gwen Stefani in her Versace jumpsuit), but really, who could keep track?

title: Insiders and Outsiders Redux
description: Matt OBrien praises Larry Summers for his dont raise rates op-ed, and rightly so  or at least I agree, and have been saying the same thing, and even using the same imagery. But Im interested in Matts remark that Larry would have made a good Fed chairman. Quite possibly  but would he be saying the same thing if he were in fact at the Fed?

title: Shots Fired Near Marseille on Day of French Prime Ministers Visit
description: PARIS  Several men fired shots in the air on Monday in a poor suburb of Marseille while the French prime minister, Manuel Valls, was in the city to defend the governments local security plan, police officials said. No one was wounded.

title: Verbatim: The Life of a President
description: President Obama, in an interview with Vox, on paying attention to chaos in the world.

title: In China,Heavy Industry Unexpectedly Falls Sharply
description: HONG KONG  As demand dwindles, steel prices in China have fallen 12 percent in the first five weeks of this year, almost as much as in all of 2014.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Egypts Leader Seeks Inquiry Into Soccer Stadium Deaths
description: CAIRO  President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi on Monday called for an investigation into a confrontation with riot police officers that killed at least 25 people at the gates of a soccer stadium here, as prosecutors ordered the arrest of the leaders of a fan group.

title: Gay Marriage in Alabama Begins, but Only in Parts
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Despite a federal judges rulings legalizing same-sex marriage, most probate judges in Alabama on Monday refused to issue marriage licenses to gay and lesbian couples, escalating a legal showdown that echoed the battles over desegregation here in the 1960s.

title: Boyhoods Bafta Wins Put It Neck and Neck With Birdman
description: Going into Sunday, it looked like Alejandro G. Irritus Birdman would assuredly, in one fell feathered swoop, land the best picture and best director Oscars on Feb. 22. On Saturday night, the Directors Guild of America give the picture and Mr. Irritu its top award, the other major guilds  the producers and the actors  having already done the same. As several Oscar prognosticators noted, the only film that ever won all three guild awards only to lose best picture was Apollo 13, in 1996. (It lost to Braveheart.)

title: Twitter Reports a Surge in Government Data Requests
description: Twitter on Monday released its twice-yearly transparency report, showing a surge in government requests for users Twitter information.

title: Playwrights Horizons Season Includes World Premiere by Anne Washburn
description: The Off Broadway Playwrights Horizons theater company announced the six productions for its 2015-16 season on Monday. They include a world premiere by Anne Washburn  the author of the critically acclaimed drama Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play  and works by Taylor Mac (A 24-Decade History of Popular Music), Danai Gurira (In the Continuum) and Jordan Harrison (Maple and Vine).

title: Special Deal on Paul Taylor Tickets Will Leave You Money for Burgers, Too
description: One of the great bargains in New York is coming back: Paul Taylors newly reconstituted dance company, Paul Taylors American Modern Dance, is planning a March 10 performance at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center where all tickets will be two for $15.

title: 1940: Lebrun Visits British Troops
description: WITH THE BRITISH ARMY IN FRANCE  For the first time since the war began President Albert Lebrun of the French Republic visited the British Expeditionary Force today [Feb. 9]. From Paris, he came to British field headquarters in his own one-car private train. Here at the station he was met by Viscount General Gort, Commander-in-Chief of the B.E.F. The day was one of raw, humid penetrating cold. President Lebrun and his party went to the headquarters of the Welsh Guards. There they inspected some of the troops, visited their billets and chatted with a group of schoolchildren, who heralded the Presidents arrival by singing the Marseillaise. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 10, 1940

title: British Pottery, Illustrated
description: From a series for T in which the artist Leanne Shapton makes new artworks from pictures in old books.

title: China Tells Schools to Suppress Western Ideas, With One Big Exception
description: BEIJING  They are out there, hiding in library stacks, whispering in lecture halls, armed with dangerous textbooks and subversive pop quizzes: foreign enemies plotting a stealthy academic invasion of Chinese universities.

title: Icahn to Get Boards Seats in Settlement With Manufacturer Manitowoc
description: First, the Manitowoc Company announced that it would split itself in two, after facing pressure from two of the most prominent activist shareholders around.

title: Dean Smith Was Pioneer in Use of Analytics
description: For decades, Coach Dean Smith would tell his players, both at halftime and after a game, how many points they had scored and had allowed per possession. In the 1960s, he began to assign managers to track the statistic.

title: Stressed by Money? Get on the Couch
description: I felt calm as I sat on a blue couch for my close encounter with the nascent field of financial therapy. I watched as Joel Reimer, a fit, 50-something man in a golf shirt, put sensors on my thumb and fingers.

title: Deloitte Chooses Female Chief Executive
description: Deloitte said on Monday that it had chosen Cathy Engelbert as its chief executive, making it the first of the big four accounting and consulting firms in the United States to be headed by a woman.

title: Former Spy Chief in South Korea Sentenced in Election Case
description: JEJU, South Korea  In a political blow to President Park Geun-hye, a South Korean appeals court on Monday convicted a former government intelligence chief on charges of intervening in the 2012 vote that elected her president.

title: Obama Awaits Outcome of Ukraine Peace Talks Before Deciding on Arms
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Monday that he would wait for the outcome of peace talks before deciding whether to provide lethal weapons to Ukraine. Such assistance would represent a striking break with European allies who say that arming the country against Russian aggression would make the conflict worse.

title: Political Talks in Yemen Hit Turbulence From the Start
description: SANA, Yemen  Feuding political parties resumed United Nations-mediated talks with the Houthi militants controlling Yemens capital on Monday, but two parties withdrew within hours complaining of threats from the Houthis.

title: The 70s-Inspired Rock of Tor Miller
description: Sitting on a couch under a poster of James Dean at a temporary apartment in West Hollywood, Tor Miller is recalling his journey from New York University student to his current status as a singer-songwriter on the precipice of fame. His debut EP, Headlights, out now, has garnered impressive buzz  its lead track, Hold the Phone, was recently dubbed the hottest record in the world by the influential BBC DJ Zane Lowe.

title: On the Homeless Beat: Reporters Notebook
description: On Feb. 9, the Metro reporter Winnie Hu wrote an article about the unsheltered homeless, a relatively small subset of New York Citys homeless population, and the citys plan to devote more resources to what homeless advocates say is a growing demographic.

title: First Draft Focus: Merkel Comes to Washington
The 10 Best Dressed at the 57th Grammy Awards
description: Stars honored a more serious tone than usual at last nights event and opted for monochromatic, glamorous looks.

title: 1965: France Bars Malcolm X
description: PARIS  French authorities today [Feb. 9] barred Malcolm X from entering the country to deliver a talk. The American black nationalist leader arrived from London at Orly International Airport this morning, learned from French security officials that his presence was undesirable, and was put on a flight back to London two hours later. An Interior Ministry spokesman said it was decided that a meeting Malcolm X was to address tonight could provoke demonstrations that would trouble the public order.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 10, 1965

title: Its Monday. Why Does It Always Have to Be a Snow Day?
description: All around me, doors are swinging open and closed, boots are dripping on the wood floor, the dog is jumping up and down with white flakes on her snout, siblings are arguing over who gets more of the shoveling money, and my husband is reorganizing our books and doing the laundry.

title: Climate Is Big Issue for Hispanics, and Personal
description: WASHINGTON  Alfredo Padilla grew up in Texas as a migrant farmworker who followed the harvest with his parents to pick sugar beets in Minnesota each summer. He has not forgotten the aches of labor or how much the weather  too little rain, or too much  affected the family livelihood.

title: American Sniper Trial Sets Town on Edge
description: STEPHENVILLE, Tex.  The trial of the man charged with killing Chris Kyle, a former sniper for the Navy SEALs, is scheduled to open here on Wednesday at 9 a.m. The blockbuster war movie about Mr. Kyle, American Sniper, now playing at Cinemark Cinema 6 three miles from the courtroom, will be showing at 3:40 p.m., 7 p.m. and 10:20 p.m.

title: After Criticism, India Police Arrest 8 in Haryana Rape-Murder
description: NEW DELHI  Under mounting criticism for their slow response to a missing persons report filed last week, the police in the Indian state of Haryana arrested eight men on Monday suspected of raping and murdering a mentally impaired woman whose battered body was found in a field.

title: Airbag Is Approved, but Ski Racers Are Largely Shunning It for Now
description: MOLVENA, Italy  Broken collarbones. Shattered shoulders. Internal bleeding. Punctured lungs. Those injuries, and worse, are possible every time a world-class skier plunges out of a starting gate and slides down a snowy racecourse.

title: Henk Tijms: Dropping Balls Into Bins
description: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Henk Tijms, a Dutch mathematician and emeritus professor at the VU University Amsterdam. We first met Dr. Tijms about a year ago through his Devils Penny. This new puzzle has a similar feel, but is a bit more challenging. Lets play

title: Whiteheads Storied Career Beyond Goldman Sachs Is Hard to Reproduce
description: The storied career that John C. Whitehead led over the past 70 years or so is virtually impossible to imagine on Wall Street today.

title: The Morning After the Grammys, Kanye West Speaks Out About Beck
description: The morning after the Grammys, Kanye West was still feeling charged.

title: The S.E.C.s Hazy Approach to Crime and Punishment
description: In Gilbert and Sullivans The Mikado, a line expresses the need to let the punishment fit the crime. The Securities and Exchange Commission is struggling with that notion when it decides whether to grant a waiver to an automatic bar from certain securities trading.

title: Comparisons With Others Can Obscure Our Own Goals
description: On and off over the years, I have used a training app called Strava. It allows you to keep track of your performance on different biking, running and skiing trails. You can even break down overall times into sections or compare your performance over the entire trail.

title: Unearthed From Towns Archives: Copy of Magna Carta From 1300
description: A tattered copy of the Magna Carta has been discovered in the archives of the municipality of Sandwich, a sleepy seaside town in eastern England, according to the local government and a historian at the University of East Anglia.

title: A Sprawling Manor for $125,000 (Some Disassembly Required)
description: YORKTOWN, N.Y.  It might just be one of the greatest real estate deals in New York. For $125,000, a roughly 8,000-square-foot Tudor home overlooking lakes and forests in a nature preserve here is up for grabs, the epitome of baronial-bucolic Westchester County living.

title: Training Birds to Aid a Scientific Breakthrough
description: Humans have probably been pondering the flight of birds as long as there have been humans. And in the age of science, it would seem that every aspect of flight had been studied in order to build flying machines, from passenger airplanes to tiny robots.

title: ScienceTake | Weighing Flight
description: With a new device scientists measure the force of a wingbeat while birds fly freely.

title: Best Selling Science Books
description: 1 BEING MORTAL, by Atul Gawande. Metropolitan/Holt. The surgeon and New Yorker writer on how doctors fail patients at the end of life, and how they can do better. (Last months ranking: 2)

title: Tracking Where Same-Sex Marriage Is Being Refused
description: Counties where probate judges are declining to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples in Alabama, according to Freedom to Marry.

title: The 10 Best Dressed at the 57th Grammy Awards
description: At the Grammy awards, showstopping red carpet looks are usually only outdone by shocking onstage performance costumes. But this year, the most dramatic trend was the color black; and in a move as respectful and somber as many of last nights messages (moments during the telecast acknowledged and condemned domestic and racially motivated violence), singers left their gimmicky, theatrical costumes at home. Instead they stepped out in their monochromatic and glamorous best, which was for the most part either marked by cutouts or inspired by mens dressing.

title: Afghan Strike Is Said to Kill Commander Linked to ISIS
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A former Taliban commander who had recently pledged allegiance to the Islamic State militant group was killed in a military operation in Helmand Province on Monday, according to Afghan officials and a tribal elder in the area.

title: Joan Didion: From the Face of Celine to the Subject of a New Photography Exhibition
description: This Thursday, Julian Wassers images of the iconic American author will be on display at New York Citys Danziger Gallery.

title: Key Points From the Obama-Merkel News Conference
description: President Obama held a joint news conference with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Monday after their discussion of the crisis in Ukraine, nuclear negotiations with Iran and how to confront the Islamic State. Here are some key points.

title: Bringing the Ocean to a Sea
description: Q. Has anyone suggested piping or channeling water from the Pacific Ocean to the Salton Sea to replenish the disappearing body of water?

title: Scenes of Same-Sex Marriage, and Rejection, Across Alabama
description: New York Times reporters have fanned out across Alabama to explore and explain how the same-sex marriage process is playing out in a handful of locations.

title: Jeb Bush Website With 250,000 Emails Will Start Tuesday
description: Jeb Bush said he would launch a website on Tuesday on which he will make available about 250,000 emails from his time as governor of Florida, as well as the first chapter of an e-book about his administration.

title: Charlie Chaplins First Oscar Is Reported Stolen
description: PARIS  Charlie Chaplins 1929 honorary Oscar statuette was stolen in Paris late last month from the offices of the Association Chaplin, according to the organization.

title: Pope Francis As Unifier
description: Soon after Jorge Bergoglio became Pope Francis, I wrote severalpiecesexploring the idea that the new popemight be striving to effectively transcend the liberal/conservative civil war thats dominated Catholic life in the West since the Second Vatican Council, and find a new synthesis or center for the church somewhere beyond that post-1960s conflict.I have not written as much on that theme in the last year, mostly because of whats been happening with the debate around divorce and communion: There the popes choices have at least temporarily added fuel to Catholicisms internal conflict, rather than cooling it, in ways that threaten to overshadow other elements of his agenda, other possibilities for his time as Peter.

title: Rubles Fall Tests Governor of Russias Central Bank
description: MOSCOW  Elvira S. Nabiullina, the governor of Russias central bank, was deep into a speech about her new currency policy when it became clear nobody was paying attention.

title: Partying After the Grammys
description: Warner Music Group hosted a party at the Chateau Marmont, and GQ and Giorgio Armani joined forces at the Hollywood Athletic Club.

title: For Its Next Big Project, Creative Time Heads to Central Park
description: It was hard to miss the nonprofit public arts organization Creative Times most recent large-scale production, the artist Kara Walkers blockbuster A Subtlety, staged at the decommissioned Domino Sugar Factory in Brooklyn last spring. If you didnt catch it in person, surely you saw it on Instagram, where it seemed every one of its 140,000 visitors took a selfie to commemorate the pilgrimage. This year, Creative Time will head to Manhattan with Drifting in Daylight: Art in Central Park, which will feature seven to 10 sculptural, social and interactive works commissioned by the Central Park Conservancy to celebrate its 35 years of stewardship of the islands largest green space.

title: My Little Pony and Transformers Toys Help Lift Hasbro Sales, and Its Profit Jumps
description: Strong sales of Transformers action figures, My Little Pony products and other licensed toys helped Hasbros revenue rise 5 percent last year, despite negative currency fluctuations and broader industry woes.

title: Partying After the Grammys
description: After Sam Smith crooned and Kanye West robo-sang, the Grammy action on Sunday night migrated from Staples Center to parties all over the Los Angeles area.

title: Same-Sex Marriages Proceed in Parts of Alabama
description: On Monday, some probate judges in the state began issuing licenses in defiance of an order from the states chief justice.

title: Chinese Phone Upstarts Sell With Personality, Not Product
description: HONG KONG  It looked like a classic tech product introduction: There was a room packed with fans, a huge screen lit with slick shots of smartphones, and an entrepreneur in dark clothes.

title: Lincoln Center Segal Awards Expand Field of Honorees
description: In the 28 years since they were established the Martin E. Segal Awards have involved a low-key luncheon that honors two rising artists chosen by two of Lincoln Centers 11 resident organizations. Each was awarded $7,500, to be used for career advancement and future study.

title: Twyla Tharp to Debut New Works on Anniversary Tour
description: The choreographer Twyla Tharp is celebrating the 50th anniversary of her choreographic debut with a national tour this fall. Ms. Tharp said on Monday that she plans to take 12 dancers on the road performing a program of new works set to music by Bach, Henry Butler, Steven Bernstein and John Zorn. The tour is to open in Dallas on Sept. 18, and will include stops in Beverly Hills, Calif.; Chicago; Denver; and Washington  with stops in at least 15 cities total  before wrapping up at Lincoln Center on Nov. 22. A detailed schedule has yet to be announced.

title: A Business Plan for Space
description: Who can own the moon? Or an asteroid? Or a homestead on Mars?

title: Training the Mind Not to Wander
description: A wandering mind can lead to accidents and lost productivity. Now, a study finds that real-time brain monitoring can be used to help people regain focus.

title: Bafta Awards
description: The looks on display in London provided a sedate counterpart to those at the flashier Grammys, also held Sunday.

title: Investors Should Know Pay Gap Between C.E.O.s and Workers
description: Richard Trumka is the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the nations main labor federation.

title: League Appoints Medical Adviser
description: Nagged by concerns that greater efforts are needed to safeguard players, the N.F.L. on Monday named its first chief health and medical adviser.

title: Sidecar, a Ride-Hailing Start-Up, Pushes Into Package Delivery
description: Start-ups like Uber and Lyft are making it acceptable to carpool with total strangers. In the future, you may start carpooling with their lunch.

title: Obama and Netanyahu Clash From Afar Over Israelis Planned Speech
description: WASHINGTON  The latest conflict between President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel erupted into public view on Monday, as the two leaders clashed from afar over Mr. Netanyahus plans to visit Washington next month and the direction of negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program.

title: Rubio, Eye on 2016, Hires a Coveted Former Aide to Romney
description: Senator Marco Rubio has hired a coveted former aide to Mitt Romney to oversee his political activities in the Northeast and probably in a New Hampshire campaign, signaling that he is serious about a presidential bid.

title: Interview Excerpt: Sheikha Hoor Al Qasimi on Hosting her First Biennial
description: Qasimi talks to Carol Kino about her experiences in 2003, when she took over the biennial from her father.

title: Migrants Are Plucked From Sea Off Libya, but 29 Die Aboard Italian Rescue Ships
description: ROME  Twenty-nine migrants who were rescued alive in rough seas off the Libyan coast died before the Italian Coast Guard could get them to shore, officials said on Monday.

title: Joan Didion: From the Face of Cline to the Subject of a New Photography Exhibition
description: Last month, an online fracas erupted when Cline released its campaign featuring a sunglass-shaded, 80-year-old Joan Didion photographed by Juergen Teller. Was the image a step forward for feminism, or had Didions personal style eclipsed the substance of her work? Julian Wasser, for his part, was merely perplexed. I dont know how that happened, says the photographer from his home in Los Angeles. I dont know how she fit into that, because shes just a down-to-earth, regular person.

title: Turning Carbon Dioxide Into Rock, and Burying It
description: HENGILL, Iceland  In a cramped work trailer not far from Icelands largest geothermal power plant, a researcher pored over a box of core samples  cylinders of rock that a drilling rig had pulled from deep underground just a few minutes before.

title: Matt Harvey, in Camp Early, Says His Arm Feels Strong
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Beneath a benign blue sky that beckons frozen snowbirds to Florida was an even more tantalizing sight on the scoreboard at Tradition Field, where the Mets train each spring: a large picture of Matt Harvey in full windup.

title: Skiing in the Place of Legends
description: Johnny Collinson, Ian McIntosh and guide Joey Vallone ride a dangerous line skied by past legends of La Grave, France.

title: Apple Grabs 93% of the Handset Industrys Profit, Report Says
description: Apples record-breaking holiday quarter, which brought in$18 billion in earnings, allowed the company to capture 93 percent of the profit in the handset industry, according to a new report from Canaccord Genuity, an investment firm.

title: In Performance | Ailyn Prez
description: The soprano Ailyn Prez sings an excerpt from Micalas aria in Bizets Carmen, which runs through March 7 at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Estado Islmico suma pocas victorias a medida que disminuyen sus rehenes
description: Read this article in English.

title: For Domestic Airlines, Open Skies Have Limits
description: WHY should business travelers care about the confounding complexities in the debate over international aviation accords known as open skies agreements?

title: Push-Ups, and Some Zen, at the Baggage Carousel
description: I WENT to New York about 15 years ago with plans on becoming a dot-com zillionaire. I moved right before the first dot-com bubble burst, so that didnt work out. Then I figured I needed an actual skill and I enrolled in N.Y.U.s Interactive Telecommunications Program at the Tisch School of the Arts.

title: Obama Defends Refusal to Meet Netanyahu
description: During an appearance with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, President Obama defended his decision not to meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel two weeks before the election there.

title: Merkel and Obama United on Ukraine
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Obama said the alliance between the United States and Europe remained strong, despite potential disagreements on whether to provide arms to Ukraine.

title: Unchanged for More Than Two Billion Years
description: Scientists have discovered micro-organisms living beneath the ocean floor that appear to have not evolved for more than two billion years, a finding that nonetheless may support the theory of evolution.

title: Justice Clarence Thomas Faults Court on Same-Sex Marriage Decision
description: In his dissent, Justice Thomas denounced the Supreme Courts decision not to intervene in Alabamas legal dispute regarding same-sex marriage.

title: Justice Thomass Dissent Hints of Supreme Courts Intentions on Same-Sex Marriage
description: The Supreme Courts decision on Monday not to delay same-sex marriage in Alabama offered the strongest signal yet that gay rights advocates are likely to prevail in coming months in their decades-long quest to establish a nationwide constitutional right to same-sex marriage.

title: Dont Speak to Congress, Mr. Netanyahu
description: JERUSALEM  If Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is correct, if the leaks are to be believed, the Obama administration is edging toward an agreement with Iran that would temporarily restrict, but not eliminate, Irans capacity to eventually produce nuclear weapons. The government of Israel finds these terms dangerous.

title: Review: Tuck Everlasting Swaps Out the Circle of Life for an Eternally Unspooling Ribbon
description: ATLANTA  A ballet was once a staple of the American musical in the 1940s, when the form first grew to maturity. But dancers swirling through dream sequences havent been seen much for the past few decades or more, as more vernacular movement  or little dance at all  has become standard. So its a wonder, and a pleasure, that the stirring climax of the new family musical Tuck Everlasting, making its premiere at the Alliance Theater here, consists of a gorgeous, sweeping ballet that dramatizes the life of its heroine, as she grows from young girl to young woman to motherhood and beyond.

title: Greece to Propose a Debt Compromise Plan to Creditors
description: ATHENS  Hoping to defuse a standoff that has set Europe and financial markets on edge, Greek officials intend to propose a detailed compromise plan at an emergency meeting with creditors on Wednesday in Brussels, a finance ministry official here said on Monday.

title: European Leaders Debate Aid to Ukraine, but Not Russias Transgressions
description: MUNICH  It was at the venerable Munich Security Conference in 2007 that Vladimir Putin first sounded the resentful Cold War blast that now defines his foreign policy, bitterly accusing the United States of seeking a monopoly on global power. Subsequent Munich conferences were marked by desultory efforts to reset the relationship, to maintain the appearance at least of collegiality. All that was before Ukraine.

title: Gay Weddings Held in Parts of Alabama
description: Same-sex couples wed in Birmingham on the first day that Alabama issued same-sex marriage licenses.

title: Your Letters: Supplement Standards, New Teeth and Bingo
description: Nutrition

title: China Hits Qualcomm With Fine
description: HONG KONG  In the last decade, foreign technology companies have plowed billions into China in the hopes of tapping into a fast-growing market. Now that the country has the worlds most Internet users and its largest smartphone market, multinationals are bumping into a regulatory ceiling.

title: Womens Beanpot: Also a Battle for Boston
description: The tournament, which features Harvard, Northeastern, Boston College and Boston University, has grown significantly in its 37 years, but it is still looking for recognition from a larger audience.

title: Women Seek a Bigger Beanpot
description: BOSTON  Before the first womens Beanpot hockey tournament, in 1979, Harvard Coach Joe Bertagna purchased a two-toned brown beanpot for $6 at Howards Flying Dragon Antiques in Essex, Mass.

title: David Brock Resigns From the Board of a Pro-Hillary Clinton Super PAC
description: The intense jockeying for money and position around Hillary Rodham Clintons likely presidential campaign burst into the open on Monday when a top Clinton ally resigned from the board of a super PAC preparing to raise hundreds of millions of dollars to support her bid.

title: Walkabout: Selfie Stick Bans at Several Notable New York Attractions
description: Backlash Some of New York Citys premier attractions, including the Museum of Modern Art and The Guggenheim, are restricting the use of selfie sticks, which are long rods that hold smartphones and allow individuals and groups to take more expansive photos. (Skift)

title: Ex-Wife of Suspect in Patz Case Testifies That He Confessed to Something Terrible
description: They had been dating only a short time when Pedro Hernandez decided it was time to level with the woman he would eventually marry.

title: From Smartphones to Museum Walls
description: The idea of using small cameras to document the world around you led the Columbus Museum of Art to mount an ambitious show of Instagram photos.

title: Fixing Climate in Iceland
description: CarbFix, a pilot program at Icelands Hellisheidi Geothermal Power Station, seeks to tackle climate change by injecting greenhouse gasses into the ground for permanent storage.

title: Criticism, but No Penalty, for Dolan
description: James L. Dolan, the Knicks owner, will not face discipline from the N.B.A. over a vitriolic email he sent in response to a critical fan, a league spokesman said Monday.

title: Bumpy Start for Jeb Bush Tech Hire
description: Jeb Bushs new technology guru had a rough first day on the job, finding himself in a social media storm over some old Twitter posts.

title: A Never-Ending Genetic Quest
description: There has never been a scientific career quite like Mary-Claire Kings. Years ago, her doctoral thesis concluded that humans and chimpanzees were, genetically speaking, 99 percent the same  a revolutionary thought. Her later work on human cancers resulted in the discovery of the so-called breast cancer gene, BRCA1, which transformed the diagnosis and treatment of the disease.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Syria and More  Pictures of the Day

title: An Incubator for Innovation
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  To halt climate change, the world desperately needs advances in clean energy. But in recent years, Silicon Valley, the nations engine for technical innovation, has turned its back on investments in the field.

title: Review: A Jerome Robbins Tribute by New York City Ballet Brims With Brio
description: This season, New York City Ballet has been organizing some of its repertory programs by nationality of composer. American composers got their turn during the Saturday matinee at the David H. Koch Theater. Yet the American most heavily represented was a choreographer: Jerome Robbins.

title: Review: Being Mortal and The Forgotten Plague Explore Death and Disease
description: The end of life. The very end. The worst-case scenario. What might happen down the road. The issue. The unfixable problem.

title: Review: In The Whites, Richard Price Tries on a Pseudonym in a World of Brooding Cops
description: The Whites, the title of Richard Prices riveting new novel, is a reference to the great white whale in Moby-Dick  a book that seems to be a kind of touchstone for the author (writing here under the pen name Harry Brandt), having popped up, at least glancingly, in such earlier novels as Clockers and Freedomland. This time, the parallels to Melvilles classic are beyond obvious: All of the storys main characters are haunted by something terrible that happened in the past, and all are obsessed with hunting down their nemeses.

title: In Nevada, a Controversy in the Wind
description: For the past few years, the geologists Brenda Buck and Rodney Metcalf have combed the wild terrain of southern Nevada, analyzing its stony dunes and rocky outcroppings  and to their dismay, tallying mounting evidence of a landscape filled with asbestos.

title: Was Brian Williams a Victim of False Memory?
description: How reliable is human memory? Most of us believe that our memory is like a video camera, capturing an accurate record that can be reviewed at a later date.

title: Hannibal Buress Evolves From Cult Star to Showman
description: At the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Sunday night, Hannibal Buress did not backtrack from what was probably the most consequential joke told in recent memory, the now famous bit about sexual assault accusations against Bill Cosby.

title: Review: Gamelan Ensemble Hammers Out Ritual Rhythms of Bali
description: A Balinese gamelan orchestra is an intricate machine of connected parts, speaking in a highly articulated language built over many centuries. The music it plays is composed and vigorous, ceremonial and ritualized, intensely visual and movement-oriented when it includes dancers and singers, bright with the silver sounds of hammers striking metallophones, usually designed with five or seven notes to the octave.

title: Atlantic Corals: Colorful and Vulnerable
description: A council that sets regulations for fishing off the mid-Atlantic coast will meet on Wednesday to consider protections for little known and fragile ecosystems of deep sea corals in and around 15 ocean sites.

title: Review: Anna Netrebko Saves the Day for the Met Orchestra
description: The Met Orchestras concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday, which packed the place, opened and ended with James Levine conducting excellent performances of second symphonies: Beethovens to begin, Schumanns to end. He and his players were also inspired for Elliott Carters Three Illusions, a nine-minute work in three movements completed in 2004 when the composer turned 96.

title: Cal Performances at UC Berkeley Takes On a New Mission
description: As arts groups around the country grapple with their identities in the 21st century, Cal Performances at the University of California, Berkeley, said Monday it was dedicating itself to a new mission: promoting artistic literacy and diversifying the audiences of the events it presents.

title: Review: Pennsylvania Ballet, at the Merriam Theater, Shows Exuberance and Panache
description: PHILADELPHIA  How fast does a ballet company change when it acquires a new artistic director? At Pennsylvania Ballet, changes are already apparent, only six months after the appointment of Angel Corella.

title: A Ceramics Shop Pops Up Under a Neem Tree in India
description: More than a decade after he spent his meandering postcollegiate years on the Indian subcontinent studying Sufi mysticism and following a musical guru, the Austrian artist Matthias Kaiser returns today to open a pop-up ceramics shop under a neem tree in Ahmedabad, India. Hes stocked the roadside stall with art made, as always, of loosely interpreted recollections: a kilns worth of functional vessels carrying the echoes of papaya and potato chaat, Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeannerets modernist city of Chandigarh and hairless dogs, three-wheeled tractors and giant moving haystacks that had a truck hidden somewhere underneath, Kaiser explains.

title: Alabama, Where Same-Sex Marriage Remains Deeply Unpopular
description: Public opinion surveys show that a majority of adults  and a growing one  now supports same-sex marriage. But the rapid change in public opinion may obscure another fact: Large areas of the country remain overwhelmingly opposed to same-sex marriage, with little sign of change.

title: At the Museum of London, the City That Sherlock Holmes Knew

description: At companies like Square, Apple, Google, Amazon and PayPal, to name just a few, some of the smartest programmers in the world are doing everything they can to virtualize cash registers, credit cards, receipts, coupons and probably even pockets. It is not a great time for the old-fashioned wallet. And yet apparently even Squares founder himself is not quite ready to go out into the world completely devoid of some physical money-carrying device. Keep it tight, Jack Dorseytweeted a while back, with a link that led to the Americana 2.0.

description: The car-service driver knew the Orthodox Jewish neighborhood of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, well enough that he knew the different hours for Shabbos in summer and winter, and kept his radio off on Saturday nights so as not to upset his largely Orthodox passengers.

description: Young people are almost always encouraged to load up on stocks in their retirement portfolios. The prospect of returns higher than bonds over the long run in exchange for greater short-term price swings is considered a deal too good to pass up for someone with money that will remain untouched for many years.

title: Old Ways Prove Hard to Shed, Even as Crisis Hits Kimono Trade
description: AMAMI OSHIMA, Japan  Kazuhiko Kanai uses the traditional method to dye the elegant kimonos for which this small, semitropical island is renowned: he carries a bundle of pure white silk to a nearby rice paddy and hurls it into the mud.

title: Left and Right Align in Fighting Obamas Trade Agenda

title: Supreme Court Undercuts Alabama Chief Justices Argument to Delay Same-Sex Marriages
description: Until Monday, Chief Justice Roy S. Moore of Alabama had what some legal experts called a plausible argument for delaying the onset of same-sex marriage in the state, which had been ordered by a Federal District Court judge. After all, the United States Supreme Court will decide the issue for the entire nation in coming months and it made sense, Chief Justice Moore and other opponents of same-sex marriage said, to freeze things until the highest court ruled.

title: Audra McDonald and Will Swenson to Star in A Moon for the Misbegotten in Williamstown
description: The six-time Tony Award winner Audra McDonald will star opposite her husband, the Tony nominee Will Swenson, in a production of Eugene ONeills drama A Moon for the Misbegotten in August as part of the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts, the festivals artistic director, Mandy Greenfield, announced on Monday. Ms. McDonald will play the strong-willed Josie, a farmers daughter who plots against their alcoholic landlord, James Tyrone Jr. (Mr. Swenson), only to find charged emotional connections with him. Gordon Edelstein will direct the play, which will run Aug. 5-23 on the festivals main stage.

title: The Parent Agenda, the Emerging Democratic Focus
description: Just a few years ago, one could be forgiven for wondering whether the liberal agenda had run its course. With near-universal health care  the unfinished business of the 20th-century Democratic Party  enacted, there was no obvious next step in the partys mission of expanding the safety net. The big Democratic policies yet to be fully addressed, like immigration overhaul and restrictions on carbon emissions, pitted the partys new progressive constituencies against its traditional, white working-class base.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 6 P.M. (TCM) CHARADE (1963) A Parisian widow (Audrey Hepburn) tries to find her murdered husbands hidden fortune with the help of a vacation acquaintance (Cary Grant) while eluding the killers who want it themselves in this romantic, Hitchcockian caper directed by Stanley Donen. And while this film includes scenes of ghoulish humor and gruesome violence, Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times, theres a lot to be said for it as a fast-moving, urbane entertainment. Hepburn, he added, is cheerfully committed to a mood of how-nuts-can-you-be in an obviously comforting assortment of expensive Givenchy costumes, and Mr. Grant does everything from taking a shower without removing his suit to fighting with thugs, all with the blandness and the boredom of an old screwball comedy hand. Henry Mancini and Johnny Mercer received an Oscar nomination for their song Charade.

title: History of Lynchings in the South Documents Nearly 4,000 Names
description: DALLAS  A block from the tourist-swarmed headquarters of the former Texas School Book Depository sits the old county courthouse, now a museum. In 1910, a group of men rushed into the courthouse, threw a rope around the neck of a black man accused of sexually assaulting a 3-year-old white girl, and threw the other end of the rope out a window. A mob outside yanked the man, Allen Brooks, to the ground and strung him up at a ceremonial arch a few blocks down Main Street.

title: Insurance and Its Discontents
description: The phone call came two billing cycles after Ben and I had increased his session frequency to twice a week. A woman identifying herself as an independently licensed care advocate with a large insurance company left a message asking me to call back. My neck tightened. No psychologist wants to hear from an insurer. Like some neer-do-well relative, insurers call only when they want money  or rather, when they want to keep money theyd once promised to disburse.

title: Giving Airbnb a Run for Its Money
description: When travelers think about vacation rentals, they almost always think of Airbnb. The easy-to-use site, founded in 2008 and now with more than a million listings worldwide, is the first stop for many tourists  which means properties are snapped up fast, especially during major events such as concerts, games and conferences. Yet a handful of new contenders is striving to disrupt the vacation rental market by targeting specific kinds of travelers, be it families with children or jet-setters seeking luxury villas and airport transfers by helicopter. Below, a guide to some of the upstarts and, at the end of this column, a reminder of some veteran sites that all too often end up in the shadow of Airbnb.

title: Sophia Loren on Her Life in Hotels
description: The actress Sophia Loren is a symbol of Italy to generations of moviegoers. Born in Rome on Sept. 20, 1934, as Sofia Villani Scicolone, she was raised outside Naples and suffered intense deprivation during World War II. As Italy entered the postwar Dolce Vita era, she became a star of Cinecitt, Romes film industry center. She won an Oscar in 1962 for her performance in La Ciociara, or Two Women, about wartime Italy. Her memoir, Yesterday, Today, Tomorrow: My Life, was published late last year by Atria Books. She is the mother of Carlo Jr. and Edoardo, with her husband, the producer Carlo Ponti, who died in 2007. Following are edited excerpts from a conversation with Ms. Loren.
