In the final stages of a long-running investigation into corruption in the worlds biggest financial market, federal prosecutors have recently informed Barclays, JPMorgan Chase, the Royal Bank of Scotland and Citigroup that they must enter guilty pleas to settle the cases, according to lawyers briefed on the matter.

title: The Olsen Twins, Victoria Beckham, Margaret Cho? (This Is Not a Joke)
description: Thanks to the successful transitions of Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen and Victoria Beckham from celebrities to full-fledged fashion designers respected by the style community at large, the idea that an actress/singer/what-have-you might credibly make some clothes has gained a certain amount of traction these days. So perhaps it should come as no surprise that just in time for fashion week, which begins on Thursday, theres a new crossover candidate: Margaret Cho  boundary-pushing comedian/author/actor and, now, jumpsuit designer.

title: Valentine's Day Countdown
description: Flowers are good, but weekend getaways are better.

title: Video Review: The Jaguar F-Type R Conducts Its Own Symphony
description: PATRONS of the arts should love the Jaguar F-Type coupe as much as auto enthusiasts. As sculpture, its as much Rodin as road machine, with undulating aluminum panels draped over a bonded and riveted aluminum platform. Originally shown as the C-X16 concept drawn by Jaguars design director, Ian Callum, the production version remains remarkably true to his vision.

title: Driven | 2015 Jaguar F-Type R Coupe
description: The Jaguar F-Type Coupe is as much Rodin as road machine, with performance to match the undulating aluminum panels draped over a bonded and riveted aluminum platform.

title: Rise in Murders Has St. Louis Debating Why
description: ST. LOUIS  Across from the Little Explorers Learning Center, diagonal to a crumbling house where heroin dealers and hangers-on often mill about, a garland of teddy bears adorns a telephone pole, a memorial to the latest victim to fall here at one of this citys deadliest corners.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Feb. 3-9, 2015
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Surrounded by Strangers
description: Once again, readers have spotted a succession of mysterious strangers wandering through the tops of our stories.

title: In Performance: Ailyn Prez of Carmen
description: Ailyn Prez, an up-and-coming soprano who has been making the rounds of major opera houses in Vienna, London, Berlin and Milan, made her Metropolitan Opera debut this month as Micala in a revival of Bizets Carmen. Ms. Prez, who won the 2012 Richard Tucker Award, was praised for her performance by Zachary Woolfe, who wrote in The New York Times that she was a confident, forthright presence in a role that can fade into merely demure. Here she is singing a decidedly nondemure rendition of Micalas aria.

title: Amy Pascal Keeps Sonys Marquee Projects in Portfolio, Now as a Producer
description: LOS ANGELES  Amy Pascal may be giving up the Sony Pictures crown, but shes keeping the jewels.

title: 1940: U.S. Talks With Neutral States
description: WASHINGTON  The beginning of informal diplomatic conversations between the United States and other neutral nations for the purpose of exploring possibilities of the eventual restoration of world peace on a sound and lasting basis for all nations was announced today [Feb. 10] by Secretary of State Cordell Hull. The latest American peace venture, Secretary Hull indicated, is aimed at long- term economic objectives rather than an immediate cessation of hostilities. He also declared that there is no connection between the present conversations and the forthcoming European tour of Under Secretary Sumner Welles.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 11, 1940

title: Verbatim: Jeb Bushs Beloved BlackBerry
description: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, writing about his love of email in the first chapter of his new e-book.

title: Hang Seng Bank to Sell Part of Stake in Industrial Bank of China
description: Hang Seng Bank, the lender controlled by HSBC, agreed on Tuesday to sell about half its stake in Industrial Bank of China for as much as $2 billion.

title: Brock Is No Stranger to Political Rumbles Involving Clintons
description: As rough and tumble as they get.

title: Jordan and Emirates Carry Out Airstrikes in Syria Against ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  Fighter jets deployed by Arab allies launched a series of airstrikes in Syria in the early hours Tuesday, as the United Arab Emirates returned to combat missions against the Islamic State for the first time since December, and Jordan separately continued its escalation of strikes against Sunni militants.

title: Filming China's Dark Side
description: Zhao Liang's films, which explore the relationship between the Chinese government and its citizens, have received critical acclaim abroad, but are not screened in China.

title: A Landsman Drives the Bus
description: Dear Diary:

title: Coca-Cola Earnings Plunge 55%
description: The Coca-Cola Company missed its profitability targets last year, as consumers continued to reduce their appetite for sugary drinks and diet sodas.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: A Van Cleef & Arpels Bracelet That Plays a Pretty Trick on the Eye
description: Van Cleef & Arpelss beguiling, one-of-a-kind bejeweled gold cuff is a riff on 1960s Op Art. When opened and laid flat  dozens of ribs make it as flexible as rope despite its rounded heft  the bracelet appears to be made of small interlocking onyx circles dotted with diamonds. But when clasped around the wrist, the circles part to reveal a dense underlayer of cultured pearls affixed to the armature. A contrasting row of emeralds leads the way to the slyly hidden closure. Creating the bangles elaborate architecture required nearly 500 hours and the skill of 10 craftspeople  Van Cleefs so-called Mains dOr, or golden hands  among them a designer, a model maker, a lapidary, a gem setter and experts in hard stones, pearls and diamonds. Together, theyve woven a rich illusion indeed.

title: Pride, Prejudice, Prostitutes and Pickles: Scholars Unearth Two Letters Relating to Jane Austen
description: Newly discovered Jane Austen artifacts can always be counted on to cause a stir, as when a scholar claimed several years ago to have found a previously unknown pencil portrait of the Divine Miss Jane.

title: A Bookstore Corner That Is Forever France
description: Let them read Houellebecq! In a push to enhance the profile of French writers and French literary culture, the cultural services of the French Embassy in New York has been signing up independent bookstores across the United States to create special sections, called French Corners, to display French works in the original and in translation.

title: K.K.R. Profit Falls 89% on Turmoil in Energy Sector
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Tuesday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 89 percent, hurt by turmoil in the energy sector.

title: Hedge Fund-Backed Investor Puts Himself Up for G.M. Board
description: Six years ago, Harry J. Wilson was enlisted by the Obama administration to help overhaul General Motors as part of a taxpayer-financed bailout.

title: Grammys Post-Mortem
description: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss Kanye West, Beck, Iggy Azalea, Papa Johns and other stars of the show.

title: Even a Good Baby Is Exhausting
description: If this diary entry doesnt make a ton of sense, then forgive me: Evy has been home since Groundhog Day, and Im tired.

title: 1922: Hitler in Bavaria
description: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

title: Kanye West, Beck, Papa John and Other Grammy Awards Stars
description: The same old things happened at the Grammy Awards on Sunday night. Popular young musicians were misunderstood and underused, older musicians were framed with indulgent clarity, a soft-edged (and not very popular) choice was voted album of the year. Corniness and bad aesthetics ran rampant. Various factions on Twitter flipped out at regular intervals.

title: 1965: Bomb Hits G.I. Barracks
description: SAIGON  Communist Viet Cong terrorists blew up a U.S. Army barracks tonight [Feb. 10], inflicting heavy loss of life, a U.S. military spokesman reported. One American has already been found dead and 14 others were wounded. Another 30 Americans were missing in the blast and were believed dead under the wreckage. About 60 men lived in the four-story hotel used as a barrack at Qui Nhon, 250 miles northeast of here, but several of them were away when the explosion occurred, the spokesman said. He said the hotel was completely destroyed. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 11, 1965

title: What Is the Best Portrayal of a Marriage in Literature?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Charles McGrath and Leslie Jamison discuss the best portrayals of marriage in literature.

title: Terrorist Claims Return Sept. 11 Suit to Spotlight
description: WASHINGTON  Ron Motley could have come straight out of a John Grisham novel, a charismatic Southern trial lawyer with the swagger of a man who had bet big in life and usually won.

title: Starwood Hotels to Split Off Time-Share Business
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide said on Tuesday that it planned to spin off its time-share division into a separate publicly traded company, joining the swelling ranks of corporations breaking themselves up.

title: Review: In Jories Grahams From the New World, Flux Is a Whirling Constant
description: Wild is the wind that rushes through so many of Jorie Grahams poems. It sends birds spiraling aloft. It ripples lakes and ponds, making the sun glint. It pushes around the leaves, blades of grass and tree limbs that appear in stanza after stanza. Updraft or downdraft, her gusty poems declare, Hang onto your hat.

title: In a League of Flying Elbows, the Use of Mouth Guards Soars
description: By joining the growing faction of N.B.A. players who choose to wear a mouth guard in games, a player is forced to confront a certain small issue: Where do you keep the thing when youre on the bench?

title: Doulas, a Growing Force in Maternity Culture, Seek Greater Acceptance
description: On the morning of the day Marisa Pizarro gave birth, the usual tumult reigned in her apartment in Lower Manhattans financial district. Her husband, a music producer known as J Grand, in shower sandals and gym shorts, was busy tending to their toddler daughter, the financial news on TV and his iPad, where he was still rearranging tracks on a forthcoming release.

title: Senate Panel, 25-0, Backs Ashton Carter for Defense Post
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday voted unanimously  25-0  to approve the nomination of Ashton B. Carter as the next defense secretary.

title: With Proof From ISIS of Her Death, Family Honors Kayla Mueller
description: For one tortured weekend, the parents of Kayla Mueller refused to believe that their daughter was dead. From their home in Prescott, Ariz., they issued an impassioned plea to the Islamic State, which had held her captive since August 2013, and urged the extremist organization to contact them privately with proof of her death. The militants acquiesced and sent at least three photographs of her corpse.

title: Up Close And Delusional
description: Jonathan Chait notes that people are still trying to cast Paul Ryan as reasonable and moderate  hey, he visits bookstores favored by liberals. As Chait says, this sort of political evaluation by personal style is unreliable at best; and Ryan quite clearly deliberately exploits it, too, making moderate noises without ever giving an inch on his hard-line right-wing policies. Remember, this is the guy who pretended to offer a budget based on fiscal responsibility, but when you took out the magic asterisks it was really tax cuts for the rich, severe benefit cuts for the poor, and overall would actually increase the deficit.

title: Obama Had Statement to Read if Terror Halted Inauguration
description: The night before President Obama was inaugurated in 2009, David Axelrod got a call from an agitated Rahm Emanuel, the president-elects chief of staff, according to Mr. Axelrods book, Believer, which was released on Tuesday.

title: Kayla Muellers Letter to Her Family
description: After news of her death was confirmed, Ms. Muellers family released a copy of an unpublished letter that she wrote to her loved ones in the spring of 2014.

title: U.S. Embassy Shuts in Yemen, Even as Militant Leader Reaches Out
description: SANA, Yemen  In his first interview since the Yemeni government collapsed, the leader of the Houthi militants who control Sana, the capital, depicted his movement as eager to share power with its rivals and to reach out to the countrys traditional allies, including the United States and Saudi Arabia  even as the American Embassy prepared to shut down.

title: Decos Modern Twist
description: From Louis Vuitton to Prada, patchwork seemed to pop up everywhere this season.

title: In Geoengineering Study, Science Academy Sees Merit in CO2 Removal, Risk in Reflecting Sunlight
description: Experts convened by the National Academy of Sciences have weighed in with valuable reports on the two main geoengineering strategies for countering global warming driving by the buildup of greenhouse gases:

title: From Israel, a Drama That Started a National Debate About Divorce
description: In the early stages of the competition for the Oscar for best foreign language film, Israels submission, Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem, impressed so many observers that it was considered a shoo-in for the shortlist. That ended up not happening, even though Gett was nominated for a Golden Globe. But the films writers and directors, the sister-and-brother team of Ronit and Shlomi Elkabetz, have other satisfactions: their film has set off an impassioned debate in Israel about changing that countrys restrictive divorce laws.

title: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Gets a New Name
description: The Institute of Medicine on Tuesday proposed a new name and new diagnostic criteria for the condition that many still call chronic fatigue syndrome.

title: Anwar Ibrahims Wife Reacts to Ruling
description: Wan Azizah Wan Ismail, the wife of the Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, spoke after her husband lost his appeal against a sodomy conviction.

title: A New Mobile Map Captures Internet of Moving Things
description: Welcome to the world of data in motion, all the time.

title: Spanish Airport Operator Aena Prices I.P.O. at Top of Range
description: LONDON  Aena, the Spanish airport operator, priced its initial public offering at the top end of its expected range and will begin trading on Wednesday in the largest new stock debut in Europe this year.

title: Kao Soy
description: Northern Thai food in Red Hook, Brooklyn

title: Restaurant Review: Kao Soy in Red Hook, Brooklyn
description: Only half of the tables inside Kao Soy were taken, but the delivery guys were coming and going through the door on Van Brunt Street every few minutes. The December wind off the harbor that was shaking the little brick buildings in Red Hook, Brooklyn, was keeping everybody at home, ordering pad see ew and massaman curry from the new neighborhood Thai place.

title: Flip Side of Reducing Student Debt Is Increasing the Federal Deficit
Times Insider: By the Book
description: A conversation with Pamela Paul, editor of The New York Times Book Review, and some of the authors from her new collection, By the Book.

title: Amid Debate on ISIS War Bill, a Democrat Proposes Peace
description: With President Obama and congressional leaders negotiating the terms of a new war resolution to counter the Islamic State, a key antiwar Democrat is pushing what amounts to a peace bill.

title: Review: In The Slap, Culture Clash and Family Dysfunction
description: Harry (Zachary Quinto) is an adult bully with a scary temper. Hugo (Dylan Schombing) is a 5-year-old bully given to scary temper tantrums.

title: Women Enter a Male Golf Bastion
description: In 2007, Louise Suggs said she was glad to have lived long enough to see the Womens British Open played for the first time on the St. Andrews Old Course. For the 91-year-old Suggs, the wonders never cease. On Tuesday she was one of seven women offered honorary membership in the Royal and Ancient Golf Club, which voted last September to end its all-male policy.

title: Theres Something About Money (Implicitly Wonkish)
description: Continuing a family tradition, Rand Paul is saying crazy things about the Fed and monetary policy. Its important to note, however, that hes not that far out of the modern Republican mainstream. Remember this:

title: Box Toughens Security to Draw Regulated Customers
description: Box, a cloud-based data storage and collaboration company, hopes it has solved one of the last great impediments to businesses going fully online.

title: Binders Full of Women Foreign Policy Experts
description: As mind-boggling world events dominated headlines last summer, an impressive number of women reported first-hand from various hot spots. Sabrina Tavernise arrived on the scene of downed Malaysian Airlines Flight 17 in eastern Ukraine even as the plane still burned. Alissa Rubin escaped death in a helicopter crash in Iraq. Anne Barnard delivered harrowing dispatches from Gaza. And yet, when it came time for round table analysis, grey suits continued to deluge the discussion.

title: Down Deep, the Life of Corals
description: Environmental groups and sport fishermen are pushing for protection of deep-sea corals in ocean canyons that run from New York to Virginia.

title: What People Mean When They Say Audit the Fed
description: Remember Audit the Fed? It was the call that united populists of the right and left (and quite a few terrified centrists) around the cause of congressional investigators poking around the inner workings of the Federal Reserve, including its setting of interest rate policies.

title: Yelp Buys Eat24, an Online Food-Ordering Service, for $134 Million
description: Yelp has long been known as the go-to website to find a good place to eat for dinner. Now, Yelp wants to go a step further and start bringing dinner to you.

title: Neil Patrick Harris on Hosting His First Academy Awards
description: When I used to watch the Oscars at home with my family, we would print out ballots, write down our predictions and see who won. As I got older, our viewing parties had more of a gambling slant  same ballot, different stakes. Now they just involve more drinking, and when its at my house, theres a lot of Velveeta and Pace Picante.

title: Federal Judge Sets Hearing in Alabama on Same-Sex Marriage
description: MOBILE, Ala.  A day after a federal ruling legalizing same-sex marriage took effect in Alabama, a federal judge set a hearing that could determine whether resistant local probate judges must grant licenses to gay couples. At the same time, some officials who had refused to issue the licenses, in compliance with a state judicial ruling, reversed course.

title: The Damien Hirst of New Delhi Brings a Personal Exhibition to New York
description: Subodh Guptas Seven Billion Light Years includes readymade and appropriated objects that reflect on Indian culture.

title: No Manly Firmness in Denying Health Care, McCaskill Says
description: Is repealing the Affordable Care Act an issue of manhood?

title: Lurching Start for Tesla in China
description: BEIJING  For $104,000, Yu Hangmei expected a car that could, at the very least, be driven. What Ms. Yu said she got instead was a new electric Tesla Model S sedan and a malfunctioning charging station.

title: Chocolate Making at Home
description: A new breed of chocolate lovers is making bars from the raw cacao bean.

title: The Kitchen-Counter Chocolatiers
description: ATLANTA  Obsessives are common in the world of cooking. They go down the rabbit hole of jury-rigged sous-vide machines, or spend two weeks lost in the 38-page bread recipe from the Tartine Bakery. They have cases of homemade lager in the hall closet and roast coffee in a wok.

title: The Gaines Family Always Knew What Dean Smith Stood For
description: There was a day to savor in March 1997 when Dean Smith surpassed Adolph Rupp as the coach with the most wins in major college basketball, and Clarence Gaines, also known as Big House, watched with a smile.

title: Battered Ukrainian City of Mariupol Braces for Worst as Rebels Close In
description: MARIUPOL, Ukraine  The morning routine begins promptly at 8:05 at Public School 68, with a round of calisthenics followed immediately by the daily shelling drill.

title: N.F.L. Forms Committee to Oversee Any Potential Return to Los Angeles
description: Amid concerns about multiple teams moving willy-nilly to Los Angeles without league approval, Roger Goodell, the commissioner of the N.F.L., has formally established a committee of owners to oversee the process of putting a team in the countrys second-largest market.

title: Stressed Families a Theme in Coming MCC Theater Season
description: New plays about families under varying kinds of stress, by the writers Matthew Lopez (The Whipping Man), Noah Haidle (Mr. Marmalade), and John Pollono (Small Engine Repair), will be staged in the 2015-16 season of MCC Theater, the companys artistic directors announced Tuesday.

title: English Premier League Sells British TV Rights for $7.8 Billion
description: LONDON  The English Premier League, the world's most widely watched soccer league, said on Tuesday that it had sold British television rights for a record 5.1 billion pounds, or about $7.8 billion.

title: Celebrations After Election in Delhi
description: Arvind Kejriwal, leader of the young anticorruption party Aam Aadmi, spoke with supporters after winning in the vote for the Delhi Assembly.

title: Maria Loi Is Back in Business
description: Headliner

title: For Many Veterans, American Sniper, Right or Wrong, Starts an Important Conversation
description: This week, the trial of the man accused of killing Chris Kyle opens in a Texas courtroom, even as the Clint Eastwood film based on Mr. Kyles life, American Sniper, is playing in a theater three miles away. Much as Mr. Kyles death shocked the nation, the film has generated fierce debate nationally over the meaning of his life and his death, and the Iraq war itself. To some, Mr. Kyle represents all that was right with the American-led invasion, to others, all that was wrong. Yet to many veterans, his story offers a chance to discuss and debate a remarkable array of complex and personal questions: the mix of motivations that lead people to sign up in the military, the riot of emotions troops feel when they kill or witness death, the struggle to reengage with civilian society upon coming home. A number of people have sent At War essays about how they viewed the film, including the piece below by a former Marine. What do you think? Send us your thoughts: atwar@nytimes.com.

title: From The Upshot: The Fed, a Beacon of Openness
description: What People Mean When They Say Audit the Fed

title: Will Greece Ever Get Out of Debtors Prison?
description: The efforts of the new Greek government to write off a portion of its debt are being cast by powerful European policy makers as a bid for debt forgiveness. But the whole concept of forgiveness implies that there is a magnanimous creditor and a profligate borrower, and thats just not true. Greece now has more debt than it can ever repay, and lenders share some of the blame for this.

title: Panel Urges Research on Geoengineering as a Tool Against Climate Change
description: With the planet facing potentially severe impacts from global warming in coming decades, a government-sponsored scientific panel on Tuesday called for more research on geoengineering  technologies to deliberately intervene in nature to counter climate change.

title: Increase in Budget for Rikers Is Applauded
description: Mayor Bill de Blasios proposal to add about $54 million to the Correction Department budget was praised on Tuesday by inmates advocates and longtime department critics who said it demonstrated a commitment to rein in the brutality and corruption that have long plagued Rikers Island.

title: Williamsburg Warehouse Fire Revives Talk of a Promised Park
description: When Councilman Stephen Levin looks at the smoldering wreckage of the CitiStorage warehouse on the Williamsburg, Brooklyn, waterfront, he sees a decade of broken promises.

title: Greek Debt Proposals Offer Room for Discussion
description: Greece has the choice between backing down and a showdown. It may be leaning toward the former.

title: High Line Is Expected to Help a Chelsea Site It Hurt Decades Ago
description: The Terminal Stores, a warehouse complex in the West Chelsea section of Manhattan, can in many ways pin its decline, and planned revival, on the High Line.

title: The Case Against the Case Against the Crusades
description: Inmy Sunday column on the controversy surrounding President Obamas National Prayer Breakfast speech, I tried to explain what I saw as the problems with the presidents high horse references to Western Christian sins without letting the column getsucked down too deep into the quicksand of historical-moral controversy.But now (because what else are blogs for?) lets step a little deeper into that quicksand, and talk a little bit about the Crusades, the most contested of the various examples  the others were Jim Crow, slavery, and the Inquisition that the president cited as Islamic State-like case studies in which Christianity wasused as a license for cruelty and persecution. The references to slavery and segregation inspireddebates about how deeply religion was implicated in those institutions(the short answer: a lot more deeply than many Christian conservatives careto admit today, though not in exactly the same way that religion is implicated in the crimes of ISIS; the South was many things, including a home to terrorism, but it was not a utopian theocracy); the reference to the Inquisition inspired some discussion ofjust how bad the institution really was (the answer: not as bad as Black Legend-stylehistory would have it, but at its worst quite, quite bad enough). But only the Crusades inspired a debate about whether they deserve to be condemnedat all.

title: SXSW Film Festival Announces Midnight Slate
description: The midnight slate at this years South by Southwest film festival will include haunted houses, unpleasant dinner parties, not-so-sweet dreams and a little bit of cannibalism. Festival organizers announced today the horror and genre-focused collection of movies that will round out their feature lineup: 11 films that range from the weird to the terrifying.

title: Netanyahu Uses Twitter to Defend Speech to Congress
Review: New York Philharmonic Explores Israeli Musical Identity
description: A concert called New Music From Israel inevitably raises the question of what makes music Israeli. This was the title of the program that some impressive musicians from the New York Philharmonic presented on Monday night as part of the Contact! series at SubCulture, the popular basement performance space on Bleecker Street. Yotam Haber, the evenings affable host, got right to this issue of musical identity in his introduction.

title: Niger Adds Its Troops to the War on Boko Haram
description: DAKAR, Senegal  With the regional war against the Boko Haram militant group widening, Nigers Parliament has agreed to send troops across the border to join the fight.

title: Shelf, iPad, Bed Table: Reading, January 2015
description: How can you rely on someones opinion of a book if you dont know what else theyve read?

title: Jewelry Designer Irene Neuwirth Goes to the Gem Show
description: Fifteen years after her first visit, the native Angeleno still makes the trip to the Tucson Gem, Mineral & Fossil Showcase to collect treasures for her line.

title: Lively Morgue Tumblr 473  475
description: Lively Morgue Tumblr 473  475

title: New York City Police Officer Is Said to Be Indicted in Shooting Death of Akai Gurley
description: A New York City police officer was indicted Tuesday in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man in a Brooklyn public housing complex stairwell in November, several people familiar with the grand jurys decision said.

title: To Lure Younger Fans, PGA Tour Will Offer a TV Network Online
description: The PGA Tour hopes that a new digital network will help bring it younger fans  those who prefer short videos to televised tournaments and footage of golfers whooping it up when theyre not characters in hushed-voice network broadcasts. These millennial fans want to watch golf differently from earlier generations who were weaned on the feats of Arnie and Jack.

title: On This Day: Senator Obama Makes It Official
description: The pace of political maneuvering for 2016 might seem like it is moving faster than a speeding campaign bus, but this cycle has nothing on President Obamas first run for the White House.

title: Saba Software to Be Taken Private
description: Saba Software, a troubled cloud-computing firm based in Silicon Valley, has agreed to be taken private by Vector Capital for about $300 million.

title: New DNA Tests Ordered in Argentine Prosecutors Death
description: BUENOS AIRES  The judge overseeing an investigation into the mysterious death of a federal prosecutor here last month has asked forensic experts to identify DNA traces found at his home, it was revealed on Tuesday.

title: F.C.C. Dissenter Takes On Net Neutrality Proposal
description: The net neutrality talkathon got a lively and pointed contribution on Tuesday from Ajit Pai, a Republican commissioner on the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Freeze-Framing Decay
description: Will Ellis photographs old industrial sites and other crumbling structures for his blog Abandoned NYC.

title: Opposing Lawyer on Strauss-Kahns Claims
description: A lawyer representing some of the prostitutes in the trial of Dominique Strauss-Kahn argued that the former I.M.F. chief must have known their profession when he met them.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Ukraine and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Feb 10, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Ukraine, France, South Sudan and Bulgaria.

title: Chelsea Manning, Soldier Sentenced for Leaks, Will Write for The Guardian
description: Chelsea Manning, the former Army intelligence analyst sentenced to 35 years in prison for leaking a trove of secret documents to WikiLeaks, has joined The Guardian newspaper as a contributing opinion writer.

title: Venezuela Announces Plan to Relax Currency Controls
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Venezuelan officials on Tuesday announced details of what they said would be a free market in which people and businesses could exchange local currency for dollars  an easing of the tightly controlled exchange rates that critics say have fed the nations economic crisis.

title: Twitter Finance Chiefs Account Briefly Seized by Spammer
description: A lot of Twitter users find the nuances of the social network difficult to navigate, such as the difference between private direct messages and public replies and what level of access that third-party apps get to your Twitter account if you use it to sign in or post content from them.

title: Netanyahu Will Proceed With U.S. Speech
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said he would give his speech to Congress, as he has a profound disagreement with the United States over negotiations with Iran.

title: Review: In Schitts Creek, a Spoiled Little Rich Family Starts Over
description: Has anyone given us more pleasure playing perfectly oddly matched couples than Eugene Levy and Catherine OHara? As the dog-owning Flecks in Christopher Guests Best in Show and the folk-singing Mitch and Mickey in his A Mighty Wind, they perfected a mix of barbed deadpan (Mr. Levy) and vibrant loopiness (Ms. OHara) that was crucial to those films special brand of warmly lunatic humor.

title: Low Vitamin D in Childhood Linked to Later Heart Risks
description: Vitamin D deficiency in childhood may be linked to hardening of the arteries in middle age, a long-term Finnish study has found.

title: Review: Building Wonders Examines Ancient Structures on Nova
description: Building Wonders, a three-part series within the PBS show Nova, tries hard to take the miraculousness out of three formidable ancient structures but, happily, it fails. If anything, the programs leave you even more impressed with their subjects: the Colosseum, the stone city of Petra and Hagia Sophia.

title: Review: Thomas Hampsons Conflict Resolutions
description: Perhaps you had this professor in college: the learned, old-fashioned one, long settled in his post, whose lectures would emerge in a stream-of-consciousness ramble. The veteran baritone Thomas Hampsons recital at Carnegie Hall on Monday felt like one of those lectures, sauntering from topic to topic.

title: A Duplex Penthouse in Central Vienna
description: Atop a turn-of-the-20th-century building, it is on the market for $1.87 million.

title: Agreement on Ukraine Cease-Fire Deal Is Reported
description: MOSCOW  Negotiators meeting in Minsk, Belarus, reached a tentative deal for a cease-fire in Ukraine on Tuesday night, setting the stage for a meeting of the leaders of Russia, Ukraine, Germany and France to sign the agreement on Wednesday, according to media reports.

title: What You Get for ... $2,950,000
description: This weeks properties include a contemporary in California, a plantation house in Louisiana and a penthouse in Miami.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: French Muslims, Never Fully at Home
description: In the wake of last months terrorist attacks, Bharat Choudharys photos show how French Muslims struggle to live in a society that they fear will never fully accept them.

title: Review: Meistersinger, Wagners Playful Paean to Culture, in London
description: LONDON  Wagners Die Meistersinger is a long opera about many things and, as hijacked by Adolf Hitler in the 1930s, those included a view of German cultural supremacy so welcoming to the Third Reich that it still bothers some of us. But more broadly its an opera about art at a moment of crisis, rooted in past triumphs but needing to move forward to future uncertainties. That makes it an appropriate piece for the English National Opera, whose new production, staged by Richard Jones, opened on Saturday at a moment of unsettling change and possible crisis for the company.

title: Jury in Patz Murder Trial Views Taped Confession
description: The confession was not a surprise to jurors: Pedro Hernandez had told several people through the years that he had killed a child in New York City, and five of those people had testified earlier in Mr. Hernandezs murder trial.

title: Samsung Tweaks Television Policy Over Privacy Concerns
description: After an outcry over privacy concerns, Samsung has clarified that some of its so-called smart televisions listen in on the conversations of viewers only if the viewers permit the devices to do so.

title: John Boorman Tribute at Film Forum Goes Beyond Deliverance
description: Its not unlikely that you think of the British director John Boorman, if you think of him at all, as the man who directed Deliverance, a movie that came out 43 years ago. Film Forum is anticipating as much  a news release for the current retrospective of his films begins, Boorman, Tribute to Director of Deliverance.

title: Apple Building Solar Farm to Power California Operations
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple is going big on solar.

title: Grammy Show Ratings Fall
description: The Grammy Awards broadcast on CBS Sunday night attracted an audience of 24.8 million viewers, down 13 percent from last year, and the fewest since 19 million watched in 2009.

title: Richard Price Finds His Pseudonym for The Whites Annoying
description: Richard Price is a skilled literary ventriloquist, with a pitch-perfect ear for deadbeat street slang and sardonic cop banter. But when he tried impersonating another writer, with the aim of writing a fast-paced, plot-driven crime novel under the pen name Harry Brandt, he couldnt quite pull it off.

title: Review: Music From Japan Brings In Some Neighbors as Well
description: With Japanese music still lingering in memory from the Juilliard Schools weeklong, storm-abbreviated Focus! festival last month, the New York presenter Music From Japan strutted its stuff with its own festival over the weekend. In two programs at Asia Society, Music From Japan, long a force in opening pathways for Japanese music in the West, was also celebrating its 40th anniversary.

title: In Paris, a New Exhibition Buttons Up
description: Buttons can be made from just about anything, from elephant skin to raffia, announces a text on the wall of Dboutonner la Mode (Unbutton Fashion), a new exhibition at the Muse des Arts Dcoratifs in Paris. And its true: The 3000 buttons on display, gathered by prolific collector Loc Allio, include pearls, leather, fur, bone, wood, straw, plastic, Wedgwood and papier-mch. Petite canvases though they may be, each button is a full-fledged artistic work, created by craftsmen ranging from embroiderers and ceramicists to jewelers and silversmiths.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: At Rebecca Minkoff in SoHo, Interface-to-Face Service
description: Theres a Simpsons episode in which Homer presses the Tab key on his computer keyboard and holds a cup to the disk drive, waiting for diet soda to come out. Twenty years after the episode aired in 1995, Homers dreams have come true.

title: Review: Maxine Linehan Transforms the Popular Into the Personal
description: Grounded is a word that doesnt describe most cabaret performers. But it applies to Maxine Linehan, the fiercely talented, self-assured theatrical singer who appeared at the Metropolitan Room on Friday evening. Ms. Linehan, who was born in Ireland, exudes the comfortable rootedness of a performer who knows who she is and where she came from. At the same time, Ms. Linehan is an adventurer. On her latest album, Beautiful Songs, she takes favorites that you thought you knew and infuses them with an intensely personal point of view.

title: Natarajan Chandrasekaran of Tata Consultancy Services: Making a Habit of Accountability
description: This interview with  Natarajan Chandrasekaran,  chief executive of  Tata Consultancy Services, who is known as Chandra, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Freer Gallery to Close for Renovations in January
description: The Freer Gallery of Art, a Smithsonian Institution museum that houses one of the finest collections of Asian art, is closing for renovations in January, the Smithsonian announced.

title: Chicos Clothing Stores Near Sale to Sycamore Partners
description: Chicos FAS, the womens clothing retailer, is nearing a sale to the private equity firm Sycamore Partners for upward of $3 billion, according to a personbriefed on the matter. If completed, the deal would be the largest buyout of the year.

title: A Conversation With Edward J. Minskoff
description: Mr. Minskoff is the founder and president of Edward J. Minskoff Equities, a real estate acquisition and development company that owns and manages nearly six million square feet of office, residential and retail space, mainly in Manhattan.

title: Living In Tottenville, Staten Island
description: A former oystering port turned bedroom community, Staten Islands Tottenville neighborhood has experienced intense growth in the last couple of decades.

title: Phillip Lims Meticulous Grooming Regimen Is All About Maintenance
description: Raised in Huntington Beach, Calif., Phillip Lim, 41, introduced his 3.1 Phillip Lim fashion line in 2005 and quickly found a following for his urbane, wearable aesthetic. Two years later, he won the Council of Fashion Designers of America women's wear award. Today the label, based in SoHo, is a fashion powerhouse with 14 free-standing stores worldwide and three more shops scheduled to open this year. He will show his fall 2015 collection Monday.

title: The Military Marriage Trapeze Act
description: I clipped in my harness, took a deep breath at the base of the metal ladder and slowly started the long, precarious, 23-foot climb. As the ladder gently swayed with every movement, I tried to create the illusion of composure while getting to the platform at the top as quickly as possible. The mixture of adrenaline and fear is my version of a Long Island iced tea: seems like such a good combination, until you get sick or black out. I remind myself that people (like me) actually pay for this feeling.

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Marriage Equality and the Rule of Law in Alabama
description: Major civil rights battles always have their share of setbacks, and the fight for same-sex marriage faced one on Monday in Alabama, where most county probate judges refused to grant marriage licenses to same-sex couples, defying last months federal court ruling declaring that the states ban on such unions violated the U.S. Constitution.

title: Excommunication of a Mormon Critic
description: John P. Dehlin released what he said was a transcript of a recording he surreptitiously made of an August meeting with Bryan King, a regional stake president in the Church of Latter Day Saints, in which they discussed the churchs reasons for seeking to discipline him.

title: Mormon Church Expels Outspoken Critic
description: John P. Dehlin, the founder and host of a popular podcast for Mormons who question their faith, announced on Tuesday that a 15-member church disciplinary council had unanimously decided to excommunicate him for apostasy.

title: Obama to Recall Military Personnel From Ebola Zone, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will announce Wednesday that he is withdrawing almost all the American troops who were sent to West Africa to help contain the spread of the Ebola virus, administration officials said Tuesday.

title: A Defeat for Prime Minister Modi
description: Fresh from the diplomatic high of a successful summit meeting with President Obama, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has been brought down to earth by domestic politics. He and his Bharatiya Janata Party, or B.J.P., were crushed in the election Tuesday for New Delhis 70-member state assembly, winning three seats while the upstart Aam Aadmi Party, or A.A.P., captured the rest.

title: Brian Williams Suspended From NBC for 6 Months Without Pay
description: Brian Williams, the embattled NBC news anchor whose credibility plummeted after he acknowledged exaggerating his role in a helicopter episode in Iraq, has been suspended for six months without pay, the network said on Tuesday night.

title: Alex Rodriguez Offers Apology in Meeting With Yankees
description: Alex Rodriguez met with Hal Steinbrenner and other top team executives at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday to clear the air after a two-year battle with the Yankees and Major League Baseball over his use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Colleges Use Anti-Apartheid Strategies to Battle Fossil Fuels
description: Divestment, the rallying cry against apartheid in the 1980s, just isnt what it used to be.

title: Halliburton to Trim Its Work Force by 7%
description: HOUSTON  Halliburton announced on Tuesday plans to lay off about 7 percent of its work force, or 5,200 to 6,400 workers, in response to plummeting oil prices.

title: Jon Stewart Will Leave The Daily Show on a Career High Note
description: Jon Stewart, who turned Comedy Centrals The Daily Show into a sharp-edged commentary on current events, delivering the news in layers of silliness and mockery, said on Tuesday that he would step down after more than 16 years as its anchor.

title: Does Helping Condo Developers Hurt the City?
New York City Buildings Inspectors Charged in Bribe Schemes
description: More than a dozen New York City buildings inspectors and clerks have been charged with exploiting their positions as gateways to the citys booming real estate industry to obtain hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes, law enforcement officials announced on Tuesday.

title: N.Y.C.F.C.Offers Clearer Glimpse of Its Plan in an Opening Victory
description: MANCHESTER, England  Coach Jason Kreiss preparations for New York City F.C.s first season might have been meticulous, but he lacked one vital resource. With his teams Major League Soccer opener against Orlando City a little more than three weeks away, he had no game footage to pore over.

title: SpaceX Launch of Solar-Storms Satellite Is Postponed Again
description: The launch of the Deep Space Climate Observatory, a satellite intended to warn of solar storms shortly before they hit Earth, was postponed on Tuesday because of high-altitude winds at the launch site in Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: New Yorks Building Horror Stories
description: Almost anyone trying to develop a building or repair a brownstone or hold onto a budget-rate apartment in New York City has a horror story to tell. For the builders, its often about strange, excruciating delays and rules that seem straight out of the Charles Dickens Circumlocution Office. For the tenants, its the way landlords always seem to have a way with the authorities.

title: Yelp Pays $134 Million for Food-Ordering Service
description: The online review service Yelp said on Tuesday that it had acquired Eat24, an online food-ordering start-up, for $134 million in cash and stock. The move is a departure for Yelp, whose main business has been selling advertising bought by local businesses with those reviews. But Yelps growth is starting to slow, and it reported a decrease in regular visitors in its most recent quarter. In a statement, Jeremy Stoppelman, Yelps chief executive, said the purchase would help Yelp customers more easily do business with companies online. Yelp will have plenty of competitors. GrubHub, an online food ordering company and a longtime competitor of Eat24, recently acquired DiningIn and Restaurants on the Run, two delivery services that take food directly to customers who order it through the company. Yelp also faces start-ups like Postmates, which enables customers to order food from almost any restaurant for delivery, and Square, which recently bought the food delivery start-up Caviar. Bigger competitors may be coming, too. Amazon and Google have experimented with on-demand delivery services, and Uber, the ride-hailing start-up, has signaled its own ambitions of becoming a way to deliver anything to anyone.

title: Richter Leads Sothebys London Contemporary Art Sales
description: A Gerhard Richter abstract painting sold Tuesday night at Sothebys contemporary art auction in London for 30.4 million, or about $46.3 million, including fees.

title: New F.B.I. Headquarters Enters the Bidding Phase
description: WASHINGTON  Small guys need not have applied. And even larger ones may not have been inclined.

title: New Dosages of Old Drugs Are Used to Raise Their Prices
description: Doctors have long prescribed a muscle relaxant called cyclobenzaprine to treat injuries like back strains, using five- or 10-milligram pills.

title: On YouTube, Vivid Evidence of Wars Horror in Ukraine
description: Even though the United States is now considering proposals to arm Ukraines military, to counter aid to separatists from Russia, the war in the eastern provinces of Donetsk and Luhansk has nearly disappeared from American television screens.

title: In Thailand, the Ghost Business Thrives
description: BANGKOK  Shortly after midnight, the phone rang in the cramped radio station where Kapol Thongplub hosts a nightly call-in show dedicated to the supernatural.

title: Complicated Politics of Medicaid Expansion Are Playing Out State by State
description: WASHINGTON  In Pennsylvania, Gov. Tom Wolf, a newly elected Democrat, is scrapping his Republican predecessors conservative approach to expanding Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act. Mr. Wolf said this week that he would instead pursue a straightforward expansion of the government health insurance program for the poor, no longer charging premiums or limiting benefits for some enrollees.

title: Private Equity Firms in a Frenzied Race to Hire Young Investment Bankers
description: They are only in their early to mid-20s, but some young bankers on Wall Street are the most sought-after financiers around, with lucrative pay packages dangling before them.

title: Australia Arrests 2 on Suspicion of Plotting Imminent Attack
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Australias counterterrorism police have arrested two men in a Sydney suburb and thwarted an imminent attack, the police said Wednesday.

title: Contact the Reporters
description: Contact the reporters on this story.

title: Mexican Political Family Has Close Ties to Ruling Party, and Homes in the U.S.
description: In the fall of 2013, one of Mexicos top housing officials posted an item on Twitter about an advertising campaign promoting mortgages for low-income Mexicans. The campaigns message was simple: The most important thing in life is in your house.

title: Val Fitch, Who Discovered Universe to Be Out of Balance, Is Dead at 91
description: Val Fitch, who shared the 1980 Nobel Prize in Physics for work that revealed a surprising imbalance in the laws of nature and helped explain why the collision of matter and antimatter has not destroyed everything in the universe, died on Thursday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 91.

title: As Snow Piles Up in Boston, So Do Frustrations With Beleaguered Transit System
description: BOSTON  Rebekah Adelstone usually drives to work, which takes 15 minutes. Since record snows have fallen, she has not wanted to risk losing her precious parking spot, so she has taken a bus to the subway. But on Tuesday, after even more snow fell, the subway system was shut down. So she ended up taking two buses to work, and her commute stretched to two hours.

title: Obama to Seek War Power Bill From Congress, to Fight ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has informed lawmakers that the president will seek a formal authorization to fight the Islamic State that would prohibit the use of enduring offensive ground forces and limit engagement to three years. The approach offers what the White House hopes is a middle way on Capitol Hill for those on the right and left who remain deeply skeptical of its plans to thwart extremist groups.

title: Sarah Schleper, Now Representing Mexico, Is Poised for a Second Run
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  In 2011, Sarah Schleper was 32 years old and had been a member of the United States ski team for 16 winters, a stint that included four Olympic Games, seven national championships and four World Cup podium finishes.

title: Impasse on Funding for Homeland Security Is Looming in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  With a little over two weeks until the Department of Homeland Security runs out of money, Republican leaders in Congress publicly announced Tuesday what had become a grim, if private, truth in the Capitol  they are at an impasse, with no easy way out.

title: A Late-Night Host Seamlessly Mixing Analysis, Politics and Humor
description: Its hard to imagine a presidential election without Jon Stewart at The Daily Show, but we are going to have to get used to it now that the host of the landmark political comedy program of our era is leaving his desk before the first primary of 2016.

title: Jon Stewart and The Daily Show': A Comedy Launchpad
description: Just over 16 years ago, Jon Stewart took over The Daily Show, which has served as a primary source of news and satire for a generation. His mission: to skewer, mock and fact-check what he saw as the inanities of American politics and media. In the process, The Daily Show served as a launching pad for some of comedys most notable talents to go onto other shows or projects. Jon Stewart must be a happy papa.

title: Boston Buried in Near-Record Snowfall
description: Gov. Charlie Baker of Massachusetts deployed National Guard troops to help with snow removal as the state tried to dig out from its third major winter storm in two weeks.

title: Report Details the Worker Complaints That Blurred N.Y.U.s Emirates Vision
description: Like other Persian Gulf states, the United Arab Emiratesimports much of its labor forcefrom Bangladesh, Indonesia and the Philippines. And it imports prestige from liberal Western institutions like universities and museums.

title: Tributes to Kayla Mueller
description: Friends and family of Kayla Mueller, the American hostage of the Islamic State who was killed in Syria, paid tribute to her in her hometown, Prescott, Ariz.

title: Substantiated Complaints About New York Police Departments Use of Chokeholds Increase
description: Last year, a police oversight board substantiated six complaints by people who said New York City officers had restrained them with a chokehold, a banned maneuver that was used by an officer in the fatal encounter with Eric Garner on Staten Island in July.

title: In Defiance on Gay Marriage, Alabama Sets Itself Far Apart
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  On Sunday night, Blake Guinn, a 21-year-old city councilman in a deeply conservative suburb here, looked on Facebook and learned that, once again, Chief Justice Roy S. Moore of the State Supreme Court had defied a federal court in the name of state sovereignty. Somehow, it did not seem entirely unexpected.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 10, 2015
Review: Christina Bianco Stars in Application Pending
description: Christina Bianco has become relatively well known as an impressionist through stage work and YouTube videos, so the myriad voices she deploys in the one-woman comedy Application Pending might not be surprising. But the speed with which she switches among them as she portrays dozens of characters is remarkable. Must we trot out the phrase tour de force? Yes, we must.

title: To an Overzealous Copy Editor
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Ah, an earworm puzzle with a twist: An overzealous, fictional copy editor has gotten hold of the puzzle and corrected all of the sensationalized spellings of some well-known musical groups. Thats funny. Its also one of the puzzles that was solved by competitors at the Westport, Conn., library crossword puzzle tournament this past Saturday, Feb. 7.

title: In a Bandbox Gym, a Team Thats Long Had Room for Improvement
description: The Pope Physical Education Center resides on the second floor of St. Francis Colleges main building in Brooklyn, just above the student center, below the library, past the community fish tank, and near enough to the swimming pool that when the gym doors are ajar the smell of chlorine washes over the entire arena.

title: Email to NBC News Staff About Brian Williams Suspension
description: Brian Williams, the NBC news anchor whose credibility fell after he acknowledged exaggerating his role in a helicopter incident in Iraq, was suspended for six months without pay, the network said Tuesday night.

title: De Blasio, Sipping Tea, Has to Take a Sick Day
description: The tickle arrived at the end of a long week, visiting Mayor Bill de Blasio amid final budget preparations, days after his State of the City address.

title: Bushs 2016 Tech Officer Ousted Over Offensive Remarks
description: In the first organizational upheaval of his likely presidential campaign, former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida parted ways Tuesday with a new aide who was to oversee his digital efforts.

title: Arizonas Director of Child Welfare Agency Is Replaced
description: Charles Flanagan, the director of Arizonas child services agency, created a year ago to fix widespread problems with how the state treated allegations of child abuse and neglect, was dismissed on Tuesdayby Gov. Doug Ducey.

title: Emerging Hillary Clinton Team Shows Signs of Disquiet
description: Lingering tensions between Hillary Rodham Clintons loyalists and the strategists who helped President Obama defeat her in 2008 have erupted into an intense public struggle over who will wield money and clout in her emerging 2016 presidential campaign.

title: Rapper, Shaped by Tumultuous German Youth, Is Designated a Global Terrorist
description: BERLIN  Denis Cuspert was drawn early to gangsta rap, and later to Islam. Born and raised in West Berlin, jeered at as a half-African child and often at odds with his American stepfather, he fell in with Salafists in Germany, left for Egypt in 2012 and made his way, eventually, to Syria. By last spring, the German authorities said, he had joined Islamic State guerrillas and swore allegiance to their leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

title: Big Aspirations Start in a Small Home
description: The St. Francis College Terriers, who play in a 1,200-seat gym in Brooklyn, are off to their best start in a decade.

title: Justified Recap: Lets Examine Avery Markhams Scheme
description: Season 6, Episode 4, The Trash and the Snake

title: Netanyahu Says Speech to Congress Is His Duty
description: JERUSALEM  For the third time in three days, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Tuesday that he still planned to address a joint meeting of Congress next month on the Iranian nuclear program, despite mounting calls here and abroad for him to cancel.

title: Big Aspirations Start in a Small Home
description: The St. Francis College Terriers, who play in a 1,200-seat gym in Brooklyn, are off to their best start in a decade.

title: French Teachers, on the Front Lines
description: SAINT-OUEN-LAUMNE, France  On a recent morning at the Lyce Edmond Rostand in this largely middle-class suburb of Paris, Cline Cauvin, a history and geography teacher, was leading high school students in a discussion about freedom of the press.

title: Missouri: Prosecutor Seeks Dismissal of Grand Jurors Lawsuit
description: The St. Louis County prosecutor, with the backing of Missouris attorney general, asked a federal judge on Monday to dismiss a lawsuit from a grand juror who wants to speak publicly about the case of Darren Wilson, the Ferguson police officer who fatally shot an unarmed black man last summer and was not indicted. Missouri law prevents grand jurors from discussing their work in most instances, and the 12-member panel that decided not to indict Mr. Wilson for killing Michael Brown, 18, has remained anonymous. One juror sued last month seeking protection from the restrictions, naming the prosecutor, Robert P. McCulloch, as the defendant. That lawsuit, which said that the publics understanding of the grand jury was not entirely accurate, indicated a willingness to discuss what happened during the hearings and advocate for legislative change to the way grand juries are conducted. In the lawsuit, the grand juror, who is represented by the American Civil Liberties Union of Missouri, indicated a fear of being prosecuted if he or she spoke publicly.

title: Decrees Governing Frances Bakeries Prompt a Wider Debate on Work Rules
description: PARIS  Stphane Cazenave, a baker in Saint-Paul-ls-Dax in southwestern France, was awarded a prize last year for best traditional baguette, in a contest organized by the confederation of French bakers. Back home, business was good, and Mr. Cazenave kept his bakery open seven days a week.

title: Greek Prime Minister Tsipras Wins Confidence Vote Before Talks With Creditors
description: ATHENS  With Greece preparing for tough talks with creditors in Brussels, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's government easily won a confidence vote in Parliament early Wednesday with assurances that it would reverse an economic program that has slashed living standards.

title: Midcentury Modernism Arrives in the California Desert
description: In the coming days, design and art lovers will descend on the desert east of Los Angeles for the 10th edition of Palm Springs Modernism Week. Among the lectures, house tours, exhibitions and fairs this year, one unofficial event stands out  and even offers the chance for the snowbound to get in on the action. The auction site Paddle8 has partnered with the design firm Homepolish to create Desert Living: Icons of Modern Design, a pop-up series of interiors vignettes at the Ace Hotel and Swim Clubs 4,000-square-foot clubhouse space. The four installations, says Jason Stein, Paddle8s senior design specialist, reflect what our favorite homes in Palm Springs would be; a setting wed want to live in. And though midcentury art and design are, as expected, well represented, the collectibles on offer extend far beyond the Mad Men-era nostalgia typically associated with the region. One California-themed tableau includes Frank Gehrys cardboard chair, Bill Currys Cattail lamp, John Baldessari prints and an Ed Ruscha painting; another explores the notion of opulence through such pieces as a chrome 1970s Gucci wine cooler and a Helmut Newton nude photograph. And a future-themed area features Gerald McCabes seven-stemmed Daisy table and artwork by Kenny Scharf, Sam Francis and David Hockney. The environments will be accessible to visitors this weekend and are, Stein promises, really layered; for those stuck in less salubrious climes, everything is up for auction starting Wednesday on the Paddle8 site.

title: The Perfect Pint (of Ice Cream)
description: It may seem unlikely given the time of year, but a handful of indie ice cream makers across the country introduced new, handcrafted flavors this month. And the small-batch pints, created in collaboration with other American purveyors of artisanal goods and available to be shipped anywhere in the U.S., are a welcome relief from the traditional Valentines Day sweets this time of year.

title: The Damien Hirst of New Delhi Brings a Personal Exhibition to New York
description: Many of the objects in Subodh Guptas career-spanning new exhibition, Seven Billion Light Years, are ordinary: The works on display include kitchen utensils piled together as part of a sculpture, a window buried in the ground and a broken stove attached to a painting. But Gupta thinks of them as more than discards; these are also someone elses memories on display. Because he transforms certain objects into larger-than-life, sometimes shocking sculptures, Gupta has been called the Damien Hirst of New Delhi; alternately, his methods of appropriating and displaying other peoples objects could be described as Duchampian. The truth is, Gupta is a sentimentalist at heart. His objects, whether gilded or left as-is, are intimately bound up with Indian culture  agriculture and cooking traditions that are fading away from modern society.

title: A Lesson in Natural Makeup From the Masterful Pat McGrath
description: The makeup artist Pat McGrath is a master of creating bold, hashtag-worthy looks with her whimsical use of sequins, glitter and Crayola-like color, but her most impressive trompe loeil might be when her handiwork is completely invisible to the eye. When shes not pushing the avant-garde with wild materials, McGraths makeup can be so subtle that it appears as if the models arent wearing any at all. As it turns out, achieving this no-makeup makeup effect (seen on many a runway  and surely many more in the weeks to come during the fall/winter 2015 fashion shows), requires the right mix of products (11 to be exact) and ample blending. Here, McGrath reveals the secrets behind her stealth technique that results in casual perfection.

title: The Human Touch
description: As fashion continues to demand ever more output and speed, many designers are finding freedom in the artisanal. Welcome to a season of exposed topstitching, frayed edges, crinkled linen, drawstring burlap and other disciplines of applied art.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New Starring Helena Bonham Carter and Kim Gordon
description: The Oscar-nominated actress and the noise-rock pioneer chew on duck-fat caramels, jazzy rap and the anti-Barbie.

title: Judge Orders Saints Owner to Take Psychiatric Examination
description: As part of a fight over the future ownership of the Saints, a district court judge in New Orleans has ordered the teams owner, Tom Benson, to take an examination to determine if he is mentally fit. Benson said last month that his third wife, Gayle, would inherit the Saints and the New Orleans Pelicans when he dies. Bensons daughter and two grandchildren sued, claiming Gayle Benson had taken advantage of her husbands infirmities to wrest control of the teams.

title: Word of the Day | impenetrable
description: impenetrable  \()im-pe-n-tr-bl\  adjective

title: Residents of Brooklyn Housing Project Stay Wary After Officer Is Indicted
description: Akai Gurley carried no weapon, they said. All he did was step into a darkened stairwell.

title: Jails Have Become Warehouses for the Poor, Ill and Addicted, a Report Says
description: Jails across the country have become vast warehouses made up primarily of people too poor to post bail or too ill with mental health or drug problems to adequately care for themselves, according to a report issued Wednesday.

title: Obama Administration Plans to Open Center to Fight Cyberattacks
description: President Obamas homeland security adviser said Tuesday that the administration was planning to open a new center that would quickly assess and deter cyberattacks on the United States.

title: Whats on TV Wednesday
description: 7 P.M. (Reelz) INVICTUS (2009) This rousing drama from Clint Eastwood, based on the book Playing the Enemy by John Carlin, was inspired by a true story of reconciliation and athletic triumph. Morgan Freeman portrays Nelson Mandela, newly elected as South Africas first black president, and Matt Damon is Franois Pienaar, the captain of the Springbok rugby team, a source of Afrikaner pride despised by many blacks. Mandela views the team as a vehicle to bring the countrys races together, especially if it can win the Rugby World Cup tournament in 1995, which South Africa is to host. Invictus has implications beyond its immediate time and place that are hard to miss, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Its an exciting sports movie, an inspiring tale of prejudice overcome and, above all, a fascinating study of political leadership. In Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom (2013), Justin Chadwicks biopic, at 6:35 on Showtime, Idris Elba portrays Mandela and Naomie Harris is his wife, Winnie. Mr. Elbas towering performance lends Long Walk to Freedom a Shakespearean breadth, Stephen Holden wrote in The Times. His Mandela is an intensely emotional man whose body quakes in moments of sorrow and whose face is stricken with a bone-deep anguish. The carefully chosen words in his eloquent declarations of principle, spoken with gravity and deliberation, are deeply stirring.

title: Corrections: February 11, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: In Yemen, Militants Are Increasingly Isolated
description: SANA, Yemen  The Houthi militiamen who effectively rule Yemen were increasingly isolated Wednesday as several Western countries joined the United States in closing their embassies here, despite few signs of deteriorating security in the streets.

title: Keep Focus on Ebola
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Fence the Jaguar Out
description: BOZEMAN, Mont.  IT was near the United States-Mexico border that we attracted the attention of the Mexican military. My scientific colleagues and I  American and Mexican  were there to conduct research on large carnivores when we were stopped by several officers with rifles slung over their shoulders.

title: What Is the Purpose of Society?
description: The world of food and agriculture symbolizes most of whats gone wrong in the United States. But because food is plentiful for most people, and the damage that conventional agriculture does isnt readily evident to everyone, its important that we look deeper, beyond food, to the structure that underlies most decisions: the political economy.
