title: A Sentimental Cover Song From the Singer-Songwriter Jessie Baylin
description: A lot has changed for Jessie Baylin since the release of her 2012 album, Little Spark. For starters, the New Jersey-born singer-songwriter has put down some serious roots in Tennessee with her husband, the Kings of Leon drummer Nathan Followill. She also became a mother to their now-2-year-old daughter Violet, and she strongly considered putting her music career to bed for good. I wasnt sure if I wanted to make another album, she recalls from her Nashville home. I felt something was happening and I had some ideas, but I wasnt writing as much and my focus was elsewhere.

title: Coach: Fall 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Comparing Authorizations of Force
description: Comparing President Obamas proposal for Congress to authorize use of force against the Islamic State to authorizations approved in 2001 and 2002.

title: Newtown Panels Report Aims to Improve Safety
description: More than two years after Adam Lanza shot and killed 20 schoolchildren and six faculty members at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., as well as killing his mother and himself, a state commission released a draft report of a wide-ranging set of recommendations on Thursday with the goal of preventing such killings.

title: Ginsburg Says U.S. Is Largely Ready for Gay Marriage
description: Despite the recent tumult in Alabama surrounding same-sex marriage, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said on Thursday that it would not take a large adjustment for the country if the Supreme Court ruled that same-sex marriage was a constitutional right.

title: Studying Oversize Brain Cells for Links to Exceptional Memory
description: In 2010, a graduate student named Tamar Gefen got to know a remarkable group of older people.

title: Ford and Forza Team Up on New GT, a Supercar for Street and Screen
description: DETROIT  ONE of the biggest coups of the recent North American International Auto Show in Detroit was Fords new GT, a sleek supercar that was developed in secret and revealed to a surprised audience.

title: U.S. Court to Hear Tsarnaevs Bid to Move Bombing Trial Out of Boston
description: BOSTON  A federal appeals court said Thursday that it would hear arguments on whether to move the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the Boston Marathon bombings, out of the city.

title: A Closely Watched Metric That Can Be More Art Than Math
description: As investors engage in an increasingly desperate global competition for higher-yielding securities, debt issuers appear to be taking advantage of the extraordinary demand by manipulating one of Wall Streets favorite metrics of profitability.

title: N.B.A. Is Having an All-Star Party (and Youre Not Invited to the Main Event)
description: The N.B.A. is doing just fine these days. The game is in the hands of immensely popular stars like LeBron James and Kevin Durant. New contenders, like the Golden State Warriors and the Atlanta Hawks, have added appealing story lines to the regular season. And the leagues owners will soon be reaping the benefits of a new television contract that will pay out $2.66 billion a year, nearly triple the amount of the current deal.

title: Do Millennials Watch Jon Stewart?
description: The conventional wisdom is that the millennial generation is infatuated with Jon Stewarts The Daily Show  to the point where its their main news source  but thats not right.

title: Waiting to Wed in Alabama
description: For three days, same-sex couples and their supporters camped out in the Mobile, Ala., probate court, waiting to be issued marriage licenses.

title: Verbal Warming: Labels in the Climate Debate
description: The words are hurled around like epithets.

title: F.B.I. Director Speaks Out on Race and Police Bias
description: WASHINGTON  The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, delivered an unusually candid speech on Thursday about the difficult relationship between the police and African-Americans, saying that officers who work in neighborhoods where blacks commit crimes at a high rate develop a cynicism that shades their attitudes about race.

title: Senate Gives Approval for Defense Secretary, if Not His Bosss Policies
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday confirmed Ashton B. Carter to be the next defense secretary, installing a new Pentagon chief as the United States increases military action against the Islamic State.

title: Let Children Change
description: For a large part of my life, I was constantly late. I spent hours in detention in high school, and was once threatened with jail for being late to court as a lawyer. Our oldest son was tardy (because of me) more than 50 times during his first semester of kindergarten. I annoyed people, disappointed people, let people down.

title: Larry Summers Likes the Idea of Bitcoin
description: As Treasury secretary, Lawrence H. Summers took on complex economic policy.

title: A Deep Discount on Yahoos Alibaba Stake Spinoff
description: Yahoo cant even earn a reward for doing what shareholders wanted.

title: QE Truthers
description: Everyone knows about the infamous open letter warning Ben Bernanke not to engage in quantitative easing, lest he cause inflation and currency debasement; many are also familiar with the remarkable unwillingness of that letters signatories to admit, after more than four years of low inflation and a rising dollar, that they were wrong. But not many people seem to know about an opinion piece by John Taylor and Paul Ryan, released at about the same time, that is even more revealing about the GOPs monetary madness.

title: Disney Tackles Succession, This Time Without Drama
description: To the growing list of Robert Igers accomplishments during his near-decade tenure as Disneys chief executive, add succession planning.

title: Review: Tomi Ungerer, Bad Boy of Art, in a Reappraisal
description: Among New Yorks several alternative spaces, the Drawing Center often seems to do the least with the most. Its recently refurbished, overdone SoHo space regularly features exhibitions that end up looking academic, dutiful and dull, regardless of how interesting they may be in concept. They also can seem weirdly repressed, as if the Drawing Center wants to protect us from the deep thrill of perhaps the most intimate and irresistible  and the sexiest  of all art mediums.

title: Fashion Week Parties: Kick-Off
description: AmfAR hosts its annual kickoff to New York Fashion Week and VFIles takes over Space Ibiza.

title: F.B.I. Director Speaks About Race
description: James B. Comey, the director of the F.B.I., made a speech at Georgetown University in which he called for an honest discussion about race and the attitudes of law enforcement.

title: BCBG Max Azria: Fall 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: U.S. Is Escalating a Secretive War in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  As an October chill fell on the mountain passes that separate the militant havens in Afghanistan and Pakistan, a small team of Afghan intelligence commandos and American Special Operations forces descended on a village where they believed a leader of Al Qaeda was hiding.

title: A Charming Valentines Gift for the Norman Rockwell Museum
description: Just in time for Valentines Day, the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, Mass., is receiving a sweet gift  sweet in subject matter but made all the sweeter because the museum itself could probably never have afforded to buy the gift. It announced the donation to its permanent collection of Boy and Girl Gazing at the Moon (Puppy Love), a 1926 painting that Rockwell created for a cover of The Saturday Evening Post, a heartland scene of a redheaded boy and pigtailed girl sitting side by side on a rickety bench, mooning at the moon.

title: Car Carrying Bob Simon Sped Up Before Crash, Authorities Say
description: The livery cab that was carrying the CBS News correspondent Bob Simon on Wednesday night when it slammed into metal barricades, killing Mr. Simon, was speeding up in the seconds before the crash, the authorities said on Thursday.

title: Patacon Pisao
description: Venezuelan street food on the Lower East Side.

title: Plantains, Top to Bottom
description: The cachapa is enormous even flopped in on itself, a thick pancake of ground sweet corn with whole kernels peeking through. Inside is mozzarella, caught mid-ooze, and two bands of double-smoked bacon, each as broad as a strop, juicy with brine and curling black at the edges. No distinction is allowed between salty and sweet, as if one could not exist without the other.

title: Cisco and Texas Instruments Adapt to a New Tech World
description: For at least a couple of old tech companies, the week offered some good news. And perhaps some lessons about what survival, even prosperity, will look like.

title: Minnesota Orchestra Going to Cuba
description: The Minnesota Orchestra announced Thursday that it would travel to Havana to play two concerts in May, making it the first major American orchestra to play there since President Obama moved to normalize relations with Cuba.

title: Breaking Up With My Meds
description: In the fall of 2014 the author decided to quit the prescription medications she has been taking to treat her anxiety, depression and insomnia, and began the process of gradually reducing her dosages. In Going Off, a series of Anxiety posts in the coming weeks, she will chronicle the challenges she faces from both the drugs and the withdrawal in her pursuit of a drug-free life.

title: Starved for Energy,Pakistan Braces for a Water Crisis
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Energy-starved Pakistanis, their economy battered by chronic fuel and electricity shortages, may soon have to contend with a new resource crisis: major water shortages, the Pakistani government warned this week.

title: Obama, a Selfie Stick and the Affordable Care Act
description: President Obama has made it abundantly clear that he will do almost anything to make sure the Affordable Care Act is a success.

title: Big City Book Club Discusses The Assistant
description: Thanks to everyone who participated in tonights lively discussion. We encourage all who chatted here tonight to sign up as a member of the Big City Club so that you can receive emails and notifications about our upcoming discussions.

title: A Secret Skate-Park Clubhouse for Grown-Up Brooklynites
description: Skateboarding, like playing in rock bands or foregoing health insurance, tends to be viewed as the province of the very young. But for one group of mostly Brooklyn-based men in their 30s and 40s, many of whom came of age on the ramps and rails of lower Manhattan in the 80s and 90s, skating is still very much a way of life. And now, in a low-slung Long Island City warehouse, a group of 40 or so of them have erected a monument to their hobby: a secret, members-only DIY club reputed to be the largest and most elaborate skate park in town.

title: Study Finds Rising Levels of Plastics in Oceans
description: Some eight million metric tons of plastic waste makes its way into the worlds oceans each year, and the amount of the debris is likely to increase greatly over the next decade unless nations take strong measures to dispose of their trash responsibly, new research suggests.

title: Saturday Night Live Documentary Will Kick Off Tribeca Film Festival
description: A documentary about the 40-year history of Saturday Night Live will open the 14th annual Tribeca Film Festival, organizers said Thursday.

title: Few Health System Studies Use Top Method, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The gold standard of scientific research, routinely used in the development of new drugs, has been neglected in studies meant to improve the American health care system, researchers reported on Thursday in the journal Science.

title: Ebola Victims Still Infectious a Week After Death, Scientists Find
description: People who die of Ebola probably remain infectious for at least a week after death, according to a new study.

title: Cush Jumbo Summons the Spirit ofJosephine Baker at Joes Pub
description: Josephine Baker made her professional debut at just a year old, in 1907, joining the finale of her mothers song-and-dance act in honky-tonks and wine rooms. Cush Jumbo waited until the comparatively advanced age of 4 to step onstage, tap-dancing with her older sister to When Youre Smiling at their local South London theater.

title: In a Shift, Pakistan Pats Afghanistan on the Back
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In a sign of closer cooperation between often hostile neighbors, Pakistans military on Thursday credited Afghanistan with helping to capture the Taliban militants who orchestrated the attack on a Peshawar school in December that killed 150 people.

title: Details of the Ukraine Cease-Fire Negotiated in Minsk
description: MOSCOW  The 13-point agreement to end the war in Ukraine reached after 16 hours of negotiations in Minsk, Belarus, is no less precarious than previous cease-fire deals.

title: Debate sobre el biocombustible: reducir el carbono quemar rboles y cosechas?
description: Read this article in English.

title: As Tiger Woods Motivates Lindsey Vonn, Her Finale Is Positive if Not Medal Worthy
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  Lindsey Vonn and Tiger Woods kissed in the finish area Thursday after Vonn struggled and finished 27th in the first run of the giant slalom at the Alpine world ski championships.

title: New York Fashion Week Parties: Kick-Off
description: New York Fashion Week unofficially kicked off Wednesday night with the amfAR gala at Cipriani Wall Street. Meanwhile, at Space Ibiza, the VFiles after-party was decidedly not black tie. Here are some photos.

title: Deal for Orbitz Shows Merger Boom Has Room to Go
description: Expedias plan to buy Orbitz Worldwide indicates that some first-class M.&A. tickets remain available.

title: Easy on the Eyes at Richard Chai
description: I wanted it to feel really lived-in, cigarette on one hand, glass in the other, like shes really having a good time, explained the makeup artist Mark Carrasquillo about his 90s-inspired beauty look for Richard Chais fall/winter 2015 collection. What Kate Moss and Shalom Harlow looked like at parties after the shows.

title: A Sharp Loss for Kellogg as Sales of Cereal Falter
description: Consumers continued to shun cereal and its snack bar derivatives, causing steep losses at the Kellogg Company at the end of last year.

title: Creatures of the Wind: Fall 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Private Eye Is Said to Face Prosecution in a Hacking
description: Private investigators may be the newest front for federal prosecutors in cracking down on the hacker-for-hire business.

title: A Shrine to Modi? No Thanks, Indias Premier Says
description: NEW DELHI  Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India publicly distanced himself on Thursday from a gesture of idolatry from his followers, a group of whom recently attempted to inaugurate a temple in his honor in the western state of Gujarat.

title: Professor Biden Expounds on Population Replacement Rates
description: The students gathered at Drake University in Des Moines, Iowa, on Thursday were treated to over 90 minutes of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., visiting professor.

title: Duckie Brown: Fall 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Concern in Denmark as Its Currencys Peg to the Euro Is Strained
description: COPENHAGEN  To better understand the wave of negative interest rates among European central banks, consider the krone.

title: Ukraine Cease-Fire Leaves Control of Border Unresolved Until Years End
description: WASHINGTON  The cease-fire accord announced in Minsk on Thursday was hailed by Secretary of State John Kerry and European leaders as a potential breakthrough that could finally bring the bitter conflict in Ukraine to an end.

title: With Convention, Philadelphia Scores Rare Win Over New York
description: Democrats are in a Philly state of mind, having chosen the city to host their 2016 convention, and for the City of Brotherly Love, it is a rare win in a heated rivalry that most Philadelphians feel passionate about and many New Yorkers tend to ignore.

title: Where to Eat, Stay and Wander in Hollywood
description: As the film industry has changed, Hollywood as a tourist destination has as well  less defined and more dispersed, not so much a neat geographical dot on the map as a mind-set. Heres where to find it.

title: Hollywood Gets Its Groove Back
description: Hollywoods grande dame hotels, the Sunset Tower and the Chateau Marmont, stand like stone sentries on Sunset Boulevard, less than two miles from the decidedly less stylish stretch of Hollywood Boulevard that hustles from morning to night with camera-toting tourists and Spiderman and Batman impersonators. The Tower and the Chateau are as romantic, seductive and happening as ever, at once guardians of an imperiled history but very much of the moment, with deal-making lunches and opening parties drawing clumps of paparazzi outside the driveway of Chateau Marmont, and limousines backed up along Sunset Boulevard in front of the Sunset Tower.

title: A Peek at the Promised Land
description: Recent years have been grim for red Burgundy lovers. Rising demand worldwide and several consecutive microscopic vintages have combined to send prices soaring to the vertigo-inducing heights once reserved for cult cabernets and other wines better suited to be status-conferring luxury goods.

title: Buddhist Art of Myanmar
description: Works in the new show at Asia Society.

title: New York Fashion Week: Creatures of the Wind Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: F.B.I. Director James Comey on How Everyones a Little Bit Racist
description: The hostility that Republican lawmakers and conservative commentators directed at Attorney General Eric Holder when he spoke openly  and truthfully  about racial profiling was clearly related to the fact that Mr. Holder is black. How will the same politicians and talking heads respond to a similarly frank speech that the F.B.I. director James B. Comey, who is white, delivered at Georgetown University today?

title: A Collection of Campaign Mementos, Starting With Washington, Goes to Auction
description: Merrill C. Berman runs an investment firm in Rye, N.Y., that doubles as home to his collection of about 20,000 works on paper. With one full-time employee, he keeps track of prints, posters, drawings, collages, postcards, brochures, buttons, billboards, stationery and sundry graphics produced in the last two centuries. The pieces express strong opinions, whether protesting against capitalists or making ham and spark plugs look glamorous.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Kingsman
description: The director Matthew Vaughn narrates a sequence from Kingsman: The Secret Service.

title: Hooked on the Freewheeling Podcast Serial
description: Its hard to say what, exactly, made Serial, the breakaway podcast about an old murder, so addictive.

title: Ex-Knick Anthony Mason in Hospital After Serious Heart Attack
description: Anthony Mason, a cornerstone of the tough-minded Knicks teams that came close to winning an N.B.A. championship in the 1990s, was in a New York-area hospital on Thursday, battling the effects of a serious heart attack that appeared to put his life in jeopardy.

title: Matthew Vaughn Narrates a Scene From Kingsman: The Secret Service
description: In this video, the director Matthew Vaughn discusses a sequence from his spy thriller Kingsman: The Secret Service, based on the comic book series by Mark Millar. The scene features a group of new recruits vying to become Kingsmen, who are presented with a task that could prove deadly if not completed correctly.

title: A Millennial Caregiver
description: The bad news from my mother arrived as a text: In the emergency room all day today. fluid in lung. doctor said it looks suspiciously like cancer.

title: New York Fashion Week: Creatures of the Wind Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: Review: Exploring Buddhist Art of Myanmar at Asia Society
description: Religious images live switched-on, switched-off lives. I remember walking through the National Museum in Kyoto, Japan, some years back, taking in its rows of Buddhist sculpture, and being stopped by one piece, not because it was especially beautiful  it wasnt  but because a vase with a single fresh flower had been placed in front of it, like an offering in a temple. I stayed with the image because someone  a guard? a visitor?  was telling me, in terms I dont often think of in museums, that it was important, in a personal, spiritual way.

title: A Valentines Day Weekend of Pet Adoptions, Chocolate and Improv
description: Not long ago, one of the Misers single friends celebrated Valentines Day by adopting a puppy, a Chihuahua-pug mix named Whiskey. It seemed impulsive at the time, but Whiskey  were talking about the dog here  quickly became and remains a source of happy distractions.

title: New York Fashion Week: Duckie Brown Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: New York Fashion Week: Duckie Brown Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: Paris Aims to Embrace Its Estranged Suburbs
description: GRIGNY, France  Paris is about to get bigger, much bigger. Next year, assuming plans move ahead, the city and a ring of inner suburbs will be joined, in an effort to redress a centurys worth of urban decisions that have exacerbated the countrys gaping cultural divide.

title: Leaders Comment on Minsk Agreement
description: The leaders of Russia, Ukraine, Germany and France, the main players in the cease-fire negotiations in Minsk, discuss the talks.

title: How Should a Person Handle Heartbreak?
Assaf Shaham: Division of the Vision
description: Assaf Shahams first solo show in the United States is full of ambitious gestures. Most of them concern the history of photography and its demise as a chemical medium, which as a subject for art making may be on the verge of exhaustion, although Mr. Shaham squeezes out a few more points.

title: Reaction to Journalists Being Freed
description: Family members of two Al Jazeera journalists arrested in December 2013, Mohamed Fahmy and Baher Mohamed, spoke after an Egyptian court freed the men while the government moved toward a retrial.

title: Jan Schoonhoven at David Zwirner
description: This is the largest overview yet mounted in New York of the tender, Minimally inclined art of Jan Schoonhoven (1914-1994), a Dutch artist who emerged in the postwar period and by the early 1960s was making white-on-white wall reliefs of shallow grids. Built from paper, cardboard and wood painted white, these grids dominate the show, their units square or rectangular, their perpendicular divisions thick or thin. Invariably enriched by the play of light  especially when their interior planes are slanted  they achieve both a quietly stunning variety and a sense of timelessness through utmost simplicity.

title: Susan Bee: Photograms and Altered Photos From the 1970s
description: During the 1970s, the artist Susan Bee was writing a masters thesis on the photograms of Moholy-Nagy and Man Ray at Hunter College; helping to edit an experimental poetry magazine, L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E, with her husband, Charles Bernstein; and making her own photographic experiments in a cramped studio. As her personal interests shifted increasingly toward painting, she packed the photographs away. They recently resurfaced in storage and Southfirst has been smart enough to make a beautiful show of them.

title: Tal R: Altstadt Girl
description: When the Danish artist Tal R started emerging on the international scene in the early oughties, he had talent to burn and seemed to do just that, frittering it away on works that were both seductive and disposable, fun to look at and easy to forget. But over the past few years, something more fixed and solid has crept into his art. It is especially noticeable in this show of smallish, concentrated paintings of modern life. They stick with you.

title: Sweet Kitten Heels on Coachs Tough, Boho-Chic Runway
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Off the Runway
description: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.

title: At W Hotels, a Room and a New Dating Profile Photo
description: Calling all lonely travelers: W Hotels of New York wants to help you. And although the company cant get into the matchmaking business outright, it can offer guests some assistance with online dating.

title: Crossing at Your Peril
description: When the trains approach and the barriers descend, motorists sometimes have little time to reverse to safety at one rail crossing in Elmwood Park, N.J.

title: Effortless Hair to Accompany Honors Easy, Romantic Fall/Winter 2015 Collection
description: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

title: In New York Area, Points Where Train and Tragedy Are Likely to Intersect
description: The former police chief in Elmwood Park, N.J., vividly remembers the moment 30 years ago when the gates at the railroad crossing on the edge of town lowered on the bus carrying his son and his classmates on a field trip.

title: In Rare Show of Consensus, President Signs Veterans Act Into Law
description: President Obama on Thursday hosted what has often felt like a rarity in recent years: a White House bill-signing ceremony.

title: Review:Stphane Denve Leads the Philharmonic in What Feels Like an Audition
description: With the announcement last week from the New York Philharmonic that Alan Gilbert will step aside as music director in the summer of 2017, every appearance by a guest conductor is going to be seen as a tryout for the job. So it was on Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, when the acclaimed French conductor Stphane Denve made his much-anticipated Philharmonic debut.

title: Review: Meshell Ndegeocello Hails Nina Simone
description: There were moments of such intensity during Meshell Ndegeocellos Lincoln Center American Songbook concert on Wednesday evening that she and her musicians seemed to be conjuring a supernatural trance. The show, Pour Une me Souveraine  A Dedication to Nina Simone, at the Appel Room, focused on material from Ms. Ndegeocellos 2012 album of the same name. In her refusal to adhere to a style, or to stay within a genre, Ms. Ndegeocello is a direct descendant of Ms. Simone, who played by nobodys rules and paid dearly for it.

title: Review: Richard Egarr and Carlo Grante on Keyboards
description: Two recitals this week  one wonderful, one not  set a listener to thinking about keyboards, their composers and their players.

title: Why Hacking the Atmosphere Wont Happen Any Time Soon
description: Its worth spending some more time on the National Academy of Sciences reports on geoengineering prospects and concerns  the concerns mainly being about adding sun-blocking particles to the atmosphere to counteract global warming driven by the buildup of heat-trapping greenhouse gases.

title: Sofia Coppolas Juicy Red Valentine
description: Sixteen years ago, the filmmaker and vintner Francis Ford Coppola named a personal batch of blanc de blancs sparkling wine after his effervescent daughter Sofia, who loved it so much that they decided to produce it on a larger scale and sell it to the public. The blend, best known as the bubbly packaged in chic little raspberry-colored cans (accompanied by miniature straws), became the first Coppola wine named after Sofia. To date, the collection has also included a non-alcoholic sparkling beverage, an off-dry riesling, a refreshing ros and a soft, versatile chardonnay. And this Saturday, on Valentines Day, Coppola introduces the first bottle of red to bear her name, with a flavor profile designed, in part, by her.

title: Review: Martha Graham Dance Revisits a Classic in Gala
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company, founded in 1926, is always searching for ways to stay relevant: cleverly reinventing classics, commissioning new works from trendy choreographers. For its current season at the Joyce Theater, its artistic director, Janet Eilber, has enlisted even bigger, more recognizable names than usual, more determined than ever, it seems, to broaden the troupes appeal.

title: Christies and Sothebys Auctions in London Keep the Bubble Afloat
description: London  When art prices rise and rise, theres always talk of a bubble. But could the 21st-century contemporary art boom be a bubble that never really bursts?

title: Review: The Reporter Ethel Payne in Eye on the Struggle
description: During its heyday in the first half of the 20th century, The Chicago Defender was Americas premier black newspaper. Every issue carried its blazing motto: American Race Prejudice Must Be Destroyed.

title: Review: From Ancient to Modern Ponders the Origins of Sumerian Artifacts
description: What happens to ancient artifacts after theyre dug up by archaeologists is more complicated than the casual museumgoer might realize. From Ancient to Modern: Archaeology and Aesthetics, a thought-provoking exhibition at New York Universitys Institute for the Study of the Ancient World, tells a fascinating tale about the 20th-century discovery and interpretation of some extraordinary objects made by Sumerian artisans about 4,500 years ago.

title: Ride-Hailing Service Lyft Is Said to Be in Talks to Raise $250 Million
description: In the battle over ride-hailing services, Lyft is preparing a counterpunch against Uber, its much bigger rival.

title: Celebrating the Chinese Lion Dance
description: Jason Lam stepped out from his lion dance costume to document a tradition that serves as a hinge between his Chinese ancestry and his American upbringing.

title: A Room of Their Own
description: A look inside the presidential suite at the Waldorf Astoria.

title: Security Headaches Doomed Brooklyn Bid for Democratic Convention
description: In pitching a Democratic National Convention at an arena just blocks from his home in Park Slope, Brooklyn, Mayor Bill de Blasio hoped to capitalize on the alchemy of liberal politics and multicultural cool that propelled his own rise to prominence.

title: Inside the Waldorf Astorias Presidential Suite
description: YOU probably wont be eligible for the generous discount accorded federal employees on official business. Youll have to make do without the monogrammed towels and bedding and the bulletproof panes of window glass. Nor will a special Metro-North train be manned and idling on a siding below Park Avenue to whisk you away in case Midtown Manhattan traffic becomes impassable.

title: Letters: The Sacrifice
description: The Sacrifice

title: Greek Debt Standoff Awaits a Decisive Move
description: Clad in snug black pants and his signature untucked shirt, the Greek finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, sauntered into a conference room in the Berlin headquarters of the German finance ministry.

title: Review: Bosch, Amazon Primes New Crime Series
description: The list of brooding, taciturn small-screen police detectives is already impossibly long, so you might think Amazon made a mistake in committing to Bosch, whose title character is yet another variation. But this 10-episode series, which is being rolled out Friday on Amazon Prime, proves gripping nonetheless.

title: Obama Signs Suicide Prevention for Veterans Act Into Law
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama signed a measure into law on Thursday to fight a wave of suicide among veterans struggling with post-traumatic stress, a problem that has won increased attention as American troops have returned from Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: Review: Costa da Morte Lustrously Depicts Extreme Coastlines
description: The Galicia region of Spain may have found a potential filmmaker laureate in Lois Patio, who lustrously portrays its extreme coastal environments in Costa da Morte. In this high-definition series of cinematic landscape paintings, fishermen, woodcutters and other hardy mortals are often mere matchsticks within improbable panoramas of shimmering blue ocean, rock cascades and towering trees shrouded in mist.

title: Pictures of the Day: United States, China and Elsewhere
description: Ukraine, Germany and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Feb. 12, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the United States, China, Ukraine and Germany.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Review: In White Rabbit, a Bullied Teenager Is Pushed to the Edge
description: The opening of White Rabbit leaves little doubt that a storm is brewing: A teenager named Harlon broods in a car, then turns to the camera with the heavy slowness of a reptile. Like the thickly atmospheric photography, the shot sets a foreboding tone. But all too much of Tim McCanns drama about this disturbed loner comes to feel like a checklist of warning signs.

title: In the Studio | Victoria Beckham
description: Victoria Beckham chats with Vanessa Friedman about being a working mother in charge of a growing fashion label at her minimal office in the Battersea area of South London.

title: Review: Wyrmwood: Road of the Dead Puts Zombies in the Outback
description: Like greyhounds after the hare, Wyrmwood: Road of the Dead bursts out of the gate panting and doesnt let up. The hare in this case is a mysterious zombie plague that follows a meteor shower in the Australian outback, and the greyhounds are a pair of siblings whose particular talents  one artisanal, the other supernormal  prove especially useful in battling the undead.

title: Review: Hits, a Comedy, Lampoons Internet Fame
description: One bit on David Cross and Bob Odenkirks 1990s sketch program, Mr. Show, featured a yokel who, after the siege in Ruby Ridge, Idaho, declared his house a sovereign nation. That sharp, even impatient strain of satire returns in full force with Mr. Crosss modest, focused directorial debut, Hits, which also centers on an embattled citizen.

title: G.O.P. Consultant Pleads Guilty in PAC Case
description: A Virginia-based Republican political consultant pleaded guilty on Thursday to charges that he illegally coordinated spending between a 2012 congressional campaign and a super PAC, federal prosecutors said.

title: Review: The Last Five Years, a Decoupling Starring Anna Kendrick
description: The Last Five Years, the composer Jason Robert Browns emotionally fraught musical about a passionate relationship that crashes and burns, almost requires some familiarity with its rarefied milieu: the New York City hothouse of ravenously ambitious performers and writers. Over the years, the show, which had its premiere in Chicago in 2001 and opened Off Broadway the next year, has gained traction as a regional theater staple. It is now a movie adapted and directed by Richard LaGravenese. Its lovers, Cathy Hiatt, an aspiring actress played by a winsome Anna Kendrick, and Jamie Wellerstein, by a fire-breathing Jeremy Jordan, fall in love and marry in a whirlwind of romantic hyperbole.

title: Clip: Da Sweet Blood of Jesus
description: A scene from the film.

title: Neighbors Say Suspect in Chapel Hill Shootings Was Threatening
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  Neighbors knew Craig Stephen Hicks. He was the angry man on Summerwalk Circle, they said  irritated about noise, irascible about parking, hostile to religion. And armed.

title: Ackman and Dalio, Two Hedge Fund Titans, Size Each Other Up
description: William A. Ackman, the billionaire hedge fund manager, was trying hard not to talk about himself.

title: Theater Listings for Feb. 13-19
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: Da Sweet Blood of Jesus, Spike Lees Vampire Movie
description: Da Sweet Blood of Jesus, Spike Lees new film, is a grisly and ghoulish vampire story. It is also an evident labor of love. The opening images  a solitary dancer undulating on the Red Hook waterfront, the Brooklyn Heights Promenade and other Kings County spots  offer a reminder that no filmmaker has shot this borough as beautifully and fondly as Mr. Lee. Marthas Vineyard, where much of the action takes place, looks pretty good too. And though there are episodes of bloody mayhem and steamy sex, the mood is contemplative, at times almost serene. Mr. Lee has earned a reputation as a polemicist and provocateur, but he has also been, from the beginning, a sensualist and a visual stylist.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Swept Off Her Feet Solved
description: On Wednesday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 21-year-old college student with chronic headaches who suddenly became too dizzy to walk. She had a medical history that was complicated by back surgery and a subsequent infection, and chronic headaches after a car accident. More than 300 of you wrote in with suggested diagnoses, but only a handful of you noticed the clue that led the medical student who saw the patient to the right answer.

title: Save the Childrens Insurance
description: NO child in America should be denied the chance to see a doctor when he or she needs one  but if Congress doesnt act soon, thats exactly what might happen.

title: This Weeks Movies | Feb. 13, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Fifty Shades of Grey, Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem and The Last Five Years.

title: The New School Announces Effort to Defend Arts Integrity
description: The New School for Drama has established the Arts Integrity Initiative, a project that will both study and take an active role in instances in which theatrical and other works are censored or altered without authorization.

title: Egypt Restricts News Coverage of Slain Activist Shaimaa el-Sabbagh
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian authorities on Thursday barred the news media from discussing the case of a prominent activist whose killing last month has aroused outrage over the rate of civilian deaths from police violence.

title: For Oscars Telecast, Few Black Nominees Mean Fewer Black Viewers
description: LOS ANGELES  If past patterns hold, the next Academy Awards telecast might be remembered as the Revenge of Selma.

title: Review: In Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem, a Woman Fights for Her Freedom
description: The hypnotic Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem is the story of a woman wronged by men and God, if finally, in a sense, redeemed by cinema. Under Israeli law, a woman can be divorced only if her husband presents her with a religious bill of divorce called a gett (sometimes spelled get). No gett, no divorce. The long-suffering title character desperately wants to be free of her husband, who refuses to let her go. So year after year, Viviane pleads her case before a rabbinic court, waiting for her divorce as days slip into weeks and then months, her pacific face glazed with tears and her body occasionally rocked by a laugh tinged with knowing and madness.

title: Review: In The Rewrite, Hugh Grant Is an Author Seeking a Comeback
description: The Rewrite, the fourth screen collaboration of Hugh Grant and the director and screenwriter Marc Lawrence, is a return to form for the long-running team after the debacle six years ago of Did You Hear About the Morgans? By return to form, I dont mean to suggest that their pre-Morgans films  Two Weeks Notice and Music and Lyrics  were more than reasonably intelligent romantic comedies buoyed by Mr. Grants appeal as a bumbling, sheepish charmer.

title: Law Students Leave Torts Behind (for a Bit) and Tackle Accounting
description: A group of 170 Brooklyn Law School students cut short their winter break and headed back to campus in January for an intensive three-day training session. But not in the law.

title: An Auction Debut for Ai Weiweis Zodiac Heads, in London
description: LONDON  A set of 12 gilded bronze animal-head sculptures by the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei sold late Thursday night at Phillips in London to one of three telephone bidders for 2.9 million, with fees, or about $4.4 million.

title: Review: In Kingsman: The Secret Service, Colin Firth Get His Suits Splattered
description: If you dont mind the church full of parishioners who are slaughtered to the sounds of Lynyrd Skynyrds Free Bird or the Arab terrorists who are blown to smithereens or the guns that are pointed at pet dogs or the human heads that explode like firebombed melons as Pomp and Circumstance plays, it may be possible to enjoy Kingsman: The Secret Service. That said, as this bludgeoning movie grinds to a halt, its gears clogged by viscera and narrative overkill, even those who enjoy go-go gore may end up yearning for the soft touch and subtleties of Guy Ritchie.

title: Colorado: Senate Rejects Funding Plan for Drivers Licenses for Immigrants
description: An effort to fund the state program that provides drivers licenses to undocumented immigrants has failed, leaving the program with little ability to function. On Thursday, State Senator Jessie Ulibarri, a Democrat, submitted an amendment that would have assigned funds collected from immigrant applicants to pay for the program. The Republican-controlled Senate voted down the measure. Unauthorized immigrants can receive drivers licenses in 10 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. Colorados program began in 2014, and state motor vehicle offices issuing these license have been swamped with requests from immigrants. But critics maintain that the program rewards people who have crossed into the country without authorization. Last month, the states joint budget committee voted not to approve about $166,000 in new funds for the program, forcing officials to lay off workers and stop issuing the licenses at four of the five participating motor vehicle offices. One office, in Denver, was left to process the licenses.

title: Mexicos Guerrero State Heads Toward Elections
description: As the election season begins, what has been at best a tenuous hold on order in Mexicos most violent state is fast disintegrating.

title: Apple Backslides on Work-Hour Limits
description: Apple sold more iPhones last year than anyone could have imagined. But the company found that a lower percentage of factories assembling its products complied with a policy preventing excessive work hours.

title: Review: What We Do in the Shadows, a Vampire Comedy
description: A daring film crew, armed with crucifixes and guarantees of safety, sets out to record the daily lives of four vampire housemates in What We Do in the Shadows, a goofily amusing mockumentary from the New Zealand comedians and actors Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi.

title: Mexican Towns Galvanized by Tragedy
description: CHILPANCINGO, Mexico  A former cattle trader juggles two cellphones to direct truckloads of armed volunteers who have replaced the meager police forces across a swath of small towns.

title: Fox and Telemundo to Show World Cup Through 2026 as FIFA Extends Contracts
description: Fox and Telemundo have not shown a second of World Cup action, but on Thursday they added the 2026 Cup to their rights to broadcast the 2018 and 2022 soccer tournaments in the United States.

title: Missouri House Passes Right to Work Bill, Ignoring Threat of a Veto
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo.  A bill that would make Missouri the latest state to adopt so-called right-to-work laws or policies passed the Republican-controlled House here on Thursday, but without enough votes to override an expected veto from the Democratic governor.

title: Egypt to Purchase Fighter Jets and a Warship From France
description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande of France on Thursday announced the sale of nearly $6 billion worth of military hardware to Egypt, including two dozen Rafale fighter jets and a naval frigate.

title: The Making of Wild Tales, an Oscar Nominee
description: As the Argentine film director and screenwriter Damin Szifrn sees it, what separates civilization from barbarism is a complex battery of social inhibitors that prevent us from retaliating with violence to the many slights and aggravations of daily life. But thats definitely not the case with the characters he created for his dark and sometimes surrealistic comedy Wild Tales, which has been nominated for the Oscar for best foreign-language film and opens Feb. 20.

title: A Record Year of Recalls: Nearly 64 Million Vehicles
description: The auto industry recalled almost 64 million vehicles for safety problems last year, a record, according to figures released on Thursday by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Saudi Women Free After 73 Days in Jail for Driving
description: Two Saudi women detained since early December for challenging the conservative kingdoms ban on female drivers announced on Thursday that they had been released after 73 days.

title: Owners of Host Teams Can Skip the All-Star Festivities
description: The N.B.A.s All-Star weekend is being co-hosted by the Knicks and the Nets, but if fans expect to see a lot of the teams owners, they will be disappointed.

title: Study Backs Kentucky Medicaid Expansion
description: WASHINGTON  Gov. Steven L. Beshear of Kentucky released a study Thursday predicting that his expansion of Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act would generate a positive fiscal impact of nearly $1 billion for the state over the next seven years.

title: New York Archdiocese Parishioners See System of Secrets as They Fight Church Closings
description: For aggrieved parishioners at churches ordered closed or merged by Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan last November, it seemed like a simple task: Get a copy of the formal decree of his decision on their parishes, so they could properly appeal to the Vatican.

title: Todd Snyder: Fall 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: A Universal Comeback
description: While the movie industry was focused on difficulties at Warner Bros. and Sony Pictures, Universal Pictures has put together a 2015 slate that brings an echo of the studios 1980s heyday.

title: Universal Pictures Regains a Bit of Its Old Sheen
description: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.  Lobbed between four owners over the last 15 years, Universal Pictures has lately had a reputation in Hollywood as a reliable also-ran.

title: Teachers Find Little Grace in Archdioceses Latest Offering
description: On her way to teach social studies at a Catholic school on Thursday morning, Alexis DAngelo paused to do some elementary arithmetic.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 12, 2015
ISIS Releases Interview With Woman Linked to Amedy Coulibaly
description: The Islamic State group said Thursday that a woman it described as the widow of the French gunman responsible for a deadly siege at a Paris supermarket last month  a woman who is now among Frances most wanted fugitives  was living among the groups followers, presumably in Syria or Iraq. The assertion by the Islamic State, published in an English-language version of its online jihadist propaganda magazine, is believed to be the first time the group has said anything concerning the whereabouts of the woman, Hayat Boumeddiene, 26. French officials suspect that she was an accomplice of the gunman, Amedy Coulibaly, killed in a Jan. 9 shootout with the French police. The article asserted that Mr. Coulibaly had arranged for her travel to lands controlled by the Islamic State before the attack. She was quoted as saying that she was happy to be living in an area controlled by the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL, and was quoted as advising other women followers of the group to be bases of support and safety for your husbands, brothers, fathers, and sons. Turkish officials have said that Ms. Boumeddiene traveled to Turkey from Spain before the Paris attack and entered Syria through a Turkish border crossing on Jan. 8, one day before the supermarket siege.

title: Red Cross Faces Attacks at Ebola Victims Funerals
description: Red Cross volunteers helping to safely bury people who die of Ebola in Guinea have been attacked in recent days by people attending the funerals, complicating efforts to stop the spread of the disease.

title: After Tina Maze Falters, Lasse Kjus Remains a One-of-a-Kind Racer
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  Vail Valley was the happiest valley for Lasse Kjus in 1999, and he returned this year perfectly prepared to share his place in the history books with Tina Maze.

title: Cellphone Video of Fatal Police Shooting
description: A cellphone video uploaded to YouTube appears to show the fatal police shooting of a man who threw rocks at officers before running across a crowded intersection.

title: Obama Heads to Tech Security Talks Amid Tensions
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  President Obama will meet here on Friday with the nations top technologists on a host of cybersecurity issues and the threats posed by increasingly sophisticated hackers. But nowhere on the agenda is the real issue for the chief executives and tech company officials who will gather on the Stanford campus: the deepening estrangement between Silicon Valley and the government.

title: Police Killing of Man Who Threw Rocks Is Reviewed in Washington State
description: Investigators in Washington State were reviewing video taken with a cellphone that appears to show the fatal police shooting of a man who threw rocks at police officers before running across a crowded intersection, law enforcement officials said.

title: Taking Things Up With the Crew
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Most people pooh pooh the kind of words that you only see in crossword puzzles, but not me. If youre smart, you will remember these words and use them to your advantage. They might give you your toehold in a difficult puzzle.

title: Review: Everything You Touch, a Brash Examination of Self-Image
description: The work of the playwright Sheila Callaghan is not exactly ready-to-wear. Her plots dont progress along expected lines; her characters dont stick to a single style. Theres a lot of color and a lot of pattern and some pretty crazy layering.

title: Review: The Iceman Cometh Revived, With Nathan Lane and Brian Dennehy
description: The zombies stomping all over pop culture these days will seem about as scary as Santas elves once youve met the dead souls inhabiting the sepulchral gloom of Robert Fallss production of Eugene ONeills The Iceman Cometh. The bloodletting and brain-eating in this case may be metaphoric, but make no mistake: None of the suffering men and women seeking comfort in the bottom of a bottle in Harry Hopes saloon will emerge truly alive.

title: Review: In The Events, a Shooting Leaves a Survivor in Purgatory
description: An agitated anguish beats against the walls of ritual in The Events, a solemn, searching and ultimately very moving play about a faith-shattering act of violence. This gutsy work by the Scottish dramatist David Greig, which opened on Thursday night at New York Theater Workshop, sets the restless pain of a mass-shooting survivor against the stolid, consoling presence of a community choir.

title: Jon Stewarts America
description: Since the golden era of fake news is over, does this mean that what passes for real news and real politics are also over?

title: Hello, I Must Be Going: A Third Miami Museum Director Departs
description: MIAMI  Eyebrows were raised in art circles Wednesday at news that Suzanne Weaver had left as interim director of the Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami  just over four months after the new private museum announced her arrival, and not even three months after it first opened in its temporary home.

title: Numbed by Snow, Boston Area Shudders at the Thought of More
description: BOSTON  In this citys Seaport district, a long, yellow snow melter, recently sheathed in lumpy icicles like the shaggy fur of a yeti, is liquefying 350 tons of snow an hour.

title: David Carr, Times Critic and Champion of Media, Dies at 58
description: David Carr, who wriggled away from the demon of drug addiction to become a journalistic celebrity, a name-brand media columnist at The New York Times and a best-selling author who reported on his own near demise and recovery, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 58.

title: Anthony Says He Is Likely to Sit Out Rest of Season
description: Carmelo Anthony, who has been dealing with an injured left knee since October, said Thursday that it was very likely he would sit out the remainder of the Knicks season.

title: Congress Shows a Lack of Enthusiasm for Giving Obama War Powers to Fight ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  Ever since President Obama ordered American warplanes to begin bombing terrorist targets in Iraq and Syria last year, members of Congress have insisted on having a say in the matter. The president, they declared, could not, or at least should not, take the country back to war without the input of the nations elected representatives.

title: Government Will Change How it Rates Nursing Homes
description: The federal government on Thursday announced that it was changing the way it measures nursing homes, essentially adjusting the curve that it uses to rate homes to make it more difficult for them to earn coveted four- and five-star government ratings.

title: Review: Huang Yi & Kuka, a Pas de Deux Between Human and Machine
description: Some lonely children create invisible friends. As a solitary boy growing up in Taiwan, the choreographer Huang Yi pined for a robot. He had good reason: In his poignant artists statement for his show Huang Yi & Kuka, at 3LD Art & Technology Center, he reveals that when he was 10, his wealthy parents became bankrupt and suicidal. The family moved to a 40-square-foot room; Mr. Huang, feeling compelled to be a perfect child, masked his emotions to become the picture of obedience. In other words, a robot.

title: Mic News Director Is Fired After Plagiarism Accusations
description: In the latest plagiarism scandal in journalism, Mic, a news site intended for the so-called millennial generation, has fired its news director after numerous examples surfaced showing that he had lifted material from other sources without proper attribution.

title: Indictment in an Arson Attempt in Ferguson
description: SEDALIA, Mo.  Federal grand jurors have indicted a man on charges that he tried to set fire to a Ferguson convenience store in November, shortly after it was announced that a white police officer there would not face state charges in the death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black 18-year-old.

title: Trinity Industries Full-Court Press on Guardrails
description: Since 2012, when allegations surfaced that there might be a safety flaw in a highway guardrail system manufactured by Trinity, the company has significantly expanded its lobbying of state attorneys general, who have the power to investigate and possibly sue the company. Here is a look at parts of that effort.

title: Troubled Guardrail Maker Goes on a Lobbying Blitz
description: The Four Seasons Hotel on the Las Vegas Strip is known for its steakhouse, its palm tree-decorated rooftop pool bar and its quick access to the sprawling gambling floors at the Mandalay Bay casino, just downstairs.

title: Style Icons Update a Fendi Classic for a Good Cause
description: The Fendi Baguette was a fashion-world success from the day it was released in 1997 and, thanks to being a favorite of Carries on Sex and the City, it became a bona fide pop culture icon soon after. As of 2015, more than 1,000 versions of the design have been created ranging from rare limited editions to mass-market reimaginings. In celebration of Fendis new flagship store on Madison Avenue, the Italian brand has now teamed up with five powerhouse women to present yet another unique line of the famous shoulder bag. This time around, Rihanna, Jourdan Dunn, Rachel Feinstein, Leandra Medine and, yes, Sarah Jessica Parker, have each designed their own 3Baguette, the smaller version of the bag. Each piece will be auctioned online from February 13 through March 13 with proceeds going to a charity of each guest designers choosing, from the Brain Trauma Foundation (Parker) to the Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center (Feinstein).

title: Philip Johnsons Not Glass Houses
description: The legendary architect and his companion, the curator David Whitney, spent their weekends in the worlds most famous transparent box. Or did they?

title: The Trash Collector
description: Joost Bakker grows flowers he trades for bones to make soup at his restaurant, and uses the leftovers to feed his garden. Meet the poster boy for zero-waste living.

title: Mostly True
description: Two writers and one artist reflect on the slipperiest of all literary forms: their own diaries.

title: Word of the Day | consort
description: consort  \kn-sort\  verb and noun

title: China: Motorist Tries to Drive Into American Consulate
description: A man crashed into a barrier while trying to drive into the United States Consulate in Shanghai lateThursday, the police said. One Chinese guard was slightly injured, the police added. The man, who was taken into custody, had no apparent political motive, according to the authorities. His wife told them he had refused to leave their home for nearly a month out of fear that someone was trying to kill him, the state-run Xinhua news service reported. The suspect, Liu Daojie, 35, from Fujian Province in southeast China, told the police he had spotted armed police officers outside the consulate and decided to drive into the compound to draw attention to his concerns, Xinhua reported. A State Department spokesman said that all staff members were accounted for and that the consulate would operate normallyFriday.

title: Harvey Goldschmid, Ally of Ordinary Shareholders, Is Dead at 74
description: Harvey J. Goldschmid, an expert on corporate law who, as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was a strong advocate of making public corporations responsible to shareholders, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 74.

title: How Arizona State Reinvented Free-Throw Distraction
description: A shark attack. The return of Elvis. Twerking farm animals. A shirtless guitarist. Kissing unicorns. An old lady yelling at you to get off her lawn. Distracted yet? So, too, are college basketball players, who have tried  and often failed  to overcome the creative attempts of students at Arizona State to destroy the focus of free-throw shooters.

title: California: 22 Hurt in Military Training as Vehicles Fire Extinguisher Goes Off
description: Twenty-two Marines and sailors were injured at a military base in the Southern California desert on Thursday when a fire-extinguisher system went off during a training exercise, the military said. The accident happened inside an amphibious assault vehicle at the Marine Corps Air Ground Combat Center in Twentynine Palms, east of Los Angeles, the Marine Corps said. Some of the Marines and sailors were taken to a hospital to be treated for inhaling the fire retardant, and they were in stable condition, according to the Marine Corps. None of the injuries were life-threatening, Capt. Maureen T. Krebs, a Marine Corps spokeswoman, said. The vehicle, which resembles a tank, is used to move troops from ships to land.

title: David Carrs Life and Times
description: David Carr combined formidable talent as a reporter with acute judgment to become an indispensable guide to modern media, said Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., The Timess publisher and chairman.

title: Events in Connecticut for Feb. 15-21, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island for Feb. 15-21, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester for Feb. 15-21, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey for Feb. 15-21, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 3:45 P.M. (TCM) THE BIRDS (1963) A flock of birds never looks quite the same after a viewing of Alfred Hitchcocks classic horror film about a California town tormented by malevolent fowl. Tippi Hedren stars as a spoiled socialite who follows a handsome man (Rod Taylor) to the home of his mother (Jessica Tandy), where, for no apparent reason, the attacks begin. Making a terrifying menace out of what is assumed to be one of natures most innocent creatures and one of mans most melodious friends, Mr. Hitchcock and his associates have constructed a horror film that should raise the hackles on the most courageous and put goose-pimples on the toughest hide, Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times.

title: David Carrs Life and Times
description: David Carr combined formidable talent as a reporter with acute judgment to become an indispensable guide to modern media, said Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., The Timess publisher and chairman.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Feb. 13
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a doula and Officer Peter Liang, who was indicted in a mans shooting death.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: All of us in law enforcement must be honest enough to acknowledge that much of our history is not pretty. At many points in American history, law enforcement enforced the status quo, a status quo that was often brutally unfair to disfavored groups.

title: Corrections: February 13, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: David Carr, a Journalist at the Center of the Sweet Spot
description: For a while, a few years ago, there was a weekly video on the New York Times website called The Sweet Spot, taped during off hours in the cafeteria on the 14th floor. The idea was that it would be an informal, incisive discussion of various developments in the world of culture and media. Sometimes it managed to live up to its name, and sometimes it didnt, but for me the show  or webcast, or schmooze fest, or whatever it was  had a much simpler reason for being: It guaranteed that I would have a few hours a week in the company of David Carr. For anyone who cared about journalism, there was simply no better place to be.

title: The Quotable David Carr
description: David Carr was often more quotable than the personalities he wrote about. His plainspoken style was sometimes blunt, and searingly honest about himself. The effect was both folksy and sophisticated, a voice from a shrewd and well-informed skeptic.

title: Chris Martin to Curate Global Citizen Festival for 15 Years
description: Chris Martin, the lead singer of Coldplay, has signed on as an ambassador for the anti-poverty group Global Citizen, and will serve as the curator of its international music festival for the next 15 years, said Hugh Evans, the chief executive of the Global Poverty Project, which oversees the campaign.

title: China to Employ Customs Workers With a Nose for Hard Cash
description: In a country where cash is king but the 100 renminbi note is the highest denomination, it is not unheard of for individuals to make purchases with suitcases stuffed with pink bills emblazoned with Maos face. Some have also taken this habit abroad, ready to spend big on real estate or luxury goods, even though China limits the amount private citizens can transfer out of the country to $50,000 a year.

title: Your Turn: A Weekly Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Celebrating the Chinese Lion Dance
description: Southern Chinese lion dancing comes from an ancient tale: Terrorized by a mythical monster, a horde of villagers descended from the mountains and huddled under an enormous monster of their own in an attempt to repel the beast. Year after year, to the accompaniment of firecracker bursts and drums, the ritual is repeated as protection against evil spirits. At least thats one version.

title: Aid to War-Torn Ukrainians
description: To the Editor:

title: An Iraqis Plea to the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Keep the Medical Device Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Making the Ukraine Cease-Fire Stick
description: A glimmer of hope but no illusion was the inauspicious way Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, described the Ukraine cease-fire she and President Franois Hollande of France brokered in talks in Minsk, Belarus, with Presidents Vladimir Putin of Russia and Petro Poroshenko of Ukraine. Ms. Merkel certainly deserves a lot of credit for her determined shuttling among Kiev, Moscow, Munich, Washington and Minsk in the urgent search for a resolution of the biggest security crisis to confront Europe since the end of the Cold War.

title: How Colleges Handle Rape Charges
Mr. Obamas Easy Call on Keystone Bill
description: Congress has delivered to President Obama a bill commanding him to approve construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline from Canada, accompanied by a warning from House Speaker John Boehner to ignore the left-fringe extremists and anarchists who oppose the project.

title: A Womans Place Is on Late Night
description: LOS ANGELES  WHEN Jon Stewart exits The Daily Show at some point in 2015, it will be the sixth time in just over a year that a prominent late-night desk will be up for grabs. All this turnover would seem like a great opportunity to throw a female host into the mix. But it hasnt happened yet. So next time, right? Theres always next time. Except next time probably wont be for a long time. Most late-night hosts stay put for decades. Its the closest thing to a Civil Service job in TV.

title: Money Makes Crazy
description: Monetary policy probably wont be a major issue in the 2016 campaign, but it should be. It is, after all, extremely important, and the Republican base and many leading politicians have strong views about the Federal Reserve and its conduct. And the eventual presidential nominee will surely have to endorse the party line.

title: Larry vs. Marco
description: Pride goeth before a fall. Capitalisms great triumph over socialism has been followed by a series of humbling setbacks since. Capitalism is not necessarily self-regulating, as we learned during the financial crisis. Capitalism does not necessarily lead to democracy abroad. Capitalism does not automatically produce sufficient social mobility.

title: In Home Stretch of Career, A.P. McCoy Leaves Victories, and Carnage, Behind
description: LONDON  Simply by the way tough and dangerous physical sports are set up, it seems inconceivable that one man can beat every competitor in every one of the 20 years of his career.

title: How to Topple a Dictator (Peacefully)
description: Several years ago, before their protest movement was co-opted by violence, a group of young Syrians looking for a way to topple President Bashar al-Assad traveled to an isolated beach resort outside Syria to take a weeklong class in revolution.

title: ArcelorMittal Reports $955 Million Loss; ThyssenKrupp Ekes Out a Small Profit
description: LONDON  The worlds largest steel maker, ArcelorMittal, reported on Friday a $955 million loss for the fourth quarter, showing how difficult it is to make money in slumping commodities businesses like steel and iron ore.

title: Test Yourself | A Candlelight Dinner for Two, at White Castle
description: Here are several paragraphs from a 2007 article, Slyders by Candlelight.

title: 6 Qs About the News | In Chapel Hill Shooting of 3 Muslims, a Question of Motive
description: In In Chapel Hill Shooting of 3 Muslims, a Question of Motive, Jonathan M. Katz and Richard Prez-Pea report on a triple homicide in North Carolina.

title: Chinese President Returns to Maos (and His) Roots in Yanan
description: President Xi Jinping of China has capped a year resonant with echoes from the Maoist era by going back on Friday to where it all began.

title: On Tinder, Taking a Swipe at Love, or Sex, or Something, in New York
description: On a recent night, with Valentines Day looming, I went out for drinks with a woman I know and a few of her friends. It was a Thursday, and the bar they chose, Bondurants, on the Upper East Side, was packed with people just like them: good-looking, semi-affluent millennials, downing craft beer and milling about in hungry-looking, monosexual clusters.

title: How Christian Rudder, a Founder of OKCupid, Spends His Sunday
description: The lovelorn this Valentines Day can take heart. The dating site OKCupid generates approximately 30,000 first dates every day around the United States. Thats an eye-catching number, even for Christian Rudder, a founder of the website and data geek, whose first book, Dataclysm: Who We Are When We Think No Ones Looking, was published in September. Yet Mr. Rudder, 39, met his wife, Reshma Patel, the owner of a public relations firm, in a totally off-line way. They hit it off in 1999 when his band was playing a show with her boyfriends band in Boston. The couple, who married in 2006, live in North Williamsburg with their 3-year-old daughter, Plum.

title: What Role Has Community College Played in Your Life or the Life of Someone You Know?
description: What associations do you have with the idea of community college? Who, if anyone, do you know who has been to a community college? What was the experience like for that person? Would you consider attending one?

title: Questions Rise on Fate of Chinese Bishop
description: HONG KONG  For the better part of the last 60 years, Bishop Cosma Shi Enxiang was imprisoned in Chinese jails and labor camps. For the last 14, he was held without charge in a secret location.

title: Eurozone Growth Exceeds Expectations
description: PARIS  The European economy ended last year on a better note than economists had expected, an official report showed on Friday. And a surprisingly strong growth figure for Germany suggested a possible turning point for a region still seeking to shrug off the hangover from the financial crisis.

title: For Victoria Beckham, a Neutral Zone Amid Chaos
description: LONDON  In the first of our second video series focusing on the working lives (and spaces) of designers, Victoria Beckham, whose fall collection will be shown Sunday in New York, takes us inside her Battersea offices and talks minimalism, mess and what makes her an average mom. And thats just what didnt make it into the final cut. (This interview has been edited and condensed.) VANESSA FRIEDMAN

title: What to Expect on the Second Day of New York Fashion Week
description: Its Friday the 13th. Fashion week is just starting to hit its stride. Have we anything to fear, besides the usual fear itself?

title: Ask Well: Put on the Snowshoes
description: Question:

title: New York Today: Mothers Helpers
description: Good morning on this frozen Friday.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: David Carrs Life and Times
description: David Carr combined formidable talent as a reporter with acute judgment to become an indispensable guide to modern media, said Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., The Timess publisher and chairman.

title: Why Republicans Are Suddenly Talking About Economic Inequality
description: For decades, Democrats have been the party that emphasizes concerns about inequality. So why are many top Republicans  including a number of the partys presidential hopefuls  talking about the issue?

title: Daily Report: Obama Heads to Security Talks Amid Tensions
description: President Obama will meet in Palo Alto, Calif., on Friday with the nations top technologists on a host of cybersecurity issues and the threats posed by increasingly sophisticated hackers. But nowhere on the agenda is the real issue for the chief executives and tech company officials who will gather on the Stanford campus: the deepening estrangement between Silicon Valley and the government, David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth report.

title: China Says Its Soldiers Will Need to Watch Their Weight
description: Chinas military announced last year that it was changing its recruiting standards, to admit enlistees who were slightly stouter than their predecessors. The idea was to ensure that the supply of new cadets would not be restricted by the growing waistlines of young Chinese.

title: Everything but the Crossword
description: This magazine is about to change. There will be new columns, new columnists, new page concepts and layouts, new features and new typefaces. Were excited for you to meet them all next week, but first we want to take this opportunity to bid farewell to the magazine were leaving behind.

title: Reply All: The 2.1.15 Issue
description: TOM BRADY CANNOT STOP

title: The Short Cut
description: When I was in high school in the Midwest, in the early 50s, we all had crew cuts. Maybe, at times, we simply had short hair  anything other than short hair would have been somewhere between unfashionable and suicidal  but the hairstyle that engaged our connoisseurship was the crew cut. I was convinced that the barber many of us patronized gave the best crew cuts in the city. Anyone who believes that there is no room for artistry when dealing with an inch or so of hair never sat in this mans chair.

title: Dorm Wrecker
description: Im a woman who lives in an on-campus apartment with three male roommates, one of whom was just nominated to run for president of his fraternity. If he is elected, he will be required to move into the fraternity house. My universitys coed housing policy stipulates that if one of the roommates moves out, the other residents could be split up and forced to live with students of the same sex. At the beginning of the year, we were all on the same page regarding our universitys policies with respect to coed living. Is this roommate ethically obligated to stay in order to prevent this? L. RODRIGUEZ, TROY, N.Y.

title: Its Buggy Out There
description: Hunter Mountain, a three-hour drive northwest of New York, calls itself the Snow-Making Capital of the World. When operating at maximum capacity, the ski resorts 1,100 or so snow guns can blanket 240 acres with as much as three feet of snow in just two days. The recipe for all that manufactured powder is pretty simple  mostly water and air. But theres often another, rather surprising ingredient: a bacterial protein that works like Kurt Vonneguts ice-nine, the fictional substance that instantly freezes water. Scientists have long known that certain terrestrial microbes perform this alchemy. In recent years, however, new discoveries have increasingly persuaded them that such micro-organisms live a double life in the sky, manipulating the weather for their own benefit.

title: Celebrating Theater in London and New York
description: An exhibition celebrating 40 years of theater in London and New York will be shown in both cities in 2016, Boris Johnson, the mayor of London, will announce on Friday at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

title: Fifty Shades of Criticism
description: This week, A.O. Scott, one of The Timess chief film critics, wrote about what is perhaps the most buzzed about movie of the year thus far: the film adaptation of the novel Fifty Shades of Grey. But what challenges are presented when reviewing a movie with as much hype as this one? And what of those presented when writing for a family newspaper about a movie whose main theme is kinky sex?

title: Today in Politics
description: For Obama, a Salute in San Francisco and a Scowl in Silicon Valley

title: Morning Agenda: Standoff Over Greek Debt
description: | David Carr, a champion of media and a friend and mentor to so many, died last night. This newsletter is dedicated to him.

title: Rebels Kill Dozens of Soldiers in Myanmar in Fighting Near Chinese Border
description: BANGKOK  More than 50 government soldiers and police officers have been killed in Myanmar in recent days in clashes with an armed ethnic group, the state news media said on Friday, in the latest setback for the governments national reconciliation efforts.

title: 9 Killed as Train in India Hits Boulder
description: NEW DELHI  Nine passengers were killed and 10 were seriously injured when a train in southern India derailed Friday morning near Bangalore after hitting a boulder that had rolled onto the tracks, officials said.

title: Monopolys Inventor: The Progressive Who Didnt Pass Go
description: For generations, the story of Monopolys Depression-era origins delighted fans almost as much as the board game itself.

title: Love in the Time of Twitter
description: Before she got engaged a couple years ago, Lisa Sokolowski, a blogger in Leland, N.C., rarely mentioned her boyfriend on her regular Twitter account.

title: Taking Her Class Around the World
description: Dear Diary:

title: In Senegal, a Coastal Region Sees a Resurgence
description: As the low-slung pirogue hummed along the Casamance River in the remote southern portion of Senegal, dolphins accompanied us. I had first spotted them on the overnight ferry from Dakar to Ziguinchor. But here they were within reach, companions who swam alongside the boat, nudging their noses toward us as we headed upriver.

title: Restaurant Report: Miles in Bordeaux, France
description: For most of the world, Bordeaux and wine are inextricably linked. But with the emergence of reasonably priced, inventive neo-bistros  much like the ones that have been sweeping the Parisian culinary scene  the citys expanding dining scene is primed to compete with its famed varietals as a reason to visit.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: A Park Avenue Address, Not Exactly
description: By rights, mail intended for future residents of a certain luxury condominium under construction on the Upper East Side should read 45 East 60th Street. After all, the Grolier Club, which is right next door to the persistent din, is 47 East 60th Street.

title: Surprisingly, a Voluntary Climate Treaty Could Actually Work
description: Negotiators around the world are deliberating proposals for an international climate change treaty that will contain a glaring loophole: It wont be binding.

description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.
