description: There was a moment late in Jessye Normans Carnegie Hall recital of popular standards on Saturday evening when the clouds parted, a shaft of lightning illuminated the hall, and an adoring audience that had waited patiently for a burst of vocal fireworks erupted in a spontaneous standing ovation.

description: OTTAWA  A strike by about 3,000 locomotive engineers and conductors at the Canadian Pacific Railway unexpectedly ended on Monday, its second day, as both sides agreed to arbitration. The announcement came about half an hour before a bill was to be introduced in Parliament ordering the members of the union, the Teamsters Canada Rail Conference, back to work.

title: Southeast Region Hit by a Heavy Blast of Snow, With an Icy Cold Follow-Up

Flights were canceled, schools closed, Mardi Gras parades were rescheduled, and at least two state legislatures, in Kentucky and Tennessee, announced they would not meet on Tuesday as the storm continued into North Carolina.

description: Arnaud de Borchgrave, a Belgian counts son and storied foreign correspondent who cabled back bell-ringing scoops throughout the Cold War decades, often from the battlefield, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 88.

description: When Frank Johnstons insurance carrier rejected his claim that flooding from Hurricane Sandy had severely damaged the foundation of his Fire Island home, the company cited an engineering report that seemed to establish his problems were unrelated to the storm, and were caused instead by the long-term deterioration of wooden piers beneath his house.

title: With Lunar New Year Show, Another Link to China for a New York Fireworks Family

title: Jim Jarmusch Soundtracks Surrealism With His Rock Band Sqrl
description: Music is very much a release for me because its so immediate, says the director Jim Jarmusch. Though Jarmusch is best known as the radically independent mind behind art-house classics like Down by Law and Dead Man, the filmmaker is also a member of the amorphous post-rock group known as Sqrl. (The band composed the scores to the recent Jarmusch films The Limits of Control and Only Lovers Left Alive.) Tonight, Sqrl will debut a new soundtrack  not to one of Jarmuschs own films, but to four silent works from the surrealist Man Ray. The concerts are part of WNYCs New Sounds Live series, Silent Films/Live Music, which pairs movies, both classic and contemporary, with performances from acclaimed musicians. (The current run of shows also features the composer Alfonso Villalonga and the Wordless Music Orchestra performing the score to the Spanish film Blancanieves.)

title: Group Seeks New Tolls in Manhattan to Pay for Regions Transportation Needs
description: A group of transit advocates will release a proposal on Tuesday to overhaul New York Citys bridge toll system and to raise money for the regions transportation needs.

description: This post discusses in some more technical detail the issues that are the subject of David Leonhardts Feb. 17 column.

title: Inequality Has Actually Not Risen Since the Financial Crisis
description: The notion that income inequality has continued to rise over the past decade is part of the conventional wisdom. Youve no doubt heard versions: The rich just keep getting richer. Inequality is higher than ever. Nearly all of the gains from the economic recovery have gone to the top 1 percent.

title: Enrollment Period for Health Insurance Ends; Now the Tax Penalties Start
description: The Affordable Care Acts second open enrollment period ended on Sunday. Well, almost. Some computer problems over the weekend have led the administration to give a one-week extension to people who tried and failed to sign up.

title: Dealt Setback, Obama Puts Off Immigrant Plan
description: WASHINGTON  One day before hundreds of thousands of undocumented immigrants were to begin applying for work permits and legal protection, administration officials on Tuesday postponed President Obamas sweeping executive actions on immigration indefinitely, saying they had no choice but to comply with a federal judges last-minute order halting the programs.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE ITALIAN AMERICANS More than four million Italians emigrated to the United States from 1880 to 1924, mostly coming from southern Italy and Sicily to escape poverty. This series, narrated by the actor Stanley Tucci and written by John Maggio, spans four generations of Italian-Americans, beginning with the large wave of immigration in the late 19th century and continuing to the present day. Along the way, the two-part series uses archival material and interviews with experts and prominent Italian-Americans (like Mario M. Cuomo, above; Tony Bennett; and Gay Talese, to name a few) to tell the stories of those who played important roles in shaping the relationships between Italians and Americans, and how immigrants, once considered outsiders, have risen over time to become leaders in business, politics and the arts.

title: Debating the Rules and Ethics of Digital Photojournalism
description: Significant questions have arisen after a large number of images were disqualified from this years World Press Photo competition because of excessive  and sometimes blatant  post-processing. After independent experts examined the images being considered for prizes in the final rounds, and presented their findings to the jury, 20 percent of the photos were disqualified by the judges. This was often because of significant addition or subtraction to the image content.

title: The Roadblock to Sentencing Reform
description: For more than a year, members of Congress have been doing a lot of talking about the need to broadly reform harsh federal sentencing laws, which are a central factor in the explosion of the federal prison population. Its an overdue conversation, and one of the few in which Democrats and Republicans find some agreement  but, so far, they have nothing to show for it.

title: The Moral Injury
description: David J. Morris returned from Iraq with a case of post-traumatic stress disorder. The former Marine turned war correspondent was plagued by nightmares. His imagination careened out of control; he envisioned fireballs erupting while on trips to the mall. His emotions could go numb, but his awareness was hypervigilant. Images and smells from the war were tattooed eternally fresh on his brain, and he circled back to them remorselessly.

title: Reform the Condominium
description: FROM New York to Miami, from South Padre Island, Tex., to Park City, Utah, the American condominium has become the hot new investment for global capital. In Manhattan, the trend is so pronounced that a whole new category of real estate has emerged around the southern edges of Central Park: supertall, ultraluxury buildings, with more than half of the homes being sold to anonymous buyers (some perhaps looking to stash ill-gotten gains) who rarely, if ever, occupy them. The city, meanwhile, struggles to produce sufficient housing for those who do live here.

title: How Useful Are Standardized Tests?

description: In the last 30 years, the United States has signed more than 100 open skies agreements with other countries to remove restrictions on international air travel  a policy that has been great for travelers because it has lowered fares and increased service.

title: In Europe, Car Sales Gain for 17th Straight Month
description: PARIS  The European car market maintained its modest upward momentum in the first month of the year, industry data showed on Tuesday, with sales gaining for a 17th straight month. But the market is still far below where it was before the 2008 global financial crisis.

The demand appeared to be part of a strategy by eurozone creditors to get Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece and his finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, to back away from their anti-austerity pledges. In exchange, eurozone officials said they would consider rolling back some of the austerity terms at a later date.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Four Taliban suicide bombers disguised in Afghan police uniforms stormed a heavily fortified provincial Police Headquarters in central Afghanistan on Tuesday, killing at least 20 officers and wounding eight others.

title: Aftermath of Attack on Pakistani Police
description: Security officials and residents inspected the site of a suicide bombing near police headquarters in Lahore, Pakistan, that killed at least five people.

title: Julianne Moore on Forging a Bond With Alzheimers Patients
description: Julianne Moore was a late-ish add to the awards race, coming in quietly with her performance in the independent film Still Alice, about a high-achieving cognitive psychologist receiving a diagnosis of early onset Alzheimers. Now, after picking up a Golden Globe and a SAG Award, among other prizes, shes a front-runner for the Oscar for best actress .

title: Love, Panic, Adoption and Jerk-Chicken Knishes
description: When Evys apnea monitor went off, the piercing beep told me that this alert wasnt like the rest. Even a room away, the shorter beeps told me that, instead of one of the leads coming loose, something was wrong.

title: Prosecutor Asks for Charges Against Dominique Strauss-Kahn to Be Dropped
description: PARIS  A prosecutor asked a criminal court in Lille, France, on Tuesday to drop charges against the former International Monetary Fund chief Dominique Strauss-Kahn, saying there was not enough evidence to convict him of procuring prostitutes, according to news reports.

title: Seeing Value After a Plunge, Hedge Funds Bet on Energy Stocks
description: A few hedge fund managers have been tiptoeing back into the beaten-down energy sector.

title: Asset Managers on Track to Overtake Investment Bankers on Average in Pay
description: LONDON  Asset managers are no longer the unappreciated, underpaid stepchildren in finance, and may soon overtake average investment bankers in pay, according to a new report on banker and fund management pay from Britain.

title: David Carr, a Times Reporter, Is Eulogized
description: David Carr was remembered at his funeral Mass on Tuesday as a deft journalist who was, his older brother John said, a unique combination of Minnesota nice and New York attitude.

title: 1940: Britons Freed From Hell Ship
description: More than 300 British merchant seamen rescued from a German vessel described as the Hell Ship arrived home. (britishpathe.com)

title: Hillary Clinton, Privately, Seeks the Favor of Elizabeth Warren
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton held a private meeting with Senator Elizabeth Warren in December, seeking to cultivate the increasingly influential senator and to grapple with issues raised by a restive Democratic left, such as income inequality.

title: Looking Back at Nearly 15 Dog Years
description: There is plenty of time for dogs to act doglike at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show while other dogs are being judged.

title: Is Network News Dead?
Baby Penguin on View at Central Park Zoo
description: Just in time for the next polar-type cold spell, the Central Park Zoo has big small-penguin news:

title: Modi Promises to Punish Religious Violence in India
description: NEW DELHI  Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India said on Tuesday that his government would not accept violence against any religion, on any pretext, and that it would take forceful steps if such crimes occurred, in a speech widely interpreted as a response to a series of attacks on Roman Catholic churches in and around New Delhi.

title: 1965: Troops Clash After Bombing
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Congolese troops crossed the border and exchanged fire with Ugandan troops south of Lake Albert, Uganda Minister of Internal Affairs Feli Onama announced today [Feb. 17]. Other Congo troops crossed the Ishasha river into southwest Uganda and tried to enter the Uganda customs post there. In both cases they were forced to return into the Congo, Mr. Onama said. The border with the Congo is already closed following a weekend bomb attack of two Uganda villages. In Nairobi, Kenya, the government there warned the United States of the serious repercussions arising from its policy on the Congo.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 18, 1965

title: Does Fiction Have the Power to Sway Politics?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Mohsin Hamid and Francine Prose debate literatures influence on politics.

title: Hillary Clinton and the 2016 Democrats: Mostly Liberal, Together
description: Among seven potential Democratic presidential contenders, Hillary Clinton is the overwhelming favorite  and the third-most liberal candidate. How the other candidates are arrayed on an ideological spectrum could make her run for the White House easier than the last time out.

title: IBM, G.E. and Others Create Big Data Alliance
description: A key element of the big data business is getting what much of computer technology secretly craves: Normality.

title: Medicine Given Even Before Smokers Are Ready to Quit Is Found to Help Them
description: WASHINGTON  Doctors typically wait until smokers are ready to quit before prescribing pills to help them do it. But a new study has found that even for those who are not ready to stop smoking immediately, medicine taken over time can substantially improve their chances of eventually quitting.

title: Desperation Drives Gazans Over a Fence and Into Israeli Prisons
description: EL BUREIJ, Gaza Strip  It was not much of an escape.

title: Despite Ukraine Truce, a Battle That Continues
description: ARTEMIVSK, Ukraine  A battle for a railroad town in eastern Ukraine escalated sharply on Tuesday, with both the Ukrainian Army and Russian-backed militants saying that their soldiers were engaging in pitched street battles.

title: At Heart of U.S.-South African Trade Dispute, a Serious Game of International Chicken
description: MILFORD, Del.  The 40,000 chickens  a few short weeks from becoming Valu-Paks at the supermarket  scratched their way toward the rows of water drips, eager for a little midday sip. Eyeing an open door, one bird made a vague attempt to wander away, before it was gently returned to the brood.

title: Scenes From West Virginia Train Fire
description: Video shows the fireballs erupting from a train that derailed in West Virginia on Monday while carrying millions of pounds of oil.

description: The 139th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in New York features 192 breeds. Here are a few.

title: Tom Bullocks The Ideal Bartender Offers Words of Advice
description: In 1913, former President Theodore Roosevelt, countering a report that he was frequently drunk, testified in a libel suit that one of the few drinks he had had since leaving the White House was a mint julep at the St. Louis Country Club. And, he said, he took only a sip or two.

description: For anyone who spent the years 2010 to 2012 obsessing over the fate of the eurozone during the crisis set off by Greek debt, the last few days have been a time of uncomfortable dj vu.

description: New York

title: Dibbly-Dobbly? Silly Mid Off? Slog Sweep? What It All Means
description: The Cricket World Cup is underway in Australia and New Zealand. But unless you are from Britain, India, South Africa or a few other places, you are very likely so cricket-challenged that you dont know a googly from a doosra. Fear not! Here is a quick look at a small fraction of the marvelously weird lexicon of cricket.

title: How A California Punk Designed Jay Zs Holy Grail
description: Los Angeles artist Brian Roettinger brings his zine-inspired sensibility to some of musics biggest acts.

title: A High-End Property Collapse in Singapore
description: SINGAPORE  Lamborghinis, Porsches and Bentleys fill the driveways of multimillion-dollar villas in Sentosa Cove. Yachts line the 400-berth marina nearby. A number of homes have guardhouses for security.

title: Fast Action Needed to Stave Off Greek Tragedy
description: Greece desperately needs a quick fix. Time is running so short that a deal is needed in the next few days to stop Athens from going bust. That will be, at best, a short-term patch while a long-term solution is worked out.

title: Sharp Rise in Occupational Therapy Cases at New Yorks Schools
description: A class of first graders at Public School 503 in Brooklyn sat on the floor one recent Friday, cross-legged on an alphabet-themed rug.

title: Shuko
description: Kaiseki and omakase sushi surprises in this new restaurant south of Union Square.

title: Restaurant Review: Shuko in the East Village
description: You like spicy? Jimmy Lau asked from behind the counter at Shuko, the new restaurant just below Union Square where he and his partner, Nick Kim, prepare an elevated and memorable species of Japanese food. Before I could answer, he handed me a spicy tuna roll that would casually knock over my ideas about spicy tuna rolls, and spice, and tuna.

title: For Fall/Winter 2015, Designers Cozy Up to Buffalo Plaid
description: Uniform dressing, from military greens to prep-school pleats, has always been a popular inspiration for designers, and this season, several have taken on the unofficial uniform of hunters: the oversize checks of buffalo plaid. First, at Coach, Stuart Vevers put a spin on the classic American print with pastel hues, balancing out the mostly black collection. Buffalo plaid also brightened another show consisting otherwise of almost entirely black looks: Alexander Wangs, to which the designer added a splash of color with a red buffalo plaid coat shown halfway through. And the 3.1 Phillip Lim show featured the print expressed in multiple colorways: a classic black and white with red accents near the beginning, and an earthier version in beige, black and ochre near the end. Lims eye-catching interpretation, cool and a little tough, was perfect for his downtown girl.

title: Clothes and Character: Maleficent
description: Though nominated twice for an Oscar already, the costume designer Anna B. Sheppard was taken by surprise last month, she said, when her assistant interrupted a fitting with Morgan Freeman to announce it had happened again: she was up for her costume design for Maleficent, Disneys Sleeping Beauty tale told from the antagonists point of view.

title: Review: With Queen and Country, John Boorman Continues a Tale
description: To appreciate Queen and Country, John Boormans gently nostalgic, quasi-autobiographical film about Britain in the early 1950s, it isnt entirely necessary to have seen his earlier Hope and Glory. You should, of course, see it, if you havent already: One of a handful of great movies that look at World War II through the eyes of a child, Hope and Glory is distinguished by mischievous good humor and by the unashamed acknowledgment that war can be fun as well as horrible.

title: Exchanging Sword for Pen, Rodriguez Apologizes to Yankees and Fans
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Preparing to make a highly scrutinized return to baseball after a long suspension for drug use, Alex Rodriguez issued a brief, handwritten statement on Tuesday afternoon to say he was sorry for his behavior.

title: Greek Bureaucracy, Not Just Austerity, Is an Economic Drag
description: ATHENS  Yannis Stamatiou is one of this countrys many business owners who say Greeces economic problems are not just about austerity.

title: Red Tape in Greece
description: Some businesses struggle to stay afloat during the nations economic crisis because of austerity measures and bureaucracy.

title: British Library Expanding Its Endangered Archives Online
description: LONDON  At a moment when libraries and archives in the Middle East face threats of damage and destruction from war and ideology, the British Library has announced that it has now made four million images from its Endangered Archives program available online.

title: Swiss Museum Unable to Get Gurlitt Art Trove Amid Dispute Over Will
description: Nearly three months after announcing that it would accept the gift of an art collection amassed by a Nazi-era dealer, including several pieces known to have been looted from Jewish families, the Kunstmuseum Bern expressed frustration Tuesday that a dispute over a will was preventing it from taking possession of the works.

title: Border Crossings, From Gaza to Israel: Reporters Notebook
description: Jodi Rudoren, the Jerusalem bureau chief, and Majd Al Waheidi, a correspondent in Gaza, recently wrote from the Gaza Strip about an increase in surprising border crossings. Heres the story behind their story.

title: A Gastronomic Paradise
description: A loosely affiliated group of Puerto Rican cooks, farmers and activists are reintroducing diners to the buried culinary treasures of their island.

title: Reclaiming Puerto Ricos Food Paradise
description: VIEQUES, P.R.  The sun was starting to recline on the horizon, but as the chef Jose Enrique slid a beaten-up Ford Explorer into a parking space here at an easygoing beachside hotel called El Blok, he admitted that his menu for this Saturday evening was still up in the air. What would he be cooking?

title: Princeton Gets a $300 Million Trove of Rare Books
description: Princeton University has announced the largest gift in its history: a trove of rare books valued at nearly $300 million, including a Gutenberg Bible, an original printing of the Declaration of Independence, all four of Shakespeares Folios and significant musical manuscripts written by Bach, Beethoven, Mozart, Schubert and Wagner.

title: Ford Hires Wall St. Banker to Lead Global Strategy
description: To lead its business development efforts, the Ford Motor Company is turning to a longtime Wall Street banker and analyst with a specialty in the auto industry.

title: Darren Criss to Replace John Cameron Mitchell in Hedwig and the Angry Inch
description: The actor and singer Darren Criss, best known as one of the stars of the FOX series Glee, will be the next star performer in the title role of the musical Hedwig and the Angry Inch on Broadway, the producers announced on Tuesday. He will begin a 12-week engagement on April 29, replacing John Cameron Mitchell.

description: Italia Independent opens in SoHo; Purple magazine and Rag and Bone take over the Standard East Village.

title: Driven | 2015 Chevrolet Trax
description: The 2015 Chevrolet Trax is a small crossover thats the beginning of a very large wave.

title: Inquiry by Israeli Comptroller Criticizes Spending Habits of Netanyahu and Wife
description: JERUSALEM  Food costs at the Israeli prime ministers residence more than doubled after Benjamin Netanyahu took office in 2009, reaching nearly $120,000 in 2012, a third of it in takeout meals. The state paid about $2,000 a month to clean the Netanyahus private home in the seaside town of Caesarea, though the family spent most of its time in Jerusalem.

title: Washington Landmarks Covered in Snow
description: A winter storm throughout the Mid-Atlantic region brought heavy snowfall to Washington on Monday night, in a season that has seen unusually high levels of snowfall in the East.

title: Rethinking Money, Not as Good or Bad but as a Tool
description: Almost everything were taught about money is focused on spending it and saving it. Parents, teachers and even personal finance books discuss saving money as keeping it, increasing it and controlling it. Saving money involves figuring out ways to get more of it, to build a bigger cushion. Were taught thats the ultimate goal.

title: Southeast Snowstorm Leaves Beauty and Danger
description: ATLANTA  Communities across the Southeast were paralyzed by snow and ice, left without power and rushing to clear frozen roadways Tuesday morning after a pounding winter storm, with officials warning of more trouble that may come with a second round of cold weather later this week.

description: After holding back for too long, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India delivered a firm statement Tuesday condemning religious violence.

description: Alex Rodriguez issued a hand-written statement Tuesday apologizing for his behavior that led to a season-long suspension for performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Icahn Invokes S.E.C. in Unusual Twist in Fight With Wachtell Lipton
description: Notice about a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into possible violations at a company usually sends shudders through management. But that may not be the case in a nasty fight between the activist investor Carl C. Icahn and Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, the New York law firm, which has established a reputation for resisting hostile takeovers and proxy solicitations.

description: Art programs at hotels are increasingly popular, and the Marriott-owned chain Renaissance Hotels is putting a spin on the idea by transforming a windowpane at the entryway of each of its 159 global properties into an attention-getting work of art.

title: Coachs Ph.D. in Psychology Is Applied on Court and in Classroom
description: ST. PAUL  Thirty-two students sat at long tables in a University of St. Thomas classroom one recent morning, reviewing notes or checking their smartphones, when John Tauer walked in. Tauer wore a purple dress shirt and gray pleated slacks under his black topcoat, but not the tie and blazer he would wear that night for his other job, coaching the St. Thomas mens basketball team.

title: Filmmakers Set Sights on 52, the Worlds Loneliest Whale
description: If a crowd-funding push succeeds, a unique and solitary whale known as 52 may soon have its silver screen moment.

title: Advice for Finding Your Groove
description: Last week, I invited Christine Carter, author of The Sweet Spot: How to Find Your Groove at Home and at Work, to coach a few of us through the real world issues that get in our way when it comes to settling into a happy, functional routine at home and at work.

title: Fishing for Sweaters for Fall 2015
description: Never have the runways looked so tempting, as designers continue to introduce fur-hooded parkas, oversize shearling coats and rugged boots for fall  an appealing lot for the fashion set, which continues to trudge through snow and slush from one venue to the next. And a few fresh takes on the classic fisherman cable-knit sweaters are in the running for the coziest crop yet of winter-weather staples on fall 2015 runways. At Coach and Alexander Wang, the cream-colored tops  decked out with fringe and stud details, respectively  brightened up otherwise dark collections. And in Vera Wangs gender-bending fashion show today, her oversize rendition of the traditional knit again lightened things up  especially paired with long shorts and high booties.

title: The Chevrolet Trax Is a Crossover in a Smaller Package
description: AMERICANS shun station wagons and hatchbacks, but they cannot get enough of sport utility vehicles and crossovers. The Chevrolet Trax, a name that word processors desperately want to correct, is much like a small hatchback dressed in North Face gear. Its something youll be seeing much more of  the subcompact crossover. Look for Jeep Renegade, Mazda CX-3 and Honda HR-V at a campsite (or Jamba Juice) in the near future.

title: Shake-Up at Mattress Company May Be Due
description: The burning bed is flaring up again. The investment firm H Partners, complaining of a dormant stock price at Tempur Sealy and private equity directors asleep on the job, wants the top executive replaced and a seat on the board. A torturous financial history suggests its probably time to shake up the mattress company and the industry again.

title: U.N. Envoy to Syria Announces Possible Truce in Aleppo
description: UNITED NATIONS  In what could be a diplomatic breakthrough in the Syrian conflict, a senior United Nations envoy said Tuesday that he had persuaded President Bashar al-Assad to stop bombing and shelling the northern city of Aleppo as part of a proposed six-week truce.

title: Diesel Black Gold: Fall 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Judge Hears Arguments Over G.M.s Exposure to Recall Suits
description: In the fraught summer of 2009, the federal bankruptcy judge Robert E. Gerber proved to be a crucial figure in General Motors struggle for survival. With the economy in deep recession and the once-dominant automaker bleeding red ink, he presided over a fast-track bankruptcy process that allowed G.M. to remake itself  with the help of $49 billion from federal taxpayers  as a new company free of onerous liabilities.

title: A Taste of Japan at Grand Central
description: To Sample: Japanese Treats for the Train Ride Home

title: Judge Says Cuomo Must Set Election to Fill Grimms House Seat
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo must soon schedule a special election to fill the vacant congressional seat representing Staten Island and parts of Brooklyn, or a federal court will do it for him, a judge ordered on Tuesday.

title: Getting Closer to the California Print Junkie Who Designed Jay Zs Holy Grail
description: From a young age, the artist, graphic designer and California native Brian Roettinger grew up acutely aware of design in his daily life  in large part, he says, because of the stuff my parents and grandparents had around the house, including a vast record collection, not to mention quintessential suburban 70s furniture. Looking and talking about photos was a common affair in our household. My mother, meanwhile, would make macram and paint.

title: Senior Swagger
description: Bermuda shorts and bucket hats usher in the season of the septuagenarian.

title: When Consumers Dont Spend
description: Consumer spending is at the heart of a strong economy. It is the source of pay and profits. It is the engine of economic activity.

title: President Obama and Whig History
description: Finishing up business left undone last week, Im grateful to Ta-Nehisi Coates for taking the time to critique my own critique of President Obamas prayer breakfast speech. A few thoughts in response, working my way aroundhis points.

title: Ashton Carter Sworn In as Secretary of Defense
description: WASHINGTON  Ashton B. Carter was sworn in Tuesday as the 25th secretary of defense  and the fourth to serve the Obama administration  taking the oath of office in a small White House ceremony where Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. called him a thinker and a doer.

title: Carter Sworn In as Defense Secretary
description: Ashton B. Carter pledged his commitment to help the president make the best possible decisions during his swearing-in ceremony as defense secretary.

title: Nashvilles Clandestine Black Schools
description: On Monday, March 4, 1833, the nations seventh president and Tennessees most famous son, Andrew Jackson, was sworn in for his second term. On that same day another Tennessean, Alphonso M. Sumner, clandestinely opened a school for black children in Nashville. It was a bold move: In the wake of Nat Turners uprising two years earlier, Southern whites had begun a particularly violent reign of terror against black efforts at organizing institutions like schools and churches  were critical to the black struggle for freedom, justice and civil rights. But Sumner, a free black barber, bet that the paternalistic sympathies of white Nashvillians would allow them to turn a blind-eye to a school for free black children, owned and operated by him.

title: An Encore of Over-the-Knee Boots at Rodarte
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: A Wheeldon Nutcracker for the Joffrey
description: Christopher Wheeldon will create a new Nutcracker in December 2016 for Chicagos Joffrey Ballet, the company announced on Tuesday. The new production will mark the end of a Chicago tradition; Robert Joffrey, who founded the Joffrey Ballet with Gerald Arpino, choreographed The Nutcracker for the company in 1987, and it has been performed each December since the company moved to Chicago from New York in 1995.

title: Re-election Bid Offers Test of Mayors Appeal to Two Chicagos
description: CHICAGO  In some of this citys predominantly black neighborhoods on the South Side, Rahm Emanuel was not well known when he swept into the mayors office in 2011. After all, he had been a congressman from the other, mostly white side of town. But most voters knew that President Obama, himself a South Sider, had trusted him to be White House chief of staff, and that backing went a long way. Mr. Emanuel won every majority black ward in the city.

title: Israeli Girl Injured in Palestinian Rock-Throwing Attack in 2013 Dies
description: JERUSALEM  A 4-year-old Israeli girl who was critically injured in a car accident caused by Palestinian rock throwers two years ago died on Tuesday after a severe bout of pneumonia that relatives said was complicated by her neurological trauma.

title: Fallout Over Argentine Prosecutors Death Draws International Tensions
description: INTENDENTE ALVEAR, Argentina  Fallout from the mysterious death of a federal prosecutor raised diplomatic tensions between Argentina and the United States on Tuesday, on the eve of a controversial march in the prosecutors honor that has fueled unease between the government and parts of the judiciary.

title: Spanish Judge Drops Charges Against 9 Priests in Sexual Abuse Case
description: MADRID  A Spanish judge leading an investigation into accusations of sexual abuse against priests in the southern city of Granada has decided that the case can proceed against only one of the priests because the statute of limitations has expired for the lower-level criminal charges filed against 11 other people, including nine priests.

title: Review: Helen Macdonalds H Is for Hawk, a Memoir on Grief and Falconry
description: In the current issue of The New York Review of Books, in an essay about the films and fiction of Miranda July, Lorrie Moore writes, We dont always know what intimate life consists of until novels tell us.

description: At the southern end of Phuket island, the house is on the market for $2.78 million.

description: Turning Point As JetBlue welcomes its new chief executive Robin Hayes, the airline faces a challenge as it strives to balance its unique passenger services with the desire to increase profits. (USA Today)

description: Flexible work arrangements help a father to care for his toddler, a government lawyer to make her doctors appointments and a New York City worker to sleep in.

description: Senator Elizabeth Warrens coterie of progressive supporters expressed support for her private meeting with Hillary Rodham Clinton, calling it a potential win for economic populism.

description: President Obama, after a federal judge in Texas ordered a halt to the presidents executive actions on immigration, according to a pool report.

title: Feb. 17, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Gaza City, Pakistan, Myanmar and Ukraine.

title: A Child, Coping, with Autism and Everything Else
description: My son has started turning. Turning his body, I mean, pivoting 360 degrees on the threshold before going through doors, mostly, though sometimes its an N.B.A.-like fake left or right just before he starts to move forward. Once we noticed, we asked him about it and got, eventually, a pretty clear answer: I was turned the wrong way. Ah.

title: How Can We Find More People Like You?
description: Airbnb tries to take its trust revolution to Japan.

title: To the Readers: Alex Rodriguez Is Not Going Away. Sorry.
description: Tents are perfect for the circus. If Alex Rodriguez had used one for his latest apology, he might as well have shown up in grease paint, floppy shoes and a rainbow wig. Rodriguez, the clown prince of baseball, would be setting himself up for laughs.

title: Review: Matthew Perry in an Odd Couple Refitted for a New Century
description: In comedy, opposites dont attract. Instead they repel each other attractively. And by that standard, the CBS remake of The Odd Couple, that has its premiere on Thursday, isnt so bad. It may even work.

title: Review: A La Donna del Lago With Melting Tenderness at the Met
description: For years, the superb mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato has sung Tanti affetti, the final showpiece aria from Rossinis La Donna del Lago (The Lady of the Lake), as a surefire encore in recitals. But on Monday night on the Metropolitan Opera stage, vocal display seemed the last thing on her mind.

title: Review: Ensemble ACJW Performs Meredith Monks Instrumental Backlight
description: The composer Meredith Monk is known for her uncanny ability to coax the human voice into sonorities both ethereal and startling. Ms. Monk, also a dancer, singer, choreographer, director and filmmaker, has been honing this extended vocal technique since the 1960s, championed by her own ensemble. Her otherworldly vocal quilts are often a patchwork of noises, cries and ululations, interwoven with chanting and humming. Other works are more lyrical, with plaintive, folk-tinged vocal lines stretched over somber, spare accompaniments.

title: Review: Blue Heron Performs Missa De plus en plus at Corpus Christi Church
description: Clever or pretty? Spiritual or erotic? When it comes to the music of the 15th-century Franco-Flemish composer Johannes Ockeghem, certain distinctions become moot.

title: Review: Cop Show, Colin Quinns Police Procedural Satire
description: The comedian Colin Quinn is a cunning self-deprecator: He makes fun of his own middling level of fame with an aggressive edge that suggests that he really ought to be bigger by now. On Twitter, he draws attention by encouraging his haters, retweeting their most imaginative insults. (Recent sample: My girlfriend and I are going to play the CQ game. Every time you come on screen, we drink arsenic.)

title: Mac Wellman, a Playwriting Mentor Whose Only Mantra Is Oddity
description: On a recent Tuesday afternoon, Mac Wellman, the Donald I. Fine Distinguished Professor of Play Writing, sat at the head of a table in a Brooklyn College classroom. It was the first meeting of the semester, and he needed to arrange tutorials with his graduate students. He asked them to draw up a plan for the terms work: something small, something secret.

description: One of the longest-running lawsuits related to a merger was settled on Tuesday when Boston Scientific agreed to pay Johnson & Johnson $600 million in connection with an 11-year-old deal gone awry.

description: The high-performing schools are a great draw in Wilton, Conn., for those who can do without the more convenient commute enjoyed by suburbs to the south.

title: A Conversation With Jed Walentas, Real Estate Developer in New York
description: Mr. Walentas, 40, is a principal of Two Trees Management, which has developed and managed more than four million square feet of commercial and residential real estate, mostly in New York City. The company was started by Mr. Walentass father, David, who is also credited with helping put the Dumbo neighborhood in Brooklyn on the map.

title: Crossed Fates in Central African Republic
description: In Return to Boda, Sam Phelps wants to remind viewers how now-warring groups once coexisted in a small town in the Central African Republic.

title: A Judges Assault on Immigration
description: President Obama surely knew that his recent executive actions to protect millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation would run into trouble as soon as a 26-state lawsuit opposing the actions landed on the desk of Federal District Judge Andrew Hanen, of Brownsville, Tex.

title: A Gastronomic Paradise
description: A loosely affiliated group of Puerto Rican cooks, farmers and activists are reintroducing diners to the buried culinary treasures of their island.

title: A Book Prize for Wonder Woman
description: Americas favorite female superhero has a new medal to pin on her Stars-and-Stripes bustier, thanks to the New-York Historical Society, which has awarded its annual American History Book Prize to Jill Lepores best-selling The Secret History of Wonder Woman.

title: Honoring Churchill at Blenheim and Beyond
description: Fifty years after his death and 75 since being appointed prime minister and delivering his Finest Hour speech to the House of Commons, Sir Winston Churchill is being memorialized in England and France.

title: Tangled Up in Red Tape in Greece
description: As the nations economic crisis continues, some businesses are challenged as much by the countrys bureaucracy as by its austerity measures.

title: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Are Suspended on Wednesday
description: Because of Ash Wednesday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Italian Soccer Has Too Many Colored Players, Revered Coach Says
description: After watching the final match of a prestigious tournament for young soccer players in Italy on Monday, the revered former coach of Italys national team, Arrigo Sacchi, told reporters that he had spotted just one problem with the winner: too many of the players were not white.

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT LEASE

title: Lorena Rojas, Actress in Spanish-Language Soap Operas, Dies at 44
description: Lorena Rojas, a Mexican actress known for her roles in popular Spanish-language soap operas like Alcanzar Una Estrella (To Reach a Star) and El Cuerpo del Deseo (The Body of Desire), died on Monday at her home in Miami. She was 44.

title: Perella Weinberg Said to Fire Its Restructuring Chief
description: The boutique investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners has fired the head of its restructuring advisory practice for attempting to poach colleagues for a new firm that he was setting up, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

title: Amare Stoudemire Is Said to Have Agreement With Mavericks
description: Amare Stoudemire and the Dallas Mavericks have a tentative agreement in place for the forward to join the team for the remainder of the season.

title: Valuation for Snapchat Could Rise to $19 Billion
description: Snapchat, the start-up with disappearing photo messages, may be popular with teenagers. But in investors eyes, it is commanding a very grown-up valuation.

title: Sophie Theallet: Fall 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: A Soldiers Life
description: In a series of photographs, a female commando in the Congolese Army reveals private moments and her surprising role in her countrys long-running war.

title: Off the Runway
description: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.

title: At Thom Browne, a Challenge From the Fringe
description: American fashion, like American politics, may be a discipline won by moving toward the middle, but the most riveting action often takes place on the sides. It is the extremists on the edges who make the clothes that are the most fun to see, and provocative to consider.

title: Well Be Back
description: The rise of Hong Kongs democracy movement.

title: Elie Tahari: Summer 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Meticulous Preparation Is for Broadcasters, Too
description: In the production truck outside Madison Square Garden on Tuesday afternoon, nearly 20 members of the USA Network crew were preparing for the second night of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, which was to culminate with awarding Best in Show to the dog judged worthier than its six rivals.

title: As Rivals Falter, Indias Economy Is Surging Ahead
description: SRIPERUMBUDUR, India  Chinas economy is slowing. Brazil is struggling as commodity prices plunge. Russia, facing Western sanctions and weak oil revenue, is headed into a recession.

title: Celebrity Encounters at the Fashion Shows
description: Have you heard the one about Nicki Minaj, in the birds-of-paradise feathers, in the operating room?

title: Robert E. Herzstein, Who Foiled Nixon Over White House Tapes, Dies at 83
description: Robert E. Herzstein, who successfully sued on behalf of historians and journalists to prevent former President Richard M. Nixon from removing and even destroying his White House papers and tapes after his resignation, died on Thursday at his home in Washington. He was 83.

title: Hungary Keeps Visit by Putin Low-Key as It Seeks to Repair Relations With West
description: WARSAW  When Vladimir V. Putin played host at the Kremlin early last year to Hungarys prime minister, Viktor Orban, the notion of a reciprocal visit that would bring the Russian president onto European Union soil seemed perfectly in keeping with a whole series of stick-in-the-eye moves toward Europe by the two leaders in recent years.

title: You Give Back What You Can, While You Can
description: Documenting the violence in Rios favelas.

title: Rand Paul Is Looking to April to Announce Plan to Run for President, Associates Say
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Rand Paul is eyeing April 7 as the day he will announce his plans to run for president, people close to him said, a step that would position him ahead of his potential Republican rivals as a declared candidate and allow him to begin raising money directly for his campaign 10 months before the Iowa caucuses.

title: After Public Acrimony, Quieter Steps by Mayor de Blasio and Police to Mend Rift
description: It was an unusual lunch date, powered by political winds and a heap of pastrami: Mayor Bill de Blasio and the police union leader who had, weeks earlier, appraised the mayor publicly as a total nincompoop.

title: Facing Suits, a Nursing Home in California Seeks Bankruptcy
description: A California nursing home fined by the state for substandard care and facing multiple lawsuits by patients and their families has taken the extreme measure of filing for bankruptcy protection in the face of millions of dollars in potential payouts.

title: Give Greece Room to Maneuver
description: Greeces lenders, most notably Germany, insist that they are defending important principles: a country must pay its debts, and the long-term success of the euro depends on everyone abiding by the rules.

title: Veterans in Congress Bring Rare Perspective to Authorizing War
description: WASHINGTON  Veterans of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan now serving in Congress have emerged as some of the most important voices in the debate over whether to give President Obama a broad authorization for a military campaign against the Islamic State or something much more limiting.

title: Americans May See Appeal of Medical Tourism in Cuba
description: HAVANA  Anuja Agrawal jumped on the phone. President Obama had just announced that he would restore diplomatic relations with Cuba  and Ms. Agrawal, who runs a medical tourism company in Orlando, Fla., did not want to miss her opening.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 17, 2015
Doctors Strive to Do Less Harm by Inattentive Care
description: Suffering. The very word made doctors uncomfortable. Medical journals avoided it, instructing authors to say that patients have a disease or complications or side effects rather than suffer or suffer from them, said Dr. Thomas H. Lee, the chief medical officer of Press Ganey, a company that surveys hospital patients.

title: A Different (and Surprising) Economic Tale of New York City Emerges
description: When Bill de Blasio ran for mayor in 2013, he declared that New York Citys middle class wasnt just shrinking, but also stood in real danger of disappearing altogether. The claim was part of the tale-of-two-cities theme that drove his campaign, the gilded metropolis indifferently snuffing out its gasping work force.

title: 30 More Problem Days, Boston Transit Chief Says
description: BOSTON  As if the record snowfall and piercing subzero temperatures were not bad enough, residents here awoke Tuesday to reports that the already crippled Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, one of the largest transit systems in the country, would not be fully functional for at least 30 more days.

title: Anne Moody, Author of Coming of Age in Mississippi, Dies at 74
description: Anne Moody, whose searing memoir, Coming of Age in Mississippi, told what it was like to grow up black in the era of Jim Crow, died on Feb. 5 at her home in Gloster, Miss. She was 74.

title: Celebrating Oscar de la Renta and His Successor
description: On one side of the runway sat the old guard, the perfectly coifed, expensively furred women who made Oscar de la Renta a Park Avenue icon, women like Nancy Kissinger and Mercedes Bass. Barbara Walters was settled in their company; Annette de la Renta, the designers widow, was too, seated beside Anna Wintour. Bill Cunningham, before the show, hurried over to give her a warm hug.

title: Oscar de la Renta: Fall 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Japan Post Offers $5.1 Billion for Australian Package Delivery Company
description: TOKYO  Japans national postal service is buying the largest private package and freight delivery company in Australia, Toll Holdings, for 6.5 billion Australian dollars, the two groups said on Wednesday.

title: Head of New Yorks Top Court Says Judges Should Oversee Grand Juries in Deaths Involving Police
description: New Yorks top judge proposed on Tuesday that judges oversee grand juries deliberating police-related killings of civilians and be granted greater leeway to make the testimony to such juries available to the public.

title: Review: Little Children Dream of God, a Drama of Haitian Refugees
description: The presence, or absence, of a presiding deity may be a question we all ponder from time to time, but its a matter of daily significance in Little Children Dream of God, a warm and fanciful drama by Jeff Augustin about a Haitian immigrant trying to forge a new life on the rough streets of Miami.

title: Review: In Hamilton, Lin-Manuel Miranda Forges Democracy Through Rap
description: Theyre brewing up a revolution down on Lafayette Street. And even theater reactionaries seem destined to be swept up in its doubt-defying ardor.

title: Puzzle the Blogging
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Its tough to construct and edit a midweek puzzle. Your theme cant really turn too many cruciverbal somersaults, lest it be pushed into Thursday territory (despite Will Shortzs claim that Thursdays are not meant to be anything special themewise, thats where the really cool ones tend to hang out). The clues need to wander surreptitiously away from Monday straightforwardness, but not creep into weekend-level brain-twisting. You can see how getting it just right might be difficult.

title: Islamist Faction in Libya Now Strikes From the Sky
description: CAIRO  The Islamist-backed faction in Libyas civil conflict said Tuesday that it had carried out its first airstrike, targeting opponents in the town of Zintan in an escalation of the violence tearing the country apart.

title: In a Logistical Riddle for the Court, a Terrorism Suspect Is His Own Lawyer
description: Abid Naseer, who is accused of being a Qaeda operative and planning an attack in Manchester, England, stood at a table on Tuesday for opening statements in his trial.

title: Presidents Cup in South Korea May Lack Native Sons
description: LOS ANGELES  The golf calendar is stuffed fuller than a pro-am goody bag, with 43 PGA Tour events, including the four majors, plus the FedEx Cup playoffs.

title: New Rules Set on Armed Drone Exports
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday issued new rules for the international export of armed drones, a move that seeks to preserve an American lead in a fast-growing market but one likely to speed the proliferation of a much-criticized weapon in the battle against terrorism.

title: Obama Cites Health Plan Tally of 11.4 Million
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Tuesday that 11.4 million people had selected private health insurance plans or renewed their coverage under the Affordable Care Act in the enrollment period that ended Sunday.

title: Transit Groups Next Challenge: Selling a New Version of Congestion Pricing
description: A transit advocacy group unveiled a proposal on Tuesday to remake the way tolls are set across New York City. Now comes the hard part  persuading lawmakers and drivers to embrace an idea that was defeated in Albany nearly seven years ago.

title: Illinois: Imam Charged With Sex Abuse
description: A Chicago-area imam was charged with sexual abuse on Tuesday in a case that has raised questions about whether a cloistered South Asian communitys conservative views on sex and purity had discouraged women from coming forward with accusations of abuse. The charge was announced hours before four women filed a lawsuit accusing the imam, Mohammad Abdullah Saleem, who founded a school called the Institute of Islamic Education, of a pattern of sexual abuse dating back to the 1980s. A 23-year-old woman who worked as a school secretary last year told the police that Mr. Saleem had repeatedly groped her and once pulled her onto his lap and held her there over her objections. He categorically denies the allegations, his lawyer, Thomas T. Glasgow, said after a court appearance. He said the school had investigated and found no evidence for the claims.

title: Fear of Israeli Leaks Fuels Distrust Over U.S. Talks With Iran
description: WASHINGTON  With the Obama administration racing to negotiate the outlines of a nuclear deal with Iran by the end of March, aides to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel have charged in recent days that they are being deliberately left in the dark about the details of the talks. The Americans have said that is untrue, but even one of Washingtons closest negotiating partners reports being warned about being too open with the Israelis, because whatever we say may be used in a selective way.

title: 16 Die in Crush at Carnival in Haiti Capital
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  A stampede on Tuesday left 16 people dead and 78 injured when a singer atop a Carnival float struck an overhead power line, igniting sparks and panic, the authorities said.

title: Narciso Rodriguez: Fall 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: As N.B.A. Trading Deadline Nears, Celtics Have Lots of Picks and Possibilities
description: The N.B.A. trading deadline is Thursday at 3 p.m. Eastern time. Until then, there will be stories on the Phoenix Suns potential trade of Goran Dragic, the overhaul of the Denver Nuggets and the Houston Rockets ongoing analytic search for better players.

title: The State of Your New York Block
description: The State of the City speech, delivered each winter by the mayor, is a time-honored policy platform. But it doesnt tell you whats really going on out there. For that, you need to ask residents.

title: A Regal Beagle Seizes the Spotlight
description: It took 20 minutes for David Merriam, the Best in Show judge at the Westminster Kennel Club Show on Tuesday, to give the dog-loving audience at Madison Square Garden a bit of a shock. After a devilishly long route to making up his mind  he seemed to enjoy building the suspense, smiling a bit impishly as he deliberated  he made the surprising choice of Miss P, a 15-inch beagle and the grandniece of Uno, the first beagle to ever win the big show, in 2008.

title: Gaps in Frances Surveillance Are Clear; Solutions Arent
description: PARIS  Last June, Patrick Calvar, the head of Frances domestic intelligence service, faced a decision: continue surveillance on a French Islamist who had been viewed as a potential threat for a decade, or shift limited resources to help monitor a swelling new generation of fighters returning from Syria.

title: Russia: Court Upholds Activists Suspended Sentence
description: A Moscow appeals court on Tuesday upheld a suspended three-and-a-half-year prison sentence against Aleksei A. Navalny, a leader of Russias opposition to President Vladimir V. Putin who was convicted last year of fraud in a case widely seen as politically motivated. The court also released Mr. Navalny, an organizer of an opposition rally planned for March 1, from house arrest. A three-and-a-half-year prison sentence handed down to Mr. Navalnys brother, who was convicted in the same case, remained unchanged. Mr. Navalny called his brother a hostage.

title: Miu Miu Womens Tales Taps a Cannes Grand Prix Winner
description: For the latest installment of the Miu Miu short-film series Womens Tales  an ongoing project that has included commissions by Miranda July, Ava DuVernay and Zoe Cassavetes  the brand enlisted Alice Rohrwacher, the writer and director of Corpo Celeste (2011) and the Cannes Grand Prix recipient The Wonders (2014). In fact, it was my first short, Rohrwacher says of her 15-minute-long piece, De Djess. With a short film, youre able to do some experimenting and still stay within formal guidelines. That, and Miu Miu allowed Rohrwacher an enormous amount of artistic freedom; the houses designer, Miuccia Prada, only asked to see the completed film, a rare occurrence in the movie-making realm.

title: Word of the Day | auxiliary
description: auxiliary  \og-zil-y-re, -zil-re, -zi-l-\  adjective and noun

title: Critic of N.F.L. Settlement on Concussions Reverses Position
description: Joe DeLamielluere, one the biggest critics of the settlement in a suit that accused the N.F.L. of failing to warn former players about the dangers of concussions, has reversed himself and joined the agreement, according to a court filing on Tuesday. DeLamielluere, a former offensive lineman, joined nine others who initially opted out but will now take part in the settlement, which provides up to $5 million for a limited number of severe neurological conditions. In all, 211 retired players, or about 1 percent of the total, opted out of the deal, which lawyers for the N.F.L. and the former players revised Friday to meet some concerns of Anita B. Brody, the federal judge in the case.

title: Whats on TV Wednesday
description: 9 P.M. (ABC Family) MATILDA (1996) For every child who ever thought the world was unfair, theres hope that, like Matilda (Mara Wilson), he or she may one day discover a way to even the score. In this film based on Roald Dahls novel, Matilda is a clever heroine born to a loathsome set of parents  played here by Danny DeVito, who also directed the film, and Rhea Perlman  who is sent to a school overseen by a monstrous woman who torments her students. But things begin to change when Matilda realizes that she can use her telekinetic powers to defend herself and her fellow underdogs. Though the film may be too twisted for very young children, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, the sweet, self-possessed little heroine is someone to admire: Even when addressed by her father as You lyin little earwig, Ms. Wilsons poised Matilda never loses the quiet confidence that guarantees she will prevail.

title: Dogs Time to Shine
description: The 139th annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show concluded at Madison Square Garden with the Best in Show competition.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I felt like my world crashed a little bit.

title: Corrections: February 18, 2015
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Dogs Time to Shine
description: The 139th annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show concluded at Madison Square Garden with the Best in Show competition.

title: Songwriters Hall of Fame to Honor Toby Keith, Cyndi Lauper, Robert Hunter and Jerry Garcia
description: The 2015 inductees to the Songwriters Hall of Fame will include such varied musicians as Toby Keith, Cyndi Lauper, Linda Perry, Bobby Braddock, Willie Dixon and the Grateful Dead writing duo of Robert Hunter and Jerry Garcia. The ceremony will take place at the Marriott Marquis in New York on June 18.

title: Coming Soon: Celebrity Web Networks From the Media Company Whalerock
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  An under-the-radar media company here called Whalerock could become a threat to the entertainment establishment.

title: Civilian Toll in Afghan War Rose in 2014, U.N. Reports
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Last year was the deadliest for civilians caught up in Afghanistans war since the United Nations began keeping records in 2009, the world body said Wednesday  a harbinger of the new dynamic of the conflict, in which insurgents and Afghan forces increasingly engage in face-to-face battles.

title: Past Imperfect: Lives in the Biographers Mirror
description: Life, Soren Kierkegaard observed, can only be understood backwards; but it must be lived forwards. At first glance, that observation would seem to accord biographers of departed souls an advantage denied their works subjects.

description: To the Editor:

title: Regulating Payday Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Talk About Those Unpaid Bills
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  INTUITION, and a long line of social science research, suggests that citizens are more motivated to become politically involved when an issue is personally important to them.

title: The Modern Asylum
description: LAST month, three ethicists from the University of Pennsylvania argued in the Journal of the American Medical Association that the movement to deinstitutionalize the mentally ill has been a failure. Deinstitutionalization, they wrote, has in truth been transinstitutionalization. As a hospital psychiatrist, I see this every day. Patients with chronic, severe mental illnesses are still in facilities  only now they are in medical hospitals, nursing homes and, increasingly, jails and prisons, places that are less appropriate and more expensive than long-term psychiatric institutions.

title: The Mission of College? Think About It
Records in Child Abuse Case: Acting D.A. Responds
description: To the Editor:

title: Democracy Is in Recession
description: Every month now we get treated to another anti-Semitic blast from Turkeys leadership, which seems to be running some kind of slur-of-the-month club. Who knew that Jews all over the world were busy trying to take down President Recep Tayyip Erdogan? Last week, it was Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglus turn to declare that Turkey would not succumb to the Jewish lobby  among others supposedly trying to topple Erdogan, the Hurriyet Daily News reported. This was after Erdogan had suggested that domestic opponents to the ruling Justice and Development Party, or A.K.P., were cooperating with the Mossad, Israels intelligence arm. So few Jews, so many governments to topple.

title: A Stronger Freedom of Information Act
description: Congress came tantalizingly close last year to passing a bill to strengthen the Freedom of Information Act, which allows journalists and the public to access federal government records. The legislation, which would have brought more transparency, was blocked in December when the House speaker, John Boehner, refused to hold a vote on the Senate bill with no explanation. Two months later, lawmakers have a second chance.

title: College, Poetry and Purpose
description: PHILADELPHIA  Over four decades at two universities, Anne Hall has taught thousands of students, enough to know that they come to college for a variety of reasons, with a variety of attitudes. Many are concerned only with jobs. Some are concerned chiefly with beer.

title: My Mother Is Not a Bird
description: I stood watching my mothers last bellowing breaths. There were three of us holding her  me, my husband and my father  in the room wed designed just for her. She was propped up in a rented hospital bed, lying on brown cotton sheets with the highest thread count I could find. My mother had been gasping like this for two days  a raspy, gurgling sound that I struggle to describe accurately with metaphors: a choking fish, a crackling microphone, a dying deer. But they all sidestep the truth. That was the sound of my 60-year-old mother dying of cancer.

title: Resuming Drilling in the Atlantic
Test Yourself | The Westminster Dog Show
description: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 16 article, Westminster Dog Show Offers No Joy for Fans of a Charming Galoot.

title: An Expensive Sunset for the Brent Oil Field
description: LONDON  Cleaning up an oil field in a forbidding environment like the North Sea may be almost as formidable a task as developing one, and in the coming years, those waters are likely to serve as a laboratory for what happens when the useful lives of oil fields expire.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Hand of a Superhero
description: In Hand of a Superhero, Jacqueline Mroz writes about prosthetic hands made with 3-D printers.

title: Altice Offers $4.4 Billion for Vivendis Stake in Numericable-SFR
description: LONDON  The French media group Vivendi said on Wednesday that Altice had offered to buy its 20 percent stake in Numericable-SFR.

title: Crdit Agricole Earnings Beat Expectations
description: PARIS  Crdit Agricole, one of Frances largest banks, on Wednesday reported quarterly profit that beat market expectations, helped by a resurgence in its investment banking activities and a sharp reduction in its provisions against loan losses.

title: Should Farm Animals Have More Legal Protections?
description: The Animal Welfare Act, enacted in 1966, protects dogs, cats, rabbits and reptiles  but excludes farm animals. For example, Nicholas Kristof recently wrote about how chickens are often raised to have breasts so large that their legs cant support their body weight. And other Times writers have written about abuse of pigs, sheep and cattle.

title: Crossed Fates in Central African Republic
description: The moment Sam Phelps left the Central African Republic, he knew he had to return.

title: Hong Kongs Leader Hails Year of the Sheep   and Suggests a Role Model
description: Just what to call the next Lunar New Year has vexed English speakers, as the Chinese character can represent both sheep and goats. In his official New Year message, Hong Kongs leader, Leung Chun-ying, opts for a little of both. The video of his statement is filled with goats of all varieties: live, stuffed, illustrated. But Mr. Leung asked residents to look to sheep, the meek creature that lives in flocks, as a guide.

title: State Media Outlet Faults Billionaires Son for Crude Comment
description: When the son of one of the richest men in China responded to a reporters question about what he sought in a mate, the response shouldnt have surprised anyone. Thats simple, said 27-year-old Wang Sicong. A big chest is enough.

title: To Jump-Start Your Exercise Routine, Be Mindful
description: By now, many of us, beset by bad weather and declining motivation, are struggling to maintain our New Years exercise resolutions. But a timely new study offers encouragement, suggesting that by paying more attention to the experience of exercise itself, even the most reluctant of exercisers might begin to find pleasure in movement.

title: What to Expect on Day 7 of Fashion Week
description: Homestretch, fans!

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: City Blocks, Reviewed
description: Good morning on this soon-to-be-sunny Wednesday.

title: Swiss Prosecutors Search Offices of HSBC Unit
description: LONDON  Local prosecutors in Switzerland conducted a search of the offices of HSBCs Swiss private bank in Geneva on Wednesday as part of a new investigation into potential money laundering.

title: Daily Report: U.S. Sets New Rules for Export of Armed Drones
description: The Obama administration on Tuesday issued new rules for the international export of armed drones, a move that seeks to preserve an American lead in a fast-growing market but one likely to speed the proliferation of a much-criticized weapon in the battle against terrorism, Scott Shane reports.

title: Tesco, Britains Largest Retailer, Names John Allan as Chairman
description: LONDON  Tesco, the embattled British retailing giant, said on Thursday that John Allan, a deputy chairman of the electronics company Dixons Carphone, would take over as chairman on March 1.

title: Ukrainian Soldiers Retreat From Eastern Town Raises Doubt for Truce
description: ARTEMIVSK, Ukraine  Ukrainian soldiers were forced to fight their way out of the embattled town of Debaltseve in the early hours of Wednesday, casting further doubt on the credibility of a days-old cease-fire and eroding the promise of ending a war in Europe that has killed more than 5,000 people.

title: Sony Aims for Huge Leap in Profit
description: HONG KONG  The light at the end of the tunnel may finally be coming into focus for Sony.

title: Project Sheds Light on What Drives Genes
description: More than 200 scientists working on an ambitious federal project have begun to understand the complicated system of switches that regulates genes, turning some on and others off, making some glow brightly while others dim. They hope these discoveries, described in two dozen papers released on Wednesday, will eventually lead to a deeper understanding of diseases and new ways to treat or cure them.

title: Today in Politics
description: Immigration Ruling in Texas Muddies the Debate in Washington

title: Morning Agenda: Snapchat Reaches for $19 Billion Valuation
description: SNAPCHAT REACHES FOR $19 BILLION VALUATION | Snapchat, the start-up with disappearing photo messages, is said to be raising a round of venture capital that could value the company at up to $19 billion, Mike Isaac writes on the Bits blog, citing a person with knowledge of the discussions. Snapchat could raise up to $500 million in the round of financing, the person said. If the round closes, Snapchats value will have nearly doubled since last year, when the company was in talks to raise money at a $10 billion valuation.

title: A Lunar New Year With a Name Thats a Matter of Opinion
description: HONG KONG  China said goodbye to the Year of the Horse on Wednesday, and on the first day of the new lunar year revelers welcomed the Year of the Sheep.

title: Poland to Pay $262,000 to Inmates Held at Secret C.I.A. Prison
description: WARSAW  Poland will abide by a European court ruling that ordered it to pay a total of $262,000 in reparations to two former inmates of a black site prison run by the C.I.A., the minister of foreign affairs said on Wednesday.

title: Magnificent Obsessions Show at the Barbican Explores Portraits of the Artist as Collector
description: LONDON  Their works may be coveted by collectors, but artists often have a predilection for building eccentric collections of their own. Many like to pick up bric-a-brac from curiosity shops, market stalls and auction houses. Predictably enough, Damien Hirst owns skulls and stuffed animals. Less widely known is that Peter Blake hoards vintage shop signs, while Martin Parr boasts an impressive collection of Soviet souvenirs.

title: High-Spirited Comedies Rush the Stage
description: To get the gist of the comedy in the coming Broadway musical Something Rotten!, about a playwright competing against Shakespeare in 1595 London, consider this exchange between two characters who happen to be named Shylock and Nostradamus about the most avid theatergoers of the Elizabethan era.

title: Larry David on Broadway Theater, Seinfeld and Death Etiquette
description: In his dressing room at the Cort Theater, Larry David started eating dinner, but not before lowering expectations. I should warn you: Im not a skilled eater, he said, leaning forward to grab a white plastic takeout bag. I have problems getting the food onto my utensil and getting it into my mouth properly. Its not a pretty picture.

title: Subtle Bias, Fed Head Edition
description: This isnt a big deal, but it nonetheless had me doing a double-take. I was looking up educational backgrounds of prominent economists, for a post I havent found time to put together yet, and when I got to Janet Yellen I saw something that seemed off; so I went to see whether there was anything comparable on her predecessor. No, there wasnt:

title: Video Shows Racist Behavior by Chelsea Soccer Fans in Paris
description: LONDON  Video footage showing white fans of the English soccer team Chelsea shoving a black subway rider in Paris has revived concerns about racism in what is often labeled the beautiful game.

title: Jeb Bush on Obamas Home Turf to Attack His Foreign Policy
description: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida is in President Obamas hometown on Wednesday to lay out a foreign policy vision that he says is in contrast to the inconsistent and indecisive policies of the current White House.
