description: Having emerged from the shadow of womens wear, mens wear is offering some of todays most compelling design, thanks to a new generation of young mavericks. With eyes on the street, the designers presented clothes for fall/winter 2015  in London (Craig Green, Alex Mullins and Martine Rose), Paris (Julien David and Gosha Rubchinskiy) and New York (Proper Gang)  that not only reflect what men like to wear, but what they will aspire to. T cast a similarly youthful set of breakthrough models from New York Fashion Week, which ends today, to model these six designers fall collections.

title: Hackers May Have Taken Customer Data From Morgan Stanley Broker
description: Theres been little dispute that a former Morgan Stanley broker, Galen Marsh, violated the firms rules when he downloaded information about 350,000 customers onto his personal computer. But Mr. Marsh may not be responsible for posting that information online late last year and trying to sell it, people familiar with the investigation said on Thursday.

title: Nutrition Panel Calls for Less Sugar and Eases Cholesterol and Fat Restrictions
description: A nutrition advisory panel that helps shape the countrys official dietary guidelines eased some of its previous restrictions on fat and cholesterol on Thursday and recommended sharp new limits on the amount of added sugar that Americans should consume.

title: Carmelo Anthony Has Knee Surgery; Recovery May Take 4 to 6 Months
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Carmelo Anthony underwent successful surgery on his left knee Thursday, a procedure that might require four to six months for recovery.

title: Putting a Price on Privacy: $29
description: Want a slice of privacy with your high speed Internet service? That will be $30 a month.

title: The Global Issue Covers
description: We asked several artists to make works based on the idea of chaos in the world, and how this is something we have all learned to live with.

title: Ronald Perelman, a Mogul With Muscle, Takes Over Carnegie Hall
description: RONALD O. PERELMAN, billionaire business titan and a self-described frustrated musician, owns five drum sets and has played with the likes of Bon Jovi and the Beach Boys. Yet he is landing at Carnegie Hall not by practicing on his snare drum but by taking over as the eminent music institutions standard-bearer.

title: Saudi King Unleashes a Torrent of Money as Bonuses Flow to the Masses
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  European leaders are still battling over austerity. The United States Congress is gearing up for another fight over the budget. But in Saudi Arabia, there are no such troubles when you are king  and you just dole out billions and billions of dollars to ordinary Saudis by royal decree.

title: Anna Deavere Smith to Deliver Jefferson Lecture
description: Anna Deavere Smith, known to millions of West Wing fans as President Josiah Bartlets national security adviser, will be returning to Washington on April 6 to take up a different role: the 44th Jefferson Lecturer in the Humanities.

title: Trappings of Chinese New Year Left at Sea by West Coast Port Dispute
description: Mung beans, sticky rice and banana leaves. Confetti and little red envelopes for gift money.

title: Now Cleared for Landing at Airports: Bees
description: MIRABEL, Quebec  A jet taxied down a nearby runway, the roar of its engines merging with the steady buzz of thousands of wings. His head covered with a beekeepers veil, Alexandre Beaudoin lifted a frame out of one of five buzzing hives, each housing about 70,000 bees. The bees paid no attention to his intrusion  they were sedated with smoke first  and continued their work.

title: J. Mendel: Fall 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Why a Reporters Epic Rant on Twitter Gets No Argument Here
description: On Twitter this week, James Risen laid out his plan for the future:

title: F.T.C. Challenges Merger of Sysco and US Foods
description: The Federal Trade Commission filed suit on Thursday to halt the proposed merger of Sysco and US Foods, contending that the deal would inflict higher prices and worse service on restaurants, hospitals, hotels, schools and other food service customers.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Queen and Country
description: John Boorman narrates a sequence from his film.

title: Tom Wolfes Papers Pop Up at the New York Public Library
description: ADMIRERS of Tom Wolfe had much to celebrate when the New York Public Library announced in late 2013 the acquisition of his archives. Having processed the collection, which includes about 190 boxes of material, the library is now briefly displaying a selection from it in Becoming the Man in the White Suit: The Tom Wolfe Papers.

title: A New Play Explores a Harlem Friendship That Never Was
description: In 1963, during one of the most turbulent years of the civil rights movement, the writer James Baldwin found himself on the cover of Time magazine, having become a national voice for civil rights with his book, The Fire Next Time. Meanwhile, the cornet-voiced jazz singer Dinah Washington, whod had a hit a few years back with What a Diffrence a Day Makes, was newly married, settling down in Detroit and looking forward to the release of a new album, Stranger on Earth. The two figures  each of them on a similar path of political awakening  probably never met (Washington would die of an overdose, at age 39, before Christmas), but that hasnt stopped the Obie Award-winning playwright and performer Carl Hancock Rux from imagining what would happen if they had with his new play Stranger on Earth.

title: John Boorman Narrates a Scene From Queen and Country
description: In this video, the director John Boorman discusses a scene from his drama Queen and Country, a follow-up to his 1987 film Hope and Glory.

title: Government Survives Vote of Confidence in France
description: PARIS  Frances Socialist government survived a confidence vote in the National Assembly on Thursday, two days after it forced through a contentious package of economic measures without a ballot.

title: Inspectors Say Iran Is Evading Questions as Nuclear Talks Enter a Crucial Stage
description: WASHINGTON  With only five weeks remaining for a basic agreement to be reached with Iran on the fate of its nuclear program, the worlds nuclear inspectors reported on Thursday that Iran was still refusing to answer their longstanding questions about suspected work on nuclear weapons and designs.

title: Yahoo Courts Mobile App Makers with New Tools
description: Yahoo doesnt just want to transform itself into a mobile company. It also wants to get its technology and ads into hundreds of thousands of independent apps, too.

title: Chairman of Phillips Sees Major Changes in Auctions
description: It was Phillipss strongest contemporary sale in more than two years, with talked-about lots, including works by the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei and the Los Angeles-born Mark Bradford. On the heels of that success, in London last week, Phillips is preparing for its big spring auctions in New York. For May, Phillips says it already has a Cy Twombly lined up, Untitled (Steps) from 1960, estimated at $2 million to $3 million.

title: The Habsburgs Treasures at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Gza von Habsburg, an art historian in suburban New York, would have inherited part of an Austrian empire if only his ancestors had not made some terrible life choices. He did inherit the title of archduke and an interest in the history of luxury goods  the kind his family commissioned for centuries. Recently, he watched as about 100 of his familys former heirlooms were installed at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts here for a new exhibition, The Habsburgs: Rarely Seen Masterpieces from Europes Greatest Dynasty, that runs through May.

title: Kehinde Wiley
description: Works from the artists first museum retrospective, at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: A Sprawling Retrospective for Kehinde Wileys Heroic Portraits
description: A New Republic, featuring 56 works by the award-winning artist, opens this week at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Iolani Palace in Hawaii Is Recovering Its Looted Furnishings
description: HONOLULU  Piece by piece, the furnishings of the last Hawaiian queen, Liliuokalani, are returning to Iolani Palace here, on a grassy square wedged between office buildings and populated by egrets. The royal property was dispersed through auctions and giveaways around 1900, but benefactors are retrieving it from antiques stores, thrift shops, backyards, storage units, museums and government offices worldwide.

title: CSX Oil Train Was Not Speeding in West Virginia Crash, Inquiry Finds
description: An oil tanker train was traveling well within the speed limit when it crashed this week in West Virginia, federal officials said Thursday, but three days after the accident, they were still unable to reach parts of the wreckage because fires continued to burn.

title: Ban Ki-Moon Praises Response to Killings
description: The United Nations secretary general said at a White House summit to counter violent extremism that he takes heart at the solidarity displayed after killings in Copenhagen and Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: Looking Back With Intensity
description: Shalmon Bernstein was attuned to the show within a show, where people were revealed by their costumes or context. He is now rediscovering the gems in his own archives.

title: Calvin Klein Collection: Fall 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Heat Acquire Goran Dragic Amid Shock and Satisfaction at N.B.A. Trade Deadline
description: The 2012 N.B.A. finalists, Miami and Oklahoma City, each in danger of missing the playoffs this season, shook up the conference races on Thursday amid a wild rush of deals before the trade deadline at 3 p.m. The transactions prompted Philadelphia center Joel Embiid to summarize many observers feelings with a tweet: Someone tell me whats going on please help.

title: The Ball and Chain of Student Debt
description: New information helps explain why consumers have been cautious in recent months, despite a better job market and cheaper gas.

title: Elizabeth and James: Fall 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Obamas Economic Report Focuses on Income Inequality
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday stepped up his efforts to define which economic problems need urgent attention  and what kind of attention would work  if not under his administration, then the next.

title: A Sprawling Retrospective for Kehinde Wileys Heroic Portraits
description: Barely two months in, it has already been a big year for the Brooklyn-based painter Kehinde Wiley. Last month, the artist received a 2014 U.S. State Department Medal of Arts; and this week, he prepares for his first museum retrospective, A New Republic, which will open at the Brooklyn Museum on Friday. Throughout his career, Wileys pieces have canonized the people they portray: Descendants from Africa, Haiti, Jamaica and elsewhere, depicted along with emblems of culture and identity. My work, for a long time, has focused on the ideals that we celebrate in America and abroad, he says. Many of his paintings outsource their influence from popular movements that predate the 19th century, like Flemish portraiture from the Northern Renaissance. But instead of using dark colors to create a sense of severity or authority, Wileys portraits explode with energy and color  particularly in their use of clothing, which occupies a central role in his work. Fashion is fragile and fleeting, he notes. But it is also an indicator for the cultural and social appetites for a nation.

title: At Napa Music Festival, Chefs Are in the Lineup
description: Chefs are often called the new rock stars, and now one California music festival plans to give some culinary headliners their own stage.

title: Jordan Stakes Role Against Terrorism
description: Foreign Minister Nasser Judeh said that Jordan would lead the fight against violent extremism, saying any doubt that this is our war as Muslims has been removed.

title: Lucy Skaer: Sticks & Stones and Random House
description: In two shows, the excellent British artist Lucy Skaer covers much ground in several mediums with uneven results. The repurposing and recycling of objects, images and forms  from other art, her own work, her life  are prominent in Ms. Skaers work, as with many artists today. The strategy yields outstanding results in the five related sculptures at Murray Guy. The tone is set by a low-lying sculpture: two thick, rough-edged slices of mahogany inlaid with smaller objects found around her studio  a tiny prototype, parts of other sculptures, a small lithography stone and an oblong blue ceramic tile. The piece, which evokes sculptures by Carl Andre and Bruce Nauman, is itself a prototype for the next four: an all-ceramic version; one in marble with touches of malachite; another in aluminum with gunmetal; and, finally, an all-wood version (including veneer). Together they form a stunning meditation on processes, materials and craft, on mutating details and textural contrasts, on looking, achieving an almost cosmic scope. I doubt each would seem quite so rich on its own.

title: Saya Woolfalk: ChimaTEK: Hybridity Visualization System
description: Saya Woolfalks engagingly imaginative exhibition evokes the lobby for a New Age boutique. It includes paintings of psychedelic kimonos, digital animations of archetypal iconography and exotic avatars and colorful mannequin heads decorated with bones and jewelry. Like the young video artist Jacolby Satterwhite among others, Ms. Woolfalk extends the genre known as Afro-futurism, which includes the music of Sun Ra and George Clinton and science-fiction novels by Samuel R. Delany and Octavia Butler.

title: First Draft Focus: A Reunion, of Sorts
Helmut Lang at Sperone Westwater
description: In time, Helmut Lang may become as forward-looking in his art as he was in his fashion design. Right now, he only looks back, content with making standard-issue Post-Minimalism derived from ideas and materials pioneered more than 40 years ago by artists like Richard Van Buren, Keith Sonnier, Lynda Benglis, Eva Hesse and Hannah Wilke. Mr. Lang has long been acquainted with contemporary art, but this work evinces an all-too-typical amnesia about the recent past and a seeming disdain for the rigors of finding your own art rather than settling for a pastiche of the achievements of others.

title: Reuben Cox: Topical Songs
description: Reuben Cox started off in the documentary mode, photographing people from social groups and subcultures: marriages at City Hall, rural transgender women, bands and fans at the club CBGB, or players at a contract-bridge world championship. In this show, he turns the camera elsewhere or discards it entirely and uses changes in photography as a metaphor for his own move cross-country, from New York to Los Angeles, and the onset of middle age.

title: Photos of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Italy, China and Pakistan.

title: Review: August Wilson on His Creative Process as a Playwright
description: August Wilson died almost 10 years now, but that doesnt stop him from giving a mini-master class Friday on  appropriately  PBSs latest episode of American Masters. In archival footage, we hear him describe his writing process.

title: White Sneakers
description: After seasons of loud, colorful trainers comes the welcome respite of quiet leather kicks.

title: Katarzyna Kozyra: Looking for Jesus
description: In Looking for Jesus, an entertaining, philosophically intriguing, 70-minute video by the Polish artist Katarzyna Kozyra, the camera follows Ms. Kozyra in Jerusalem, where she finds and interviews men who believe they are Jesus. Shes looking for people with a condition known as Jerusalem syndrome, characterized in part by delusional over-identification with characters from the Bible.

title: G.M. Names New Counsel After Wave of Recalls
description: General Motors named a new top lawyer on Thursday to succeed its embattled general counsel, Michael Millikin, who faced scathing criticism on Capitol Hill after the companys ignition switch scandal.

title: Review: Western Society, Its a Selfie World After All
description: Go ahead. Take a picture. Make a memory. Then send it out into the universe, and maybe it will turn into somebody elses memory, too. Youll be a star. Youll be an interchangeable nobody. These destinies are not mutually exclusive.

title: Canada Charges SNC-Lavalin in Fraud and Bribery Involving Qaddafi Regime
description: OTTAWA  SNC-Lavalin, the Montreal-based engineering company, and two of its units were charged on Thursday with fraud and bribery in relation to their dealings with the regime of Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan dictator.

title: Feb. 19, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Ukraine, Italy, South Korea and India.

title: Inside the Towers of Secrecy
description: For more than a year, Louise Story and Stephanie Saul, two reporters from The Timess investigations unit, worked on a series of articles about international shell companies that own some of New York Citys most expensive real estate, and the people behind them.

title: Review: In Reif Larsens I Am Radar, an Odyssey of Exploding Particles
description: I Am Radar is a big, fat, enticing-looking epic that begins with a hauntingly surreal moment. In Elizabeth, N.J., a place not known for strokes of magic, a woman named Charlene is in a hospital, giving birth to her first son. Her husband, a Serbian refugee named Kermin, is with her. But during the birth, the hospital experiences a power failure, and the frightened doctor has only a flashlight to aid him during the delivery. Even so, the doctor can tell something strange is happening. Under the pocket lights dull beam, the author, Reif Larsen, writes, the child appeared almost prehistoric.

title: Deadly CRE Germs Linked to Hard-to-Clean Medical Scopes
description: WASHINGTON  Federal officials warned health care providers across the country on Thursday that difficult-to-clean medical scopes inserted down the throat might be infecting patients with deadly drug-resistant bacteria.

title: Gees Bend Quilts in 2 Shows at Lehman College
description: Many people are familiar with the Gees Bend quilts by now. Made by generations of African-American women who were the descendants of slaves, and later sharecroppers, the quilts developed on an isolated peninsula carved out by the Alabama River southwest of Selma. Over the last decade and a half, however, the art world has discovered Gees Bend, and the quilts have been exhibited in museums nationwide. A small show at the Lehman College Art Gallery of 14 quilts by seven artists, all made since 1990, and an accompanying exhibition of photographs, offers an update.

title: Chinese New Year Returns With Bargain Meals, Music and Parades
description: Chinatown is whatever you make of it. There is the strange blend of chain restaurants and knockoff clothing outlets on Canal Street. There are the popular restaurants, like Joes Shanghai or Golden Unicorn, where an hours wait is the price of authenticity. Then there are the narrow side streets and uninviting storefronts where the real treats lie: feasts that reward the adventuresome and often cost less than an appetizer anywhere else.

title: Weekend Entertainments from the Archives of The New York Times
description: 62 YEARS AGO

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: food recommendations, varicose veins and persistent grief. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: In Corporate Crimes, Individual Accountability Is Elusive
description: We have never hesitated to investigate and prosecute any individual, institution or organization that attempted to exploit our markets and take advantage of the American people, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. proclaimed this month when the Justice Department announced that Standard & Poors, the ratings agency, had agreed to pay $1.375 billion to settle civil charges that it inflated ratings on mortgage-backed securities at the heart of the financial crisis.

title: Review: Kehinde Wiley: A New Republic at the Brooklyn Museum
description: You can love or hate Kehinde Wileys bright, brash, history-laden, kitsch-tinged portraits of confident, even imperious young black men and women. But it is hard to ignore them, especially right now, with scores of them bristling forth from Kehinde Wiley: A New Republic, the artists mind-teasing, eye-catching survey at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Before Oscar Night, Playing the Odds With a Bettors Mind-Set
description: The Academy Awards ceremony will emphasize the suspense of the unknown on Sunday night. But Hollywood insiders are well aware that many nominees have little chance of winning  and know who those nominees are.

title: World Music Institute, a Tour for the Ears and Hips
description: STANDING inside a large ring of amateur dancers in front of a stage cluttered anticipatorily with brass instruments and conga drums, Chris Rogicki demonstrated Cuban salsa moves that could have been mistaken for dating strategies.

title: Fall/Winter 2015s Golden Girls
description: Throughout New York Fashion Week, which comes to a close today, and just in time for this Sundays 87th Academy Awards, designers have presented red-carpet gowns befitting the most smoldering of starlets. A selection of gold looks, reminiscent of the Oscar itself, appeared first at Donna Karan, then at Michael Kors and today at Ralph Lauren. And on each runway, the sparkling gowns were one-of-a-kind showstoppers.

title: American Sniper, the Peoples Choice for Best Picture
description: The public has a clear favorite heading into the Academy Awards on Sunday night: American Sniper.

title: Egypts Crisis Across the Border With Libya
description: Egyptian armed forces on Monday carried out a predawn airstrike in Libya in response to the beheading of as many as 21 Egyptian Coptic Christians by the Islamic State, the extremist group also known as ISIS or ISIL. The Egyptians attacked camps, training facilities and weapons depots belonging to the group near the Libyan town of Derna, a militant stronghold.

title: Assembling Micro-apartments
description: Tiny prefabricated apartments are assembled at the Brooklyn Navy Yard for use in My Micro NY, New York, a building to rise at East 27th Street in Manhattan.

title: New York Fashion Week: Calvin Klein Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: New York Fashion Week: Calvin Klein Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Fraternity Sues Wesleyan University Over Order to Admit Women
description: Almost five months after fraternities at Wesleyan University in Connecticut were ordered to admit women as both members and residents, one organization announced on Thursday that it was suing the university, saying the policy put in place in the name of equality was, in fact, discriminatory.

title: Obama Designates Monument in Chicago and Backs Its Mayor, Rahm Emanuel
description: CHICAGO  President Obama on Thursday offered a hearty White House embrace to his friend and former chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, who is running for re-election as mayor here and faces voters next week.

title: A Twist on a Very French Chignon for J. Mendel
description: She is that French Vogue 70s woman, explained the hairstylist James Pecis backstage, of his beauty inspiration for J. Mendels fall/winter 2015 show. Back then there was a reoccurrence of this type of look  all the girls were side parting and rolling their hair back. So for todays runway, he updated the classic chignon to complement the designers ultra-feminine collection. After parting the hair to the left, he divided it into several sections, saturating each one with Phyto Professional Wet Gel for a smooth, sleek texture. Pecis then used a blowdryer to add volume to the front of the hair before pulling it all into two ponytails, which he twisted together, pinning them up into a sleek, smooth variation on the elegant chignon. The effect: trs magnifique.

title: Review: In Brittens The Rape of Lucretia, a Savage Act With Resonance Today
description: Juilliard Operas production of Brittens The Rape of Lucretia has arrived at a time when disturbing reports about sexual assault on college campuses have been in the news. In a program note, the director Mary Birnbaum, says she and her cast drew a clear parallel between college rape culture and this harrowing Britten chamber opera, with a libretto by Ronald Duncan, first performed in 1946.

title: Oscars 2015: The Carpetbaggers Predictions
description: Get your Oscar ballot ready. Here are the Baggers coin tosses and sure things and likely winners:

title: Obama Makes Pullman a National Monument
description: President Obama designated the Pullman District in Chicago a national monument and spoke about the history of the area, which helped create a new American middle class.

title: Off the Runway
description: Scenes from the last day of New York Fashion Week.

title: Review: In The Jack and Triumph Show, a Mamas Boy Faces Temptation
description: Lets begin with a hat-tip to June Squibb, an Oscar-nominated actress, for being willing to play third fiddle to an undereducated man-boy and a vituperative dog puppet. Thats what she does in Adult Swims irreverent new comedy, The Jack and Triumph Show, which begins Friday night. The show is hilarious with a capital If: Its hilarious If you like Triumph the Insult Comic Dog.

title: Review: Legends & Visionaries by New York Theater Ballet
description: For a small company that seemed near to closing not long ago, New York Theater Ballet is looking almost indecently healthy. I went to its Legends & Visionaries program at New York Live Arts this week hoping to enjoy maybe two of the four works; I left not only having enjoyed three or four (I will explain this ambiguity) but also with affectionate admiration for the dancers. Never before in my experience of this troupe have its performers made so engaging and memorable an impression.

title: Exclusive | 1045 Fifth Avenue
description: A 10-room penthouse on the 14th and 15th floors is poised to enter the market for the first time ever.

title: Denim, Remixed
description: These crisp trousers, flowy topcoats and fitted blazers make us see indigo in a whole new hue.

title: This Weeks Movies | Feb. 20, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review Hot Tub Time Machine 2, McFarland USA and Wild Tales.

title: Ondria Hardin Transforms at Marc Jacobs
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Ondria Hardin before (left) and after (right) makeup by Francois Nars, hair by Guido Palau.

title: The Shame of Solitary Confinement
description: Last year, Dave Maass, an investigative researcher for the Electronic Frontier Foundation, found a document on the website of the South Carolina Department of Corrections that listed nearly 400 inmates in the states prisons who had broken a rule against posting on social-media sites. Prisons often bar inmates from Facebook, Twitter and other sites, citing a concern that they could use social media to plan contraband drops or intimidate witnesses  and also because their presence online is evidence that theyre using contraband cellphones, since prisoners generally lack Internet access through other means.

title: Theater Listings for Feb. 20-26
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: N.F.L. Suspends Use of Helmet Sensors
description: The N.F.L. will not use sensors in players helmets next season to measure head hits, ending  at least temporarily  one effort to gain a better understanding of concussions.

title: Comedy Listings for Feb. 20-26
description: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Malaria in Widening Area Resists Drug, Study Finds
description: BANGKOK  The worlds best drug for treating malaria, a medicine that is the key to saving millions of lives in Africa and beyond, is losing its efficacy in a much larger swath of territory than was previously known, according to research that was released Friday.

title: At New York Fashion Week, the Last LooksAre Diverse
description: New York Fashion Week drew to a close in an odd and fractured state: decentralized and unfocused.

title: Review: Hot Tub Time Machine 2 Heads Back to the Bubbles
description: Who knows what the world will look like in 2025? The goofballs from the smart-dumb 2010 guy comedy Hot Tub Time Machine are accidentally given an advance peek in the frenzied, chaotic sequel. As could have been predicted, Hot Tub Time Machine 2 is vastly inferior to the first Hot Tub, but its not stupid so much as desperately frantic.

title: Movie Listings for Feb. 20-26
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Movie Review: Hot Tub Time Machine 2
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Hot Tub Time Machine 2.

title: Allianz Global Investors Chief Helps to Fix Britains Troubled Financial Markets
description: LONDON  As the chief executive of Allianz Global Investors, one of Europes biggest money managers, Elizabeth Corley is familiar with suspense.

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for Feb. 20-26
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Review: McFarland, USA
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews McFarland, USA.

title: Critics in G.O.P. Say Chris Christie Is in a Bubble
description: He does not return phone calls. He does not ask for support. He arrives late for meetings. And he acts as if he has all the time in the world.

title: Jazz Listings for Feb. 20-26
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Review: In McFarland, USA, Kevin Costner Coaches Cross-Country Runners
description: An entirely predictable, mostly honorable movie, McFarland, USA tells the story of a washed-up coach who turns a bunch of misfits into a team of champions. Its Hoosiers, more or less, relocated to a poor agricultural town in Californias Central Valley in 1987. The sport is not basketball, football or baseball  the usual athletic pursuits in this genre  but cross-country running. The director, Niki Caro, who is originally from New Zealand and whose earlier films include Whale Rider and North Country, has an eye for dramatic landscapes, which lends some visual grandeur to the training and racing scenes.

title: Researcher Discovers Superfish Spyware Installed on Lenovo PCs
description: Lenovo, the Chinese tech giant, was shipping PCs with spyware that tracks its customers every move online, and renders the computers vulnerable to hackers.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Feb. 20-26
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for Feb. 20-26
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Tech Investors Create a Billion-Dollar-Baby Boom
description: What a difference a year makes.

title: MSNBC Removes Two Hosts to Focus on Straight News
description: Facing weak ratings for its afternoon shows, MSNBC is shaking up its daytime schedule to focus on straight news coverage. The cable news network said on Thursday that it was canceling its 1 p.m. broadcast hosted by Ronan Farrow, as well as its 2 p.m. broadcast hosted by Joy-Ann Reid. In their place will be a two-hour block of news with Thomas Roberts, host of MSNBCs Way Too Early at 5:30 a.m. Ms. Reid will work as a national correspondent, and Mr. Farrow, the 27-year-old son of Mia Farrow and Woody Allen, will work on a series of prime time specials and interviews. The change is a strategy shift at MSNBC, which long has filled its schedule with left-leaning political commentary and now is moving toward straight news from 9 a.m. until 3 p.m.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Feb. 20-26
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for Children for Feb. 20-26
description: Can Do Duck: The Musical

title: In the Studio | J.W. Anderson
description: Jonathan Anderson chats with Vanessa Friedman about the evolution of his small fashion label while balancing his new position as creative director at Loewe, the Spanish luxury brand.

title: Movie Review: Wild Tales
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Wild Tales.

title: Spare Times Listings for Feb. 20-26
description: Around Town

title: The Times Company Announces Board Nominees With Web Credentials
description: The New York Times Company announced two new nominees for its board, Dara Khosrowshahi, the chief executive of Expedia, and Rebecca Van Dyck, a Facebook executive, on Thursday.

title: Long-Term Care Insurance: Costs Are Up but Vary Widely
description: Rates for long-term care insurance, which can help pay for care in your own house or in a nursing home, rose this year an average of nearly 9 percent, a new industry report finds.

title: Marc Jacobs: Fall 2015 RTW
description: New York

title: Howard University Fills in Wikipedias Gaps in Black History
description: WASHINGTON  Wikipedia is a vast ocean of erudition, with entries on virtually every subject, obscure to earth-shattering, and, it may seem, every human being of even vague renown. It is also, its leaders concede, very white.

title: Review: Wild Tales Explores the Blurred Limits of Morality
description: As high-spirited as its title suggests, Wild Tales opens on a savage note and ends, well, thats for you to find out. In between its shocker start and equally startling windup, this Argentine anthology offers up a scabrous, often unsettlingly funny look at human behavior in extremis. Its a mad, mad social Darwinian world, churning with men and women who, whether pushed a lot or just a little, are all eager to do the worst to one another. They pounce and then they pummel, engaging in drag-down fights that leave them black and blue and sometimes stone-cold dead.

title: For Nascar Drivers, Switching Teams Has Paid Off Before
description: When Kyle Busch was dropped by Hendrick Motorsports after 2007 and signed to race for Joe Gibbs Racing, few could have predicted what happened next. Busch went from one win with Hendrick in 2007 to eight victories with Gibbs in 2008.

title: Review: All the Wilderness, a Tale of a Teenage Outsider
description: The kind of kid whos a dinner bell for bullies, James (Kodi Smit-McPhee), the gangly antihero of All the Wilderness, wears the teenage-misfit badge on his bony frame like a romantic totem. A recent tragedy has exacerbated Jamess already ingrowing personality, and now his quirks  quoting Carl Sandburg; drawing pictures of dead houseflies  have acquired a morbid cast that neither his therapist (Danny DeVito) nor his concerned single mother (Virginia Madsen) can pierce.

title: In Turkey, Even Snow Can Be Tainted by Politics
description: ISTANBUL  You are free to throw snowballs at this window, the signs say in the Kadikoy district on the Asian side of Istanbul, and not because the shopkeepers here love the sound of breaking glass.

title: Review: In Approaching the Elephant, an Experimental Classroom Jungle
description: In Approaching the Elephant, the director Amanda Rose Wilder embeds herself in a tiny New Jersey free school that practices a style of self-directed learning, an idea originated by anarchists in Barcelona in the 1900s. Her film invites questions about what makes good schooling, or a strong documentary, but she seems most enamored by what children do, period.

title: Review: In The DUFF, a Wounded Teenage Girl Combats Mockery
description: Adapted from a novel by Kody Keplinger, whose website says that she wrote the book as a senior in high school, The DUFF begins, in an apparent nod to The Breakfast Club, by informing us that teenage stereotypes have changed: Jocks play video games, princesses are on antidepressants. You could have fooled these characters, who ruthlessly enforce the traditional pecking order.

title: Moves Dont Get Knicks and Nets Too Far
description: It was one of the wildest N.B.A. trade deadline days in recent memory, with 11 transactions taking place across the league before the 3 p.m. cutoff time, and both New York teams had a small hand in it.

title: Iraqi Assault to Retake Mosul From Islamic State Is Planned for Spring
description: WASHINGTON  The assault to retake Mosul, Iraq, from the Islamic State will require 20,000 to 25,000 Iraqi and Kurdish troops and is expected to begin in April or May, an official from the United States Central Command told reporters on Thursday.

title: Review: Kung Fu Elliot Documentary Follows a Martial Arts Enthusiast
description: Matthew Bauckman and Jaret Belliveaus gritty documentary, Kung Fu Elliot, feels at first as if its gently parodying a making of movie. Its subject, Elliot Scott, is a quirky, sweet-faced martial arts enthusiast and filmmaker from Nova Scotia who hopes to become, he says, Canadas first action hero. Hey, everyone needs a hobby.

title: Hillary Clinton and Inevitability: This Time Is Different
description: Whenever I mention that Hillary Clinton is an overwhelming favorite for the Democratic nomination  and would be even if Senator Elizabeth Warren ran  the conversation usually comes back to 2008. She was supposed to be inevitable last time, the refrain goes, and she lost.

title: Addressing Dysfunction, Port Authority Plans to Install Nonpolitical C.E.O.
description: For decades, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has been a house divided, an agency overseen by people who owed loyalty to one governor or another. The internal division often devolved into dysfunction and has occasionally led to misfeasance, such as the move in 2013 to close some traffic lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge.

title: Utilities Push Into Fuel Stations for Electric Cars
description: Since hitting the mass market about five years ago, electric vehicles have failed to take off, largely, experts say, because a robust network of public charging stations has not been built.

title: India Deploys Expert Teams to Study Rise in Flu Cases
description: JAIPUR, India  Indian officials this week scrambled to cope with a rise in cases of the flu, which they say has sickened thousands of people and caused the deaths of 700 since the beginning of January.

title: N.F.L. Teams With Eye to Future Train a Lens on Marcus Mariota
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Inside a luxurious lounge that had been transformed into an area filled with cameras, laptops and seemingly endless ropes of cable cords at Lucas Oil Stadium, Marcus Mariota faced a line of questioning that ended with his being asked whether he possessed the skills to succeed in the N.F.L.

title: Giuliani: Obama Had a White Mother, So Im Not a Racist
description: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York on Thursday defended his assertion that President Obama did not love America, and said that his criticism of Mr. Obamas upbringing should not be considered racist because the president was raised by a white mother.

title: Turkey: Deal Set to Aid Syrian Rebels
description: After months of talks, Turkey and the United States on Thursday signed an agreement to train and equip moderate Syrian rebels to fight militants from the Islamic State, Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu said, according to the Anadolu News Agency. Mr. Cavusoglu also suggested that the fighters could join the rebellion against the Syrian government, although American officials have emphasized that the primary goal is to combat the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL. Turkey, along with Jordan and Saudi Arabia, will provide training sites for the program, which is scheduled to begin in March and is expected to train about 15,000 fighters over three years, Turkish and American officials have said. The United States has said that it plans to send about 400 soldiers and other military personnel to train the fighters.

title: Ideology Seen as Factor in Closings in University of North Carolina System
description: An advisory panel of the University of North Carolinas Board of Governors has recommended closing three academic centers, including a poverty center and one dedicated to social change, inciting outrage among liberals who believe that conservatives in control of state government are targeting ideological opponents in academia.

title: After Shake-Up Last Year, Sanofi Names New Chief
description: The French pharmaceutical giant Sanofi on Thursday named Olivier Brandicourt, a top executive at Bayer, as its new chief executive, replacing Christopher A. Viehbacher, who was fired in October.

title: F.B.I. Chief Not Invited to Meeting on Countering Violent Extremism
description: WASHINGTON  The White House did not invite the most senior American official charged with preventing terrorist attacks  the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey  to the three-day conference this week on countering violent extremism in the United States and abroad because the administration did not want the event too focused on law enforcement issues, according to senior American officials.

title: Yann Demange, Director of 71, Poised for Cinematic Breakout
description: PARK CITY, UTAH  By his own admission, the director Yann Demange has a fetish for darkness. Night photography, urban decay, ghostly sodium lighting  he incorporated it all into his debut feature, 71, set in that tumultuous year in Belfast during the Troubles, as the conflict in Northern Ireland was known.

title: Mayor de Blasios Traffic Law Vilifies Bus Drivers, Union Says
description: A new law penalizing drivers who fail to yield and injure or kill a pedestrian who has the right of way is a central piece of Mayor Bill de Blasios plan to eliminate traffic deaths. But the arrest last week of a bus driver who struck a 15-year-old girl angered union officials, who sent a memo to members this week warning that bus drivers were under attack and were being treated like criminals.

title: The Man Who Knows Too Much
description: LOS ANGELES  The first mistake, ordering tickets a day in advance, left 24 hours for the second: telling anyone in this town youre seeing The Judge.

title: New Details Revealed in Shooting by Police in Washington State
description: New details emerged Thursday about the fatal police shooting of a man in Pasco, Wash., that was captured on video and has resulted in local and federal investigations.

title: In the Land of the Head Hunters, a Recreated Artifact of Ancient Ways
description: In the Land of the Head Hunters, out on Blu-ray and DVD from Milestone, is the reconstruction of a reconstruction. It preserves an artifact that used a once advanced technology to document a no longer extent way of life, and was itself all but lost to history.

title: Apple Is Forming an Auto Team
description: SAN FRANCISCO  While Apple has been preparing to release its first wearable computers, the company has also been busy assembling a team to work on an automobile.

title: Awarded Stolen Wages, Workers Struggle to Collect
description: After due consideration of records and testimony, the State of New York found that Marco Lino, who chopped vegetables and mopped floors and hoisted crates six days a week in a Bayside, Queens, greenmarket, was owed $51,025.20 in unpaid wages. For Gregoria Geronomina Jimenez and 34 other workers at three restaurants in Upper Manhattan run by the same owners, the Industrial Board of Appeals ruled that $385,364.34 in earnings had not been paid over four years. Jin Ming Cao, a waiter at a Chinese restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, was underpaid by $142,812.05, part of $1.8 million that a federal judge decided was due to 26 employees of that restaurant and two others run by the same people.

title: N.J.I.T. Will Get an Arena, but It Still Needs a Home
description: For a man who was dealing with no heat upstairs and frozen pipes in his basement at home, Lenny Kaplan was remarkably upbeat on Thursday.

title: Rogers Cousin
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Its not often that a constructor expresses his regrets so clearly in a crossword puzzle, but today we need to lend some support to David Woolf, who is rethinking his avocation of choice.

title: New York City and State Officials Joining Forces to Combat Tenant Harassment
description: With tenant harassment complaints against landlords on the rise, New York City and state officials announced on Thursday the creation of a multiagency task force aimed at weeding out and punishing bad landlords.

title: Jerome Kersey, Stalwart of Top Trail Blazers Teams, Dies at 52
description: Jerome Kersey, a hard-working forward from a small college who overachieved in pro basketball, starting on two Portland Trail Blazers teams that reached the N.B.A. finals, died on Wednesday in Tualatin, Ore., near Portland. He was 52.

title: In Hearing, Judge Revisits a 1990 Killing on a Subway Platform
description: The victim was a tourist from Utah, and his murder on a Manhattan subway platform seized the city in a way that few killings of the era did. Now, almost 25 years after the man, Brian Watkins, was stabbed to death, the case is back in State Supreme Court.

title: Owner of the Colts Pays Six Figures for a Les Paul Six-String
description: The owner and chief executive of the Indianapolis Colts  who has a collection of guitars that were played by the likes of Bob Dylan, Jerry Garcia and Elvis Presley  added another on Thursday night, a 60-year-old electric guitar that some musicians say occupies an important place in guitar history.

title: Never an Islander, Eric Nystrom Returns Home to Nassau Coliseum
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Skating at Nassau Coliseum without igniting a flood of memories is most likely impossible for the Long Island native Eric Nystrom of the Nashville Predators, the N.H.L.s best team.

title: Plaques, Yes. Pennants, No.
description: A busy year at Monument Park once meant adding one or two plaques to its walls. And every so often, a Yankee uniform number would be retired.

title: F.D.A. Reverses Course on 23andMe DNA Test in Move to Ease Restrictions
description: The genetic testing company 23andMe on Thursday took a step toward being able to offer consumers health-related information again, winning approval from the Food and Drug Administration for a test for mutations that cause a rare disease.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 19, 2015
Driver Faces Life Sentence in Crash That Killed Expectant Brooklyn Couple
description: A man accused of plowing his car into a livery cab carrying a pregnant Orthodox woman and her husband, killing the Brooklyn couple and their newborn son, was convicted Thursday of second-degree manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide, prosecutors said.

title: Harris Wittels, Television Comedy Writer, Is Dead at 30
description: Harris Wittels, a producer and writer for the NBC sitcom Parks and Recreation who also performed as a stand-up comic and musician, died on Thursday. He was 30.

title: Rangers, Again Prolific Late in Game, Are Beaten at Their Own Game
description: The Rangers were unbeaten on a four-game trip, scoring 11 third-period goals, including three in a come-from-behind 6-5 win over the Islanders on Monday.

title: Illinois: Cubs Allowed to Continue Renovations
description: The Chicago Cubs can proceed with a construction project at Wrigley Field, a federal judge ruled Thursday, but the projects future remains uncertain as a lawsuit continues by property owners who say the renovations will block their views of the stadium. Owners of properties across the street from the outfield have long sold tickets to spectators who watch from their rooftops. Some owners have argued in federal court that a renovation project underway at the stadium, which includes large signs that would be placed in the outfield, violates a contract between them and the team. Judge Virginia M. Kendall of United States District Court in Chicago said Thursday that she did not have the evidence needed for a temporary restraining order to stop construction, as the rooftop owners requested. Both sides will be back in court next month for a hearing on a preliminary injunction that could derail the renovations. Weve got Opening Day on April 5, Judge Kendall said. Im going to get my job done before then.

title: Big Hello for the Year of the Yang
description: The Hung Sing Kwoon Kung Fu and Lion Dance Club stopped at Jade Asian Restaurant in Flushing, Queens, on Thursday to celebrate the Chinese Lunar New Year, symbolized this year by a zodiac animal whose Mandarin name, yang, is translated into English variously as sheep, goat or ram.

title: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Are Suspended Through Saturday
description: Because of snow cleanup, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday and Saturday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Jimmy Kimmel: The Artist That Never Was
description: In this new series for T, notables from the worlds of fashion, art, design and entertainment illustrate their responses to a brief questionnaire, revealing their favorite things, darkest secrets  and how they see themselves and the world around them.

title: The Art and Allure of Marc Jacobss Dramatic Stage Sets
description: New Yorks fall/winter 2015 Fashion Week went out on a high note, as per usual, with Marc Jacobss presentation at the Park Avenue Armory last night. As big a draw as the clothes (a darkly opulent ode to Diana Vreeland) and the people-watching (Nicki Minaj and Deborah Harry sat front-row) was the set: a Stefan Beckman-designed backdrop inspired by Jeremiah Goodman paintings of Vreelands famous red room, the latest in a series of immersive  and sometimes provocative  installations. Here, a look back at some of the brands other memorable set designs.

title: Word of the Day | clout
description: clout  \klaut\  noun and verb

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 8 A.M. (CUNY) A TIMESTALKS CONVERSATION: DAVID CARR INTERVIEWS LAURA POITRAS, GLENN GREENWALD AND EDWARD J. SNOWDEN On Feb. 12 Mr. Carr, who wrote about media for The New York Times, sat down at the New School with Ms. Poitras, the Oscar-nominated director of the documentary Citizenfour, about Mr. Snowden, the National Security Agency whistle-blower; Mr. Greenwald, the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist who first wrote about Mr. Snowdens revelations; and Mr. Snowden himself, who joined the discussion via a video link from Russia. Mr. Carr died later that night. (Repeats at 4 and 9 p.m.) In Science Goes to the Movies, a new series at 7:30 p.m., Faith Salie, an NPR host, and Heather Berlin, a neuroscientist, dissect the science portrayed in some current films, starting with hallucinations in Birdman, black holes and gravity in Interstellar and the work of the theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking in The Theory of Everything. Emily Rice, an astrophysicist with the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History, weighs in.

title: Slowly Learning to Fill Big Shoes
description: Bol Bol, Manute Bols 15-year-old son, carries high expectations as he begins to navigate high school basketball in suburban Kansas.

title: Corrections: February 20, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: If I talk to him for an hour, they undo him in two hours.

title: Girls, Math and Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Remaining Days
description: To the Editor:

title: Guns on Campus?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Plot to Kill Health Care
description: Republicans hate activist judges  those black-robed elites who are willing to upset the lives of millions of people just to further a political cause. Ditto trial lawyers trolling for clients, the ambulance-chasing, Better Call Saul guys. They hate them, until they need them.

title: Cranking Up for 2016
description: Scott Walker, the governor of Wisconsin, is said to be a rising contender for the Republican presidential nomination. So, on Wednesday, he did what, these days, any ambitious Republican must, and pledged allegiance to charlatans and cranks.

title: Helping to Heal the Trauma of War
Separate Philanthropy From Political Clout
description: The Clinton Foundation has become one of the worlds major generators of charity, mobilizing global efforts to confront issues like health, climate change, economic development and equality for women and girls.

title: In Boston, 50 Shades of White Snow
description: BROOKLINE, Mass.  THE first snow day was perfect. My husband and I lay in bed in January and watched the falling snow cover trash cans and quince bushes and pine trees alike, a democratizing force on the landscape. Downstairs, our three kids watched cartoons (or pretty much whatever they wanted) and raided the usually off-limits snack shelf.

title: When Americans Lynched Mexicans
description: THE recent release of a landmark report on the history of lynching in the United States is a welcome contribution to the struggle over American collective memory. Few groups have suffered more systematic mistreatment, abuse and murder than African-Americans, the focus of the report.

title: Indonesias Corruption Fighters in the Fight of Their Lives
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Over the past decade, Indonesia was so determined to erase the tainted legacy of Suharto, the strongman forced to resign in 1998, that it established one of the worlds more effective anticorruption agencies. Now the future of that agency, the Corruption Eradication Commission, known as the K.P.K., is under serious threat in a standoff with the police and President Joko Widodo.

title: Bostons Winter From Hell
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  BY now youve seen the starkly beautiful shots of Boston buried under snow: the panoramic city under a white blanket; snowbanks so high they crest over parked cars; piercing icicles glinting for two full stories from gutters dammed with ice; coat-muffled people dwarfed by snow-walled corridors that once were sidewalks.

title: Empathy, not Expulsion, for Preschoolers at Risk
description: CHICAGO  A few years ago, a boy here was on the verge of being expelled because his teacher felt he was a danger to his classmates.

title: The Nationalist Solution
description: The struggle against Islamic extremism has been crippled by a failure of historical awareness and cultural understanding. From the very beginning, we have treated the problem of terrorism through the prism of our own assumptions and our own values. We have solipsistically assumed that people turn to extremism because they cant get what we want, and fail to realize that they dont want what we want, but want something they think is higher.

title: Test Yourself | An Apology Letter From Alex Rodriguez
description: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 17 article, Exchanging Sword for Pen, Rodriguez Apologizes to Yankees and Fans.

title: Man Group to Buy London-Based Investment Manager
description: LONDON  The British hedge fund company Man Group continued its recent spending spree on Friday, reaching a conditional agreement to acquire the investment management business of NewSmith. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: 6 Qs About the News | The Year of the Goat
description: To mark the beginning of the Year of the Goat (or is it the sheep?), we pose questions that link to a variety of Times articles from the past and present, as well as to outside resources. Use this collection to teach students about the holiday and its cultural significance and traditions.

title: Is the Minimum Wage Too Low?
description: About half of all workers in the United States who are at or below the federal minimum wage of $7.25 an hour are ages 16 to 24. Would a higher minimum wage help young people get ahead? Would it help lift families out of poverty? Or would it unintentionally have the opposite effect by dampening hiring? Economists disagree about the effects of a higher minimum wage. What do you think?

title: Children, Caged for Effect, to Mimic Imagery of ISIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The killings have been both deliberately lurid and strangely intimate. Designed for broadcast, they have helped the Islamic State militant group build a brand of violence that shocks with its extreme brutality, yet feels as close to viewers as the family images on their smartphones.

title: At New York Private Schools, Challenging White Privilege From the Inside
description: On a recent morning, 20 or so high school students, most of them white, milled about the meetinghouse at Friends Seminary, a private school in Manhattan. They were trying to unload on their classmates slips of paper on which they had jotted down words related to the topic Things I dont want to be called.

title: Mariam Ghani, a Brooklyn Artist Whose Father Leads Afghanistan
description: Mariam Ghanis apartment is a map to her layered identity.

title: Looking Back With Intensity
description: Shalmon Bernstein arrived in the New York magazine world in the early 1970s with a fully developed eye, a clear, sober voice and a sense of purpose. I thought in terms of being able to change peoples perceptions, he said. Then, a decade later, he simply stopped, for reasons that even now are hard for him to explain. What made me stop? he asked the other day from his home in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. What was more important to me? Money was a part of it, he said. But looking back now, he saw another force at work.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Feb. 20
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from Chinese New Year and Niagara Falls.

title: Internet Taxes, Another Window Into the Net Neutrality Debate
description: In a rare act of bipartisan unity, Republican and Democratic senators last week presented legislation that would permanently ban taxes on high-speed Internet service to American homes.

title: Punch Lines and Laughs as TV Show in Vietnam Mocks Government Policy
description: HANOI, Vietnam  The Kitchen Gods were asked by the emperors assistant: What curves gently?

title: J. W. Anderson: Clear Desks, Full Days
description: In episode two of our In the Studio series, we go inside the workspace of Jonathan Anderson, the 30-year-old British designer behind J. W. Anderson, to discuss the need for efficiency, the difference an LVMH investment makes and the problem with desks (among other burning questions that did not make the final cut). This conversation has been condensed and edited.

title: Eurozone Economy Gains Momentum, Survey of Private Sector Shows
description: PARIS  The eurozone economy perked up again this month, a private sector report showed on Friday, powered by continuing strength in Germany and surprisingly strong growth in France.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Student Crossword | Virus Outbreaks
description: Test your knowledge of virus outbreaks by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: New Yorks Forecast: Rising Seas, Continual Heat Waves, and a Little Hope
description: As you went spelunking through snowdrifts in recent days, pondering the moral necessity of pet-friendly ice melt and perhaps noting in horror the story of a Manhattan woman who froze to death hiking in subzero New Hampshire temperatures over the weekend, you were thinking about the future, defined in the moment as July. City functionaries were looking further ahead to a potentially more Hunger Games epoch.

title: Fears Persist That Violence Against Albinos in Tanzania Will Grow
description: The boy was just a year old when five men with machetes snatched him from his home. Two days later, the police found his body with the arms and legs lopped off.

title: New York Today: The Lunar New Year, in Pictures
description: Good morning on this frigid Friday.

title: Daily Report: A Boom in Technology Investments in Hunt for Next Blockbuster Company
description: What a difference a year makes, Michael J. de la Merced and Mike Isaac report.

title: Raul Rodriguez, Who Showered Rose Parade With Bouquets on Wheels, Dies at 71
description: Raul Rodriguez, who designed more than 500 floral floats for the Tournament of Roses Parade and conceived dazzling confections for other private and public celebrations around the world, died on Wednesday at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 71.

title: Today in Politics
description: Giuliani Counters Criticism of Obama Comments: This Isnt Racism

title: GFI Groups Board to Support BGC Partners Takeover Bid
description: The board of the GFI Group, the New York brokerage and clearing house, threw its support on Friday behind a takeover bid by BGC Partners after shareholders rejected a tie-up with the CME Group last month.

title: Ask Well: Sick With Two Kinds of Flu?
description: Question:

title: Emerging From a Fathers 7-Foot-6 Shadow
description: ROELAND PARK, Kan.  It is not by happenstance that toy basketball hoops are scattered about the house of 15-year-old Bol Bol, or that his bedroom in the basement is home to about 40 pairs of basketball shoes. His love for the game was passed down by his father, Manute Bol, the 7-foot-6 shot blocker whose impossibly long arms and lighthouse smile made him a fan favorite for 10 N.B.A. seasons before he died in 2010.

title: With High-Profile Departure, Kerrys Team Faces a Transition
description: The departure of Jen Psaki, the State Department spokeswoman, is only part of a larger transition for Secretary of State John Kerry and his team two years into his tenure.

title: Morning Agenda: Markets Await Greek Deal
description: MARKETS AWAIT GREEK DEAL | Uncertainty over the outcome of negotiations between Greece and its European creditors made for nervous markets on Friday morning, as shares in Europe eased off seven-year highs. Germany rejected Greeces formal request on Thursday to extend its loan program by six months, with one German official describing the Athens proposal as a Trojan horse, intending to get bridge financing and in substance putting an end to the current program, according to a Greek government official. Eurozone finance ministers will try again on Friday to break an impasse over Greeces need for further financing.

title: The Unsinkable R.B.G.
description: RUTH BADER GINSBURG isnt planning on going anywhere any time soon.

title: Kevin Spacey, Star of House of Cards and a Bromance With Bill Clinton
description: Before Kevin Spacey got into character as Francis Underwood, the fictional congressman who by the third season of House of Cards has murdered and manipulated his way into the Oval Office, he liked to portray a real-life president: Bill Clinton.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Q. and A.: Barnett Rubin on Chinas Role in Afghanistan
description: In recent months, China has made pronouncements that reveal it is willing, perhaps even eager, to grow its engagement with troubled Afghanistan, whose remote Wakhan Corridor abuts Chinas western border. On Feb. 12, while visiting Pakistan, Foreign Minister Wang Yi reiterated Chinas desire to play a constructive role in a hypothetical peace process.

title: Eurozone Officials Reach Accord With Greece to Extend Bailout
description: BRUSSELS  Ending an acrimonious standoff, European leaders hashed out a deal on Friday to extend Greeces bailout by four months, giving the troubled country a financial lifeline and avoiding a bankruptcy with potentially destabilizing consequences for the region.

title: An Engineer Creates for Fun After a Lifetime of Workaday Rules
description: I dont need your rockin chair,

title: Giuliani Comments Draw Tweets From Martina Navratilova, Judd Apatow and Others
description: In the rapid-response world of social media, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York caught fire this morning. By defending his assertion that President Obama does not love America  and by arguing that his criticism of Mr. Obamas upbringing should not be considered racist because the president was raised by a white mother  he has attracted an array of commentary from prominent figures in the worlds of sports, media, movies and, of course, politics.

title: A Helping Hand (and a Forklift)
description: Dear Diary:

title: Home Shrunken Home
description: For most single New Yorkers, the tyranny of living in a small space, or worse, a shared space, is all too familiar.

title: Mystery Solved: The Man Behind a G.O.P. Trend-Setting Poll
description: The source of the extensive, private polling data on the 2016 Republican presidential field was shrouded in secrecy. But its conclusions were widely felt.

title: Citis Mexico Chief to Retire After Rough Year of Scandals
description: The chairman of Citigroups Mexico operations, Manuel Medina-Mora, is retiring in June, after a tumultuous year at one of the banks most profitable units.

title: Chip Maker to Investigate Claims of Hacking by N.S.A. and British Spy Agencies
description: LONDON  Gemalto, a French-Dutch digital security company, said on Friday that it was investigating a possible hacking by United States and British intelligence agencies that may have given them access to worldwide mobile phone communications.

title: Obama Asserts G.O.P.s Actions Fail to Match Its Words
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama ridiculed Republicans on Friday, describing them as seeking to mimic the Democratic Partys message to the middle class even as they pursue policies that enrich the wealthy.

title: Midtown Condo, Brooklyn Lab
description: In an industrial section of Sunset Park, Brooklyn, where the street ends at the waterfront, an unassuming door opens to a cold and cavernous warehouse. There, beyond a labyrinth of boxes and dark hallways, lies an unexpected piece of Midtown Manhattan: a full-scale mock-up of a $10 million apartment planned for 53W53, an ultraluxury residential tower being built next to the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Reading Restaurant Wine Lists, for Blockbusters and Values
description: THE chief executive who oversees one of the worlds most highly sought Tuscan wines was in New York this month, trying to persuade people to buy one of his less expensive brands, something that would seem counter to his interests.

title: New York Fashion Week: Marc Jacobs Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: Whats On This Week Around the World
description: Krakow, Poland

title: Muslim Scholar, Looking to Speak the Truth, Teaches the Holocaust and Islam
description: Early in the summer of 2007, a doctoral student named Mehnaz M. Afridi traveled from her California home to a conference in southern Germany. Her official role was to deliver a paper on anti-Semitism in Egyptian literature, a rather loaded subject for a Muslim scholar. Seventy miles away, she had another appointment, and an even riskier agenda.

title: How to Fill Out Your Oscar Ballot
description: We at The Upshot have entered our share of friendly Oscar pools over the years. Weve done so even in years when we have not seen many of the nominated movies. If you find yourself in that position this year  or if you have seen a lot of movies but still arent sure how to fill out your ballot  were here to help.

title: New York Fashion Week: Marc Jacobs Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: Bush or Christie in 2016? Giuliani Says He Hasnt Decided
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has made headlines this week for comments he made about President Obamas fealty to America, is uncertain about whom he will support to replace the president in 2016.

title: 1915: Dardanelles Forts Bombarded
description: LONDON  The Admiralty announces that yesterday [Feb. 19] morning a British fleet of battleships and battle cruisers accompanied by flotillas and aided by a strong French squadron, the whole under the command of Vice-Admiral Sackville Hamilton Carden, began an attack upon the forts at the entrance of the Dardanelles. The forts at Cape Helles and Kum Kale were bombarded with deliberate long-range fire. Considerable effect was produced on two of the forts, and two others were frequently hit, but, being open earthworks, it was difficult to estimate the damage. The forts, being outranged, were not able to reply to the fire.

title: Europe Needs To Stop The Clock
description: Ive been in correspondence with various people trying to track the current Greece/euro crisis, and everyone seems to have reached the same conclusion Ive reached  namely, that whats needed above all right now is some way to stop the clock, call a time-out, whatever. Were talking about weeks, maybe a month or two  but that pause is desperately needed, because otherwise it will be all too easy to stumble into a preventable disaster.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Frederique Morrel Brings French Whimsy to Bergdorf Goodman
description: My inspiration is life and all its aspects, says the designer and artist Frdrique Morrel. That may sound like a particularly broad subject matter, but Morrels work, which is craftedby covering three-dimensional objects with vintage tapestries, does have an all-encompassing approach to its pastoral aesthetic. And beginning today, her newest pieces will be on view at Bergdorf Goodmans 5th Avenue flagship store in New York the result of an exclusive partnership with the department store (We share the same values of exclusivity, rarity and the love of well done savoir-faire, she says). The shoppable exhibition (prices range from $900 to $120,000) also marks her U.S. debut.

title: London Fashion Week: J. JS Lee Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: Video Reviews of Hot Tub Time Machine 2, McFarland, USA and Wild Tales
description: In this video, Times critics share their thoughts on Hot Tub Time Machine 2, McFarland, USA and Wild Tales. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: 1940: Sweden Divided Over Aid to Finland
description: STOCKHOLM  The domestic situation in Sweden tonight [Feb. 20] was tense as the result of King Gustavs refusal to give military aid to Finland. Despite the Kings effort to keep Sweden at peace, as he has during the thirty-three years of his own reign and as it has been kept during more than a century, the undertone of discontent over official aloofness in the aggression on Finland was distinctly audible.

title: London Fashion Week: J. JS Lee Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: Chastened Exceptionalism
description: Jamelle Bouie has a very good article responding to Rudy Giulanis attack on Obamas patriotism, making the point that Obama, while clearly deeply patriotic, does talk about America a bit differently from his predecessors.

title: Britain and Europe Sleepwalked Into the Ukraine Crisis, Report Says
description: LONDON  Britain and the European Union made a catastrophic misreading of Russia and President Vladimir V. Putin and sleepwalked into the Ukraine crisis, treating it as a trade issue rather than as a delicate foreign-policy challenge, British lawmakers said Friday in a scathing report.

title: The Lively Look of Green Chorizo
description: Chorizo sausage can be many things, but I did not realize that one of them was green.

title: The Zen of Plane Crashes
description: Late in 2012, Allan Lokos, who founded the Community Meditation Center in New York, had to put his meditation and stress-management techniques to the test in a dire situation: The plane on which Mr. Lokos, his wife and 69 other passengers were traveling crashed in Myanmar.

title: U.S. Agency Sets Fines for Maker of Airbags
description: In an escalating standoff with Takata, federal regulators said on Friday that they would begin to fine the Japanese auto supplier $14,000 a day, saying it had not fully cooperated in an investigation into defective airbags.

title: Tax Error in Health Act Has Impact on 800,000
description: WASHINGTON  About 800,000 taxpayers who enrolled in insurance policies through HealthCare.gov received erroneous tax information from the government and were urged on Friday to hold off on filing tax returns until the error could be corrected.

title: Snow Blankets Holy Sites in Jerusalem
description: A heavy snowstorm blanketed the city with a rare layer of white, covering landmarks with several inches of snow.

title: Mayors Arrest on Sedition Charges Deepens Sense of Crisis in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The abrupt arrest of the mayor of Caracas on accusations that he had plotted an American-backed overthrow of the government threatened to plunge Venezuela into new political convulsions on Friday, as his supporters rallied in the capital and pockets of protest erupted elsewhere.

title: New York in a Deep Freeze as Frigid Air Descends on the Nation
description: From frosty orange groves in Florida to the frozen waters of Niagara Falls, nearly half the nation was plunged into a deep freeze on Friday morning.

title: How a Friendship Built in Europe Turned Fatal in Queens
description: For William Klinger, Queens was the dream. There, life would be free of the frustrations he had known in Italy, where a stalled academic career had left him working in a highway tollbooth.

title: A Second Chance to Avoid a Second Tax Penalty Over Obamacare
description: About six million people face a tax penalty this year for failing to sign up for health insurance last year. Now, many of those people will get an extra chance to enroll in coverage for this year and avoid a second penalty.

title: Eavesdropping on the Seventh Grade Instagram Show
description: I may be a little too interested in my seventh graders Instagram account. Its a peephole into the social lives of her classmates. Its a juicy new reality show: The Private Lives of Private School Pubescents. Until it all turned sour, my daughter and I would snuggle up around the iPhone and watch what we called The Instagram Show, starring the boys and girls weve known since kindergarten.

title: Khirbet Khizeh, by S. Yizhar
description: Nearly 70 years ago, an intelligence officer with the newly formed state of Israel moved with a group of soldiers into a Palestinian village whose women, children and old people were rounded up, herded into trucks and sent across the border. The village was demolished to make way for the new Jewish state. The deportation was a small piece of the Palestinian exodus  some of it at gunpoint, some of it not  that accompanied the upheavals of the birth of Israel in 1947 and 1948.

title: Scouting Teams Biggest Holes as N.F.L. Combine Begins
description: The N.F.L.s scouting combine moves to on-field drills Friday, and as with every other year, an event where no football is played will heavily influence draft decisions based on various measurements that may not translate to on-field success. The 40-yard dash in particular has a tendency to send some prospects soaring and others reeling. For every Kyle Boller who runs his way into being a first-round pick, there are players like NaVorro Bowman who see their stock tumble when their feet prove a bit slow.

title: What If We Lost the Sky?
description: What is the sky worth?

title: Bombing in Somalia Capital Kills at Least 10 People, and the Shabab Claims Responsibility
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  About 10 people were killed Friday and a dozen more wounded, including several government officials and lawmakers, when two explosions ripped through the entrance of a hotel in the Somali capital, officials said. The Shabab, an Islamist rebel group, claimed responsibility.

title: Superfandom
description: A subset of online superfans of the BBC show Sherlock, imagine unrequited love between Sherlock Holmes (Benedict Cumberbatch) and Dr. John Watson (Martin Freeman).

title: Appraising Solar Energys Value
description: New research sponsored by the Department of Energy shows that buyers are willing to pay more for homes with rooftop solar panels  a finding that may strengthen the case for factoring the value of sustainable features into home appraisals.

title: Whats Next for Jon Stewart? Blogging. Or Maybe Not.
description: Jon Stewart may not be on our televisions for much longer, but his appearance Thursday night before a packed house at Joes Pub on Employee of the Month, Catie Lazaruss long-running talk show, gives hope that hell be seen around town a bit more.

title: Seems Like Old Times for Distillers and Bourbon
description: WASHINGTON  At 80, Jimmy Russell finds his knees are not quite what they used to be. So he enjoys a comfortable chair where his admirers  millennial mixologists, their arms covered in tattoos; moneyed moms who have jettisoned their cosmopolitans for manhattans; and random professionals toting rare bottles of Wild Turkey  may approach to greet him.

title: A Thankless Task
description: A few inquiries remain unanswered. I would still be delighted to hear from: David Cesarani, Liane Dirks (on Polityka), Guido Knopp (on sources), Jrg Mllner (on the sound editing of the tapes) and Time Inc.  Bettina Stangneth, writing in the acknowledgments section of Eichmann Before Jerusalem.

title: A Tour for Introverts: Landmarks and Alone Time
description: For introverts, group travel can be a noisy, rushed, herd-mentality experience of interacting with strangers on a daily basis: a draining, not relaxing, vacation. But a new concept by Sacred Introvert Retreat Tours aims to change that this spring, with a trip to Glastonbury, England, and surrounding areas.

title: About That Giuliani Uproar: He Wasnt Even Listed to Speak
description: Rarely has a political event been so overtaken by someone who wasnt initially even invited.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: H Is for Hawk
