title: Variety: A Filmy Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  The quote from todays acrostic puzzle by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon is just what you might expect to hear from The Divine Miss M, or BETTE MIDLER.

title: London Fashion Week: Central Saint Martins Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: Battle to Retake Iraqi City Looms as Test of Obamas ISIS Strategy
description: WASHINGTON  American intelligence agencies and the Pentagon are struggling to determine how difficult it will be to retake Mosul, the Islamic States de facto capital in Iraq, as planning intensifies for a battle that is becoming a major test of the Obama administrations strategy to stop the spread of the terrorist group in the Middle East.

title: Bush Spouse Backs Jeb, but Is Wary of Family Business
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  For 20 years, Columba Bush anticipated the day she would have to answer one big question: Would she support her husband, Jeb Bush, if he decided to run for president?

title: Siblings Subversive Yet Chic Punk Mohawks
description: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

title: The Creative Commerce of Peter Lik, Landscape Photographer
description: The seller of many millions of dollars worth of prints made a calculated splash with a photograph that reportedly sold for over $6 million.

title: Peter Liks Recipe for Success: Sell Prints. Print Money.
description: Peter Lik is in awe of himself. When he describes his career as a fine-art photographer, he speaks with the satisfaction of a guy who has performed miracles, at the pace of a bystander who just caught a glimpse of Superman. The words tumble forth in self-exalting, run-on sentences, most of them laced with profanity, all of them in the sunny, chummy accent of his native Australia.

title: On Oscars Weekend, Tom Ford Draws the Starriest Front Row of the Fashion Season
description: Tom Ford staged a fashion show in Hollywood on Oscars weekend, and it turns out that, yes, everyone would show up for it.

title: J.W. Anderson: Fall 2015 RTW
description: London

title: Venezuela Mayor Is Accused of U.S.-Backed Coup Plot
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The mayor of Caracas, Antonio Ledezma, who was arrested last week by intelligence agents, has been indicted on charges of conspiracy against the Venezuelan government and plotting an American-backed coup.

title: The Star-Studded Tom Ford Fashion Show
description: Celebrities like Scarlett Johansson and Julianne Moore show up for Tom Fords show in Los Angeles..

title: With Hendrick Motorsports Dominant, Sprint Cup Is Becoming a One-Team Race
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Las Vegas bookmakers have already set the odds for the 2015 Nascar Sprint Cup championship, and the consensus is that Jimmie Johnson is the driver to beat. Kevin Harvick, last years champion, and Jeff Gordon are among the other favorites, along with the 2012 winner, Brad Keselowski.

title: U.S. Open to Slowing Troop Pullout in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Four days into his tenure as defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter arrived in Afghanistan on Saturday morning and opened up the possibility of slowing the withdrawal of the last American troops in the country to help keep the Taliban at bay.

title: Cavaliers Take Off Behind Soaring Offense
description: As the N.B.A. arrives at the stretch run of its grueling 82-game season, LeBron James and the Cleveland Cavaliers are far from the pole. In fact, if the playoffs started today, they would not even have home-court advantage. But after a blistering run in the month leading up to the All-Star break  at one point they won 12 in a row  the Cavaliers appear to have hit their stride and are gaining quickly on the rest of the Eastern Conference.

title: Veteran Helps Islanders Win and Laugh
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Johnny Boychuk brings a booming slap shot, veteran leadership and a vital bonus quality to the first-place Islanders.

title: Verbatim: Rudy Giuliani Comments Further on Obama and America
description: Former New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in an interview Friday with the New York Times.

title: An Ex-Yankee Starts Over, and May Win a Starting Job
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  This is the way it can happen in baseball. An organization signs you at age 16, a decade or more passes, and then you take a phone call from the general manager while working out in the off-season. Just like that, traded to the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Coloring Sports in Action
description: Photographs from Steve Boyles Powder Sports series, in which colored powder helps bring out the action.

title: Debating a Change of Faith Under Brutal Captivity
description: VATICAN CITY  The Islamic States beheading in August of the journalist James Foley stirred global outrage, fury and despair. But for many of his fellow Roman Catholics, Mr. Foleys death in Syria transformed him into a symbol of faith under the most brutal of conditions.

title: Photos: Six Sports and a Cloud of Dust
description: Photographing sports is as much about capturing the action as it is about presenting the athlete. These days, Im off the sidelines for many assignments, instead working in studio environments for editorial and commercial projects. Athlete portraiture is all about showing the athletes personality, strengths, weaknesses, motivation, intensity, commitment. But for the Powder Sports series, a personal project, I wanted to step away from all that.

title: People Arent Androids
description: My soon-to-be-colleague Branko Milanovic writes forcefully against the term human capital; Elizabeth Bruenig notes an especially unpleasant use of the term by reformicons trying to sell child tax credits to their conservative allies.

title: Red Carpet Poetry
description: Actors and directors recite a standout line from their films during the 2015 movie awards season.

title: For Tens of Millions, Obamacare Is Working
description: In its second year, Obamacare is proving to be a success. From Feb. 22, 2015.

title: The Bright Side of Parkinsons
description: EUGENE, Ore.  FOUR years ago, I was told I had Parkinsons disease, a condition that affects about one million Americans. The disease is relentlessly progressive; often starting with a tremor in one limb on one side of the body, it spreads. The patients muscles become more rigid, frequently leading to a stooped posture, and movements slow down and get smaller and less fluid. As the disease advances  usually over a number of years  the patient becomes more and more disabled, experiencing symptoms from constipation to sleep disorders to cognitive impairment.

title: Straight Talk for White Men
description: SUPERMARKET shoppers are more likely to buy French wine when French music is playing, and to buy German wine when they hear German music. Thats true even though only 14 percent of shoppers say they noticed the music, a study finds.

title: Uniting Europes Financial Markets
description: The leaders who created the European Union hoped that binding together their economies would increase prosperity and reduce the chance of conflict. But the union is far from complete, especially in the financial sector.

title: The G.O.P. Policy Test
description: THE economy is sluggish but improving. President Obamas approval rating is mediocre but not disastrous. Memories of Mitt Romneys unsuccessful presidential campaign are relatively fresh  not least because Romney popped up briefly to remind everyone of them. And the Republicans pondering a run for president in 2016 all seem to sense that they need do to things a little, well, differently if they expect to ultimately win.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Doug Biesecker
description: Doug Biesecker, a solar physicist, is the chief program scientist overseeing the Deep Space Climate Observatory satellite (nicknamed DSCOVR) that was launched this month.

title: Whose Great Outdoors?
description: Readers respond to a Sunday Review article, Leaving Only Footsteps? Think Again.

title: In Big Media Town, Core Beat in Flux
description: AS Dean Baquet sees it, there are some coverage areas at which The Times simply must excel.

title: Hillary, Jeb and $$$$$$
description: LAST week began with the comedy extravaganza of the Saturday Night Live reunion, but not one of its sketches or jokes was half as funny as four words three days later by Jeb Bush.

title: Mountaineerings Greatest Climb Unravels
description: ESTES PARK, Colo.  THE greatest climb in the history of alpinism, a story of mythological proportions, occurred on Jan. 31, 1959. Cerro Torre, a 10,262-foot spire of granite, rises from the Southern Patagonia Ice Cap like a sharpened spear, so steep that climbing it had long been deemed impossible.

title: Dont Give Up the Gains in Education
description: Congress made the right decision a decade ago when it required states to administer yearly tests to public school students  and improve instruction for poor and minority students  in return for federal education aid.

title: Campus Life and Guns
description: The gun lobby is flirting with self-parody as it exploits the issue of sexual assaults on college campuses by proposing a solution of  what else?  having students carry guns. Experts who study the complicated issue of predatory behavior and advise colleges point out that rapes often begin in social situations. It would be nearly impossible to run for a gun, said John Foubert, the national president of One in Four, a rape-prevention organization.

title: Jeb Bushs Brainless Trust
description: WASHINGTON  I had been keeping an open mind on Jeb Bush.

title: Beware the Beagle
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md.  A BEAGLE, Miss P, was the surprise winner of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday. What a perfect name for a beagle! Our beagle was Sasha, but we could have called her Miss Pee, because the only solution to our decade-plus struggle to housetrain her was to take away all the rugs.

title: Establishment Republicans Question Scott Walkers Handling of Giuliani Comments
description: While former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York has been criticized for remarks he made at a small dinner event in Manhattan about President Obama and his love for America, establishment Republicans also have questioned the reaction of the person being honored at that reception, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, who is a likely Republican presidential contender in 2016.

title: Deeper Ties to Corporate Cash for Doubtful Climate Researcher
description: For years, politicians wanting to block legislation on climate change have bolstered their arguments by pointing to the work of a handful of scientists who claim that greenhouse gases pose little risk to humanity.

title: Please Dont Thank Me for My Service
description: HUNTER GARTH was in a gunfight for his life  and about to lose.

title: Eovaldis Untapped Potential Has the Yankees Dreaming of Big Things
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When pitchers and catchers reported for spring training Friday, there were questions about the frayed right elbow of Masahiro Tanaka, the surgically repaired right knee of C. C. Sabathia and the expected return of Ivan Nova from elbow surgery by June. Then there is the frailty of Michael Pineda, who has been a revelation when he has not been on the disabled list, which is almost constantly.

title: A Deal That Preserves Greeces Place in Eurozone, and Fiscal Restraints
description: BRUSSELS  Just a month ago, after being propelled to power by a wave of anger at Greeces economic miseries, Alexis Tsipras declared his left-wing Syriza partys election victory the start of a Europe-wide revolt against austerity. Europe is going to change, he said before setting off on a tour of European capitals to rally support for a more relaxed new direction.

title: An Ex-Coachs Spirited Ascent of a 140-Character Soapbox
description: After winning 648 games as a Division I coach, Tom Penders now retreats to a winter home in Miami during college basketball season.

title: London Fashion Week: 1205 Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: London Fashion Week: 1205 Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: Simone Rocha: Fall 2015 RTW
description: London

title: Concern in Britain as Schoolgirls Seek to Join Islamic State
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said Saturday that the countrys authorities would do everything they could to help three British schoolgirls who were believed to be traveling to Syria to join the Islamic State militant group.

title: Disclosures of Battle Plan by Pentagon Startle Many
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has been eager to show momentum against the Islamic State after a conference last week dramatized the hurdles to countering the terrorist groups propaganda. But the Pentagon may have gone too far in sharing its military planning.

title: Not a Splashy Move, but Maybe a Key One for the Thunder
description: At the trading deadline, a flurry of activity had some people wondering how Goran Dragic would turn around the fortunes of the Miami Heat and others celebrating Kevin Garnetts return to Minnesota. Brandon Knight, in the middle of a breakout season for the Milwaukee Bucks, was on the move to the Phoenix Suns, and the Philadelphia 76ers continued their pursuit of players no one has ever heard of.

title: Party Girl Hair at J.W. Anderson
description: Eastern European club girls were the high-energy beauty inspiration backstage for J.W. Andersons fall/winter 2015 runway. Its like this girl has been up all night dancing, and then goes to the nightclub bathroom to pull her hair back out of her eyes, explained the hairstylist Anthony Turner of the unfinished feel. After saturating the hair with LOreals Infinitum mousse, he pulled it back into a chignon, twisting and scrunching it up into a bun. This havent-made-it-to-bed hair is aligned with the 80s, good-taste-bad-taste mood of the show (and its banging techno sound track). Finally, he secured the bun with the kind of cheap, plastic comb that youd discover in one of Londons discount pound stores. Its an antidote to the somber mood of last season, explained Turner. Its not meant to look perfect  shes having too much fun!

title: Flood of Briefs on the Health Care Laws Subsidies Hits the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  Liberal groups are emphasizing states rights, a theme calculated to appeal to conservative Supreme Court justices. The insurance industry, once a foe, has come to the aid of President Obama.

title: Eighties-Inspired, Fire-Engine-Red Boots at J.W. Anderson
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: The Dinner Party as Teachable Moment
description: Chef Matt OConnor displayed considerable finesse as he pured broccoli florets and butternut squash at the home of Liza Wang in Irvington on a recent Friday night. But as the evening progressed, he discovered that a dazzling set of kitchen skills does not always guarantee the undivided attention of a roomful of amateur cooks.

title: The Nose Knows the Way to Barbecue
description: Just approaching the front door at Walrus + Carpenter  an eatery in Bridgeports Black Rock neighborhood that is locally famous for its barbecue  gives a good idea of what awaits inside. The rich, greasy aroma of slow-cooked meat drifts from the propertys back-lot smoker; festooning the outer wall of the restaurant building is a painted mural in the shape of a swine. There might as well be a giant overhead neon sign, flashing Abandon Diets, All Ye Who Enter Here.

title: C. C. SabathiaHopes His Results Recover With His Knee
description: TAMPA, Fla.  C. C. Sabathia looked as imposing as ever as he walked into the Yankees clubhouse Saturday morning. Whether he returns to being so imposing on the mound remains an open question.

title: Little Bit Country, Lots of Other Stuff
description: At the peak of their powers, the country duo Florida Georgia Line took hip-hop attitude, retrofitted with rural twang and concerns, and stomped to the top of Nashville on the backs of the status-quo bros who came just before them. Florida Georgia Line  Brian Kelley and Tyler Hubbard  werent any good at the status quo, but it turned out they were positively great at tossing it out.

title: Art: Scenes Inspired by Don Quixote
description: Cervantess comic masterpiece, Don Quixote, inspired many artworks, most notably tapestries by Charles Coypel, Louis XVs artist. Coypel created 28 tapestries woven at the Gobelins Manufactory in Paris. Starting on Wednesday, the Frick Collection will present a complete series of the scenes. The exhibition, Coypels Don Quixote Tapestries: Illustrating a Spanish Novel in Eighteenth-Century France, will include five of the original paintings they were based on; these have never been seen before in New York and are on loan from the Palais Imprial de Compigne and the Muse Jacquemart-Andr, Paris. The museum will also show three Gobelins tapestry panels from theJ. Paul Getty Museum and two Flemish tapestries inspired by Coypel from the Frick Collection, which have not been on view in more than 10 years. The Fricks tapestries  rarely seen, because they take so much room to display  were cleaned in 1999 and restored at the Textile Conservation Lab at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. (Through May 17, frick.org.)

title: For This Musician, the Time Has Come
description: The excellent Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes waited until his 40s  when he said he felt emotionally ready to perform Beethoven  to begin recording the Beethoven concertos with the Mahler Chamber Orchestra. Judging by the result, the wait has paid off. On Monday, Mr. Andsnes and the ensemble offer Beethovens second, third and fourth concertos, with Mr. Andsnes conducting from the keyboard. On Wednesday, they perform the first and fifth concertos. (8 p.m. Monday and Wednesday, Carnegie Hall, carnegiehall.org.)

title: Are You Going to Eat That?
description: Shocker: actors consuming food. Or are they? In the premiere of Dinner at Tiffanis, Wednesday night on the Cooking Channel, the running gag is whether the shows host, Tiffani Thiessen, late of White Collar, and her friends Nathan Fillion, Willie Garson and Lindsay Price actually ate the morsels they were shown scarfing down on their hit shows, or even from the catering table off screen. On Sex and the City, Mr. Garson reports, cast members had carte blanche at any New York restaurant, with food guaranteed in their trailers in 20 minutes. In Beverly Hills 90210, Ms. Price says, no one dared eat. (Bikini bodies, duh.) On the screen in Castle, Mr. Fillion prefers to wave his fork around and mime chewing. Whether Ms. Thiessens guests applied their sleight of hand to her roasted chicken, brussels sprouts with pancetta and fresh figs drizzled in lavender honey is anyones guess. But food isnt really the point when youre promising a walk down memory lane with Jason Priestley, Lance Bass, Elizabeth Berkley and Jonathan Silverman.

title: Watch That Lady and See a Star
description: Vivacious Lady (1938) is a good place to start when contemplating the charms of Ginger Rogers, the subject of a MoMA Acteurism series. First theres that title, a reminder of Rogerss always welcome presence, whether dancing with Fred Astaire or falling in love, as she does in this movie with Jimmy Stewart, whose own acteurism is also nicely on display. And then theres the story, which gets at what made Rogers such an invaluable star.

title: Designed to Miss Their Connection
description: When the choreographer Pam Tanowitz contemplated her commission for Works & Process at the Guggenheim, her first idea was a story ballet. One hitch. She had decided to use music by four composers: David Lang, Ted Hearne, Hannah Lash and Caroline Shaw. And during her research for the piece, Broken Story (wherein there is no ecstasy), she came across J. D. Salingers The Heart of a Broken Story, a love story about two people who never meet.

title: Among the Navajos, a Renewed Debate About Gay Marriage
description: TOHATCHI, N.M.  Tradition reigns here on the Navajo reservation, where the words of elders are treated as gospel and many people still live or pray in circular dwellings called hogans.

title: Navajo Nations Gay Marriage Controversy
description: Alray Nelson is an outspoken opponent of the tribal law that bans same-sex marriage.

title: Polluted Air Cuts Years Off Lives of Millions in India, Study Finds
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  More than half of Indias population lives in places with such polluted air that each person loses an average of 3.2 years in life expectancy, according to a recent study by researchers from the University of Chicago, Yale and Harvard.

title: Icons in the Struggle for Racial Equality
description: One day in the summer of 1955, when the artist Pamela Chatterton-Purdy was 15 years old, her father got a call from Jackie Robinson, the Brooklyn Dodgers second baseman and the first black man to play Major League Baseball in the modern era. Robinson was planning to buy a home in North Stamford, Conn., near where her family lived, and he wanted to hire her fathers van company for the move.

title: Herman Rosenblat, 85, Dies; Made Up Holocaust Love Story
description: The first curse on mankind was imposed because of an apple, and for all that happened to Herman Rosenblat in his 85 years  the horrors inflicted in Nazi concentration camps, the gunshot wound he suffered when his Brooklyn television repair shop was robbed, the global fame bestowed by two appearances on The Oprah Winfrey Show  it is an apple for which he will be most remembered. That first bite of the fruit was built on a lie.

title: Fear and Withdrawal
description: In the fall of 2014 the author decided to quit the prescription medications she has been taking to treat her anxiety, depression and insomnia, and began the process of gradually reducing her dosages. In Going Off, a series of Anxiety posts in the coming weeks, she will chronicle the challenges she faces from both the drugs and the withdrawal in her pursuit of a drug-free life.

title: Making a Fresh Start, Keeping the Cozy Feel
description: There should be no doubt that the setting for the life story of Joseph Bonacore, the owner and chef of Lawson Pub, would be Oceanside. He was born and raised here, and when he was a teenager, he worked in the kitchen of a restaurant on the site of where the Pub is today.

title: Flip-Flops
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  No, I dont know how he does it. I wish I did.

title: London Fashion Week: Gareth Pugh Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Gareth Pugh: Fall 2015 RTW
description: London

title: In Warwick, N.Y. at Pennings, Finding Ways to Keep Them Down on the Farm
description: The apples and freshly baked bread had been carefully moved aside. A local cover band played just steps away from shelves of raw honey and refrigerated glass cases, while a large, bearded man watched the door, collecting the $5 cover fee from scores of locals, many bundled in fleece and flannel.

title: London Fashion Week: J.W. Anderson Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: London Fashion Week: J.W. Anderson Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: London Fashion Week: Gareth Pugh Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Sophia Ahrens Transforms at Simone Rocha
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in London. Here, the model Sophia Ahrens before (left) and after (right) makeup by Sam Bryant and hair by James Pecis.

title: Old Indias Village of Warriors Becomes Birthplace of Bouncers
description: GURGAON, India  In a smoky nightclub on the third floor of the Sahara Mall, blowing off steam to the thudding bass line of a Bollywood dance mix, are the inhabitants of the new India  the sales representatives and software developers and call-center cubicle dwellers, all of them dancing giddily, hands flung in the air.

title: Scenes from Koh Mak and Koh Kut
description: Blissfully there is little to do on these islands beyond swimming, sunning and gazing at the coconut groves.

title: Funding That Climate Researcher Failed to Disclose
description: These documents show that Wei-Hock Soon, a part-time researcher at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass., received funding from fossil-fuel interests that he subsequently failed to disclose in a string of scientific papers.

title: Neighbors Step Up to Help New Yorkers Through Tough Times
description: The Maley family gets to see a lot more of one another.

title: Matt Harveys Return Brings Rare Buzz to Mets Camp
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  A few hundred Mets fans crowded around the chain-link fence Saturday morning, down the right-field line, taking pictures and holding out baseballs to sign. They jockeyed for position just to watch Mets pitchers stand around, just to catch a glimpse of the next step in Matt Harveys return tour.

title: N.F.L. Teams Dissect Differences Between Marcus Mariota and Jameis Winston
description: INDIANAPOLIS  For the last four days, deep within Lucas Oil Stadium, Marcus Mariota and Jameis Winston have had their heights, weights, arm lengths and hand sizes carefully inspected.

title: Carpetbagger Video: Remembering Their Lines
description: Throughout awards season, the Bagger has asked actors and directors on the red carpet to recite standout lines from their films, projects they finished many months before. Watch Ethan Hawke, Alejandro G. Irritu, Tilda Swinton and others give it a shot.

title: In Derby Warm-Up Race, a Favorite Is Disqualified
description: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla.  Jack Wolf was not overly disappointed as he watched Itsaknockout, his blossoming 3-year-old colt, seemingly finish second by two and three-quarter lengths to the heavily favored Upstart in the Fountain of Youth Stakes on Saturday at Gulfstream Park.

title: At Northern Trust Open, Frustration Gives Way to Being in the Hunt
description: LOS ANGELES  On Thursday, Sang-Moon Bae was so disgusted with his play, he signed for his round of even-par 71 at the Northern Trust Open and left the tournament grounds without bothering to try to find his swing on the range.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 21, 2015
Even as Many Eyes Watch, Brutality at Rikers Island Persists
description: On Sept. 2, four correction officers pulled Jose Guadalupe, an inmate classified in medical records as seriously mentally ill, into his solitary-confinement cell at Rikers Island and beat him unconscious.

title: Retired White Plains Police Officer Said to Kill 2 Daughters and Himself
description: A retired police officer in White Plains shot and killed two of his children on Saturday before committing suicide, according to a local newspaper.

title: Turkish Military Enters Syria to Evacuate Soldiers and Move Tombs Remains, Reports Say
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish Army launched an operation into Syria to evacuate soldiers guarding the Tomb of Suleyman Shah, which has been besieged by Islamic State militants, and move the tombs remains, an official and Turkish news media reported on Sunday.

title: Kyle Busch Will Miss Daytona After Crash
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Kyle Busch will miss Nascars showcase Daytona 500 on Sunday after breaking his right leg and left foot Saturday in a crash at Daytona International Speedway, an accident that quickly led track officials to vow to install safety barriers.

title: Inmates to Be Transferred After Riot at Texas Prison
description: A federal prison in South Texas over the next week will transfer up to 2,800 inmates to other institutions in the area, after a riot on Friday rendered the facility uninhabitable, an official said.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 22, 2015
description: The demonization of detainees is embedded in everyday practice.

title: Snow, Winds and Freezing Rain Make for Treacherous Weekend in New York City
description: A blistering combination of winter conditions  high winds, freezing rain, moderate snowfall  has struck the region as part of a cold snap, but on Friday it was predicted that temperatures will lift enough for the region to experience a warm Sunday afternoon.

title: Talia Thurm, Michael Abramson
description: Talia Joyce Thurm, a daughter of Deena R. Thurm and Dr. Jonathan S. Thurm of Englewood, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Michael David Abramson, a son of Helene S. Abramson and Ellis J. Abramson of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to officiate at the Grove, an event space in Cedar Grove, N.J.

title: Marielena Santana and Riccardo Marroqun
description: Marielena Santana and Riccardo Antonio Marroqun were married Saturday at Villa Woodbine, an event space in Miami. The Rev. Joaquin Perez, a priest in the Old Catholic Church, officiated.

title: Alexandra Rothman and Jason Costi
description: Alexandra Nicole Rothman and Jason Ira Costi were married Saturday evening at Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in Manhattan. Judge Cathy Seibel of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated, and Cantor Bonnie Streigold took part.

title: Janah Brooks Adickman and Lauren Schlossman
description: Janah Brynn Brooks Adickman and Lauren Rochelle Schlossman were married Saturday at the Santa Margarita Ranch in Santa Margarita, Calif. The officiant was Brett S. Evenson, a cousin of Ms. Brooks Adickman who was appointed as a temporary commissioner of civil marriages by San Luis Obispo County.

title: Gretchen Adelson, Michael Kaplan
description: Gretchen Diana Adelson and Michael Ian Kaplan were married Saturday evening at LaPlaya Beach and Golf Resort in Naples, Fla. Rabbi Adam Miller officiated.

title: Come Fly With Me (and Eat a Tarantula)
description: Taiyyibah Iftikhar Malik and Christopher Michael Schmitt were married Saturday evening at the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology in Philadelphia. Thomas L. Ambro, a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, officiated.

title: Alyssa Murstein and Benjamin Cannon
description: Alyssa Diane Murstein and Benjamin Saul Cannon were married Saturday by Rabbi David Baum at the Broken Sound Club in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Leaving Home, Embracing Extremism
description: With no notice, Islam Yaken slipped away from his middle-class home in Egypt to join the Islamic State in Syria. His family and close friends have not seen him since, except in propaganda and training videos.

title: Whats on TV Sunday
description: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 87TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS Neil Patrick Harris, that awards-show wonder, makes his debut as host of the ceremony, broadcast live from the Dolby Theater in Los Angeles. Oddsmakers are suggesting that Eddie Redmayne will take home the Oscar for his portrayal of the physicist Stephen Hawking in The Theory of Everything and that J. K. Simmons will win for best supporting actor as a music teacher from hell in Whiplash. In the best actress category, Julianne Moore is the front-runner for her portrait of a professor with early-onset Alzheimers in Still Alice, while Patricia Arquette, as a mother filmed across 12 years in Boyhood, is the favorite for supporting actress. And Alejandro G. Irritus Birdman may squeak by in the best picture category, which is filled out by Richard Linklaters Boyhood, a close contender; Clint Eastwoods American Sniper; Wes Andersons The Grand Budapest Hotel; Morten Tyldums The Imitation Game; Ava DuVernays Selma; James Marshs The Theory of Everything and Damien Chazelles Whiplash. Mr. Irritu, Mr. Linklater, Mr. Anderson, Mr. Tyldum and Bennett Miller, for Foxcatcher, are also nominated for best director. The countdown begins at 1:30 on E!; at 6 on Pop and WGN America; and at 6 on Channel 11. Red-carpet coverage begins at 7 on ABC. Postshow coverage follows at 11:30 on E!

description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  The weird thing about the Film Independent Spirit Awards is that theyre genuinely kind of fun. Unlike other awards shows, which can skew stuffy, tedious, forced or odd, theres a sort of devil-may-care frisson in the air. This is partly because of its locale  a giant tent on the beach here  partly because of the fact that Oscar voting has closed and the awards are a mere 24 hours away (hallelujah!), and partly because of the still scrappy and, yes, independent spirit of it all.

title: 1915: Germans Own to Big Reverse, Bombard Rheims
description: LONDON  The Germans admit serious setbacks and heavy losses within the last few days. They admit it according to their now well-established code by useless bombardment of civilians, or the destruction of a monument of architecture. Sometimes it has been a church destroyed, sometimes it has been women and children slaughtered. Sometimes is has been Arras, sometimes is has been Ypres. When everything else fails there is always Pont--Mousson. In admitting their recent reverse, the Germans have turned again to Rheims, where there is both a magnificent church to be shelled and plenty of civilians to be killed. This indicates that they regard their latest defeats as unusually serious, and wish to make their admission of them equally so.

He described himself as pro-life but, borrowing the language of the abortion rights movement, pointed to legislation he signed that leaves the final decision to a woman and her doctor.

title: 1940: Washingtons Birthday Celebrated in Paris
description: Americans in Paris, celebrating Washingtons Birthday in the capital of a country at war, joined in a spontaneous enthusiastic ovation for heroic Finland at the banquet given by the American Club of Paris at the Grand Hotel yesterday evening [Feb. 22]. Rising from their seats, 300 members and guests of the club acclaimed Harri Holma, Finnish Minister, who was one of many foreign diplomats present. Sir Ronald Campbell, British Ambassador, was also given an ovation. It was the largest gathering the American Club has seen for a long time, and oldtimers recalled that during the World War the club rarely mustered 100 members at its function. Representing the French government, Camille Chautemps, Vice-President of the Council, paid tribute to the victims of Nazi aggression and recalled that George Washington was not only a victorious general, but a liberator and hero of democracy, defending individual liberty.

title: Review: Harlequinade Returns to New York City Ballet
description: Fifty years ago this month, when New York City Ballet danced the premiere of George Balanchines Harlequinade, it was already old-fashioned. Set to the same frothy score by Riccardo Drigo that Marius Petipa had used 65 years earlier for Les Millions dArlequin, this two-act ballet is one of Balanchines affectionate recreations of Petipa style and Franco-Russian tradition. Its the kind of show that is always described as a confection, and when it returned to the David H. Koch Theater on Wednesday, after an absence of a decade, its antique charm was there, preserved. Yet the taste was not as fresh as possible.

title: Review: American Symphony Orchestra Revives Mona Lisa, Inspired by Leonardos Muse
description: Leonardo da Vincis Mona Lisa has inspired books, imitations, satirical spinoffs, songs and staged works  among them Max von Schillingss opera Mona Lisa. It received over 1,200 performances in the decade after its 1915 composition, including a production at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Spurned Last Year, Valeant Resumes Deal-Making
description: Salix Pharmaceuticals, a maker of gastrointestinal drugs that has been courted by at least four potential suitors over the last year, has finally found a buyer.

description: Iman Shumpert and J. R. Smith were smiling all Sunday morning as they moved around Madison Square Garden and encountered all the security guards, elevator operators, ushers, team staff members, coaches, onetime teammates and reporters they used to see when they were Knicks players.

title: Mary Katrantzous Doll-Inspired Eye Makeup
description: A doll lash, but not a dolly look is how the makeup artist Val Garland described the bold approach to beauty backstage at Mary Katrantzous fall/winter 2015 show. Borrowing tricks from the 90s club kids, who would wear tiny dots beneath their eyes for dance floor drama, Garland followed the direct line of sight, drawing an oblong below the pupil with MACs Midnight Well eye shadow in black onyx. False lashes were then chopped into small, square sections and ironed (yes, actually ironed) flat before being layered onto the lower lashline just above the oblong for extra emphasis. The look was finished simply with a careful curl of the top lashes (for prettiness) and a generous dab of lip balm. In a collection where texture and vibrancy loomed large, this low-key but look-at-me beauty fit the bill.

description: Leonid Yakobson was 17 when he saw a ballet class through a window while selling spices on the streets of Petrograd, Russia, in 1921. I was a well-built, lightweight lad, he later recounted. I thought, why not drop in?

The feel-good stories that Nascar hoped would dominate attention during its season-opening week, from Jeff Gordons final Daytona 500 to the $400 million makeover of Daytona International Speedway, had been overshadowed by the ugly suspension of Kurt Busch and a gruesome injury to Kyle Busch on Saturday. Those developments had cast a pall over the race, the organizations showcase event.

title: A Deal for the Player Who Likes a Challenge
description: Geza Ottlik and Hugh Kelsey wrote Adventures in Card Play in 1979. It is generally considered to be the toughest bridge book ever published. The deals were provided by Ottlik, from Hungary, and the text written by Kelsey, from Scotland. (Kelsey told me that Ottlik had found one analytical error in the book, but he refused to tell me in which deal. If you find it, please write in.)

title: Review: Belladonna, a Poisonous Duet at the 92nd Street Y
description: Its all too easy for a dance based on a story to lose its way. In Belladonna, the choreographer Adam Barruch finds inspiration in Nathaniel Hawthornes spooky tale Rappaccinis Daughter, in which a scientist cultivates a garden of poisonous plants for medicinal purposes. His beautiful daughter, Beatrice, takes care of them; Giovanni, a young student, rents a room overlooking the garden and becomes obsessed with her, only to learn that the reason she can take care of the plants is because she is poisonous herself.

title: Review: Trinity Wall Street and Julian Wachner Play Carnegie Hall
description: Julian Wachner, the impressive director of music and the arts at Trinity Wall Street, didnt seem the slightest bit nervous in his first performance as a conductor at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. He affably welcomed the audience, thanking everyone for braving not just the winter weather but the program he had planned. The concert paired Ivess Fourth Symphony, generally considered one of the most complex and challenging 20th-century symphonic works, and a rare performance of an intense 60-minute oratorio, Turbae ad Passionem Gregorianam, by the Argentine-born composer Alberto Ginastera, first performed in 1975.

Since that ABC series  the first Shonda Rhimes hit  began in 2005, one doctor dramedy after another has had its plug pulled after a season or two: 3 Lbs., Heartland, Three Rivers, Trauma, Mercy, Emily Owens, M.D.

Need a book to read on the plane? For those with hard currency, a new copy of 50 Shades of Grey goes for $2.50. Forget your toothpaste? A tube of Colgate costs 7 cents.

title: Rothschild Family Treasures Find a Resting Place in Boston
description: As the granddaughter of the Baron and Baroness Alphonse and Clarice de Rothschild of the banking and collecting dynasty, Bettina Burr recalls being mesmerized by one of the couples storied paintings. The work, by the English portraitist George Romney, showed his muse, a coquettish young Emma Hart, the mistress of Lord Nelson, dressed in frills and wearing a jaunty hat. I remember stopping and just staring, Ms. Burr said. She has so much allure, you couldnt help but ogle her.

Expecting a date in December, he was told that by Pandora tradition, the event would not be held until January or February.

The states flagship campus had announced this month that it intended to ban Iranian nationals from admittance to certain science and engineering programs, including physics, chemistry, and electrical and computer engineering, citing a 2012 federal law that limits the fields Iranians can study at American universities.

Gordon was on the pole for his final 500, with nothing but track in front of him and a racecar capable of putting him in victory lane one last time in the final year of his career.

title: Fighting Is Long Over, but Western Sahara Still Lacks Peace
description: TIFARITI, Western Sahara  Ghalla Sid Ahmed and her mother eke out a living in this isolated desert settlement, subsisting on five goats and a war pension. For 40 years they have lived in exile, barred from their land by a heavily patrolled sand berm that runs like a scar for 1,600 miles through this remote corner of the Sahara.

The case of the People of the State of New York against Amber Canavan touches on a variety of issues: animal rights, food culture and tradition, and the advisability of posting online videos of yourself on other peoples property. Essentially, he has tried to eliminate taking unnecessary risks.

description: Sommeliers, please advise: Which wine pairs best with simmering sexual jealousy? What digestif should you serve to a romantic rival? Vinous questions bubble up during Michael Sextons production of The Winters Tale at the Pearl Theater. title: A Rare Chair
description: In 1954, Hans Wegner created his famous Tub Chair, consisting of two upholstered shells on an elegant bent-plywood frame. The goal was that it should be beautiful from all angles. It has since become one of the most iconic examples of midcentury Modernism, and yet only three of the chairs were ever made  until now. The original is being produced by the Danish workshop PP Mobler and is sold in the U.S. exclusively at Wyeth.

title: Allergy Risk May Be Tied to How You Wash Your Dishes

title: Whats on TV Monday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) CITIZENFOUR (2014) Laura Poitras had been working on a film about surveillance for two years when Edward J. Snowden, the National Security Agency whistle-blower, contacted her in January 2013, using the name Citizenfour. When Mr. Snowden let Ms. Poitras know that he would not conceal his identity as the source of information about N.S.A. surveillance, she persuaded him to let her film their encounter. This Oscar-nominated documentary chronicles the encounter in a Hong Kong hotel room of Ms. Poitras; Glenn Greenwald, the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist who first wrote about Mr. Snowdens revelations; and Mr. Snowden as he hands over classified documents that provide evidence of the N.S.A.s invasion of privacy and copes with the resulting media storm. Cinema, even in the service of journalism, is always more than reporting, and focusing on what Ms. Poitrass film is about risks ignoring what it is, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Its a tense and frightening thriller that blends the brisk globe-trotting of the Bourne movies with the spooky, atmospheric effects of a Japanese horror film. And it is also a primal political fable for the digital age, a real-time tableau of the confrontation between the individual and the state. He added: Thinking about the issues Ms. Poitras raises can induce a kind of epistemological vertigo. What do we know about what is known about us? Who knows it? Can we trust them? These questions are terrifying, and so is Citizenfour.

title: Complicating the Picture of Urban Life
description: The 1980 image of Paul Newman, taken in the South Bronx during the filming of Fort Apache, the Bronx, could be a production still or a publicity photo. But the photograph was taken on location for more consequential reasons: Its photographer, Joe Conzo Jr., the teenage son of activists, was there to document a film that many in the community believed would hurt and embarrass it.

title: For Dortmund, a Dramatic Fall, but Not From Grace

Finally, they arrived at the famedSdtribne, the terraced stand at the south end of the stadium, which rises like a tilted baking sheet and clumps together some 25,000 spectators in what is known throughout soccer as the Yellow Wall.

title: Oscars 2015: Passionate Speeches, but Few Surprises

Mr. Pawlikowski managed to keep talking over the wrap-it-up music, which usually ushers off long-winded or lesser-known nominees, and actually finished his acceptance speech for best foreign language film.

Wed succumbed to the pastime of browsing cute animal photos, and together, on our respective screens, ended up looking at pig pictures. When I joked about getting one of our own, Jason said, We could name him Seor Bacon.

title: Who Loves America?

The histrionics have shed their ability to shock. Most right-minded Americans  ethically speaking, not ideologically speaking  have moved on.

title: Even Better Than a Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON  WITH the early stages of the 2016 presidential campaign underway and millions of Americans still hurting financially, both parties are looking for ways to address wage stagnation. Thats the good news. The bad news is that both parties are offering tax cuts as a solution. What has hurt workers paychecks is not what the government takes out, but what their employers no longer put in  a dynamic that tax cuts cannot eliminate.

title: Cutting Through Indias Smog
description: Proof of the grave air pollution problem confronting India is seen not just in the suffocating smog that on many days crowds out the sun in New Delhi, the worlds most polluted city. It can be measured as well in the fact that the country has the worlds highest death rate from chronic respiratory diseases, which kill an estimated 1.5 million Indians every year. A 2014 World Health Organization report concluded of the 20 most polluted cities in the world, India has 13.

title: When Medical Devices Spread Superbugs
description: Germs that are resistant to antibiotics are cropping up with alarming frequency at American hospitals. A lethal superbug known as CRE infected seven patients at the Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center and killed two of them. The germs were apparently transmitted on inadequately sterilized medical scopes.

title: 1890: Great Fire at Greenwich
description: LONDON A conflagration, which involved buildings nearly one hundred yards square, of a field of barrels of petroleum and over a dozen barges, all blazing at the same time, broke out at an early hour this morning [Feb. 23], and is still burning to-night. The scene of the outbreak was the Ordnance Wharf, Blackwall Lane, East Greenwich. Several engines were soon at the scene. Even then the flames were visible as far away as Southwark. The factory is about seventy yards long and fifty yards wide, and was used by the firm for general manufacturing purposes, and was crammed with thousands of tons of stock of the most inflammable description. How it originated is a mystery.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 24, 1890

title: 1915: Russians in North Poland
description: PETROGRAD  The Germans have swept through Augustowo and are now fighting a fresh Russian column between Lypsk and Grodno, but they are being held at bay on the right banks of the Narew and Bebrz, they have not been able to invest either Osowiec or Lomza, and the Muscovites have resumed the offensive on the north bank of the Vistula, where Marshal von Hindenburgs forces were most threatening to the safety of Warsaw.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 24, 1915

title: The Engel Macher
description: The end of January marked an important anniversary for those of us who work in womens health care: the 42nd anniversary of Roe v. Wade. This eponymous Supreme Court decision carries a great deal of emotional weight, and once a year, much of this emotion boils over into a week of protests, both for and against it. The names Roe and Wade inspire passionate opinions in even the most apolitical of Americans; and yet, ironically, it was in a country where these two names are virtually unknown that I have learned the most about their legacy.

title: The Transformation of Duke Street
description: Londons quiet Duke Street, a few blocks from the international megastores on Mount Street, has seen an influx of boutiques with a decidedly local bent. The new location from the quirky-chic shoemaker Penelope Chilvers includes a studio for custom dandy slippers, and Philip Treacys protge Laura Apsit Livens, a milliner to Rita Ora and the Duchess of Westminster, has set up her atelier inside a repurposed Victorian stairwell. Meanwhile, the historic mens wear label E. Tautz  founded in 1867 and recently revived by the Norton & Sons designer Patrick Grant  just moved their first store into the neighborhood, with tailoring in the basement and the debut womens collection on the racks. These boutiques join the recently opened Duke Street Emporium, a two-level concept store offering emerging fashion labels, beauty products and books amid exhibits from hometown artists.

title: At Burberry, Romantic (But Dont Call Them Smoky) Eyes
description: The makeup artist Wendy Rowe built a layered beauty look for Burberrys fall 2015 show. Its a folky collection thats full of eclectic patterns and prints, she explained backstage earlier today. To complement that, Ive created a patchwork of textures: a matte mouth, cashmere skin and iridescent eyes. Keeping the skin very clean and the lips tinted nude, she focused on creating romantic but, crucially, not smoky eyes. After drawing a line along the upper and lower lids with cream eye shadow, Rowe then loosely blended beneath the eye for a worn-in finish. Her advice for artlessly recreating this disheveled feel: It should look as though its been done in a rush.
