title: Debbie Harry on Four Decades of Blondie
description: On March 5, Carnegie Hall will host Tibet Houses 25th Annual Benefit Concert, whose ongoing aim is to preserve the awareness of Tibetan culture around the world. This years event has a lineup bursting with talent to match the organizations quarter-century existence, with performances from the composer Philip Glass and the rock band the Flaming Lips. Perhaps most exciting, however, will be the appearance of the legendary troika of rock goddesses Laurie Anderson, Patti Smith and the Blondie frontwoman Debbie Harry. The latter of the trio, still going strong at 69, also has an upcoming run at the posh Caf Carlyle, dozens of blocks north of the lower Manhattan landscape shes been synonymous with for the past 40 years. Harry talked with T about what we can expect from her uptown persona, how she braves the frigid New York winter and why she thinks she became a music and style icon.

title: IBM Tries to Paint the Computing Cloud Blue
description: IBM hopes everything looks better in IBM blue.

title: New Directors/New Films Picks Sundance Hit for Opening Night
description: The Diary of a Teenage Girl, about a 15-year-old, Minnie, who has an affair with her mothers boyfriend, was a hit at the Sundance Film Festival last month, and now the organizers of the annual New Directors/New Films series in New York have chosen it as their opening-night selection.

title: Shola Olatoye on Her Name
description: Ms. Olatoye, chairwoman of the New York City Housing Authority, discusses the pronunciation of her name and its origin.

title: Oscars 2015: Dull, Witless, Unjust  and Irresistible
description: Frank Bruni:Ross, I begin this conversation with a sense of shame and the feeling that were feeding a bad habit, because theres no annual event in American life more excessively and obsequiously chronicled by those of us in the media than the Oscars. From September, when studios start unveiling their award-season showboats, to late February, when the statuettes are handed out in a ceremony whose long-winded dullness never ceases to amaze, were Oscar slaves. Oscar suckers. We should be stronger. We should resist.

title: Finding the Right Balance of Time and Money
description: One summer, a friend of mine planned a river trip. The closest public airport was a day and a halfs drive from the river. So my friend decided to hire a private plane to get his group to the destination in a few hours. I know this choice sounds extravagant, but it represents a choice weve probably all experienced at some point.

title: Behind the Poster: The Absolute Brightness of Leonard Pelkey
description: The artist Jerry Marsini didnt need to travel far to research his poster design for The Absolute Brightness of Leonard Pelkey. Written by and starring James Lecesne, a co-founder of the L.G.B.T. youth organization the Trevor Project, the show is about the murder of a gay artistically-minded 14-year-old in a small town.

title: Peter Pilotto: Fall 2015 RTW
description: London

title: London Fashion Week: Erdem Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: On Immigration, Obama Turns a G.O.P. Argument on Its Head
description: For months, Republicans have said they are offended by President Obamas executive actions on immigration, saying he is essentially making law himself in violation of the Constitutions separation of powers.

title: Egyptian Blogger Sentenced to 5 Years in Prison for Protest Role
description: ISTANBUL  A blogger who came to be one of the best-known faces of the 2011 uprising in Egypt was sentenced to five years in prison on Monday, part of the military-backed governments continuing crackdown on dissent.

title: Refurbished Stations From Denver to Tokyo
description: Trainstations around the world are receiving significantfacelifts, giving them a contemporary atmosphere and putting a new emphasis on retail and restaurants.

title: The 10 Best Dressed at the 87th Academy Awards
description: Red and white gowns dominated the red carpet last night at the 87th Academy Awards and the after party. As usual, the evening wasnt short on outfit changes(Emma Stone notably took off the stunning gold number she wore to the show and put ona red-and-white look for a night out), but a majority of the leading ladies got it right the first, and only, time. As for Lady Gaga and her three custom Azzedine Alaa dresses: the one she arrived in, complete with a pair of red leather gloves that blew up Twitter, was the most unforgettable look of the night. Here, a look back at the evenings most glamorous Oscars style.

title: London Fashion Week: Thomas Tait Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

title: London Fashion Week: Erdem Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: Meet Project Phoenix, the new NYT Android App
description: The New York Times reaches more readers today than ever before in its 164-year history thanks to the rise of mobile. On Android specifically, user growth in recent years has been explosive.

title: With Palestinian Debt Rising, Israeli Utility Briefly Reduces Power to West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  Israels state-owned electricity company briefly reduced the power supply to two Palestinian districts in the northern West Bank on Monday because of a ballooning debt, according to company officials, in a measure that also reflected the growing political disconnect between the Israeli and Palestinian sides.

title: Valeants Deal for Salix Continues Frenzied Deal-Making in Drug Sector
description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals, which has a penchant for deals, has taken on a $10 billion company in its latest deal to buy Salix. Valeants pledge last year to focus on organic growth and debt reduction didnt last long. Cost cuts and tax savings from buying Salix Pharmaceuticals proved irresistible.

title: Food Habits Getting Worse Around the World
description: People in some poor and middle-income countries have healthier diets than those in rich ones, but major Western snack and soft drink makers are targeting children in ways that will damage their health, according to a new series of studies on obesity.

title: London Fashion Week: Thomas Tait Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

title: What Flying Was Like Before the Smoke Cleared
description: IF you think the air travel experience generally stinks now, consider what it was like before smoking was banned on domestic flights 25 years ago.

title: Statement Earrings at the 87th Academy Awards
description: Although statement necklaces created predictable buzz atlast nights red carpet, the more interesting jewelry moments came via large, sculptural diamond earrings. At the 2015 Academy Awards, Julianne Moore and Marion Cotillard donned round, elegant pairs, both by Chopard, while the young starlet Chloe Grace Moretz opted for a single, edgier ear cuff by Forevermark, proving that sometimes, one is better than two.

title: This Winter Has Gotten Old
description: Then Im laying out my winter clothes and wishing I was gone, going home, where the New York City winters arent bleeding me. So goes the Simon and Garfunkel song, buried deep in the memory, an oldie that seems to have been around for as long as this old winter has.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Helping Boys Succeed
Time for New Antlers
description: Q. When deer lose their antlers each year, do they grow back in the same pattern?

title: Mothers Sounds Are Building Block for Babies Brains
description: The sound of a mothers voice plays a critical role in a babys early development, multiple studies have shown. Now, researchers have demonstrated that the brain itself may rely on a mothers voice and heartbeat to grow.

title: Obama Warns of Homeland Dept. Shutdown
description: While addressing the National Governors Association, the president warned of the effects of a Department of Homeland Security shutdown on states economies.

title: Meditation for a Good Nights Sleep
description: Do you have chronic sleep problems? You may be able to significantly improve your ability to get a restful night of sleep by practicing a popular form of meditation, a rigorous new study shows.

title: Why Jeb Bush Has Only One Photo From His Wedding
description: Jeb Bushs wife, Columba, is in the spotlight this week, with new profiles out about her wariness of the family business and her expensive taste.

title: Brocades Renaissance at London Fashion Week
description: In London, opulence and regality have taken center stage at many a fall 2015 fashion show, from the historic venues in which they took place  the Tate Britain art gallery and the Victoria and Albert Museum to certain decadent details in the collections. And over the past few days, beautiful brocade fabrics have been ushered into the 21st century with dramatic shapes (a voluptuous cape at Simone Rocha), bold hues (rich berry-and-black palettes at Mary Katrantzou) and interesting lines (sophisticated patchwork and cutouts at Erdem).

title: Wall St. and Law Firms Plan Cooperative Body to Bolster Online Security
description: The threat of ever-larger online attacks is bringing together Wall Street banks and the big law firms that do work for them in an alliance that could result in some sharing of basic information about digital security issues.

title: According to the Words, the News Is Actually Good
description: We journalists pride ourselves on a willingness to bring you bad news. The more death and destruction, the more words and pictures. If it bleeds, it leads.

title: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Are Suspended on Tuesday
description: Because of snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Thomas Tait: Fall 2015 RTW
description: London

title: Sunday Routine Made Graphic
description: Sunday Routine, a regular Metropolitan section feature, looks at the way newsworthy New Yorkers spend a typical Sunday.

title: Reuters Bureau Chief Is Found Dead in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistan and Afghanistan bureau chief for Reuters, Maria Golovnina, was found dead at her office in Islamabad on Monday, according to a statement by Reuters and Pakistani officials.

title: Hunter Original: Fall 2015 RTW
description: London

title: Wim Wenders, Man of the World
description: Wim Wenders explores pristine landscapes in his new documentary, The Salt of the Earth, about the photojournalist Sebastio Salgado. Here, he recalls his own memorable brush with the great outdoors.

title: An Overture by Winter, Then Warmth and Energy
description: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon. My name is Yannick. A ripple of laughter went through the audience at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday when the conductor Yannick Nzet-Sguin took the microphone at the beginning of his Great Performers concert with the Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra. To his adoring and vocal fans, he needed no introduction: As music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Mr. Nzet-Sguin is a frequent guest in New York. But the ensemble he was presenting on this occasion  and which he has led as music director since 2008  is still unfamiliar to American audiences.

title: Ukraine Rebels Celebrate Their Taking of Debaltseve
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Pro-Russian rebels celebrated their recent victory at Debaltseve with a festive rally on Monday in Donetsk, the main city they control, where soldiers received medals in Lenin Square and the crowd cheered and waved Soviet flags.

title: France Seizes 6 Passports Under Antiterrorism Law
description: PARIS  The French authorities began to use new, sweeping counterterrorism powers on Monday to halt the stream of young people going to Syria, confiscating the passports of six people suspected of trying to go there to engage in terrorist activities.

title: An Inimitable Western
description: Jim Krantzs cinematic vision of the American West.

title: General Electric Deal for Alstom Raises Concerns Among European Authorities
description: PARIS  General Electric expressed confidence on Monday that its $13.5 billion acquisition of Alstoms energy business would be completed, even after European antitrust authorities raised concerns about how it would affect competition in the market for heavy-duty gas turbines.

title: Seeing Spots on the Womens Fall 2015 Runways
description: The virtues of leopard print as a neutral are undersung. It goes with everything and is almost always in fashion  decade after decade, the print continues to find relevance, from Bettie Pages midcentury pin-up swimsuits to Kate Mosss signature vintage leopard coat. For fall/winter 2015, designers are revisiting leopard in new ways. First, in New York, Marc Jacobs used the print as trim on the collar and pockets of a metallic belted jacket, as well as on a matching bag. Across the pond at Erdem, the designer showed a ladylike leopard skirt suit, in homage to his Hitchcockian muses. Lastly, at Burberry, a demure midcalf-length leopard coat was toughened up with a built-in harness  Page would approve.

title: At Vanity FairsOscars Party, Jay Z and Beyonc Steal the Show
description: It may have been the most exclusive party of the year, but it didnt matter: Jay Z and Beyonc can stop any room.

title: Andreja Pejic Transforms at Giles
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in London. Here, the model Andreja Pejic before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Sacha Mascolo.

title: The Power of a Tease and a Bobby Pin at Erdem
description: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Egypt and More  Pictures of the Day

title: In Performance | Patrick Mulryan
description: Mr. Mulryan sings Giants in the Sky from the Fiasco Theaters production of the musical Into the Woods, with Matt Castle on piano. The show is at the Laura Pels Theater through April 12.

title: Feb. 23, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Egypt, Bangladesh, Maldives and Ukraine.

title: Strong Sales for Larry Davids Fish in the Dark on Broadway
description: The new Broadway comedy Fish in the Dark, written by and starring Larry David, set a box-office record for the Cort Theater last week, grossing $1,177,593, according to ticket sales data published on Monday. The previous record was set by the 2010 revival of Fences, starring Denzel Washington, during its final week of performances, when the play grossed $1,175,626. Fish in the Dark, in which Mr. David plays the son of a dying family patriarch, is still in preview performances; the critics reviews will come out after opening night on March 5.

title: Readers Respond: On My Own Life
description: The neurologist whose writing opened a popular window on a medical awakening of the human mind shared his personal awakening after receiving a terminal cancer diagnosis. Readers responded to Oliver Sacks My Own Life with gratitude.

title: Oscars TV Ratings Fall 15 Percent
description: LOS ANGELES  Ratings tumbled 15 percent for this years Oscars ceremony on Sunday, delivering the least-watched show in six years, according to Nielsen data.

title: Feeding Infants Peanut Products Could Prevent Allergies, Study Suggests
description: Turning what was once conventional wisdom on its head, a new study suggests that many, if not most peanut allergies can be prevented by feeding young children food containing peanuts beginning in infancy, rather than avoiding such foods.

title: Snow Snow Snow, and East Coast Skiers Rejoice
description: In early February, the outdoor sports website Teton Gravity Research posted a video of a skier plunging down an alpine chute in thigh-deep powder, slaloming through evergreens and yelping with joy as clumps of snow pelted his goggles.

title: Christopher Kanes Perfectly Pink Crocodile Booties
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Vice Media vs. Brooklyn Indie Music Clubs
description: When word spread eight months ago that Vice Media was moving into a complex of warehouses on the Williamsburg waterfront in Brooklyn, supporters of two indie-music clubs being displaced accused the company of violating the very spirit of hipness and authenticity that it had seemingly built its brand upon.

title: Review: In The Buried Giant, Ishiguro Revisits Memory and Denial
description: Kazuo Ishiguros latest novel, The Buried Giant, is an eccentric, ham-handed fairy tale with a jumble of story lines lifted from Beowulf, Arthurian legend and assorted folk traditions. It is recounted in stilted, formalistic language thats presumably meant to evoke a bygone era, and set in a mythical Britain equally reminiscent of The Lord of the Rings and Game of Thrones. King Arthurs knight Sir Gawain is a major character, and so is a she-dragon named Querig.

title: As Ida Wins an Oscar, Poland Ends a Losing Streak
description: WARSAW  The utter tenacity with which the director Pawel Pawlikowski talked and talked and refused to be shooed off stage by the Oscar orchestra has been matched only by the Polish film industrys own persistent, decades-long pursuit of international recognition.

title: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
description: Sometimes the anticipation for the game builds all week until Saturdays kickoff. And sometimes you only have to wait a day. Heres what you should watch this week.

title: Stifel Financial to Acquire Sterne Agee
description: Stifel Financial, the financial services firm, said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire smaller rival Sterne Agee Group in a deal valued at about $150 million.

title: Married Sex Gets Better in the Golden Years
description: Yes, there is sex after marriage. Particularly if you make it past your 50th wedding anniversary.

title: Reviews: New Albums From Big Sean, Emile Haynie and DRKWAV
description: EMILE HAYNIE

title: Funding Fight Over Homeland Security Poses Dangers for the G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  After promising an era of responsible governing and an end to federal shutdowns, congressional Republicans find themselves mired in an immigration fight that could cause funding for the Department of Homeland Security to run out on Friday.

title: The Tangled Roots of English
description: The peoples of India, Iran and Europe speak a Babel of tongues, but most  English included  are descended from an ancient language known as proto-Indo-European. Scholars have argued for two centuries about the identity and homeland of those who spoke this parent language, but a surprisingly sudden resolution of this longstanding issue may be at hand.

title: New Yorks Fluoridation Fuss, 50 Years Later
description: In March 1957, as Elvis was buying Graceland and the Soviets were preparing to shock the world with Sputnik, Robert F. Wagner, the famously cautious mayor of New York, was having trouble taking a stand.

title: Marine Life Study Suggests Bigger Is Better for Successful Evolution
description: Copes rule states that evolution favors larger bodies, suggesting that the average size of animals on the planet should always trend upward. The hypothesis has its proponents, but there has been scant evidence to support it.

title: Gangland Undercover and Outlaw Country Examine Biker Life
description: Its an interesting week in the ever-evolving relationship between television and crime. The History channel, no doubt hoping to fill the Sons of Anarchy void, puts motorcycle gangs back on the air with Gangland Undercover, based on a federal informants real story. And WGN tries to push the police ride-along show to the next dubious level by adding a potential-lawbreaker ride-along.

title: Mouse Brain May Give Insight Into Diseases of Human Mind
description: When injected with bits of human DNA, mouse embryos grew brains that were 12 percent larger than those of embryos injected with the same genes from chimpanzees. Scientists at Duke University, writing in the journal Current Biology, say the experiment demonstrates the role that a particular gene sequence, HARE5, plays in the development of the human brain, which is far heavier and more complex than the brains of our closest animal cousins. The research also may help reveal why humans develop conditions like Alzheimers and autism, but chimpanzees do not.

title: Formula for Headache-Free Flying: Pack Only a Phone and a Book
description: IVE spent my career in the hospitality industry, and in 2008 started my own company, AJ Capital Partners. My business is investing in and restoring hotel properties to their glorious state, and right now we have about nine projects underway in cities across the United States.

title: Review: Carmen de Lavallades One-Woman Show Comes to New York
description: What does it mean when an 83-year-old woman says, Once I was beautiful? Carmen de Lavallade is 83, and when she speaks those words in her autobiographical one-woman show, As I Remember It, their truth is unmistakable. You can see it in the projected photos and videos from her youth as a celebrated dancer and actress. But there is also the evidence of Ms. de Lavallade in the present, belying the verb tense. Her beauty is not a thing of the past.

title: London Fashion Week: Giles Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: When the Space Age Was Young
description: A collection of space program images, dating from 1946 to the end of NASAs lunar missions in 1972.

title: Oscars Show Growing Gap Between Moviegoers and Academy
description: LOS ANGELES  In the end, it was the audience that got snubbed.

title: London Fashion Week: Giles Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

title: Disney Names Robert Chapek Chairman for Theme Parks
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company on Monday handed the reins of its sprawling theme park operation to a fast-rising executive known for streamlining the entertainment giants merchandise division.

title: Please Stop Making That Noise
description: I cant stand it when someone behind me at a movie chews popcorn with his or her mouth open. I mean, I really cant stand it.

title: Rarely Seen Images From Space Including the Best Selfie Ever
description: Hundreds of photographs from the early years of the space age are for sale. That includes the first image taken from space  from an altitude of 65 miles by a camera on a V-2 rocket launched from the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico on Oct. 24, 1946. (The boundary to outer space is generally placed at 100 kilometers, or 62.1 miles.)

title: Tiananmen Square Negatives: An Art Book or a Protest?
description: BEIJING  The latest book by the photographer Xu Yong is filled with the images of young Chinese idealists clamoring for democracy and denouncing the Communist Party, but he insists that there is nothing political about his decision to publish this trove of snapshots he had kept hidden for more than two decades.

title: Former Chinese Premier Draws Praise for His Philanthropy
description: Since Zhu Rongji stepped down as premier of China in 2003, he has pursued interests including playing a type of fiddle called the huqin, writing best sellers and practicing philanthropy. It is this last activity, in particular, that returned Mr. Zhu to the spotlight, while also drawing attention to how unusual such charity is among former Chinese politicians.

title: Christie Broke Law With Pension Move, New Jersey Judge Says
description: In a major blow to Gov. Chris Christie, a New Jersey judge ruled on Monday that he violated state law when he declined to make the full payment into the states pension system for public employees last year and ordered him to find a way to fund it now.

title: The Next Big Military Civil Rights Issue: Transgender Service
description: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter got it right on Sunday when he said that nothing but suitability for service should preclude transgender people from serving openly in the military  in other words, ability to do the job.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Chegg Is Shifting Its Services to Focus on Digital Push
description: Chegg, the textbook rental service, is planning a big reinvention of its operations a little more than a year after going public.

title: A New Lens on a Blurred History
description: Xu Yongs Negatives, with images of the protests that convulsed Beijing in the spring of 1989, is likely to be viewed as a provocation by the hard-liners who govern China.

title: She Runs S.E.C. Hes a Lawyer. Recusals and Headaches Ensue.
description: Their legal careers, and by extension their marriage, are the stuff of lore. Mary Jo White leads the Securities and Exchange Commission; her husband, John, practices law at an old-guard firm as elite as the corporations it represents. Together, they are a legal power couple that straddles Wall Street and Washington like few others.

title: Justices Weigh Denial of Visa to Husband of U.S. Citizen
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday did not seem inclined to second-guess the denial of a visa on national security grounds to the Afghan husband of an American woman.

title: London Fashion Week: Peter Pilotto Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: London Fashion Week: Peter Pilotto Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: For an Iraqi Expatriate, American Sniper Both Draws and Repels
description: Like many others, I was intrigued by the attention the film American Sniper was getting. I knew I was treading murky waters, but I decided to follow the herd and see the movie. Unlike most people in the crowd, I had a very personal stake in the film. American Sniper takes place in Iraq, my homeland, which I left shortly after the American-led invasion that Chris Kyle took part in. So the film, powerful and sad, left me with mixed thoughts and reminiscences.

title: London Fashion Week: Christopher Kane Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

title: London Fashion Week: Christopher Kane Fall/Winter 2015
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

title: A Bronx Tale Musical to Debut at Paper Mill Playhouse in New Jersey
description: Chazz Palminteris semi-autobiographical story A Bronx Tale has been a movie (directed by and starring Robert De Niro) and a Broadway solo show (directed by the Tony Award winner Jerry Zaks). Now its coming back again as a musical  with Mr. De Niro and Mr. Zaks teaming up as directors. The Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., announced on Monday that the world premiere of A Bronx Tale musical will be one of five shows in its 2015-16 season, running Feb. 4-March 6, 2016. A Bronx Tale features music by the Tony winner Alan Menken (Newsies), lyrics by Glenn Slater, and a book by Mr. Palminteri (who will not be a member of the cast this time around); Sergio Trujillo is the choreographer.

title: Jim Krantzs Wild West
description: The Chicago-based commercial photographer Jim Krantzs work has been famous in the art world for years. Krantz himself has been less so  a fact that perhaps requires some explanation. In the 1990s, Krantz, who had been documenting the cinematic vistas of the American West and its people with his camera for 20 years, went to Texas to photograph cowboys for a Marlboro advertising campaign. The final product caught the eye of Richard Prince, the appropriation artist who had achieved renown by photographing ads and presenting the resulting images in galleries and museums. Beginning in the 1980s, Prince reproduced images from Marlboro ads for his Cowboys series. One such print, at the time of its sale in 2005, was the most expensive photograph ever sold at auction.

title: An Embedded Photographer Empowers the Poor
description: A Bangladeshi photographer who tired of seeing poverty portrayed in the usual ways had a brainstorm: He lived with his subjects and had them collaborate with him.

title: Mary Jo White  From Prosecutor to Regulator
description: Before President Obama named Mary Jo White to run the Securities and Exchange Commission, she was the top federal prosecutor in New York City.

title: Greece Delays Submittal of Its Overhaul Plans
description: ATHENS  Greece on Monday delayed the submission of the proposed reforms that European creditors have made a condition of the countrys financial aid.

title: The Best Sellers: Filed Under Sports
description: The best-selling sports books in January 2015, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

title: Google Guns for Apple in Mobile Payments Race
description: Technology companies have spent years trying to persuade people to put away their credit cards and pay with mobile phones instead, but consumers have mostly shrugged. Now, with the release of Apples Apple Pay application, the race to replace credit cards with mobile phones has turned into a brawl.

title: Alan Howard, Actor With Royal Shakespeare Company, Dies at 77
description: Alan Howard, a celebrated English actor whose regal bearing and imposing voice gave life to a spate of Shakespearean kings, died on Feb. 14 in London. He was 77.

title: Jeb Bush Looms Large for Marco Rubio in 2016
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, stood in front of reporters before a book signing here, pondering the question that has dogged him ever since Jeb Bush announced his plans to pursue a presidential bid: How does a Bush candidacy complicate Mr. Rubios own Oval Office aspirations, especially among donors?

title: Defense Chief Vouches for U.S. Strategy on ISIS
description: CAMP ARIFJAN, Kuwait  The new defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter, said Monday after meeting with senior American military and diplomatic officials in Kuwait that the Obama administration had the ingredients of the strategy to defeat Islamic State militants in Iraq and Syria.

title: A Photographic Memory
description: A collection of space program photographs, dating from 1946 to the end of NASAs lunar mission in 1972.

title: Chemicals Permitted in the U.S. but Banned in the E.U.
description: A sampling of pesticides and other chemicals used in the United States but prohibited in European Union countries.

title: A Pesticide Banned, or Not, Underscores Trans-Atlantic Trade Sensitivities
description: LONDON  Syngenta, a Swiss chemicals company, produces one of Americas most popular herbicides. It is called atrazine, and 73.7 million pounds of the chemical compound were applied in the United States in 2013. It was used on more than half of all corn crops, two-thirds of sorghum and up to 90 percent of sugar cane.

title: Columbia Hires Ex-Penn Coach Al Bagnoli, Surprising Its Ivy Peers
description: Three months after he retired with nine Ivy League titles in 23 seasons at the University of Pennsylvania, Al Bagnoli stunned the conference on Monday when he abruptly joined Columbia as its new football coach.

title: Rebirth of the Cool: American Music Makes a Return to Iran
description: TEHRAN  The audience members in Tehrans Vahdat concert hall rose from their seats, clapping wildly as the frontman Bob Belden, a fun-loving New Yorker with a predilection for loud shirts, rested his soprano saxophone on a nearby stand.

title: 12 at Wesleyan University Are Hospitalized for Drug Overdoses
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.  Late on Sunday morning, students at Wesleyan University received an email from a university official: Three students had been taken to hospitals, apparently for drug overdoses, and one was in critical condition.

title: Joey Loganos Daytona Victory Fulfills Early Promise
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Jeff Gordons last Daytona 500 began as an ode to his legacy, but it might be best remembered as a harbinger of what is to come in Nascar.

title: Jurors in Patz Case View Suspects First Confession
description: The tearful confession came after six and a half hours of interrogation, and yet, when it was over, the man now on trial in the murder of 6-year-old Etan Patz had left key questions unanswered.

title: A Marine Is Convicted on Two Counts of Desertion
description: Wassef Ali Hassoun, a Marine corporal accused of faking his abduction in Iraq in 2004 and evading punishment for years by fleeing to Lebanon, was found guilty on Monday of two counts of desertion. He was sentenced to two years in prison by a military judge at Camp Lejeune, N.C., and given a dishonorable discharge.

title: E.P.A. Issues Stiffer Rules on Vehicle Fuel Ratings
description: WASHINGTON  After two years of imposing increasingly stiff penalties on automakers that overstate their fuel economy ratings, federal regulators on Monday said they would tighten guidelines used in determining the mileage advertised to consumers.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 23, 2015
Refugees Are Pushed to Exits in Pakistan
description: TORKHAM, Afghanistan  First, the Afghan families homes were raided by Pakistani policemen wielding sticks. Then the men were hauled off to jail, released only after relatives paid bribes.

title: Amexs Loss in Court May Not Help Consumers
description: Last week, a federal judge handed down a major ruling against American Express, deciding that the brand-name card issuer had engaged in anticompetitive practices for more than a decade.

title: Red Sox Place a Big Bet on the Latest Prospect From Cuba
description: Yoan Moncada sits at the intersection of dollars and dreams. He is a blank slate, completely unknown beyond the relatively few people who have watched him play. His potential, therefore, seems limitless.

title: Metro-North Engineer Tried to Slow Train Before Crash With S.U.V., Report Says
description: Nearly three weeks after a fatal Metro-North Railroad crash, the National Transportation Safety Board released a summary of its preliminary findings on Monday, but official conclusions about the cause of the crash are months away.

title: The Horrors Keep Coming at Rikers
description: Nearly a year has passed since Mayor Bill de Blasio installed Joseph Ponte as his correction commissioner and charged him with reforming the house-of-horrors city jail system at Rikers Island, where guards have routinely beaten inmates bloody as a matter of course. The mayor has since shaken up the jail systems management team, committed new resources to the reform project and pledged to make cleaning up the jails a top priority.

title: For Mets With Major Injuries, an Incentive and a Memento
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  When Matt Harvey went into the training room for his normal routine Monday morning, Dave Pearson, the Mets minor league rehabilitation coordinator, shook his hand, congratulated him for finishing the rehabilitation program and presented him with a small coin, a token of appreciation for his hard work.

title: Rhode Island City May Lose Its Red Sox and, Mayor Says, Its Heart
description: For decades, the Pawtucket Red Sox have been a minor league team as familiar to baseball fans as the Toledo Mud Hens, the Memphis Redbirds, the Durham Bulls or the Birmingham Barons. Playing at McCoy Stadium, which opened during World War II, the Rhode Island team, commonly known as the PawSox, has sent future stars such as Jim Rice, Carlton Fisk, Nomar Garciaparra, Roger Clemens, Mo Vaughn and Jacoby Ellsbury to the big club in Boston.

title: Review: In Big Love, Fleeing Tradition Becomes a Messy Escape
description: Theyre bouncing off the walls in Tina Landaus frenzied revival of Big Love, Charles Mees 2000 play of things martial and marital according to Aeschylus. Theyre also dangling from ropes and jumping on trampolines and rolling on the floor and fighting with tooth, claw, knives and slices of wedding cake. Well, as the song says, thats amore.

title: Review: The Insurgents Stars Cassie Beck in a Lucy Thurber Drama
description: Beware, America! Sally Wright, a young woman who spends a lot of time with a shotgun in her hands, is having one whale of a nervous breakdown. It is, you might say, a breakdown as big as a whole country, and its been building for centuries.

title: Shades of Grey
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Elizabeth Longs puzzle is certainly timely. With the Feb. 13 release of the movie version of E. L. Jamess novel, 50 Shades of Grey, you might think that the theme of todays puzzle ventures into non-standards-friendly territory, but it doesnt. Today, Ms. Long is really thinking about shades that belong to people with the surname Grey.

title: Bill Gates and Other Business Leaders Urge U.S. to Increase Energy Research
description: The government is spending far too little money on energy research, putting at risk the long-term goals of reducing carbon emissions and alleviating energy poverty, some of the countrys top business leaders found in a new report.

title: Sleepy Hollow Season 2 Finale Recap: Abbie Goes Back
description: Season 2, Episode 18: Tempus Fugit

title: New York Attorney General Is Said to Review Casino Bidding Process
description: ALBANY  The state attorney generals office has opened a preliminary inquiry into the process by which three projects were recently recommended for new casino licenses, according to two former bidders who were later contacted by investigators.

title: Israeli Views on Iran Diverged, Reports Say
description: JERUSALEM  Shortly after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israels dire warning at the United Nations in 2012 that Iran was a mere months away from being able to develop a nuclear bomb, Israels Mossad intelligence agency presented a more sober assessment that did not support Mr. Netanyahus timetable.

title: Presumed Heir of Indian Party Requests Leave of Absence
description: NEW DELHI  Rahul Gandhi, long expected to be the next leader of Indias beleaguered Congress Party, threw political commentators into fits of baffled speculation on Monday when party officials announced that he had requested a leave of absence because he wants time to think.

title: Ben Woolf, Actor in American Horror Story, Dies at 34
description: Ben Woolf, a former teacher who took up acting and found success on the television show American Horror Story, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 34.

title: Bill OReilly and Fox News Redouble Defense of His Falklands Reporting
description: The Fox News host Bill OReilly on Monday stepped up his defense against reports that he embellished stories about his war reporting earlier in his career, while some former colleagues continued to say he had exaggerated his experiences.

title: A Jarring Blast Arrives Without Warning
description: A man with a baby fled a cloud of heavy black smoke on Monday after a tanker truck carrying almost 9,000 gallons of fuel caught fire on a major southern New Jersey highway in Pennsauken.

title: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Are Suspended on Tuesday
description: Because of snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Better Call Saul Recap: Dont Worry Saul, Its All Good, Man
description: Season 1, Episode 4: Hero

title: After Surge in Young Migrants on Long Island, Groups Team Up to Bolster Services
description: A partnership of New York groups and a state agency said Monday that it would invest about $500,000 to provide legal, mental health and educational support to children on Long Island who recently arrived as part of a surge in illegal migration from Central America.

title: New Housing to Benefit as Citigroup Sells Queens Site
description: In 1989, Citigroup, the financial services giant, erected New York Citys tallest tower outside Manhattan in Queens, where city officials hoped to establish a new commercial district.

title: A Melancholy  and Danceable  New Song from Brooklyns San Fermin
description: The Brooklyn-based baroque-pop octet San Fermin doesnt approach new songs the way most bands in its zip code do  by assembling in a rehearsal space and jamming until something worth recording emerges. Instead, its songwriter and composer Ellis Ludwig-Leone writes preliminary versions of all eight parts for each new song himself, and then delivers them to his bandmates in the basement below his apartment, where they gather to practice. The worst thing that I ever do with the band is rehearse a new song with them, he says with a laugh. Suddenly its like, Oh, my God, I hope this is good, because were going to have to play this hundreds of times, and its terrifying.

title: A Winter Salad Recipe from Andrew Carmellini, in Honor of Bon Apptits New Kitchen
description: Bon Apptit magazines BA Kitchen was already home to some of the most exclusive culinary events in the city, having opened its doors to celebrated chefs such as Carlo Mirarchi (Robertas), David Kinch (Manresa) and Inaki Aizpitarte (Le Chateaubriand). But now, with Cond Nast an official tenant of One World Trade Center, the ad hoc dining club will have a setting worthy of its food. As good as a job as we did before, you cant compare it to being on the 35th floor of the World Trade Center overlooking the city with a view of the Empire State, says the Bon Apptit editor in chief Adam Rapoport, who co-hosts the new spaces opening party this evening. And hes tapped the James Beard Award-winning chef Andrew Carmellini to christen the place. Adams an old friend, and were in the neighborhood already, explains Carmellini, whose fashionable restaurants (Little Park, the Dutch, Locanda Verde) are, like the new Cond Nast headquarters, a Lower Manhattan fixture. Were going to have a party.

title: Accent on Singing in Coming Jazz at Lincoln Center Season
description: Jazz at Lincoln Centers 2015-16 season, with the theme Jazz and American Song, will feature a sustained emphasis on vocal music in the blues, jazz and pop traditions.

title: More Conflict Over Cutting Federal Role in Education
description: As the House of Representatives prepared to take up a Republican proposal for the reauthorization of No Child Left Behind, Congress and the White House on Monday inched toward a confrontation over the federal role in education.

title: Word of the Day | derision
description: derision  \di-ri-zhn\  noun

title: Promising Faster Wireless, Artemis Draws Closer With Dish Spectrum Deal
description: Artemis Networks, a start-up that says it has created a technology for increasing the speed and reliability of wireless networks, is getting closer to bringing that service to the public.

title: Christies Truce With Teachers Could Pay Dividends in 16
description: The relationship was not just rancorous, it was toxic.

title: Pole-Vaulters With Matching Ambitions
description: The identical twins Lexi and Tori Weeks plan to attend the University of Arkansas and study chemistry. Also on their minds: the 2016 Olympic trials.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Money is oxygen for terrorism.

title: Fading Christie Is Giving Bush Stronger Grip on G.O.P.s Center
description: Chris Christies presidential ambitions are in a lot of trouble. First he squandered his initial strength in national polls  he holds 6 to 7 percent of the vote among Republican contenders, down from about 20 percent before the scandal involving the closing of lanes to the George Washington Bridge.

title: An Embedded Photographer Empowers the Poor
description: Scenes of poverty are inescapable in a country like Bangladesh, where Western media and charities use them to generate outrage, sympathy and  sometimes  donations. That bothered Shehab Uddin, a former newspaper photographer in Bangladesh who knew there was more to the story than downtrodden people victimized by poverty, not to mention photojournalists.

title: More New Jobs Are in City Centers, While Employment Growth Shrinks in the Suburbs
description: For decades, most Americans working in metropolitan areas have gone to work outside city centers  in suburban office parks, stores or plants, not downtown skyscrapers. But as people increasingly choose to live in cities instead of outside them, employers are following.

title: V.A. Secretary Apologizes for Embellishing Military Record
description: Robert A. McDonald, the secretary of the Veterans Affairs Department, apologized on Monday for falsely claiming last month that he had served in the Special Forces.

title: Whats On TV Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) A LITTLE ROMANCE (1979) Lauren (Diane Lane, above right), a 13-year-old American living in Paris with her stepfather (Arthur Hill) and mother (Sally Kellerman)  who is currently enamored of a pretentious filmmaker (George De Marco)  falls in love with Daniel (Thelonious Bernard, center). He is a French film buff, and together they arrange a rendezvous under the Bridge of Sighs in Venice with the help of an aging pickpocket (Laurence Olivier, left). Lauren and Daniel are, I think, meant to be comic and appealing in their mixture of innocence and worldliness, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. Yet the film, directed by George Roy Hill, recalls most vividly the arch manner in which the Our Gang comedies worked  by having their child actors ape not the behavior of children but of grown-ups. Georges Delerue won an Oscar for best original score.

title: When Whites Get a Free Pass
description: NEW HAVEN  THE recent reunion show for the 40th anniversary of Saturday Night Live re-aired a portion of Eddie Murphys 1984 classic White Like Me skit, in which he disguised himself to appear Caucasian and quickly learned that when white people are alone, they give things to each other for free.

title: The Hamilton Experience
description: Every once in a while a piece of art brilliantly captures the glory, costs and ordeals of public life. Steven Spielbergs Lincoln did that. And so does Lin-Manuel Mirandas Hamilton, now playing at The Public Theater in New York.

title: Scientologys Chilling Effect
description: When I was at Fortune magazine in the 1990s, one of my colleagues was a reporter named Richard Behar. He had a special lock on his door, and he wouldnt even let the janitor in to empty his wastebasket. He used a secret phone, which he kept hidden in a desk drawer, so that calls made to sources couldnt be traced back to him.

title: Conspiracy Claims in Venezuela
description: Listening to embattled President Nicols Maduro of Venezuela ramble for hours about an international right-wing conspiracy to oust him, its clear that he would use any fabricated pretext to jail opposition leaders and crack down on dissent.

title: Fighting Back Against Climate Change
How to Develop New Antibiotics
description: THE bacteria are winning.

title: When the Best Sex Is Extramarital
description: I received a voice mail from a 40-something woman, Cynthia, who requested a late-evening session because she worked long hours at her law firm. She said that I was one of the few therapists she had Googled who seemed to have the expertise to help her. In recent years I have noticed that when potential patients Google me, they discover my university faculty profile, where I list as a research interest the psychology of infidelity. They also find a YouTube clip of an interview with me from a documentary on infidelity. Thanks to Google I am getting more patients looking for someone they think of as an infidelity expert.

title: Indonesian Maid Speaks Out About Abuse in Hong Kong
description: The markets on Po Hong Road that spill onto the sidewalks sell fresh meat, fresh fish, fresh vegetables  essentials for the nearly 4,000 kitchens that soar hundreds of feet above in the publicly subsidized Hong Kong housing estate called Beverly Garden.

description: This short documentary profiles a couple who spend their lives pursuing their passion for blowing things up.

description: Talking seriously about race and class can often feel difficult.

description: WASHINGTON  Gruesome killings by the Islamic State, terrorist attacks in Europe and tensions with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia are reshaping the early Republican presidential race, creating anxiety among party voters and sending potential candidates scrambling to outmuscle one another on foreign policy.

description: Nearly two dozen soldiers from an Army platoon were on patrol in a dangerous valley in southern Afghanistan when a motorcycle sped toward them, ignoring commands to stop.

title: Israeli Forces Kill Palestinian Man in West Bank Clashes
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli forces shot and killed a 19-year-old Palestinian man when clashes broke out during a military raid on a refugee camp in the Bethlehem area of the West Bank early on Tuesday, the military and local Palestinians said.

title: German Who Posed as Hitler Returns to Position in Anti-Immigrant Group Pegida
description: BERLIN  The co-founder of an anti-immigrant group in Germany that has denounced the supposed Islamization of Western Europe has resumed his position at the head of the movement, weeks after he stepped down amid outrage over images of him posing as Adolf Hitler.

title: Hindu Leader Is Criticized for Views on Mother Teresa
description: NEW DELHI  The head of a prominent Hindu organization came under criticism Tuesday for remarks he made about Mother Teresa, in which he said that the Nobel Peace Prize laureates service to the poor in India had been motivated by a desire to convert them to Christianity.

title: After Bailout Plan Approval, Greece Faces a Balancing Act
description: BRUSSELS  Eurozone finance ministers on Tuesday approved Greeces plan meant to ease the hardships created by its international bailout, extending that loan program by four more months.

title: Obama Proposal Recognizes How Retirement Saving Has Changed
description: Here is a short tale of how the way Americans save for retirement has changed over the last couple of generations. It helps explain what the Obama administration is up to with a new initiative this week:

title: Daily Report: Wall St. May Huddle With Law Firms for Cybersecurity
description: The threat of ever-larger online attacks is bringing together Wall Street banks and the big law firms that do work for them in an alliance that could result in some sharing of basic information about digital security issues, Matthew Goldstein reports.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Feb. 17-23, 2015
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Morning Agenda: Power Couple Ties Up S.E.C.
description: POWER COUPLE TIES UP S.E.C. | Mary Jo White, who leads the Securities and Exchange Commission, and her husband, John, who practices law at an elite old-guard firm, are a legal power couple that straddles Wall Street and Washington like few others, DealBooks Peter Eavis and Ben Protess write. But their careers can at times collide, creating headaches for the S.E.C. as it pursues wrongdoing in the nations financial markets, according to interviews with lawyers and a review of federal records.

title: Rahm Emanuel Forced Into Runoff in Bid for Second Term as Chicago Mayor
description: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel, who was easily elected mayor of this city four years ago, was dealt a setback Tuesday. Though he came in first among five candidates, Mr. Emanuel failed to seal a second term by winning support from enough voters to avoid a riskier runoff election this spring.

title: Twin Pole-Vaulters Reach the Height of Alikeness
description: BLACK SPRINGS, Ark.  Just off Highway 8, amid the cattle pastures, chicken houses and hog farms in these rolling hills, is Pole Vault Lane. Its short, gravelly path is decorated with pennants, and it leads to a metal building about half the length of a football field. It is a hangar of sorts, or, more accurately, an indoor runway designed to produce short but spectacular flight.

title: Today in Politics
description: Precampaign Costs Mounting, Clinton Gets a Silicon Valley Paycheck

title: British Lawmaker, Accused of Influence Peddling, Steps Down as Intelligence Panel Chairman
description: LONDON  After being caught in an undercover report, Malcolm Rifkind, a former British foreign secretary, said on Tuesday that he would resign as chairman of an influential parliamentary panel overseeing intelligence and would not run for re-election to Parliament in May.

title: With Right-to-Work Bill, Scott Walker Risks a New Labor Fight
description: Gov. Scott Walker won the nations attention four years ago by pushing to limit collective bargaining rights for most of Wisconsins public workers, but for months now, he has seemed to sidestep the possibility of any new moves against labor groups.

title: Words We Love Too Much
description: Perhaps hoping to disprove the clich that journalists hate math, we seem eager to sprinkle a couple of math-related terms as liberally as possible in our prose. Unfortunately, this casual usage is more likely to suggest fuzziness or even laziness than rigor and precision.

title: In Performance: Patrick Mulryan of Into the Woods
description: This weeks video features the actor Patrick Mulryan, with Matt Castle on piano, singing the number Giants in the Sky from the Fiasco Theaters production of the Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine musical Into the Woods. The show, directed by Noah Brody and Ben Steinfeld, is at the Roundabouts Laura Pels Theater through April 12.

title: Phantom Phiscal Crises
description: Matthew Klein takes on a subject dear to my heart  the mysterious, persistent fear that Japan and other countries that borrow in their own currencies could suddenly face a Greek-style fiscal crisis if bond investors lose confidence, and that this is a reason to raise taxes or cut benefits even in a depressed economy. I devoted my Mundell-Fleming lecture at the IMF to this topic, where I had this to say:

title: Deutsche Bank Hires Hewlett-Packard to Upgrade Systems
description: FRANKFURT  Deutsche Bank, acknowledging shortcomings in the way it manages digital information, said on Tuesday that it had hired Hewlett-Packard to modernize the software and computer systems used for its investment bank and other divisions that serve its biggest customers.

description: BERLIN  Private equity leaders made their case on Tuesday for investing in Europe despite concerns about the regions economy and a potential exit by Greece from the eurozone.

title: Buffalo Embraces Winters Chill
description: At Buffalos newest outdoor rink, Canalside, teenage couples skated hand in hand, while a few stumbling toddlers nearly pulled their parents down. From a pedestrian bridge above the ice, spectators drank Flying Bison beer and bit into hot sandwiches from nearby food trucks. Stereos pumped Bob Marley, although the tropical beat belied the 20-degree temperatures. All around the double-sized rink, market vendors under striped awnings sold jewelry, hockey sticks and sweatshirts printed with We Made Snow Famous and Buffalonians Never Say Die.

title: Office Depot Reports Narrower Loss in 4th Quarter
description: Office Depot, which is planning to merge with Staples, said Tuesday that it had narrowed its losses at the end of last year.

title: Restaurant Report: Green Street Smoked Meats in Chicago
description: Chicago does not want for meat in general, or the barbecued kind in particular. The city Carl Sandburg called the hog butcher for the world" boils over with stellar kielbasas and, at least on the South Side, Delta-style vinegar-forward barbecue. Theres even a mash-up of traditional barbecue and Eastern European meats called boilbecue (not recommended by this meat-eater).

title: Downtown Cincinnati Thrives as Riots Memories Recede

title: Juniper Networks Reaches Pact With Activist Hedge Fund
description: Juniper Networks, a networking equipment maker, announced on Tuesday that it would appoint two new directors to its board as part of a settlement with the activist hedge fund Elliott Management.

title: An Outpouring of Love and Onesies
description: Possibly because Im a guy, I never really thought too hard about giving people baby gifts. It was just something that did not often cross my mind. When one of my friends or family members said that they were having a baby, I might have halfheartedly found them something off their registry that wasnt too cheap, or just sent them a gift card, figuring that they may need it for diapers. If I found myself cruising the baby aisles of Target, it tended to be so overwhelming that I found the first age-appropriate toy I could, whether I thought the child could use it or not. Lets just say that gift receipts were key.

title: 1890: Arizonas Catastrophe
description: NEW YORK  The disaster at the dam on the Hassayampa River, near Prescott, Arizona, is the most fearful catastrophe in the history of the territory. The valley for miles below the dam was swept clean. The first intimation of the appalling disaster was a sound resembling thunder, and at the same instant a perpendicular wall of water, fully 50 feet high, came rushing down the narrow valley. The valley widens above Wickenburg, and much of the town lies upon lowlands close to the course of the stream, and it was almost certain that the vast body of water which rushed out of the reservoir had carried away many houses at that place.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 25, 1890

title: Review: Robert Christgau Reflects on His Career as a Rock Critic
description: Heres a cardinal rule of book criticism: Never blame someone for writing a book thats different from the one you wanted him to write. But Robert Christgaus memoir, Going Into the City: Portrait of a Critic as a Young Man, is so far from what I wanted that I cant pretend Im not crestfallen.

title: James Baldwin Denounced Richard Wrights Native Son As a Protest Novel. Was He Right?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Ayana Mathis and Pankaj Mishra discuss James Baldwins reaction to Richard Wrights Native Son, which was published 75 years ago.

title: 1965: State of Siege Is Declared
description: GUATEMALA CITY  Col. Enrique Peralta Azurdias government suspended the constitution and decreed a state of siege throughout Guatemala today [Feb. 24] because of what was called an attempt to overthrow his regime. Col. Peralta said several groups of armed men have attacked civilians and authorities as part of a widespread plan to spread terror. The national radio broadcast the state of siege decree, saying that it would be in effect as long as necessary. There was no immediate information as to who the plotters Col. Peralta referred to might be.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 25, 1965

title: Scores of Syrian Christians Kidnapped by Islamic State
description: ISTANBUL  Islamic State militants swept into several Assyrian Christian villages in northeastern Syria in recent days, taking scores of hostages, including both civilians and fighters, according to numerous interviews with residents and representatives of the many factions fighting in the area.

description: WASHINGTON  Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told Congress on Tuesday that the central bank is pleased with recent economic growth but convinced there is room for improvement and still pondering when to start raising interest rates.

description: Guests wont find a hotel magazine, laden with ads and self-promotion, in the 20 Rosewood Hotels & Resorts worldwide. Instead, the small luxury chain has launched an online quarterly that management says captures the brands personality without cluttering it with sales pitches.

description: FEW of us are satisfied with how we sleep; we all want more sleep and better sleep in the hopes of improving our minds and bodies during our waking hours.

description: Netflix, the company that in short order has progressed from a mail-order DVD rental service to a streaming site to a producer of original television content (House of Cards, Orange Is the New Black), announced Tuesday that it would distribute a new film starring Paul Reubens as the memorable 1980s TV character Pee-wee Herman.

title: Why Does Cuomo Want to Shutter New Yorks Doctor Report Card Site?
description: You need a good doctor. You try the Internet. It is baffling. The rankings seem better suited to restaurantsthree stars, four stars. Comments from patients can be nothing short of ridiculous. The physicians picture is nice, but it all has the feel of advertising.

title: Pebble Watch Goes Color on Kickstarter
description: When Apple unveiled the Apple Watch last year, the company chose to do so in the same spaceit showed off the Macintosh computer 30 years earlier.

title: In France, a Baby Switch and a Lesson in Maternal Love
description: GRASSE, France  When Sophie Serrano finally held her daughter, Manon, in her arms after the newborn, suffering from jaundice, had been placed under artificial light, she was taken aback by the babys full head of glossy hair.

title: At Gucci, a Messy Exit for One Designer Opens an Unlikely Door for Another
description: Patrizio di Marco wasnt about to go out quietly.

title: Smutty Books for Smart People
description: Trashy novels arent new, but thanks to a highbrow approach to Harlequin tropes, the people who buy them might be. This month, the online art magazine Triple Canopy is set to release Headless, a salacious murder mystery that reads like Dan Brown while name-checking Georges Bataille. Delving into full-on erotica, Badlands Unlimited  the book press established five years ago by the 2014 Hugo Boss Prize-winning artist Paul Chan  will publish a series of three novellas titled We Love Lucy, How to Train Your Virgin and God, I Dont Even Know Your Name, the story of an artist who, fresh out of rehab, meets a Finnish curator through a dating app called Bangly. Ideas about what sex is, and what pleasure can be, are changing, as they ought to, says Chan. We wanted to publish works that respond to this new spirit.

title: Pensions Haunt Christie 4 Years After Being Fixed
description: TRENTON  Four years ago, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey signed bipartisan legislation to overhaul public employee pensions and declared he had fixed the problem that was crushing state and local governments across the country with enormous debts. He held up New Jersey as a model.

title: Private Equity Leaders Focusing on Returning Money to Investors
description: BERLIN  Private equity firms are shying away from overly risky investments as the price of potential acquisitions remains high, a panel of industry leaders said on Tuesday.

title: Shire, Maker of Binge-Eating Drug Vyvanse, First Marketed the Disease
description: The retired tennis player Monica Seles spent this month making the rounds of television talk shows, appearing on everything from Good Morning America to The Dr. Oz Show to share her personal struggle with binge eating.

title: At London Fashion Week, the End of Austerity
description: LONDON  Austerity may be the watchword of Prime Minister David Camerons administration and a theme of the Tories electoral platform (see recent campaign slogans: A Britain living within its means, Lets stay on the road to a stronger economy). But British fashion designers, it seems, have not gotten the memo. Or they have, and disagree. (They would not be the only ones.)

title: Court Clears Mubarak Official
description: A Cairo court on Tuesday acquitted former President Hosni Mubaraks longtime interior minister of the last of several criminal charges that have kept him behind bars, opening a potential path to his release.

title: Film Scripts by Harold Pinter to Become Radio Plays
description: LONDON  Two film scripts by Harold Pinter, never made into movies, have been adapted as radio plays by the BBCs Radio 4. The first, Victory, based on a novel by Joseph Conrad, will be broadcast on Saturday; The Dreaming Child, based on a short story by Karen Blixen, of Out of Africa fame, will be aired on March 7. (According to the BBC 4 website, most programs can be accessed from anywhere in the world.)

title: Whose Eyelash Is This?
description: Researchers have discovered that among mammals, the optimal eyelash length is one-third the width of the eye. Can you guess what animal these eyelashes belong to?

title: Nordic Cuisine Moves In to Long Island City
description: Headliner

title: In Privacy Update, Reddit Tightens Restrictions on Nude Photos
description: For nearly a decade, Reddit, the huge online message board, has been known for its freewheeling stance on letting its users govern themselves. That has resulted in an outpouring of user-generated content  for better or, sometimes, for worse  that attracts nearly 160 million regular users to the site.

title: In a New Memoir, the Famously Pithy Dean of American Rock Critics Goes Long
description: As the half-jokingly self-designated Dean of American Rock Critics, Robert Christgau has appeared to readers in bite-size chunks for well over four decades. Throughout his storied career  he is best known for his 35 years as a rock critic and editor at The Village Voice, where he founded the annual Pazz & Jop poll and perfected the letter-graded rock album capsule review  Christgaus name has become synonymous with pith; the album reviews he has written regularly since 1969 rarely exceed 150 words. (Christgau says he must have cribbed the format from the longtime New York Daily News writer Kay Gardella, but claims to be the inventor of the good capsule review.) The memoir he releases today, then, represents new territory in more ways than one; and on the phone to discuss it, the famously cantankerous Christgau is in a good mood.

title: The Uninsured Rate Is Falling
description: Heres more evidence that the Affordable Care Act is working.

title: Yellen Says Fed Can Be Patient
description: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said at a congressional hearing that the Federal Reserve was in no hurry to raise interest rates.

title: Sony Names Thomas Rothman to Succeed Amy Pascal
description: LOS ANGELES  In another jolt to its old order, Sony on Tuesday said that Thomas E. Rothman would take over as chairman of its motion picture group, an appointment that risks new turmoil on Sonys lot, but represents a Hollywood-style comeback for the executive.

title: Jenny Lind, Taylor Swift, and Me
description: First things first: I am a big Arcade Fire fan, but I had nothing to do with Will Butlers new song about the Greek debt crisis. I will, however, be on a panel at SXSW with the Butler brothers among others. And Im having an economists version of fun by looking at some not entirely random aspects of the economics of music.

Semilla
description: Vegetable-Forward Tasting Menus in Williamsburg, Brooklyn

title: Restaurant Review: Semilla in Williamsburg, Brooklyn
description: I came up with my nature-preserve theory of tasting menus while eating a cabbage sandwich at Semilla, a new restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, across the street from Jacks Cancellation Shoes and Rachels Corset Discount Center (specializing in hard to fit sizes).

title: Hollande Discusses Kidnapping in Yemen
description: President Franois Hollande of France confirmed that a Frenchwoman had been kidnapped in the Yemeni capital, Sana.

title: Flames Rookie Embarks on a Welcome-Back Tour
description: When Kevin Hayes, now a Rangers forward, was a sophomore at Boston College in the summer of 2011, he was the tour guide for Johnny Gaudreaus campus visit.

title: Last Thoughts on a First Season
description: The Hollywood Reporter just published a list of films that could prove Oscar worthy or baity in the coming year, but the Bagger cant bring herself to read it. After three months of increasingly fevered speculation over who might win best picture, director and actor; of controversies over campaign tactics and stories told; of exhaustive poring over the tics and proclivities of 6,000 anonymous members of what remains an old boys club, its fair to say that anyone who pays much attention to this stuff, let alone covers it, deserves a break.

title: U.S. Wont File Charges in Trayvon Martin Killing
description: MIAMI  The Justice Department on Tuesday closed its investigation into the shooting death three years ago of Trayvon Martin, the unarmed black teenager in a hoodie who became a symbol of racial profiling and the face of a protest movement, without filing hate-crime charges against the gunman, George Zimmerman.

title: Russia Heightens Dispute With Ukraine Over Natural Gas
description: MOSCOW  As Russia warned Ukraine on Tuesday that it could run out of natural gas within two days because of a dispute over payments, Britain said it was sending military trainers to aid Ukrainian forces while European diplomats labored to patch up a flagging peace agreement in eastern Ukraine.

title: Politician Urges Japans Premier to Stand by World War II Apologies
description: TOKYO  The Japanese politician who issued a landmark official apology to women forced to work in wartime brothels urged Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on Tuesday to stand by Japans previous apologies for the countrys wartime agression, and not pull Japan too far to the nationalist right.

title: Putting a Price on Simon Kuznetss Nobel in Economics
description: James D. Watsons sold for $4.76 million while the one owned by William Randal Cremer, a member of Parliament and labor activist, fetched just $17,000.

title: A Three-Bedroom Villa in the Tuscan Countryside
description: Between Florence and Arezzo, the house, which has nearly five terraced acres and a pool, is on the market for $2,153,987.

title: Comcast Reports Small Profit Gain in the Face of Regulatory Uncertainty
description: Uncertainty regarding new strict rules governing the Internet as well as the prospects for its proposed merger with Time Warner Cable hung over Comcast on Tuesday, as the media conglomerate reported fourth-quarter profits that were up only slightly compared with the period last year.

title: Redesigned 20-Euro Note Introduced by E.C.B.
description: FRANKFURT  The euro may be one of the most embattled currencies on the planet, but at least it will soon feature some of the coolest technology.

title: At the 2015 New Museum Triennial, A High-Tech Take on Nude Sculpture
description: The Brooklyn-based sculptor Frank Benson is one of the only hometown artists included in the New Museums thoroughly international 2015 Triennial exhibition. Another is the muse for his new piece, the emerging downtown legend Juliana Huxtable, who as an artist in her own right will also contribute a series of photographic self-portraits to the show. Bensons piece, titled Juliana (2015), is a hyper-realistic, life-size 3D print of the transgender beauty, the third in a series of figurative sculptures whose previous subjects were a nude man and clothed woman. Draped horizontally on a plinth with fingers pinched in a Cleopatran gesture, Huxtable was originally meant to be immortalized in one of her signature looks before Benson, apprehensively, asked her to pose nude. I was nervous of what she might think of that, he says, so I sent her this intense email full of historical references. And though she is without clothing, her personal style is retained in the braids Benson painstakingly drew in a digital drafting program and the green makeup spray-painted onto the statues skin. The artwork stands as a token of how virtuosity and virtuality come together in the digital age. I want the sculpture to exist as a completely finished entity inside the computer, Benson says. The 3D model is its ultimate version and the print is the real-world manifestation of it.

title: Hitachi Deal Is a Signal that Italy is Open for Deal-Making
description: Hitachis $2.2 billion deal signals that Italy is open for mergers and acquisitions.

title: Filing Away Gmail Messages

title: Little Sprout Grows Up
description: Back when the chef Amanda Cohen was running her restaurant, Dirt Candy, out of an East Village nook that felt only slightly more commodious than a gopher hole, she received a call from someone representing a famous man who wanted to eat her food.

title: French Development Worker Is Kidnapped in Yemen
description: PARIS  A Frenchwoman working on a World Bank project was kidnapped Tuesday with her Yemeni translator in front of a ministry office in Sana, according to security officials there and President Franois Hollande of France, who took the rare step of speaking publicly about the abductions.

description: DAKAR, Senegal  An American missionary was kidnapped on Monday from a school in central Nigeria in an area prone to kidnappings for ransom, officials said Tuesday.

title: Tough Talk From European Commissioner About U.S. Tech Companies
description: LONDON  American tech companies have long suspected that Europe is out to get them. They might be right.

title: In Tepid Housing Market, Builders Cater to Desires of Well-Off
description: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa.  Lisa Gray spent a few months searching for a home that would span the generations, one where her two sons would want to bring friends throughout their teenage years and that her aging parents could navigate with ease.

title: Taylor Swift Donates $50,000 to New York City Schools
description: Taylor Swift knows how to ingratiate herself with skeptics.

title: Vanity Clause
description: One writer argues that the rise of over-grooming may be neutering his generation of men.

title: McConnell Proposes Two-Vote Solution to Break Homeland Security Impasse
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, on Tuesday offered a path to avert a partial shutdown of the Department of Homeland Security, saying he would allow a vote on a bill solely to fund the agency, followed by a second vote on legislation that would halt President Obamas 2014 executive actions on immigration.

title: Hamilton Will Get Broadway Stage
description: In a rarity for New York theater, the artists behind the red-hot musical Hamilton won out on Tuesday over commercial concerns about ticket sales and Tony Awards that usually carry the day.

title: Federal Officials Return Tiepolo Painting and Etruscan Bronze to Italy
description: Federal law enforcement authorities in New York announced Tuesday that they had returned to Italy two pieces of that countrys cultural heritage stolen decades ago before being brought to the United States: a painting attributed to the 18th-century artist Giambattista Tiepolo and an ancient Etruscan bronze statuette of Herakles.

title: Goldman Seeks to Raise Fund to Buy Energy Sector Debt
description: Wall Street money helped fuel the North American energy boom in recent years. Now that oil prices have collapsed, Wall Street is again looking for ways to profit.

title: Czech Gunman Kills 8 People and Then Himself at Restaurant
description: PRAGUE  A 62-year-old resident of the southeastern Czech town of Uhersky Brod burst into a restaurant near his home on Tuesday and began shooting, killing eight people in the lunchtime crowd before turning his gun on himself.

title: Obama Vetoes Bill Pushing Pipeline Approval
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday rejected an attempt by lawmakers to force his hand on the Keystone XL oil pipeline, using his veto pen to sweep aside one of the first major challenges to his authority by the new Republican Congress.

title: Annotated Version of Hitlers Mein Kampf to Be Published Next Year
description: BERLIN  Researchers are on track to finish roughly 4,000 annotations and historical notes to accompany a new German-language edition of Hitlers manifesto, Mein Kampf, to be published in January 2016, after the existing copyright expires.

title: A City Braces for Its Ballpark to Go the Way of Its Mills
description: The icy reminder of a baseball truth has blown down from New England, down from a Rhode Island city forever described as gritty, or struggling, or, more politely, challenged. No doubt you have seen signs for this brown-brick metropolis along the interstate, on your way to someplace else: Pawtucket, population 71,000.

description: Keith Olbermann was suspended Tuesday from hosting his ESPN2 program for the rest of the week for churlish remarks he made about Penn State on Twitter.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  Meg Whitman, Hewlett-Packards chief executive, says she thinks her company did almost everything well in its most recent fiscal quarter. Except make money.

title: Review: Farewell to Hollywood, the Last Years of a Budding Filmmaker
description: Rendering a verdict on the cinematic merits of Farewell to Hollywood seems beside the point or even inappropriate; the movies key attribute is that it exists. The co-director, Regina Nicholson, died of cancer at 19 in 2012. She is shown expressing a wish that the documentary about this period in her life survive and be fantastic.

title: Grandmaster Sachs
description: With his handcrafted, fully functioning boomboxes, the artist Tom Sachs celebrates a bygone analog era, and reflects on whats been lost now that all the worlds music can reside in our pockets.

title: Critics Notebook: New York City Ballet Wraps Up a Memorable Winter Season
description: Balletomanes know how druglike their special brand of dance can be. Energy and beauty flow from the spectacle onstage; in the audience, perceptions of time, space and human potential feel profoundly changed. The need to follow performances becomes akin to addiction; and the end of a season brings withdrawal symptoms.

title: Vial of Winston Churchills Blood to Be Sold at Auction
description: LONDON  Almost anything linked to Winston Churchill can be collectible, right down to the butts of his cigars. But it is hard to imagine an artifact rarer or more intimate than the one scheduled to be auctioned on March 12: a vial of his blood.

title: Male Statuary, Illustrated
description: A series of paintings by Leanne Shapton based on the book The Nude: A Study in Ideal Form.

title: Review: In Pam Tanowitzs Broken Story, Wit Comes Full Circle
description: In several ways, Pam Tanowitzs Broken Story (wherein there is no ecstasy) is accurately titled. The parenthetical phrase might mislead, though. The work, which had its premiere at the Guggenheim Museum on Sunday as part of the Works & Process series, does have droll fun tweaking dance traditions of romantic fulfillment. But Ms. Tanowitz and her collaborators maintain such a high level of imagination that what is fragmented by design can be experienced as a satisfying, organic whole. Ecstatic is a good word for how it made me feel.
