description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Bobby Jindal on Obamacare, ISIS and the Big Gulp
description: Best Applause Line: President Obama has shown himself incapable of being our commander in chief, said the governor of Louisiana.

title: Review: In The Lazarus Effect, Young Scientists Play God
description: The researchers in The Lazarus Effect devise a serum that resurrects the dead by stimulating brain activity. The film itself seems best watched with as few neurons firing as possible.

title: Spare Times Listings for Feb. 27-March 5
description: Museums and Sites

title: First Draft Focus: Heeding the Countdown Clock
description: [Photo: View on Instagram.]

title: Spare Times for Children for Feb. 27-March 5
description: Kids Food Festival

title: Senate Panel Clears Auto Safety Bill to Reward Whistle-Blowers
description: WASHINGTON  A Senate panel on Thursday cleared its first auto safety bill stemming from last years record number of recalls.

title: Review: In  71, Young, Green and Behind Enemy Lines
description: In 71, an excitingly jumpy, finely calibrated chase movie about a British soldier caught behind enemy lines, the director Yann Demange goes from zero to 100 in the blink of an eye. The soldier is played by Jack OConnell, last seen being brutalized (in more ways than one) in Unbroken, the Angelina Jolie biopic about Louis Zamperini. That movie proved a bad fit for Mr. OConnell, who never put down roots in the character, an Olympian turned World War II captive, because Ms. Jolie couldnt or wouldnt let him. By contrast, Mr. OConnell runs away with 71, in which his characters every emotional, psychological and physical hurdle makes for kinetic cinema.

title: 101-Year-Old Veteran Who Survived Home Invasion Dies in Canada
description: The 101-year-old war veteran who was tied up and robbed in his Ottawa home in December, then left to suffocate with a plastic bag over his head, only to free himself and call the police, has died of natural causes, Canadian news outlets reported on Thursday.

title: Bin Laden Aide Convicted of Conspiracy in 1998 East Africa Bombings
description: A Saudi who was accused of being one of Osama bin Ladens earliest and most trusted lieutenants was convicted on Thursday of joining a global conspiracy to kill Americans that included Al Qaedas deadly 1998 bombings of two United States Embassies in East Africa.

title: Review: Five Times in One Night, at Ensemble Studio Theater
description: There were ample giggles throughout the first three parts of Chiara Atiks Five Times in One Night, a series of comedy sketches with a lewd title and a tender heart at the Ensemble Studio Theater. But it was only in the fourth scene that wails and whimpers of pained recognition rang out. I saw women watching with hands over their mouths and one man who appeared to have shut his eyes entirely.

title: Carlyles 3 Founders Got $800 Million Haul in 2014
description: The three founders of the private equity giant Carlyle Group received more than $800 million combined in 2014, a regulatory filing on Thursday showed.

title: Review: In The Salvation, a Hero Lays Waste, Western Style (Danish, Too)
description: A luridly beautiful, lavishly violent western, The Salvation takes place in an America shaped less by history than by the legacies of some of its chroniclers, from Sergio Leone to Clint Eastwood to Paul Thomas Anderson. Set in a nameless, dusty patch of the Southwest apparently forsaken by God as well as the law, it spins a far-fetched tale of a not-so-simple Danish homesteader, Jon (Mads Mikkelsen), turned avenger. Yes, there will be blood, as well as Eva Green as Madelaine, whose corset cups runneth over and tongue was once ripped out by her Indian captors.

title: This Weeks Movies | Feb. 27, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review 71, The Hunting Ground and Maps to the Stars.

title: Canada: Survivor of Home Invasion Dies
description: The 101-year-old war veteran who was tied up and robbed in his Ottawa home in December, then left to suffocate with a plastic bag over his head, only to free himself and call the police, has died of natural causes, Canadian news outlets reported Thursday. The attack on the veteran, Ernest Ct, attracted national attention. An investigation led to the arrest of a suspect, Ian Bush, who was also charged last week with a 2007 triple murder involving a break-in and suffocation with plastic bags.

title: Movie Review: 71
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews 71.

title: Movie Review: Maps to the Stars
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Maps to the Stars.

title: Movie Review: The Hunting Ground
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Hunting Ground.

title: Review: In Bluebird, Momentary Distraction Sets Off a Chain of Misery
description: Blown by wind, kissed by the snow, all thats left is the dark below. Heard over the end titles of Lance Edmandss Bluebird, those words from the Fleetwoods 1961 hit Tragedy distill the films desolate mood. Set during winter in Millinocket, a fading Maine logging town, this polar vortex of a movie opens with a quotation from Thoreaus The Maine Woods that evokes human helplessness in the face of chaotic natural forces. Then it segues to shots of snow-covered logs transported by conveyor belt for conversion into pulp.

title: In Unusual Step, Regulators Invite Public to Open Meeting on Bank Merger
description: The deal seemed all but done when the CIT Group, a lender to small and midsize businesses, announced in July that it was acquiring OneWest, a regional bank in California.

title: Review: In Eastern Boys, a Train-Station Pickup Gone Wrong
description: Eastern Boys, the most compelling film to be shown at last years Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series at Lincoln Center and just now getting an American release, is impossible to shoehorn into a generic box. This story of a lonely middle-aged businessman whose involvement with a scrawny rent boy he meets at the Gare du Nord in Paris explores interlocking themes of sexuality, immigration and power dynamics with a cleareyed sensitivity and refuses to demonize even its shadiest characters.

title: Global Deal to Release New Albums on Fridays
description: For music fans in Britain, new albums come out on Mondays. In the United States, they typically hit stores on Tuesdays. In Japan, its Wednesdays.

title: Review: Young Bodies Heal Quickly Follows Brothers on the Run
description: Boasting the hectic aggression of a silent slapstick short  without the silence  Young Bodies Heal Quickly pants to keep up with its rambunctious antiheroes. This debut feature by Andrew T. Betzer joins a Mutt-and-Jeff pair of brothers on the lam as they ping-pong around the Maryland countryside and across genres: road movie, family drama, even war film.

title: Judge in Batistas Insider Trading Trial in Brazil Is Removed From Case
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The Brazilian businessman Eike Batista won a court victory of sorts on Thursday when the judge who had been presiding over his trial was removed from the case after he was filmed driving Mr. Batistas seized Porsche.

title: Rebels Accuse Saudis of Fueling Unrest to Divide Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  The leader of the Houthi rebel group here, in an unusually combative speech Thursday that reflected frustration by the rebel movement at its deepening isolation, accused Saudi Arabia, Yemens powerful neighbor, of financing armed opponents and trying to divide the country.

title: Review: The Widowmaker, a Heart Care Documentary
description: By now the average health care consumer perhaps understands that treatment recommendations from a doctor may be influenced by research grants, financial interests and other personal entanglements. The Widowmaker, a documentary by Patrick Forbes, takes a lengthy look at that phenomenon as it relates to heart attacks, promoting the coronary calcium scan, a noninvasive procedure that faced years of resistance because the medical establishment preferred the surgically implanted stent. The films only problem is that it may leave you so skeptical that youre not sure youre getting the unbiased story on the scan, either.

title: Amazon Hires Jay Carney, Former Obama Press Secretary
description: Amazon, a technology company obsessed with secrecy, is hiring a former press secretary for President Obama, whose administration has been widely criticized for its aggressive leak investigations.

title: Review: In Futuro Beach, a Haunted Lifeguard Searches for Peace
description: Within minutes of opening, Futuro Beach has followed death with sex and the loss of a friend with the gain of a lover. None of these events feel particularly momentous, however, in a film that ravishes the eye but keeps the heart at arms length.

title: Review: Out of the Dark, With Julia Stiles and Scott Speedman
description: The sweat of three writers and the acting chops of Stephen Rea still dont come close to earning Out of the Dark a passing grade. Derivative and devoid of tension, this stagy first feature from the Spanish director Llus Qulez mystifies solely on account of its R rating. When a movie this lacking in sex and scares can share a rating with the Saw franchise, the entire system announces its irrelevance.

title: Dutch Offer Preview of Net Neutrality
description: THE HAGUE  When Bruno Leenders takes the 50-minute train ride to Amsterdam, he likes to stream blues and funk music through his smartphone. At home, Mr. Leenders, a Dutch technology consultant, watches Steven Seagal action movies on Netflix. Between meetings, he dashes off a few emails.

title: Ariel Camacho, Lead Singer of Los Plebes del Rancho, Dies at 22
description: MEXICO CITY  Ariel Camacho, the lead singer of the popular norteo group Los Plebes del Rancho, died in a car accident early Wednesday on a highway near the Mexican state of Sinaloa. He was 22.

title: Obama Promotes Benefits of Trade Deals to Workers and Smaller Businesses
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, facing an uphill climb in persuading Congress to grant him the authority to complete significant trade deals, sought to ease concerns on Thursday that such agreements would help corporations at the expense of American workers.

title: U.N. Official Seeks Havens for Syrians
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations high commissioner for refugees said Thursday that European countries must accept more Syrian refugees to dissuade them from boarding overcrowded boats for a perilous journey across the Mediterranean Sea to escape the war in Syria as the level of despair rises.

title: After a Stirring Introduction, Chase Headley Hopes for a Steady Follow-Up Season
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As Alex Rodriguez stood a few feet away and signed autographs for dozens of clamoring fans on Thursday, Chase Headley skipped down the steps of the dugout, deposited his bat and helmet, and grabbed a glove before heading to the outfield. He did so all but unnoticed.

title: Why FIFA Made Deal With Fox for 2026 Cup
description: When FIFA sold the 2026 World Cup rights in the United States to Fox Sports and Telemundo this month, the announcement came with few details and no explanation for its timing.

title: 4 Different Turnaround Tales at Retailers Sears, Kohls, Gap and J.C. Penney
description: Four retailers, four turnaround bids  and they could not be more different.

title: These New York Tourists Plans: A Play, Then a Power Play
description: The athletic-looking group of men at Jersey Boys on Wednesday consisted of Arizona Coyotes players enjoying a day off. The 6-foot-2 Swede taking selfies in the N.H.L. store in Midtown was the Arizona defenseman Oliver Ekman-Larsson. Tables at Mr. Chow in TriBeCa and Del Friscos Grille near Rockefeller Center were recently filled by professional hockey players, some on their way to The Book of Mormon.

title: Secret Marijuana Farm Beneath Brooklyn Cherry Factory Leaves Many Mysteries
description: Arthur Mondellas alternate life was buried behind a roll-down gate, behind a fleet of fancy cars, behind a pair of closet doors, behind a set of button-controlled steel shelves, behind a fake wall and down a ladder in a hole in a bare concrete floor.

title: Rivals Christie and Walker Find Fortunes Reversed as CPAC Opens
description: OXON HILL, Md.  In the early stages of the 2016 Republican presidential primary, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is the hot property, his poll numbers rising and the chatter from activists and contributors growing steadily more positive. Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is the mirror opposite, his political stock falling along with his standing in surveys of Republicans.

title: Historians Pore Over ISIS Video of Smashed Statues for Clues to Whats Been Lost
description: Confronted with the latest video news release from Islamic State militants in Iraq, which shows jihadists taking sledgehammers and electric drills to ancient statuary in the city of Mosul, historians and archaeologists spent much of Thursday studying the footage for clues as to what, exactly, had been lost.

title: U.S. Push for Abstinence in Africa Is Seen as Failure Against H.I.V.
description: SEATTLE  The $1.3 billion that the United States government has spent since 2005 encouraging Africans to avoid AIDS by practicing abstinence and fidelity did not measurably change sexual behavior and was largely wasted, according to a study presented on the last day of an AIDS conference here.

title: An Immodest Proposal Rankles a Capital Known for Modesty
description: OTTAWA  You can make out Canadians reputation for modesty in their capital, a city that has largely avoided erecting anything you might call monumental. None of Ottawas landmarks are built on the grand scale of, say, the Arc de Triomphe or the Washington Monument  not even the national war memorial or the tower of the main Parliament building in the city center.

title: Move to Ban a Bullet Adds to Its Appeal
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas administration has proposed banning the manufacture and sale of one of the most popular bullets used in AR-15 semiautomatic rifles, a move that has enraged gun-rights advocates and caused a run on the ammunition at gun shops across the country.

title: Practicing in the Dark, Some Early Starters Grumble at the Honda Classic
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  An hour before his scheduled tee time, Ben Crane stood over a putt on the practice green while his caddie, Joel Stock, lined up behind him and used his smartphone to shed a little light on the situation. Only by the glow of Stocks phone was Crane able to see the hole.

title: Devils Send Jaromir Jagr to Panthers for Two Draft Picks
description: The Devils traded Jaromir Jagr to the Florida Panthers on Thursday for two draft picks.

title: Review: An Octoroon, a Branden Jacobs-Jenkins Comedy About Race
description: Walking on a stage covered with cotton balls is a tricky business. Its all too easy to slip into a pratfall. And forget about running or dancing or hopping like a bunny, as the characters sometimes unwisely attempt in An Octoroon, Branden Jacobs-Jenkinss coruscating comedy of unresolved history, which opened on Thursday night at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.

title: The Pandas Thumb
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Wow, talk about a high price of admission. I worked hard to get a toehold in Julian Lims Friday 62-word puzzle, but theres always a way, isnt there? Theres not much sense in having a puzzle no one can solve.

title: A Pageant for People as Much as for Dogs
description: Breeders know that although clothes cant make a champion, they can make sure your pup catches the judges eye.

title: Kobalt, Music Services Company, to Announce $60 Million in New Investment
description: One result of the spread of digital music around the world is an explosion in the amount of data generated from all those billions of clicks and streams  and a resulting need to follow all this information accurately.

title: Police Sergeants Union and New York City Reach Contract Deal
description: New York City has reached a contract agreement with the sergeants union, the latest signpost in Mayor Bill de Blasios bid to move beyond the police conflict that recently consumed his administration.

title: Testifying in His Own Defense, Terror Suspect Starts Strong Before Faltering
description: Abid Naseer, charged with terrorism, presented himself on Wednesday and Thursday as a studious, middle-class Pakistani, a suburban teenager who enjoyed American movies and was a semiprofessional cricket player.

title: Scenes From the Conservative Political Action Conference
description: The conference opened on Thursday outside Washington.

title: Stolen Picasso Work Is Seized in Newark
description: A Picasso painting missing from Paris for more than a decade resurfaced in the United States, where it had been shipped under false pretenses as a $37 holiday-themed art craft.

title: Aunt Charged in Beating Death of Brooklyn Boy, 3
description: The aunt of a 3-year-old Brooklyn boy was arrested and charged with manslaughter on Thursday after the medical examiners office ruled that the child had been beaten to death.

title: Terry Collins Sets Aside Cheerleading for Measured Tone
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The 2015 Mets officially convened for the first time Thursday. Matt Harvey and David Wright were back and healthy. Bobby Parnell was on his way back. And optimism was in abundance, although it often is at the start of spring training, no matter how strong or weak a team might be.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 26, 2015
Rangers Victory Pleases a Coach, but Not His Son
description: The Rangers assistant coach Ulf Samuelsson was reviewing scouting reports on the Coyotes on Wednesday afternoon when a phone call interrupted him. On the line was his younger son, Henrik, who told him, You better throw another guy in the loop there.

title: New York International Childrens Film Festival
description: Images from films in the festival.

title: Irving Kahn, Oldest Active Wall Street Investor, Dies at 109
description: Irving Kahn, who made his first stock trade in June 1929  turning a tidy profit from the stock market crash four months later  and persevered for more than eight decades to become Wall Streets oldest living active professional investor, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 109.

title: Appellate Ruling Supports a Police Whistle-Blower in New York
description: In a free-speech case that could bolster whistle-blowers, a federal appeals court ruled on Thursday in favor of a New York City police officer who said his commanders retaliated against him after he complained to them about what he believed to be a quota system that resulted in unjustified stops and arrests.

title: Review: In Focus, a Grifter (Will Smith) as Life Coach
description: A silky high-end caper about a pair of good-looking con artists, Focus is a movie blessedly free of self-importance. It constructs a seductive fantasy world out of actual places (New Orleans, Buenos Aires) and milieus (Super Bowl skyboxes, Formula One racing) and generously grants V.I.P. access to the audience. You may be a few steps behind as the big scams unfold, but you feel more like a player than a sucker. The preposterousness of the story doesnt seem like a rip-off, since the twists in the plot, for the most part, pay off nicely.

title: In Trip to Past, a False Confession Claim Meets Skepticism of Another Sort
description: The video monitor switched off. Seated on the witness stand, Johnny Hincapie, 42, took off his eyeglasses and began to weep. Everyone around him in the seventh-floor courtroom in Manhattan fell silent. After 40 seconds or so, a phone rang, and a court clerk answered, whispering, Part 73. The sobbing continued. Mr. Hincapie had just finished watching a video of himself at age 18, confessing to being part of a group that had mugged a family of tourists in a Midtown Manhattan subway station and killed the valiant son who had resisted.

title: The Sake Evangelist
description: Gordon Heady likens the taste of American sake to jet fuel, something he intends to change by becoming the countrys first master brewer. The Portland native was introduced to rice wine in college  the Japanese students he tutored in English paid him in bottles  and in 2012, he visited the southern island of Kyushu and fell in love with the 316-year-old brewery Wakatakeya Shuzo. Heady, who speaks about sake with reverence  its the drink of the gods  has since returned as an apprentice for about six months each year during brewing season. The brewers are wizards who use fermentation to bring rice to its highest purpose, he says. Fittingly, the blend he brews there  with notes of cooked citrus and wet wool  is called A Zen Ai Koshu, or Love.

title: Word of the Day | optional
description: optional  \p-shnl, -sh-nl\  adjective

title: William Dieterles Syncopation on DVD: Bending Notes and Jazz History
description: Motion pictures and jazz were both born around the dawn of the 20th century. But did Hollywood ever get the music right? Take Syncopation (1942), a snappily titled, wildly ambitious jazz chronicle that might be the last thing youd expect from Warner Bros. German-born workhorse, William Dieterle (1893-1972).

title: Joel Potrykuss Film Buzzard Is Inspired by Dead-End Jobs
description: Marty, the abrasive antihero of Buzzard, is not out to win employee of the month  quite the opposite. A temporary worker in the mortgage department of a Midwestern bank, he closes his checking account and opens a new one to take advantage of a $50 promotional offer. He returns office supplies for profit. After cutting himself in a poorly conceived attempt to attach Freddy Krueger blades to a Nintendo Power Glove, he fakes an injury at work to get the medical costs covered.

title: Winners of Pictures of the Year International
description: Daniel Berehulak, a freelance photographer for The New York Times, was named Photographer of the Year in the reportage category of the Pictures of the Year International contest. Brad Vest, of the Memphis Commercial Appeal, was named Newspaper Photographer of the Year.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 11:55 A.M. (MoreMax) MOONRISE KINGDOM (2012) In this Wes Anderson tale, 12-year-old Suzy (Kara Hayward) and her soul mate, Sam (Jared Gilman), fall in love and run away, while on an island, sending the adults in charge  Suzys parents (the Bishops, played by Bill Murray and Frances McDormand), Scout Master Ward (Edward Norton) and Captain Sharp (Bruce Willis)  into a panic as a storm approaches. Written by Mr. Anderson and Roman Coppola (they worked together several times before), Moonrise Kingdom breezes along with a beautifully coordinated admixture of droll humor, deadpan and slapstick, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. But, she added, as in all of Mr. Andersons films, theres a deep, pervasive melancholia here, too, a sense of regret evident in Mr. Bishops slouch (with his plaid pants, he is a walking John Cheever tragedy) and in the way Captain Sharp and Mrs. Bishop look, and dont look, at each other. Adulthood can seem so desperately painful, so maybe Sam and Suzy shouldnt be quite as eager to grow up.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: There are no rules as to how long cases should cook, no recipe. Lots of factors must be weighed.

title: Corrections: February 27, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: What to Expect on the Third Day of Milan Fashion Week
description: Philosophy  the study of thought  has had an unusual presence at Milan Fashion Week this season. It has hung in the air ever since Alessandro Michele, Guccis new creative director, cited Roland Barthes in the show notes of his first womens show, the first major show of the week. It made you wonder, what is the thought that runs through Fashion Week? Silly or not  Mr. Michele had to admit, Im not really interested about philosophy  these designers are the ones we trust to push fashion forward. Its reassuring to know that theyre thinking about clothes.

title: Hopeful Signs of Recovery for the Worlds Rarest Big Cat
description: While poaching and environmental degradation have had disastrous effects on animal species across Asia, one highly endangered cat has seen a small but important rise in its numbers, researchers say.

title: Hong Kong Woman Sentenced to 6 Years for Abusing Indonesian Maid
description: HONG KONG  A Hong Kong woman convicted of beating and threatening her Indonesian maid was sentenced to six years in prison on Friday, in a case that focused attention on the treatment of domestic servants here.

title: Migrants Said to Be Missing After Small Boat Overturns Near Macau
description: HONG KONG  Fifteen people were reported to be missing Friday after a small boat overturned in heavy winds off the Chinese territory of Macau.

title: House of Cards Season 3 Episode 1 Recap: Loyalty to Frank Has a Price
description: Season 3, Episode 1: Chapter 27

title: House of Cards Season 3 Episode 2 Recap: Balancing the Eggs
description: Season 3, Episode 2: Chapter 28

title: Airbus Group Profit Rose 59% in 2014 on Demand for Commercial Jets
description: PARIS  Robust demand for new commercial jets lifted Airbus Group profit by 59 percent last year, despite continued underperformance at its military division, where delays to a new transport plane led to more than $600 million in additional costs, the company said on Friday.

title: Thank Our Veterans for Serving? Its Complicated
description: To the Editor:

title: Long-Term Care Policies: Let the Buyer Beware
A Plea on Western Sahara
description: To the Editor:

title: Stopping the Violence on Rikers Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Converting the Ayatollahs
description: Over the past centuries, Western diplomats have continually projected pragmatism onto their ideological opponents. They have often assumed that our enemies are driven by the same sort of national interest calculations that motivate most regimes. They have assumed that economic interests would trump ideology and religion  that prudent calculation and statecraft would trump megalomania.

title: Happy Talk History
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  This state has an extraordinary history. Its where the Trail of Tears ended, and the Sooner land rush began. It suffered human-caused climate change at the most extreme  the Dust Bowl  and produced the wit and wisdom of Will Rogers. In all, the Oklahoma story is a compelling part of the national narrative.

title: Nothing Is Wrong With Your Sex Drive
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.  LAST week, Sprout Pharmaceuticals resubmitted its drug flibanserin to the Food and Drug Administration for approval. Flibanserin, in case you havent heard, is a drug intended to treat low sexual desire in women. The F.D.A. has rejected it twice already, and will most likely reject it a third time because (if youre Sprout) the F.D.A. is sexist or (if youre the F.D.A.) the drug doesnt work and isnt safe.

title: What Greece Won
description: Last week, after much drama, the new Greek government reached a deal with its creditors. Earlier this week, the Greeks filled in some details on how they intend to meet the terms. So how did it go?

title: Food Waste Grows With the Middle Class
description: Massive food waste by humanity is an undisputed fact documented daily in tons of discarded scrapings from dinner plates around the world. It is now being measured as a serious threat to the global environment and economy, with an estimated one-third of all the food produced in the world left uneaten at a cost of up to $400 billion a year in waste disposal and other government costs.

title: North Koreas Nuclear Expansion
description: North Korea could be on track to have an arsenal of 100 nuclear weapons by 2020, according to a new research report. The prediction, from experts on North Korea, goes well beyond past estimates and should force renewed attention on a threat that has been eclipsed by other crises.

title: Libraries of Life
description: HIDDEN behind the popular displays at many of your favorite natural history museums  in their basements, back rooms and, increasingly, off-site facilities  sit humanitys most important libraries of life, holding not books but preserved animal and plant specimens, carefully collected over centuries by thousands of scientist explorers.

title: Sit, Sparky, Stay. Good Dog! (Can I Dream?)
Community Colleges That Work
description: When President Obama called last month for making community college tuition-free for millions of students, he pointed out that graduation rates would have to improve to make the investment worthwhile. He also noted that the City University of New York system had already shown the way, with a program that has raised not just graduation rates but the rate at which students move on to four-year degrees. A rigorous new study released this week by MDRC, a nonpartisan research group, makes it clear that the CUNY approach, which offers students a network of support, could serve as a national model.

title: A Town Where a School Bus Is More Than a Bus
description: For the bulk of her career, Lavonda Thompson, a 48-year old bus driver and school custodian in Hartsville, S.C., never questioned either her role or the larger system she was serving. My job was to drive the bus and clean the buildings, she said. The childs job was to act respectful and follow directions.

title: Rev. Theodore Hesburgh, 97, Dies; Lifted Notre Dame and Advised Presidents
description: The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, the strong-minded former president of the University of Notre Dame who stood up to both the White House and the Vatican as he transformed Catholic higher education in America and raised a powerful moral voice in national affairs, died late Thursday in South Bend, Ind. He was 97.

title: How Liberalism and Racism Are Wed
description: This is the seventh in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This weeks conversation is with Falguni A. Sheth, an associate professor of philosophy and political theory at Hampshire College. Sheis the author of Toward a Political Philosophy of Race.  George Yancy

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Feb. 27
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of an ice-breaking operation on the Hudson River and a building collapse in Manhattan.

title: Lloyds Banking Group Returns to Profit and Resumes Dividend Payments
description: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group said on Friday that it returned to a profit in 2014 as it prepared to pay its first dividend since the lender was bailed out by the British government during the financial crisis.

title: Test Yourself | Younger Audiences Warm Up to Ballet
description: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 25 article, New York City Ballet Applies a Surreal Touch to Build Audiences.

title: 6 Qs About the News | In France, a Baby Switch and a Lesson in Maternal Love
description: In In France, a Baby Switch and a Lesson in Maternal Love, Maa de la Baume writes about a real-life tale of swapped newborns.

title: With White-Knuckle Grip, Februarys Cold Clings to New York
description: It will end. Allegedly.

title: What Should Be the Purpose of Prison?
description: More people are spending time in jail (PDF) because they dont have enough money to pay fines or post bail, or because they are too ill with mental health or drug problems to adequately care for themselves, according to a new report. And the United States prison population is near a record high (PDF) even though violent crime nationally has fallen by nearly 50 percent and property crime has dropped by more than 40 percent from its peak. All this raises an important question:

title: On Nantucket, Surfs Up, if Youre Part Penguin
description: How cold has it been on Nantucket? Chilly enough to freeze waves.

title: After Scandal, Petraeus Stays Under Radar, but Not Out of the Spotlight
description: WASHINGTON  As the top American military commander who oversaw the Middle East and Central Asia, Gen. David H. Petraeus worked hard to court the political elite in Kazakhstan. So the first time he met there with President Nursultan Nazarbayev, he made a joke to dispel fears that the United States had designs on the regions oil.

title: Beijing Courts Address the Right to Criticize Public Figures
description: In a political environment where public discourse is constrained by layers of censorship and self-censorship, Kong Qingdong, a neo-Maoist literary scholar at Peking University and an avid blogger, has long attracted attention with his vociferous commentaries.

title: Exxon Settles $9 Billion Pollution Case in New Jersey for Far Less
description: A long-fought legal battle to recover $8.9 billion in damages from Exxon Mobil Corporation for the contamination and loss of use of more than 1,500 acres of wetlands, marshes, meadows and waters in northern New Jersey has been quietly settled by the state for around $250 million.

title: Westminsters Rule No. 1: Dont Outshine the Dog
description: Black? Cream? Erin Roberts stared at the clothing strewn across her bed. Years of experience were being brought to bear on this decision.

title: Making Old Vegetables New Again
description: Last weekend it was time to reach into my vegetable crisper, pull out the lingering produce and use things up. I try not to buy more than what I need for recipe testing, but sometimes my imagination gets ahead of me and I soon find myself with a pile-up of vegetables that never made it into a recipe. I am sure this happens all the time with those of you who receive weekly CSA allotments. You have barely made a crack in one shipment when the next one comes in.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get the Morning Briefing in your inbox first thing? Sign up.)

title: Review: Sleater-Kinney at Terminal 5
description: Sleater-Kinney has made sure that its first tour since the band dissolved in 2006 is a resumption, not merely a reunion. At Terminal 5 in New York on Thursday night, opening a sold-out two-night stand, there wasnt a hint of self-congratulation or nostalgia: just the same joyfully adamant spirit, odd-angled indie-rock, headlong momentum, banshee intensity and sense of purpose. The three-woman band  Corin Tucker and Carrie Brownstein on lead vocals and guitars, Janet Weiss on drums and backup vocals  was still thinking as hard as it was slamming out its songs.

title: Germany Backs 4-Month Extension of Greeces Bailout
description: BERLIN  German lawmakers voted overwhelmingly on Friday to extend the terms of Greeces bailout by four months, despite growing misgivings over Athenss willingness to make economic overhauls viewed in Berlin as necessary to ensure a long-term recovery.

title: New York Today: Twilight of the Ice Age
description: Good morning on this frosted Friday.

title: Daily Report: F.C.C. Passes Net Neutrality Rules
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted on Thursday to regulate broadband Internet service as a public utility, a milestone in regulating high-speed Internet service into American homes, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Steve Lohr report.

title: Mr. Netanyahu Goes to Washington
description: The prime minister of Israel plans to address a joint meeting of Congress next week.

title: Privy to the Plot
description: The first novel I really fell in love with I rescued from being used as toilet paper.

title: The Death and Life of Great American GeoCities
description: A generation too young to remember dial-up modems rediscovers the old, weird Internet.

title: Re: The Student and the Mentor
description: The Stanford Undergraduate and Her Mentor, Emily Bazelons Feb. 15 cover story about the fallout from a relationship between a student and a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, was an examination of the difficulties in addressing rape and sexual assault on college campuses. Whats fascinating, Matt Milliken wrote on Twitter, was how my sympathies shifted over the course of the article.

title: Moth Orchids
description: Georgia OKeeffes paintings showed us how sensual flowers could be. Ellen Basss poem does this, too, reminding us of the power of metaphor: how one thing is like another, how desire can be reflected in the way we see and how our sustained attention  to language, to the things of this world  can reward us again and again. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

title: In Greenbacks We Trust
description: The U.S. dollar, as we know it today, was born in terror. On April 18, 1906, the Pacific tectonic plate, which extends under the ocean from Japan to central California, darted northward about 20 feet in just under a minute; in San Francisco, buildings that were not shattered by the earthquake burned, and within two days, 80 percent of the city was gone. At the time, American companies and governments still bought insurance from the old British firms, and the payouts to San Francisco were enormous. As was standard practice, the insurers paid in gold, shipping $65 million worth of bars  an estimated 107 tons, representing 14 percent of all British gold reserves  to the Bay Area. Afraid that all that gold leaving its vaults would permanently impoverish the kingdom, the Bank of England doubled interest rates on British bonds. In response, so many wealthy Americans sent money to England that, a few months after the gold came west from London, $30 million in U.S. gold traveled east. The British vaults were replenished, while the U.S. stock fell by 10 percent in two months.

title: How to Remember Peoples Names
description: If you are the name-forgetting type, you probably spend a fair amount of time feeling unmoored in a sea of vaguely familiar faces. Indira Pun does not have this problem. Sometimes I see a guest I have not seen for years, and right away I know their name, says Pun, chief concierge at the Mandarin Oriental Hong Kong. I exercise that like a muscle. After 11 years in the business and thousands of names committed to memory, Pun has a few name-recollection-workout suggestions.

title: When Did Youre Welcome Become a Gloat?
description: In 1947, the Friendship Train left Los Angeles bound for Europe. The train crossed North America, picking up boxcars of Colorado wheat, Nebraska beans and Wisconsin condensed milk. By the time it reached New York, the Friendship Train had amassed $40 million in donations of food, clothing and fuel from people across the country, which were loaded onto ships headed for Italy and France, then transferred onto local trains festooned with American flags. The beneficiaries  starving from a post-World War II food shortage and increasingly vulnerable to creeping Soviet power  knew exactly where their free lunch had come from.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Turner Classic Movies
description: Some people turn to psychopharmacology when they are blue. I prefer Turner Classic Movies.

title: Can a Stock-Trader-Turned-Convict Start a New Life?
description: One day in the middle of 2008, Sakhawat Khan, a Silicon Valley chip engineer, walked into a small house near the back of his two-acre property that his wife, Roomy, a stock trader, used as a home office. Roomy and Sakhawat met when they were electrical-engineering students at Columbia University. After graduating, Sakhawat started inventing, eventually gathering some 30 semiconductor patents to his name. Roomy, who was more outgoing in social situations and more restless in her appetite for risk, was drawn to Wall Street and joined Galleon Group, a New York hedge fund run by the charismatic, bullish trader Raj Rajaratnam. In 1999, she struck out on her own to trade technology stocks. She thrived. Riding the Internet boom, she said, she had amassed a paper fortune of $50 million.

title: Cubas Designation as a Sponsor of Terrorism Snarls Negotiations With U.S.
description: MEXICO CITY  More than a year ago, the State Department held a meeting with bankers and Cuban officials to deliver an unusual request: please accept Cubas money.

title: How an Adverse Supreme Court Ruling Would Send Obamacare Into a Tailspin
description: Even if you dont receive Obamacare subsidies, you could still be harmed by the Supreme Court case that could take them away.

title: 10 Intriguing Photographs to Teach Close Reading and Visual Thinking Skills
description: Updated, March 17, 2016 | We have published a companion piece: 8 Compelling Mini-Documentaries to Teach Close Reading and Critical Thinking Skills.

title: Avijit Roy, Bangladeshi-American Writer, Is Killed by Machete-Wielding Assailants
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  A Bangladeshi-American blogger known for his antipathy to religion was hacked to death on the street in this capital city by two assailants wielding machetes, the police said on Friday.

title: Today in Politics
description: Raucous Caucus: Day 1 at CPAC

title: Morning Agenda: Hedge Fund Sues U.S. Prosecutor
description: HEDGE FUND SUES U.S. PROSECUTOR | More than four years and dozens of insider trading convictions after F.B.I. agents staged a surprise raid of three hedge funds  feeding the national reputation of the prosecutor Preet Bharara as the new sheriff of Wall Street  one of those funds is fighting back, Matthew Goldstein, Ben Protess and Andrew Ross Sorkin report in DealBook. On Thursday, David Ganek, a Manhattan socialite and art collector whose $4 billion Level Global was one of the funds raided, sued Mr. Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, contending that official misconduct violated his constitutional rights.

title: How We Learned to Kill
description: THE voice on the other end of the radio said: There are two people digging by the side of the road. Can we shoot them?

title: Terrapins Rise Again, on the Back of an Understated Forward
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  Early on during Marylands 59-53 upset of No. 5 Wisconsin on Tuesday night, Terrapins forward Jake Layman received the ball outside the left post and backed down his defender, Wisconsins Sam Dekker. Layman then spun to his left and leapt, flying past not only Dekker but also Wisconsins 7-foot center Frank Kaminsky and tossing the ball up for 2 points.

title: Whats On This Week Around the World
description: Dresden, Germany

title: F.C.C. Rules in Favor of Net Neutrality
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Tom Wheeler, announced a decision to regulate broadband as a public utility, which had been called for by President Obama.

title: Ratmanskys New Sleeping Beauty Looks Back to 1890
description: Tremble with your feet! Gentle as feathers! Carry yourself; dont just walk!

title: Training for Triathlons at an Older Age
description: LAST year, at 66, Jenny F. Scott was not an obvious triathlete. A retired special education teacher, she had suffered a stress fracture running decades ago and took up serious bicycling only when she was 64 years old.

title: Emporio Armani: Fall 2015 RTW
description: Milan

title: BGC Partners Gains Control of GFI Group
description: BGC Partners said on Friday that it had successfully gained a control of the GFI Group, the New York brokerage firm and clearinghouse, after a long takeover battle.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Spain Arrests 8 on Suspicion of Fighting for Rebels in Ukraine
description: MADRID  The Spanish police on Friday carried out the first arrests in Western Europe of citizens accused of traveling to Ukraine to fight on the side of the Russian-backed rebels there.

title: Small, Successful Steps Toward Finding Your Groove
description: Three weeks ago, I invited Christine Carter, author of The Sweet Spot: How to Find Your Groove at Home and Work, to coach a few of us through the real-world issues that get in our way when it comes to settling into a happy and functional routine, both at home and work.

title: 5 Ways to Time-Travel (and Party) in New York
description: When William Faulkner famously mused on the power of history  The past is never dead. Its not even past, he wrote  he probably didnt have New York foremost in mind. The city, not known for its ability to hold on to old and historic spaces, has often directed its energy manically to the future. But in 2015, a contrarian spirit lives on in the city, and anyone with a passion for the past can plunge into almost any historical period for just a few dollars  and, in some of the more theatrical parties, by also investing in some decent vintage duds. Weve covered how to enjoy Gilded Age decadence, but if your preferences lie in different eras, here are some events to seek out.

title: Regilding the Gilded Age in New York
4th-Quarter Growth Revised to 2.2%, Less Than Initial Estimate
description: The American economy expanded at a slower pace than initially thought in the fourth quarter of 2014, as less stockpiling by businesses and a slightly weaker trade balance weighed on growth.

description: Dear Diary:

title: Restoring Historic Lobbies in Luxury Buildings
description: Grand lobbies filled with sumptuous details  ceiling murals, elaborate ornamentation, inlaid marble floors  are being rejuvenated by developers hoping to lure home buyers to once-commercial buildings being converted to high-end apartments.

title: Ericsson Again Sues Apple Over Wireless Patents
description: LONDON  Apple, no stranger to patent lawsuits, has another escalating fight on its hands.

title: Sportmax: Fall 2015 RTW

title: Annual Profit Surges for I.A.G., Parent of British Airways
description: PARIS  Profit at International Airlines Group, the parent company of British Airways, leapt by 81 percent last year, bolstered by strong passenger demand on its key routes across the Atlantic and a turnaround at its once-struggling Spanish carrier, Iberia.

title: Hillary Clinton Aides Are in Talks to Fill Top Campaign Roles
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons advisers are in serious discussions with nearly a half-dozen operatives to fill key roles such as political director on a likely 2016 presidential campaign.

title: Co-op Maintenance Reduced to Almost Nothing
description: For one West Village co-op, at least, its been a kind winter.

title: Winter Doesnt Want to End
description: After a dismally cold winter, New Yorkers are looking to spring to put a long-overdue end to filthy snow and frozen fingers.

title: Lively Morgue Tumblr 480  482
description: Lively Morgue Tumblr 480  482

title: Tiny Missouri Town Is Reeling After Gunman Kills Seven Neighbors
description: TYRONE, Mo.  In a tiny community like this one, a single, violent death touches everyone, shaking the place to its core. But few hamlets so small have suffered horrors so large as what happened here Thursday night, when a man gunned down seven of his neighbors, including some of his relatives, wounded another, and killed himself.

title: WhereRimbaud Found Peace in Ethiopia
Anarchy, State, and Dread Pirate Roberts
description: Henry Farrell has a truly brilliant essay on how the evolution of Silk Road, the dark-web trading platform for forbidden transactions, can be viewed as an experiment in political philosophy. I cant do better than his own blurb:

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

The Trouble With Boyhood
description: Id better slip this one in before last years movies vanish completely into the ether. In the Oscar-recap edition of the MoviegoersI did with Frank Bruni earlier this week, I expressed some skepticism about the idea that last Sunday nights victory of Birdman overBoyhood is going to be remembered asone of the Academys truly epic blunders not just the kind of ordinary bad Best Picture call that we see at least every other year, but the contemporaryequivalent of Dances With Wolves beating Goodfellas or Ordinary People beating Raging Bull or whatever instant classic gets passed over travesty rankles you the most. (Im a Dances With Wolves apologist, for what its worth  but yes, yes, Goodfellas is better.)

title: 1890: Cholera in Persia
description: Rigorous measures are being taken by the Russian Government, says the St. Petersburg correspondent of the Times, to prevent the spread of cholera from Persia and Mesopotamia into the Trans- caucasus. The Official Messenger publishes a long account of the progress of the disease towards the Russian frontier, with the opinions of Russian Consuls. The Consul at Bagdad states that, in his opinion the cessation of the epidemic in Mesopotamia at the end of 1889 was only temporary, and that it will soon reappear. Various arrangements of a sanitary and preventive character are ready to be put into force on the frontiers of the first warning. All vessels from the infected countries will have to submit to ten days quarantine and disinfection at Batoum and Theodosia. All pilgrims and travelers from Persia and Turkey are to be sent on through Batoum and Baku, where they will undergo quarantine and have their luggage disinfected.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 28, 1890

title: CNNs Bill Weir Explores the Worlds Threatened Wonders
description: One of Bill Weirs destinations, the island nation Vanuatu, was just hit by category five Cyclone Pam, with many reports of utter devastation.

title: Charlie Dent: A Republican Moderate (Gasp)
description: Political moderates are so near extinction in the hard-edged House Republican caucus that Representative Charlie Dent of Pennsylvania is practically a miracle of ornithology  that rare bird called a G.O.P. centrist whose forthright call is something to hear. The congressman has become the go-to quote guy for journalists as he openly, almost joyously, criticizes the new Republican majoritys failure to get much done because of its dedicated avoidance of political compromise.

title: 1915: Fire Destroys Moulin Rouge
description: Montmartres famous music-hall, the Moulin Rouge, is little more than a heap of ashes now.

title: Lessons in Family Ties, From a French Baby Swap
description: Maa de la Baumes article this week, about the families of two French girls who were switched at birth 20 years ago, has the qualities of a screenplay. But sometimes fact is stranger than fiction. Here, the reporter describes what it was like to experience that firsthand.

title: Divorce Funding Firms Help Spouses Expecting Big Payouts
description: THERESA EMERSON was married for 29 years when she fled her 6,000-square-foot custom-built house in Palm Desert, Calif., last June.

title: Laura Ingraham Implores Republicans to Look Beyond Jeb Bush
description: Laura Ingraham, the conservative radio host who has made no secret of her disdain for Jeb Bush, used her CPAC address on Friday morning to excoriate the former Florida governor and urge the party to look elsewhere.

title: The Closed Minds Problem
description: When I was a young economist trying to build a career, I lived  or thought I lived  in a world in which ideas and those who championed them met in relatively open intellectual combat. Of course there were people who clung to their prejudices, of course style sometimes trumped substance. But I believed that by and large better ideas tended to prevail: if your model of trade flows or exchange rate fluctuations tracked the data better than someone elses, or resolved puzzles that other models couldnt, you could expect it to be taken up by many if not most researchers in the field.

title: Stuff We Liked
description: Heres what we liked this week:

title: The American Lover, by Rose Tremain
description: Reading Rose Tremains stories is like sipping a Campari and soda in the bar of an elegant hotel that manages to be up to the minute without being a slave to fashion: the Carlyle, the Algonquin, the Plaza before it was turned into condos.

title: Transcending War
description: The novelist Elliot Ackerman studied literature in his undergraduate days at Tufts University, but becoming a Marine who served in Iraq and Afghanistan delayed his own literary career. I knew I wanted to write but took an eight-year detour in the wars, Ackerman said in an email interview. While fighting, I couldnt find the creative space to craft a novel or story; the emotions and material I was dealing with were too raw.

title: Elliot Ackermans Green on Blue
description: In 1971, with the war in Vietnam ferociously stalemated, David Halberstam published a biography of North Vietnams leader, Ho Chi Minh, who had died two years earlier. Books about the enemy are typical in times of war. What was atypical about Ho was its fawning tone: In his lifetime, Halberstam wrote, Ho had not only liberated his own country . . . he had touched the culture and soul of his enemy. Its a pretty lousy biography by any measure, every page a basket of freshly picked cherries, but for many historians on the right its still viewed as traitorous rot  as if Ernie Pyle had written, in 1943, Goebbels: A Celebration.

title: Poetry
description: BARELY COMPOSED  Poems  By Alice Fulton  Norton, $25.95.

title: The Big Seven, by Jim Harrison
description: A startling moment occurs in Jim Harrisons 2011 novel, The Great Leader, when the protagonist, Detective Sunderson, abruptly reflects on an incident that has landed him in the hospital. His soon-to-be ex-wife, Diane, has left with all of her things, and Sunderson drinks a bottle of Canadian whisky. This had gone on a couple of days and . . . a colleague had checked up and found him facedown and comatose on the floor of the unheated enclosed back porch after a 10-degree night. Up until this point, Sundersons steady drinking has been recklessly celebratory in this whisky-soaked novel, the kind of soaking one expects from a divorced detective at the outset of his retirement. But when he blithely reveals that he spent a few days unconscious, all the previous pages are cast into a foggy doubt. Just how screwed up is this guy, and exactly how stewed has he been for the past several chapters?

title: The Italians, by John Hooper
description: One of the epigraphs John Hooper uses to introduce the various chapters in his new book, The Italians, is a bit of dialogue from the 1949 film The Third Man. In it, Harry Lime compares the tumultuous 30 years of Borgia rule in Italy, which produced the Renaissance and some of its greatest artists, to the 500 years of democracy and peace in Switzerland, which, he claims, produced only the cuckoo clock.

title: Jorie Grahams From the New World
description: Writing about Jorie Graham at this point, seven books after she won the Pulitzer Prize for The Dream of the Unified Field: Selected Poems 1974-1994, means joining a cacophony of voices. Google her name and you will find her elders, her peers and those she has influenced (and she has influenced most poets younger than she is, and not just in English, whether they know it or not) making cases for and against the importance of her work. People have all sorts of reasons to love or hate her, and even love to hate her for reasons they sometimes cant articulate. The most evident case for Grahams importance is the volume of chatter eddying around her name. Tune all of that out and the deeper reasons for her lasting reputation grow louder. Grahams great body of work, summarized in From the New World, her new career-spanning selected poems (one can understand why active poets resist the tombstone of a collected volume), has so much in it, more of life and of the world than that of almost any other poet now writing. Or so it seems to me  as anxious, I realize, as everyone else to make my case.

title: Daniel Handlers We Are Pirates
description: Dont start with Gwen, begins the second chapter of Daniel Handlers new novel, We Are Pirates. Dont start means Dont begin but also Dont mess with, because the Gwen in question is a furious 14-year-old girl who has just been caught shoplifting. Her mother has ransacked her room and thrown all her stuff out, thinking it was stolen. Well, it was stolen now. Gwen, you see, is upset, so dont start with Gwen  the joke being, of course, that Chapter 2 is starting with her. The novel itself starts with the report of how the novels narrator meets Gwens father:

title: Why Not Say What Happened, by Morris Dickstein
description: In his 1992 book Double Agent: The Critic and Society, Morris Dickstein urged his fellow critics to engage in a cultural conversation among citizens rather than insulate themselves in a ghetto of postmodern jargon. And he insisted that like all good writing, criticism is personal or it is nothing.

title: The Age of Dignity, by Ai-jen Poo With Ariane Conrad
description: For years, nonfiction books about aging have tended to fall into certain categories: pragmatic texts about coping with specific challenges and encouraging healthy aging; memoirs of the authors experience of old age or of caring for elderly parents; research-filled narratives by experts or journalists.

title: Kings Are Surging Without Slava Voynov as He Awaits Trial
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  A lone figure skated to the top of a face-off circle, receiving passes from a coach and firing pucks at the net. All three shots sailed wide, slamming against the plexiglass as two youth hockey players scurried past on their way to practice.

title: Lene Kaaberbols Doctor Death, and More
description: As an intelligent young woman living in provincial France in 1894, Madeleine Karno has two clear career paths: She can find a husband or become a pathologist. The strong-minded heroine of Lene Kaaberbols DOCTOR DEATH (Atria, $25) comes by her passion for the forensic sciences naturally since she serves as assistant to her widowed father, Dr. Albert Karno, coroner for the town of Varbourg. But Madeleines ambitions would scandalize the neighbors, so its kept very hush-hush when she visits the local hospital to help him examine the abused body of 17-year-old Cecile Montaine, who went missing after leaving her convent school.

title: Irvine Welshs The Sex Lives of Siamese Twins
description: Put down the novel and back away from the doughnuts. It is not advisable to read Irvine Welshs 13th book, The Sex Lives of Siamese Twins, and snack simultaneously. Because Welsh, known for his gleeful depictions of the depraved degenerates who populate Scotlands seediest hollows, has turned his attention to one of his adopted homes, Miami Beach, that sun-drenched refuge for strutting grotesques and desperate narcissists. This is not Welshs first Rollerblade around Florida; Crime followed a coke-addled Edinburgh detective along the same bright sidewalks. It is, however, his first to be narrated by two Americans. And not just any two Americans. Female ones. This is a man who once successfully narrated a portion of a novel from the point of view of a tapeworm. The question is, in assuming the perspectives of women, has he bitten off more than he can chew?

title: After Birth, by Elisa Albert
description: A baby opens you up, is the problem, explains Ari, who feels she didnt actually give birth to her 1-year-old son because he was delivered via cesarean section. Theres before, and theres after, she observes. To live in your body before is one thing. To live in your body after is another. Which might be the simplest way to communicate the impact of Elisa Alberts brilliant new novel. After Birth cuts open the body of literature on mothering, birth, feminism, female friendship, female hateship  whether academic treatise or poem or novel  and wrenches out something so new we barely recognize it. Wet, red, slimy, alive: a truth baby.

title: Laura van den Bergs Find Me
description: Joy Jones, the narrator of Find Me, Laura van den Bergs pleasingly strange first novel, has spent her whole life waiting to be found. Born in the winter of 1995, she was left on the steps of a Boston hospital. The nurses gave her a name. Her birthday is only a guess. She grew up in a series of foster and group homes, feeling perpetually unwanted.

title: Hell and Good Company, by Richard Rhodes
description: Is it possible to speak intelligently about supremely ideological political events from a standpoint that airily dismisses the supremely ideological politics? Richard Rhodes has put this question to a test by writing an aggressively anti-ideological history of one of the most extravagantly ideological events that has ever occurred, the Spanish Civil War of 1936-39. The Spanish war broke out because, on one side, the radically leftist Socialist Party pushed the Republican government ever further to the left, and large parts of the labor movement pushed still more sharply leftward, unto the zones of collectivist and libertarian revolution  and because, on the opposite side, the national army and most of the Catholic Church and other parts of society veered sharply rightward, unto the nether regions of the fascist extreme. And, well, the two sides could not get along. Hitler, Mussolini and Stalin made their own specialized contributions. Three years of this and Generalissimo Francisco Franco became the caudillo of Spain, and wartime atrocities gave way to peacetime atrocities.

title: Marco Rubio at CPAC: An Immigrant Success Story
description: Best Applause Line:President Obama has treated the ayatollah of Iran with more respect than the prime minister of Israel.

title: Inside the List
description: A Massive Wobble: H Is for Hawk, Helen Macdonalds moving memoir about falconry and her fathers death, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 8. Macdonald is hardly the first best-selling memoirist to combine nature and grief: In 2012, Roger Rosenblatt spent a couple of weeks on the extended list with the elegiac Kayak Morning, in which he paddles around a Long Island creek and reflects on the death of his 38-year-old daughter, while Cheryl Strayeds Wild, about hiking the Pacific Crest Trail after her mother died, has logged more than two and a half years on the hardcover and paperback lists. (Its currently No. 3 in paperback, after 100 weeks.) Still, Macdonald was unprepared for the kind of success her book has achieved  particularly in her native England, where it was published last year and has become something of a sensation. Its freaking me out a bit! she told The Belfast Telegraph recently. There was a moment about two weeks ago when I went to do a book talk. People were queuing up to get books signed, and some were incredibly nervous and had shaking hands. I was horrified! They didnt see me as a person  they saw me as a place holder for being a writer or author or some figure that wasnt really me. That threw me into a massive wobble! Her experience, she said, taught me that this relationship with what is technically very much a wild animal is a way of getting in touch with all sorts of elemental things. . . . I was in a really dark place, and the hawk helped me through it.

title: Editors Choice
description: THIEVES OF STATE: Why Corruption Threatens Global Security,  by Sarah Chayes. (Norton, $26.95.) This important book makes the case that acute economic and political corruption causes both social breakdown and violent extremism.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE SIGNAL AND THE NOISE: Why So Many Predictions Fail  but Some Dont,  by Nate Silver. (Penguin, $17.) Silver has developed groundbreaking methods for predicting the performance of baseball players and the outcome of political races; here he assumes the role of public statistician as he investigates the world of forecasting, from finance to weather to epidemiology. Arguing for a sharper recognition of the difference between what we know and what we think we know, he proposes strategies for distinguishing true signals from a universe of noisy data.

title: Don Johnson, a Yankees Sensation Who Fizzled Out, Dies at 88
description: Not many baseball fans  not even the die-hard Yankee variety  will remember the right-handed pitcher Don Johnson, but he was the Yankees most promising rookie 68 spring trainings ago. That was 1947.

title: Making Money Decisions When You Lose Your Job
description: The numbers are striking: About 1.7 million people, on average, lose their jobs every month.

title: The Secrets of Filming Sex Scenes
description: Getting Hollywood types to speak on the record about the behind-the-scenes details of filming sex scenes was no easy feat  about a dozen people, Oscar and Emmy winners among them, said no  but once some filmmakers agreed to talk, they had a lot to say about the logistics. Read more.

title: Mutual Suspicion Mars Tech Trade With China
description: BEIJING  At an elegant guesthouse here recently, Chinas top Internet regulator entertained ambassadors and diplomats with platters of tempura and roast on a spit, unusual lavishness in an era of official austerity in China, to celebrate the Chinese New Year.

title: Etro: Fall 2015 RTW
description: Milan

title: A Sugar Rush, Not Crush
description: Its unusual to be served a homey wedge-shaped slice of layer cake at an ambitious restaurant. Its even more surprising when its a fluffy coconut number, as shaggy and proud as anything youd see on a diner counter under a cake dome  but about a thousand times more delicious.

title: Earl Lloyd, N.B.A.s First Black Player, Dies at 86
description: Earl Lloyd, who became the first black player to appear in an N.B.A. game when he took the court for the Washington Capitols in October 1950, three and a half years after Jackie Robinson broke modern major league baseballs color barrier, died on Thursday in Crossville, Tenn. He was 86.

title: One-Stop Borrowing on the Web
description: Consumer demand for a streamlined mortgage process is driving investment in online lending startups trying to deliver loans more quickly, efficiently and reliably.

title: Is Introversion Still a Liability in Politics?
description: You could almost say that introversion has become the new cool, said Brian R. Little, a professor of psychology at Cambridge University. In large part as a result of Susan Cains popular 2012 book Quiet, he explained, there has been a recognition of the quiet strengths of introversion.

title: Capture of a Drug Lord Is a Small Win in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  The Mexican police captured the leader of the Knights Templar drug gang on Friday, a victory against the brutal group but one that experts say will make little difference in the larger battle against criminal organizations that are rapidly splintering.

title: At CPAC, Rick Perry Remembers His Memory Loss of 2012
description: Best Applause Line: We survived Jimmy Carter. We will survive the Obama years, too.

title: House Passes One-Week Funding Extension for Homeland Security
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans vowing to govern effectively as a congressional majority failed a fundamental test Friday, when House leaders only narrowly managed to avert a partial shutdown of the Department of Homeland Security after an embarrassing defeat earlier in the day.

title: As Rubio Eyes White House, Floridian Eyes His Senate Seat
description: When the talk-show host Sean Hannity asked Senator Marco Rubio to place the likelihood that he would run for president on a scale of 1 to 100, he demurred. But at least one of Mr. Rubios would-be successors in Florida is wagering that the chances are closer to 100 than to 1.

title: Sophia Ahrens Transforms at Etro
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Sophia Ahrens before (left) and after (right) makeup by Mark Carrasquillo and hair by James Pecis.

title: West Village Townhouse for $17 Million
description: A 25-foot-wide, bow-fronted townhouse in the West Village, whose distinctive facade, commodious interior and outdoor garden have made it a sought-after locale for filmmakers, sold for $17,000,000, more than 20 percent above its asking price, and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Trust Your Matchmaking Mother. She Only Wants Whats Best.
description: Watch out JDate and Tinder, here come the middle-aged mothers. We are mobilizing for a common cause: to find our children their beshert (their intended soul mate), and we are serious competition. We know them so much better than your apps and sites ever can.

title: A Chickens Tour of the Mediterranean
description: A good cook needs an assortment of chicken recipes up his or her sleeve. Its fair to say that most carnivores like chicken, but even chicken fans prefer a bit of variety, a break from the familiar roasted, fried, grilled.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Elliot Ackermans Green on Blue
description: This week, Tom Bissell discusses Elliot Ackermans Green on Blue; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; John Hooper talks about The Italians; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: A Gaza Artist Creates 100 Square Feet of Beauty, and Shes Not Budging
description: DEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip  Nidaa Badwans room is less than 100 square feet, lit by a single window and a bare bulb. She has slathered one wall with aquamarine paint and covered another in a patchwork of colored egg cartons. There is a medium-size mirror, an antique sewing machine and iron, two easels, a large yellow ladder and a gas canister on which she boils water to make a sweet cappuccino drink from a packet.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Elliot Ackermans Green on Blue
description: This week, Tom Bissell and John Hooper.

title: The Red or the Blue
description: This year, New York soccer fans will have two M.L.S. teams to choose from.

title: Whose Side Are You On?
description: New York sports fans can be a melodramatic lot, but in January one particular group had become agitated on a whole other level. The debut of a newly acquired star player, believed to be set for the season opener in March, had been pushed back at least three months for contract reasons, and they were outraged. Some returned the team jerseys they had bought bearing the players name. Others vowed to boo him when he did finally arrive. One group of die-hards issued a statement saying it would like to publicly denounce the club and the player for the delay.

title: Leonard Nimoy Dies at 83
description: Leonard Nimoy was an actor, film director, poet, singer and photographer best known for his role as Spock in the television show Star Trek.

title: What I Love | Lori Goldstein
description: The look of Lori Goldsteins home is the same as that of her clothing lines: Everything goes.

title: Leonard Nimoy Dies at 83
description: Leonard Nimoy was an actor, film director, poet, singer, and photographer best known for his role as Spock in the television show Star Trek.

title: In Short-Lived Fish, Secrets to Aging
description: The turquoise killifish lives in a fleeting world: the ponds that appear only during the rainy season in East Africa.

title: Leonard Nimoy, Spock of Star Trek, Dies at 83
description: Leonard Nimoy, the sonorous, gaunt-faced actor who won a worshipful global following as Mr. Spock, the resolutely logical human-alien first officer of the Starship Enterprise in the television and movie juggernaut Star Trek, died on Friday morning at his home in the Bel Air section of Los Angeles. He was 83.

title: For Leonard Nimoy, Spocks Hold Made Reaching Escape Velocity Futile
description: The title of Leonard Nimoys autobiography was I Am Not Spock, and that so offended some fans that he followed it with a second, I Am Spock.

title: The Man Who Was Spock
description: Leonard Nimoy, best known for playing the character Spock in the Star Trek television shows and films, died at 83.

title: Leonard Nimoy Was Not (Only) Spock
description: Leonard Nimoy, who died on Friday at 83, was known the world over as Spock, the Vulcan logician and cool counterpoint to William Shatners hotheaded Captain Kirk on Star Trek.

title: Leonard Nimoy Dies at 83
description: Leonard Nimoy was an actor, film director, poet, singer and photographer best known for his role as Spock in the television show Star Trek.

title: Myth, Reality and the Underground Railroad
description: On Feb. 24, 1865, William Lloyd Garrison, the editor of the antislavery weekly The Liberator, published an odd column  odd, because the piece, written by the New York minister Thomas Jefferson Sawyer, had already appeared in the paper, less than a year before. But Garrison believed that the articles point  about collective memory, and collective forgetting  was an important one, and with the wars end in sight, he wanted to make sure his readers saw it.

title: Nimoy Explains Origin of Vulcan Greeting
description: As part of the Yiddish Book Center Wexler Oral History Project, Leonard Nimoy explains the origin of the Vulcan hand signal used by Spock, his character in the Star Trek series.

title: Tough, Studded Platforms at Giamba
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Jihadi John Stirs Britain to Defend Spy Agencies
description: LONDON  After disclosures that the man who posed in videos of the murder of Western hostages was known to British intelligence, Prime Minister David Cameron on Friday defended the security services, saying they faced tough decisions and had prevented deadly attacks.

title: Where Matchy-Matchy Meets Its Match
description: As a fashion stylist whos worked closely with superstar photographers like Annie Leibovitz and Steven Meisel, Lori Goldstein has spent most of her professional life behind cameras. In recent years, shes established a new career in front of them with her LOGO clothing lines on QVC, the television shopping network.

title: The Rhythm of Great Performance
description: For nearly 15 years, Ive been making the case  in my writing and with corporate clients  that employees can be more productive by working fewer hours and taking more time for rest and renewal during the work day.

title: My Dad: Strict. My Daughters Papa? Not So Much.
description: I have always had a complicated relationship with my father. As the oldest of four children and the only girl, I resented my dads rigidity, his chauvinism, the perceived preference shown to my younger brothers. When it came to housework, I was relegated to the girl chores, which meant I regularly spent an hour washing the familys dishes, compared with my brothers 15 minutes of taking out the garbage and sweeping the floors. When I was a little older I was stuck at home watching my eight-years-younger twin brothers, while my brother was absolved from caregiving duties because he was too irresponsible.

title: Blumarines Subtle Rock-and-Roll Eye Makeup
description: Our inspiration is about a young girl, cool, who wants to have fun, explained the makeup artist Tom Pecheux backstage at Blumarines fall/winter 2015 show today. To complement the range of textures (leather, lace, lam), designs (mini dresses, structured coats, flowing gowns) and colors (light gray, burnt orange, electric blue) in the collection, Pecheux stuck to a neutral palette. If you are a little disco, if you are a little bit rock and roll, if you are a little bit classy, a little bit punk, he says, the look will work for you. He amped things up, ever so slightly, on the eyes: loads of mascara on the top lashes, a little bit of gloss on the lid and a touch of black glitter. It was a very small beauty moment that added just enough oomph to the rock-and-roll feel of the looks.

That was the reaction of many Walmart workers after the retail giant announced it would raise wages for U.S. employees to at least $10 an hour beginning next year. While the increase is no doubt welcome, its nowhere close to the $15 an hour workers asked for and doesnt address an equally big issue: not enough hours in the first place.

title: At CPAC, Rick Santorum Says U.S. Needs Wartime President

Nope.Biggest Pander: In a bit of country-when-country-wasnt-cool, Mr. Santorum noted that he was against Common Core when he ran for president in 2012. And today Im still not for Common Core, he said.Toughest Question: Not a one.Mood in the Room: Mr. Santorum had the unfortunate luck of following Senator Rand Paul, which meant that dozens of Mr. Pauls libertarian-leaning followers exited the room during the opening minutes of his speech.

title: In Europe, Bond Yields and Interest Rates Go Through the Looking Glass
description: HVIDOVRE, Denmark  At first, Eva Christiansen barely noticed the number. Her bank called to say that Ms. Christiansen, a 36-year-old entrepreneur here, had been approved for a small-business loan. She whooped. She danced. A friend took pictures.

title: Google Unveils Plan for New Corporate Campus
description: Google on Friday submitted a proposal to raze parts of its Mountain View campus and replace it with a series of airy, space-age buildings with translucentroofs and modularinteriors that can be moved around and reconfiguredlike Lego bricks.

title: The Significance of Lloyds Plan to Pay a Dividend
description: The last time the Lloyds Banking Group paid a dividend, Gordon Brown was the British prime minister, Lehman Brothers still existed and banker was yet to become a term of abuse. The fact the British bank is making its first shareholder payout since August 2008 is, therefore, an encouraging milestone. But in valuation terms, this years dividend is more important.

title: Leonard Nimoy Is Remembered by a Constellation From Star Trek and Beyond
description: Leonard Nimoy and his Star Trek co-stars have all had careers with many acts. In recent years, theyve connected with avid Trekkies on social networks like Twitter and Facebook. And his colleagues and other admirers, including President Obama, took to those platforms on Friday to remember the man who was Mr. Spock.

title: A Fumble and Some Punts: Attention Turns to Scott Walker the Campaigner
description: Perhaps the most important question in the Republican presidential primary is whether Scott Walker, the Wisconsin governor, is a capable presidential candidate.

title: Study on Chronic Fatigue May Help With Diagnoses
description: The immune systems of people with chronic fatigue syndrome differ from those of healthy people, and patients with recent diagnoses can be distinguished from those who have had the condition for longer, researchers reported on Friday.

title: Before Justices Rule, Floridians Consider Life Without Health Subsidies
description: MIAMI  Sylvia Maltzman, a part-time tutor at a community college in Florida, pays $23 a month for the health insurance she got under the Affordable Care Act. A federal subsidy of about $475 covers the rest, and Ms. Maltzman, who has high blood pressure and arthritis, said she could not afford insurance without it.

In real life, Ms. Goldberg was barely 10 in 95, but she still felt a part of the era.
